HEADLINE: At Last, The South Loses Well

BYLINE: By Allan Gurganus; Allan Gurganus is the author of "Oldest Living Confederate Widow Tells All," "White People" and the forthcoming "Plays Well With Others."

DATELINE: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.

 BODY:
The novelist Walker Percy was often asked why so many darkly comic writers of genius arose from the American South. He answered, "Because we lost." Then he laughed, with a shaman's economy and a cracker's certainty.
In three elegant words, Percy named the region's greatest shame and its uncanny secret power: our habit of anticipating defeat while never accepting it. 
 Trust me. The South is no place for beginners. Its power of denial can turn a lost war into a vibrant, necessary form of national chic. That same knack has also given us a dreadful reputation.
The virulent Rebel spirit still flies -- unsubtle as a flag run up a pole -- over South Carolina's Statehouse. Literally. This Confederate battle flag was first raised to commemorate the Civil War's centennial 34 years back. Until now, nobody has found the nerve or the vision to simply yank it down.
And why? The answer is aptly perverse: "Because we lost," the flag must remain. That is, until now.
Sigmund Freud might have been practicing in Atlanta -- practicing on Atlanta -- when he announced:
"We overcame the transference by pointing out to the patient that his feelings do not arise from the present situation . . . but they are repeating something that happened to him earlier. In this way, we oblige him to transform his repetition into memory."
These days, those memories are saleable, exportable. Shiloh is picturesque, touristic. The President and Vice President? An Arkansan and a Tennessean. Burned Atlanta now plays host to the Fortune 500.
Having once fought hard for a divorce from the United States, having been outgunned, outlawyered, burned flat, then alimonied near to death, we Southerners were left with little more than our lore. To that, at least, we held on tight. For a century, memory was all we had to sell.
Picture Charleston's Magnolia Cemetery on Confederate Memorial Day, 1871. Pretty dresses, gray uniforms, all the crutches. To a crowd of 6,000, the Rev. John L. Giradeau gave a speech. He might have been speaking about the worries of present-day African-Americans or Israelis or Palestinians.
"Let us cling to our identity as a people! The danger is upon us of losing it -- of its being absorbed and swallowed up in that of a people which, having despoiled us of the rights of freemen, assumes to do our thinking, our legislating, and our ruling for us. Influences are operating on us with every breath we draw which, if we be not vigilant, will sooner or later wipe out every distinctive characteristic which has hitherto marked us. Are we prepared for it? . . . Nothing of the past will be left to the South but a history which will read like an elegiac poem, nothing for the present but a place on the maps which our children study . . . a single existence, a geographical one. But can we preserve our identity in the face of the difficulties which oppose it?"
The Reverend need not have worried so. Though South Carolina might look somewhat like Ohio, it is still confoundedly South Carolina. For better and for worse. Fifteen years ago, we were told the Southern accent would disappear. Tain't so!
The North sent us carpetbaggers; we sent them chef Paul Prudhomme on a golf cart. Guess who made the bigger dent? Today black professionals are returning en masse to the South. These days country music is not just played at Nashville barn dances. The region that gave birth to both jazz and the blues is at last -- thanks to Junior Chambers of Commerce -- considered jazzy, bluesy, sexy. Rather than blandify our food to match the occupying force's, we've lent our spice to the Yankee blahs. And at a pretty good markup.
But certain rankling emblems remain, symbols of the Bad Old South and not the Good New Gourmet One.
In 1962, South Carolina rehoisted the Confederate battle flag over its Statehouse. The thing is still snapping there. The trouble with raising such a pennant: Once it's up there, you can't exactly pull it down unnoticed. If you raise a war flag in a time of peace, the rules of war will always govern it -- even 131 years after you lost the bloody war. And there's the bind.
Enter Gov. David Beasley. He is a young Republican just two years into his first term. When elected, he favored the battle flag's presence. Three-fourths of all registered Republicans wanted the colors to fly forever. But South Carolina is now reeling from a series of especially ugly racist crimes, including church torchings and a drive-by shooting at a black nightclub. Daily Statehouse protesters claim that the flag sanctions such racial violence, a tacit "yes" to the Klan and deranged militia groups.
After hard grappling with the issue, Governor Beasley called a news conference televised statewide. He announced that the last government-flown Confederate flag should finally come down. Though the forces of tradition still claim the symbol as theirs, Governor Beasley admits the forces of hatred have co-opted it. The Governor has done a real service to the South. He has given it a final chance to rise -- and this time, from a Reconstruction of its own making.
The resulting furor now reads like Southern fiction at its ethics-based, glandular and atmospheric best. Business interests fear canceled conventions if the flag waves on. Senator Strom Thurmond, born just 34 years after the War ended, favors purging this symbol. The Sons and Daughters of the Confederacy ride clouds of 19th-century rhetoric -- "blood" its operative metaphor. The African- American community opposes any display of the flag. For narrative suspense, the State Legislature has still not voted on the proposal.
There are intelligent people who believe the flag should stay in place. Their credibility is undercut by two leading Republican gubernatorial hopefuls who insist: The flag is a symbol of honor. It never burned a church. The battle flag has nothing to do with slavery.
Such citizens' homework for tonight should be the reading of a little item called the "Declaration of the Immediate Causes which induce and justify the Secession of South Carolina from the Federal Union." The words "slave" and "slavery" slather through it.
One sentence condemning the North reads: "They have encouraged and assisted thousands of our slaves to leave their homes; and those who remain have been incited by emissaries, books and pictures to servile insurrection."
The condescension dripping from "books and pictures" is enough to freeze any heart. As usual, those Republicans quickest to use History as their battle cry seem to have read very little of it lately.
Governor Beasley, in striking the colors "because we lost," offers a clean gesture, brave and, not incidentally, career-making.
I phoned my most knowing friends in Charleston (very knowing, indeed). They tell me that, for Governor Beasley, symbolic shifts with prevailing winds are nothing new.
He blew into office as a (literally) flag-waving Republican governor. Yet he is a former Democrat. A boy from Society Hill, he converted to evangelical Christianity, then to the Christian Coalition, just in time to ride the botched Gingrich Revolution. (Newt Gingrich, for the record, is a Pennsylvanian who moved clear to Georgia to get elected, which explains a lot.)
Whatever Governor Beasley's motives, his battle-flag conversion offers our region a belated crack at doing something right. The South has a chance at last to lose the war correctly.
To finally admit: We've noticed that we lost! Everybody loses something. A ball game, a wristwatch, a spouse, a child -- eventually, a life. The healthiest among us are those folks able -- through some mythic algebra that can never be explained -- to upgrade defeat into an acceptance that itself becomes a form of honor. Shakespeare speaks of turning defect into perfection. But, flying the flag of the losing side blocks just such healthy personal present-tense mythologizing. Where are the new emblems of a New South?
Our region has finally offered itself a chance at visible dignity. Not just economic comeuppance, but a lunge at self-criticism -- the first step toward affectionate self-acceptance, and a unity postponed.
The Governor suggests the flag now be flown only over a Civil War museum on the Statehouse grounds. This would give a context to the martial emblem of a lost cause. But African-Americans protest its display there. They would forbid the colors' presence, even as a reminder of an emancipating war.
"Lest we forget" becomes "lest we remember." Amnesia is no cure for the pain of Southern history -- white or black amnesia.
Confucius claims that one purpose of poetry is to teach the names of birds and plants to a nation's children. Monuments and flags serve as aids to train our young about their past. The battle flag enthusiasts need reminding: Only the winning side gets to fly its symbol over seats of legislation financed by taxpayers of all races. Conversely, is it not risky for black Southerners to erase from view the very emblem of crimes that cannot be addressed too often?
Absolutist thinking -- balkanizing both sides -- is the New Secessionism. Been there, folks. Done that.
The New Secessionism places ethnic identification above national purpose, group grievance over human commonality. Correct me, but isn't that why the Civil War was fought? Isn't that why all thinking people understand: The right side won?
Brothers, sisters? The Civil War belongs, at last, not on our streets, but, please, in museums.
Six months after the South lost, Gen. Robert E. Lee wrote Gen. P. G. T. Beauregard, commending him for not fleeing the Union as many others had. Lee, I am told, is still discredited north of, say, Maryland. But in this letter he embodies all that I love about an enlightened, forthright, humble, morally imaginative, self-correcting and therefore eternally necessary South:
"After the surrender of the Southern armies . . . it became in my opinion the duty of every citizen to cease opposition and place himself in a position to serve the country.
" . . . I need not tell you that true patriotism sometimes requires of men to act contrary at one period to that which it does at another, and the motive that impels them -- the desire to do right -- is precisely the same."
Shall we run that up our only flagpole? May I see a show of hands? State by state, race by race, we cannot succeed by seceding. Done that. Lost out. Started over.
Maybe our feelings do not arise from the present situation but keep repeating something that happened to us earlier. And happened, and happened.
So, South Carolina? Make the repetition a memory. Heed the orders of General Lee. On retiring from the field of battle, brave enough to weep in plain view of his men, admitting defeat while somehow maintaining his own indelible sense of human honor, he called back, "Furl the flag, boys."
It is time.
One hundred and thirty-one years late, my beloved South, it is time to say and mean this.
Let us all hold hands and, in unison, shout it very loud at last, "Appomattox. Appomattox, and amen!"

HEADLINE: New Software Speeds Multimedia Distribution

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

 BODY:
Could this be goodbye to the World Wide Wait? The Narrative Communications Corporation, a start-up company based in Waltham, Mass., is set to begin shipping its Enliven suite of software programs today. The software permits the distribution and viewing of feature-length interactive multimedia over the Internet using ordinary phone lines.
While most existing programs for distributing multimedia require downloading the entire file, which can take 8 to 16 minutes over an ordinary phone line, Enliven downloads only a crucial set of instructions, which takes about 40 seconds, and then "streams" the file in real time. Companies currently deploying sites using Enliven technology include Sony, Broderbund, Life magazine and Ben & Jerry's. 
 "Enliven is a client-server-based solution that lets you deliver fully interactive feature-length files over ordinary networks," Hilmi Ozguc, Narrative's president and chief executive, said in a telephone interview. "The result is a CD-ROM-like experience over the World Wide Web with an ordinary phone line."
Enliven consists of three components, including a viewer, which can be downloaded free from the Narrative Web site (www.narrative.com) and which the Microsoft Corporation is now bundling with its Windows 95 operating system and Internet Explorer Web browser. The other components include the server, which costs $5,600 to $10,900, depending on configuration, and Producer, a programming tool for software developers, at $249.
"It works," said William Bluestein, an analyst with Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. Enliven is "breakthrough technology because it really solves one of the fundamental problems entertainment companies face with the Internet, which is the painfully slow download times," he said. CD-ROM companies "can leverage what they've done by putting it out over the Web, where they will have much broader distribution," he said.
Currently, the Enliven viewer is available only for the Windows 95 operating system, but Mr. Ozguc said a version for Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh operating system will ship early next year. In addition to programs developed with its own software, Enliven can translate any files created in the Macromedia Corporation's Director program, which is the dominant multimedia content development tool.
Narrative will also offer a multimedia hosting service for companies that will not do their own programming. Also scheduled to begin today, the service will cost $1,500 a month.
"The prices seem a little high to me, but they've got technology that works really really well," Mr. Bluestein said. "The whole Internet market is one where stuff is either expensive or free."
Founded in September 1995 by Mr. Ozguc, Scott Kliger and Allison Parker, all former software engineers with the Lotus Development Corporation, Narrative got its first round of $3 million in venture financing from Greylock Management. Enliven said it had completed its second round of financing, totaling $5.25 million, led by Accel Partners of San Francisco, with Greylock.
John Landry, formerly Lotus's senior vice president for development, is the chairman. Narrative's executive team includes Bobby Yarlagadda and Mark Schlichting, both senior executives with Living Books, the joint venture between Broderbund and Random House, and Lori Dustin, a former executive of the Data Translation Corporation.

HEADLINE: Republican Opposition to Party's Candidate Could Elect Democrat in a Texas District

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
Now that the elections are almost over and Republicans have a diminished majority in the United States House of Representatives, Texas Republicans have managed to create a fracas out of what sounds like a political no-brainer: would they like to send one more Republican to Congress?
If the Republican is Dolly Madison McKenna, who favors abortion rights and who made it into a runoff election by campaigning as the candidate of the "sensible center," some conservative Republicans here say the answer is no. 
 "The last thing the Republican Party needs is this high-profile woman parading around Congress saying: 'Look! I won on a pro-choice platform," snapped Al Clements, who was chairman of the committee that wrote the state Republican Party's vigorously anti-abortion platform earlier this year.
Mr. Clements and several other anti-abortion Republicans are urging the party's voters to cast blank ballots on Tuesday when Ms. McKenna faces a freshman Democrat, Representative Ken Bentsen, for a redistricted seat in a special election that many analysts say had presented a golden opportunity for Republicans to swipe a seat from the Democrats.
For the Republicans, the intraparty feud over whether to support Ms. McKenna is a potential embarrassment that has dragged both Gov. George W. Bush and his father into the fray. Both men appeared at Ms. McKenna's side last week, urging all Republicans, whatever their feelings about abortion, to turn out for her.
"It's ridiculous, absolutely absurd," former President George Bush, now a Houston resident, said of the anti-abortion leaders' call for a boycott. "You agree on 99 percent," he said of Ms. McKenna's conservative economic message. "If that's not good enough, then too darn bad."
More than just a local squabble that represents a footnote to the November elections, the battle over Ms. McKenna casts a spotlight on the something that has troubled the Republican Party for years and could continue to do so as the party fights to keep control of Congress in 1998 and win back the White House in 2000. Should it be a "big tent," open to divergent views on social issues like abortion and gay rights, or should it solidify its conservative core by emphasizing unyielding positions on these issues?
The election on Tuesday is one of three Congressional runoffs in Texas, all in the Houston area and all forced by a sweeping redistricting ruling this summer that redrew more than a dozen Texas districts and set open elections with runoffs necessary if no candidate captured more than 50 percent of the vote.
A low voter turnout -- something that has often tended to help Republicans in special elections here -- is expected. Furthermore, the redrawing of the 25th District, where Representative Bentsen and Ms. McKenna are facing off, added some conservative neighborhoods in west Houston that could normally represent trouble for Mr. Bentsen, a moderate Democrat who emphasizes his opposition to Republican proposals for cuts in education, Medicare and environmental protection. But by abstaining on Tuesday, conservative voters could effectively re-elect him.
"My guess is that the nonparticipation and even occasional crossover from religious conservatives will probably prevent McKenna from winning," said Richard Murray, a political scientist at the University of Houston. "In that district, she needs all the Republican base, but she's going to lose some of it, and that's probably fatal."
One of the many twists attending redistricting issues, none of the three runoffs involve any of the representatives whose seats were technically at issue in the judges' ruling.
In all, three districts that the judges found to be racially gerrymandered and 10 adjacent districts were redrawn. All three representatives in the gerrymandered districts, including two black Democrats, comfortably won election in their new districts: the runoffs all involve districts with only white candidates, including one in which two Republicans are now facing each other.
In the Ninth Congressional District, which stretches from the eastern fringes of Houston south to Galveston and east to the Louisiana line, Representative Steve Stockman, one of the most outspokenly conservative freshman Republicans, is facing a vigorous challenge in his bid to keep a seat that had been held by a Democrat for 42 years. Mr. Stockman's Democratic opponent, Nick Lampson, a former county tax assessor-collector in East Texas, finished just two points behind Mr. Stockman in the November election.
And in the Eighth District, north and west of Houston, a Republican -- either State Representative Kevin Brady or Gene Fontenot, a hospital investor -- will replace a retiring Republican, Jack Fields.
Democrats hold an 18-12 edge in the Texas Congressional delegation: if they lose both of the elections in which they are fielding candidates on Tuesday, the new split will be 15-15, and they will lose control of the delegation for the first time this century.
That is just one reason why a Republican victory in the 25th District would seem to be so important for the party. But for many conservative Republicans, the venom directed at Ms. McKenna, a Houston businesswoman, is intense, and it has a history. She enraged conservatives and became something of a Joan of Arc among moderates in 1994 when she mounted a futile bid for the chairmanship of the state party.
"The Republican Party is not a church," she said at the time, drawing a loud chorus of boos from delegates to the state convention who identified themselves as religious conservatives.
She also enraged the party's right wing after her loss in the 1994 primary (to Mr. Fontenot, who then lost to Mr. Bentsen in the general election) by sending her supporters a letter that described some religious conservatives as having a "hate-filled agenda of gay bashing and intolerance that is much like the fundamentalism that has recently swept the Middle East, the neo-Nazis in Germany and now the neo-fascists in Italy."
Ms. McKenna has since said she regretted making the comments. After she got 17 percent of the vote in November and squeaked into second place, past one Democrat, a socialist and seven generally more conservative fellow Republicans, she managed to secure endorsements of varying degrees of enthusiasm from the Republicans. In doing so, Mr. Bentsen argues, she has made people question what she really stands for.
"She tried to run to the center in the first election," Mr. Bentsen, a nephew of former Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen, said the other day as he campaigned at a barbecue for elderly voters in Pasadena, east of Houston. "She said she represented the so-called sensible center. You don't hear her talk about that anymore. The day after the election she went to the right and said, 'Let's make up and be friends,' and she alienated the moderates in her party by doing so."
Ms. McKenna insists she has always had the same message, but simply changed her emphasis once she made the runoff.
"My message to start with was that I was economically conservative and socially moderate," she said. "The first race was effectively to run against the other seven Republicans as being somewhat more socially moderate than they. The second half of the campaign, which I am now running, is against Bentsen, that I'm more economically conservative. So my initial message hasn't changed at all; it's just the part of it I'm using."
Ms. McKenna described differences between her and religious conservatives as "a stream" compared with the "gulf" that she says separates them from Mr. Bentsen.
But Mr. Clements, who is projects director of the Texas Right to Life Committee, said that with Republicans in control the House for the next two years, he would rather wait and run "a true Republican" against Mr. Bentsen in 1998.
"It's the old saying," he said, explaining why he and other conservative, Christian Republicans would go into the booth Tuesday and emerge with unmarked ballots. "If you vote for the lesser of two evils, you're still voting for evil."

HEADLINE: Detroit Journal;
Carolers Dent a City-Suburb Wall

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 8

 BODY:
Kathy J. Tasich, a 51-year-old suburban schoolteacher in a beige overcoat, paused next to an 11th-century basalt column in Detroit's vast art museum and expressed delight with the cultural treasures she has recently discovered in the city, after years of seldom venturing downtown.
"Lately I've been coming in and it's really interesting," she said, after discussing with a friend how to find a nearby ballet performance. "You get addicted to it." 
 But Mrs. Tasich added sadly that many of the seventh and ninth graders she teaches in suburban Warren, Mich., did not understand her visits to the city. "I've heard them say, 'You don't want to go down there and get murdered,' " she said.
While many cities in the United States have acrimonious relations with their surrounding suburbs, few have histories as full of mutual mistrust as Detroit's. Bitter racial and economic disputes have long divided the city, which is three-quarters black and the nation's poorest big city, from its suburbs, which are overwhelmingly white and mostly affluent. Some suburban residents boast at cocktail parties about how many years it has been since they last entered the city.
The latest initiative to unite the city and the suburbs came on Saturday, when the city's cultural district held Noel Night. It was an evening of caroling downtown and free visits to 19 sites, including several magnificent museums and an ornate library built early in this century, when a young auto industry made this one of the nation's wealthiest cities.
After 23 years of holding Noel Night on Wednesday evenings, when few suburban residents had the time to bring their families downtown, sponsors moved the event to Saturday this year in a bid to attract more visitors from the suburbs. The result was a qualified success.
The entertainment -- choral singing at the Detroit Institute of Arts, for example, and a Russian puppet show at the Detroit Historical Museum -- was superb. But attendance was light. More suburban families showed up than in previous years but fewer office workers bothered to go downtown on a day off.
Susan T. Mosey, the executive director of the University Cultural Center Association, which sponsored the evening, said today that no attendance figures would be available for several days. She expressed satisfaction, though, that more people had brought their children. "We accomplished our goal," she said.
Roy and Diane Midgley of suburban Clarkston, Mich., were enthusiastic about the city's potential for recovery after listening to a dozen schoolgirls ring hand bells in front of two coats of medieval armor in the art museum's vaulted lobby.
"Some of the buildings that were boarded up are no longer there or have been replaced," Mrs. Midgley said. "It is coming back."
More families were across the street at the 75-year-old Detroit Public Library. Dave and Mickie Zisler of outlying Richmond, Mich., waited with their 7-year-old daughter, Emily, to hear the lines that begin, "'Twas the Night Before Christmas." Emily, sitting near a 20-foot Christmas tree under an elaborately carved, coffered wood ceiling, was awed by the classical beauty of the library's room for children.
Minutes later she listened with rapt attention to a series of stories told by Florence (Dinghy) Sharp, an area resident and great-great-granddaughter of Clement Clarke Moore, who in 1822 composed the famous tale of a visit from St. Nicholas.
While events like Noel Night may entice some suburban residents to visit the city, much still needs to be done, said Mario L. Morrow, a political consultant in the city. "Suburban folks still come into the city to work and drive home without spending much money," he said. "It's just the reverse for citizens of Detroit -- they work in the city but they find the need to shop in the suburbs" because there are no big malls in the city.
Several events in recent days have shown that some racial and political tensions have lessened but that difficulties remain. The suburban Bloomfield Hills Country Club, a bastion of auto barons, decided on Tuesday to admit its second and third black members, including Roy Roberts, a senior General Motors executive whose rejection by the club three years ago outraged city residents.
The city and the suburbs nonetheless remain suspicious of each other. Last Monday, the Detroit City Council decided to defer plans to turn the management of the city-owned art museum over to the museum's private donors. Some city residents had objected that many donors lived in the suburbs, and that the transfer of management might have allowed some museum employees to get around a requirement that municipal workers live in the city.
Yet suburban investors have gradually begun putting money back into the city since the election in 1993 of Mayor Dennis Archer, a moderate Democrat. Even Detroit's crime rate, while still high among American cities, has begun to inch down.
"I really feel secure," Mrs. Tasich said. "More than I ever did."

LENGTH: 743 words

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Light In the Darkness

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Dr. Ma Thida, a 29-year-old Burmese surgeon, is confined alone in a Rangoon cell, forbidden reading material. She was sentenced to 20 years in prison in 1993 for "endangering public tranquillity, having contact with unlawful organizations and distributing unlawful literature." That means she supported democracy in Burma.
She is a symbol of the cruelty of Burma's military rulers, and of other oppressive regimes. Physicians for Human Rights and other groups have brought her name out of the darkness. This week Ma Thida will be among the winners of the Reebok Human Rights Award for courage in the face of tyranny. 
 Her case raises painful questions for us. Around the world now there is concern for human rights, but does it actually help the victims? How do we explain the fact that after decades of protest, inhumanity still flourishes from Burma to the Serbian sector of Bosnia?
A comprehensive world report just published by the organization Human Rights Watch underlines those doubts. Major governments talk about human rights, the report says, but they mostly put other things first -- notably what they perceive as their economic interests. But in the end the report and reflection tell us that the struggle for human rights does make a difference.
China is a heavyweight on the down side of the balance of decency. In the last year its persecution of dissenters has intensified. The great advocate of democracy Wei Jingsheng, the Sakharov of China, is serving a 14-year prison term under reportedly harsh conditions. The repression of Tibetan culture and religion has become even more vicious.
The response of most Western governments to Chinese brutality has been to change the subject. The Clinton Administration made trade and investment the prime target of its relations with Beijing. Its argument that "strategic dialogue" with China would be helpful on human rights has been mocked by growing repression.
The other signal American failure has been in the former Yugoslavia. Despite the promises of Dayton, the U.S. and its partners have allowed Croatia and the Serbian entity in Bosnia to harbor men indicted as war criminals. That failure threatens the first effort since Nuremberg to call the authors of a genocide to account.
"President Clinton would not hesitate to ask a big-city cop to risk his or her life to apprehend a murder suspect," the Human Rights Watch report said, "since that is the price to be paid for upholding the rule of law at home. But when it came to deploying law enforcement officials abroad -- in this case IFOR -- to arrest suspects in genocide and mass murder and uphold the most basic international law, he balked."
European governments failed an easier test of will in the Balkans. The Council of Europe admitted Croatia as a member last year even though President Franjo Tudjman had not carried out the Council's demand that he first cooperate in arresting war criminals, allow an opposition leader elected mayor of Zagreb to take his post and let Serbian refugees return.
Against those somber facts of the last year there are encouraging ones. South Africa is an important example. Its Truth and Reconciliation Commission has begun to expose the official murders and other horrors of the apartheid years.
But the particulars are less important than a general reality. For all the setbacks, growing awareness of the need to protect human rights has violators on the defensive. And public protest often works.
During the last year, for example, Americans became aware that some of the clothes they bought were made by children working under sorry conditions in Asia and Latin America. The outrage that resulted forced U.S. importing companies to change their sources of supply or make those sources follow decent labor practices.
Even a place as remote as Burma can feel pressure. At the end of this year the Disney Company will not have Mickey Mouse clothes made in Burma; its licensed supplier will stop manufacturing there for "strictly business reasons" -- evidently meaning the pain of a boycott. Attention may now shift to Unocal, a U.S. corporation that has invested in a huge pipeline project in Burma.
But if we want to make gains for human rights, we cannot pay mere lip service to principle as the Dayton enforcers and Council of Europe have done. We have to be serious. If we are, a world more aware of what should be can slowly turn governments toward decency and humanity.

HEADLINE: New York as Welfare Model

 BODY:
Gov. George Pataki's welfare plan contains a callous proposal to cut cash benefits nearly in half for long-term recipients. But the plan also includes worthwhile features that go beyond what other states are likely to propose to soften the blow of the new Federal welfare law. The encouraging fact is that the cruel features of the Pataki plan can be removed without wrecking New York's budget, leaving a welfare system that would serve as an enviable model for other states.
The Federal law provides states fixed blocks of money to help poor families. The law will knock many legal immigrants, childless adults and disabled children off welfare, food stamps and Medicaid. It will also prohibit use of Federal money to provide a welfare family cash support for more than five years. Mr. Pataki would cut cash benefits below current levels by up to 45 percent even before the Federal five-year limit kicked in, plunging single mothers and their children into squalor. 
 But the Pataki plan also includes generous non-cash provisions, beyond what most other states are likely to offer. They would apply without a time limit to every needy family, including those cut off from Federal aid -- families that hit the five-year Federal welfare limit, childless adults and legal immigrants. The non-cash assistance, possibly in the form of vouchers, would cover food, clothing and housing. The vouchers are to be worth as much as the cash aid the state currently pays.
To encourage work, the Pataki plan would guarantee recipients who find jobs a year of Medicaid coverage and child-care assistance. It would also allow them to keep up to $13,000 a year in wages before giving up any welfare benefits. That is a startlingly high threshold, equal to the Federal poverty line. For recipients who cannot find jobs, counties would be required to create workfare or community service slots.
These are admirable promises. But they are also unrealistic, as presently written. Voucher plans are untested on a large scale. They would require an expensive assessment of each recipient's needs for individual goods, like clothing. Workfare programs for adults who have no record of steady work are notoriously difficult to implement, and might require far more money than the Pataki administration has allocated.
Fortunately, most of the problems are fixable. A quirk in the Federal welfare law will produce a $450 million-a-year windfall for New York State, at least until the next recession. Mr. Pataki would grab almost half of the windfall for general budget relief. A better idea would be to grab $80 million less, which is all that would be needed to fully reinstate the proposed benefit cuts for welfare parents. That would remove the plan's cruelty.
A second fix would eliminate the voucher program. Mr. Pataki fears that if New York pays cash to its poor, the poor in other states will flock to collect a check. This fear is understandable but overdrawn.
If, as Mr. Pataki promises, the able-bodied poor will be required to find work or take workfare and community service slots, there will be no giveaway and no huge incentive to migrate to New York. Replacing vouchers with cash will create no budget problem because, under Mr. Pataki's budget, they cost about the same amount.
Assembly Democrats need to revise other features of the Pataki plan. For example, the proposal gives local governments excessive leeway to decide what necessities to grant each poor family.
No state can afford to create a satisfactory welfare system, because no state can afford to tax itself to create a public-sector jobs program that would allow able-bodied parents to earn their way out of poverty. President Clinton proposed, then abandoned, such a plan in 1994, and the truth is that only Washington can make such a plan work. But if Mr. Pataki is willing to use just a bit more of the Federal Government's windfall funds for welfare, instead of for tax cuts, he can eliminate all of the plan's unfairness and most of its impracticality.

HEADLINE: America's Shortchanged Diplomacy

 BODY:
President Clinton, now preparing next year's budget requests, will have to fight hard to provide Madeleine Albright with adequate resources to represent America's international interests as Secretary of State. Diplomacy is America's first and least costly line of defense against international conflict. Yet for years Congress has been letting that line erode dangerously.
Expanding American business and security interests require a wider American diplomatic presence abroad than ever before. Yet, allowing for inflation, the State Department's operating budget has declined by almost 20 percent over the past five years. If shrinking foreign aid levels and America's spotty record on paying its assessments to international organizations are also taken into account, real diplomatic spending is now down to less than half what it was in 1984. 
 State's operating budget, set at $2.6 billion this year, pays for all diplomatic personnel and premises worldwide. It also covers the costs of training foreign service officers, protecting embassies and consulates and running the information systems used to screen visa applicants, verify treaty compliance and help American businesses and tourists navigate foreign legal systems and cultures.
This country's diplomatic outposts abroad play a crucial role in tracking down international terrorists and drug traffickers and negotiating for their extradition. They contribute to the monitoring of arms control, trade and environmental treaties. They also handle some two million assistance requests a year from American citizens.
With both political parties committed to balancing the Federal budget by the year 2002, all spending requests are sure to come under heavy pressure. Congress should be demanding a lean and efficient State Department operation. But it should not be compromising America's international presence or diplomatic strength. The difference between adequate and inadequate funding of the operating budget is less than $300 million a year. Congress casually added $11 billion to last year's defense budget.
It is always a great deal less expensive, in lives as well as dollars, to head off potential threats by timely diplomatic action than to move in belatedly with military force. Maintaining that capacity to preserve the peace ought to be one of Mr. Clinton's top budgetary priorities.

HEADLINE: In America;
The Safety Net Works

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
Again and again during the fight over welfare we heard self-righteous, sanctimonious and often very rich politicians proclaim that anti-poverty programs hadn't worked. The programs were actually harming the poor, they said. Echoing Dickens's most unforgiving villains, they reasoned that the best approach would be to cut the poor's already meager benefits. That would build character, they said. So they cut the benefits and called it reform.
On Saturday, in his radio address, President Clinton reaffirmed his solidarity with those who believe that removing a plate of spaghetti or a bowl of rice and beans from the dinner table of a hungry child is somehow beneficial. 
 From his wobbly perch atop the tower of national virtue, the President spoke of his "moral obligation" to help the poor help themselves.
"The door has now been opened to a new era of freedom and independence," Mr. Clinton said, an apparent reference to the sense of liberation that the well-off have always associated with bare cupboards and eviction notices. He might also have mentioned the unparalleled exhilaration that comes from an empty stomach.
In any event, the message of the President and others is quite clear: It is time to take the scissors to the safety net.
From another quarter -- less cynical, more compassionate, more in touch with the real world -- comes a study that shows how important government programs continue to be in helping Americans, young and old, escape the dangerous and demoralizing grasp of poverty.
The study was done by the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities and its findings are not ambiguous: "Based on analysis of recently released Census Bureau data, this paper shows that Federal and state antipoverty programs have lifted millions of children and disabled and elderly people out of poverty. Many of those who remained poor were significantly less poor than they would have been without government assistance."
The study found that without such assistance, 57.6 million people would have been poor in 1995. "But when government benefits are counted, including food stamps, housing assistance, school lunch support and benefits provided through the earned-income tax credit, the number of poor people drops to 30.3 million."
Safety net programs, especially Social Security, held the poverty rate among the elderly in 1995 to 9 percent. Without them, according to the study, the poverty rate among the elderly would have been 50 percent.
Among children, means-tested programs, including Aid to Families with Dependent Children, have the biggest effect. The study said: "The safety net programs reduced the child poverty rate from 24 percent before benefits are counted to 16 percent."
You would think such substantial bulwarks against poverty would be widely applauded. Instead, anti-poverty efforts in general are derided and the mere mention of welfare makes many Americans apoplectic.
The lead author of the study, entitled "The Safety Net Delivers," was Wendell Primus, a former Assistant Secretary of Health and Human Services who left the Clinton Administration in protest last summer when the President signed a welfare bill that will result in an estimated one million children being thrown into poverty.
Mr. Primus and his co-authors took a close look at two periods of recent history: the early 1980's, when government anti-poverty benefits were substantially reduced, and the mid-80's to mid-90's, when bipartisan efforts to increase government assistance and expand the earned-income tax credit strengthened the safety net.
Recessions occurred during both periods. The study found that when government benefits are taken into account, "The number of people who were poor grew by 11 million during the recession of the early 1980's and by only 5.5 million -- just half as much -- during the recession of the early 1990's. Poverty grew far less during the most recent recession because the safety net was considerably stronger in the early 1990's."
In other words, the programs worked.
But we now have, for the poor, the toxic combination of Bill Clinton in the White House and the Republican Party in control of both houses of Congress. The next recession will provide tremendous opportunities for character-building.

HEADLINE: Nobody Reads a Good Movie These Days

BYLINE: By LINDA LEE 

 BODY:
Three French films opening this month -- Patrice Leconte's "Ridicule," Claude Chabrol's "Ceremonie,"and Andre Techine's "Voleurs" ("Thieves") -- bring to 55 the total of foreign-language films released in 1996 in New York.
Few Americans can name any of them. Fewer have gone to see them. 
 Among the most successful of this year's releases were the Dominican film "Nueba Yol" and the French films "Horseman on the Roof" and "Nellie and Monsieur Arnaud." The most successful, "Antonia's Line," took in $4.6 million. The next biggest gross belonged to "Horseman on the Roof," at $1.4 million.
But about 90 percent of the foreign-language films released the past year in New York, where most open, made less than $1 million at the box office nationally -- a cutoff point below which few distributors make money.
Foreign-language film has hit hard times since its heyday 30 years ago. In 1966, approximately 60 foreign-language films were released, and many of the titles still reverberate: "La Guerre Est Finie," by Alain Resnais; Jean-Luc Godard's "Masculine-Feminine;" Milos Forman's "Loves of a Blonde;" Claude Lelouch's "Man and a Woman;" Pier Paolo Pasolini's "Gospel According to St. Matthew," and the Czech film "The Shop on Main Street," directed by Jan Kadar and Elmar Klos.
So, did the movies get smaller? Or did the audience? Michael Barker, a co-president of Sony Pictures Classics, believes that "there are fewer European masters now."
In fact, most American distributors see a growing crisis in releasing foreign-language films. Eight years ago, Sony Pictures Classics made foreign films 60 percent of its release slate; this year, they are 40 percent.
"The art house business is really ruthless now," said Jonathan Weisgal, executive vice president at Fine Line Features. "You've got to think a thousand times before you take on a subtitled movie."
Many of this year's subtitled films never had a serious national release, which costs big distributors about $500,000 for prints and ads. Add to that approximately $200,000 to acquire a film for American distribution, and that "gives you more than three-quarters of a million into it," said Bingham Ray, a co-managing executive of another distributor, October Films. Distributors keep only half the receipts, so for them, the break-even point is usually a box office of $1.5 million
Why are foreign-language films such an albatross? Industry watchers cite three primary reasons:
*Most have little life beyond the theatrical release because there is low demand for the videos or TV rights.
*American independent movies have taken over not only the subject matter and style of foreign films, but also their audiences.
*More particularly, the explicit sexual content once uniquely associated with foreign films is not unique any more. It's no longer necessary for anyone looking for titillation in a movie theater to turn to Brigitte Bardot in " . . . And God Created Woman," a 1956 French film condemned by the Catholic Legion of Decency.
The economic pull of the video market is perhaps the most pervasive force. Since foreign titles usually have minimal ad budgets, they are remembered less often when customers go to the video store.
Most foreign films never get beyond 10,000 to 15,000 copies on video, distributors say. Judith McCourt, director of research for Video Store Magazine, says the average video store dedicates 1.2 percent of its space to foreign titles.
The exceptions are movies that win the Academy Award (this year's winner, the Dutch film "Antonia's Line," has shipped 30,000 video copies), and movies like Miramax's 1995 Italian film "Il Postino" ("The Postman")," which got five Oscar nominations and has become the most successful foreign-language film ever, with $21 million at the box office. The film is expected to do very well on video. The Mexican film "Like Water for Chocolate," the second most-successful, has sold 70,000 copies to video stores.
Those numbers offer some hope. Ms. McCourt calculates that foreign video rentals made a 156 percent return on investment in 1996. By comparison all rental films produced a 143.9 percent return on investment.
Foreign films are also no longer the only source of intimate and idiosyncratic art. The sensibility that informed the French films held up as models to a generation of American film students was absorbed by those students, who are now making their own films. And the home-grown product has more appeal.
"Now Americans themselves make talky films like 'Before Sunrise,' " said Piers Handling, the director of programming for the Toronto International Film Festival, referring to a 1995 movie starring Ethan Hawke.
"Now," Mr. Baker said, "the people that went to see 'La Guerre Est Finie' are the first to see 'Lone Star,' " an American film by John Sayles.
"And it's not just the rise of the independent American cinema," said Annette Insdorf, a professor of film at Columbia. "It is also the rise of films from Australia or New Zealand." She cites "Shine," now in theaters, or the 1994 film "Once Were Warriors." "Such films provide exoticism," she said, "and we don't have to read."
Among other factors working against foreign-language films is that "college students don't have any more cinematic culture," said Serge Losique, director of the Montreal World Film Festival. "Now, it's action films and Clint Eastwood."
Peter Brunette, a professor of English and film studies at George Mason University in Fairfax, Va., said: "Most people would feel funny teaching a course on Ingmar Bergman today. It seems old-fashioned -- you know, the great white European artist. Now the academic world looks at film as a function of culture."
Ellen Little, the president of First Look, which released "Antonia's Line," said: "For me it was the Brattle, off of Harvard Square. That was where every other day there was a new foreign film to see. I was there in the '60's and saw 'Woman in the Dunes.' "
But now, Alex Fitzsimmons, who works at the Brattle, said: "We don't really get students. If we show a French film, we get French people."
Less noted, but also present, is the argument that Americans are too lazy to read subtitles, and that the American media aggressively ignore foreign offerings.
Finally, whether it's a matter of choice or necessity, more and more foreign directors are making films in English -- a trend that dates back 30 years, when Francois Truffaut made "Fahrenheit 451."
In the last year, the Russian director Sergei Bodrov has talked to Hollywood producers about shooting a film in English, as well as Jan Sverak, the Czech director of "Kolya," Miramax's hope for a foreign-film smash next year. Lars von Trier made "Breaking the Waves," a recent film, in English; his last, "The Kingdom," was a four-and-a-half-hour epic about a hospital in Danish.
Are those directors abandoning their audience? Or did their audience already abandon them?

HEADLINE: Donations to Universities Sometimes Carry a Price

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN 

DATELINE: BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 8

 BODY:
To the needy scholars of East Asia at the University of California campus here, the unexpected offer of a few million dollars for a new center to study ancient Chinese cultures sounded at first like a godsend.
Then they paused at the fine print: The Taiwan foundation proposing to finance the center insisted that it commemorate the foundation and its namesake, Chiang Ching-kuo, the late President of Taiwan who, long before he helped lead the island toward democracy in the 1980's, was among the Chinese Nationalist leaders who have been blamed for the repression of thousands of political dissidents. 
 The university's initial bid for the money has set off an uproar among some scholars and students who fear damage to the school's reputation, undue influence from the government-financed foundation, even a loss of access to the People's Republic of China for research and exchange programs.
The dispute, however, is of a sort that is growing painfully familiar as many of the nation's best colleges and universities turn to new sources of support in the developing world to replace the dwindling money for foreign area-studies programs that were a greater priority of the Federal government and big American foundations during the cold war.
"There's a scramble now to find new means of support for these programs," said Daniel I. Okimoto, the director of the Asia/Pacific Research Center at Stanford University, which, along with Columbia University, is also considering the Taiwan foundation's offer. "You can't raise it through tuition, so it's either private like a windfall foundation or business. In that context, the availability of funds from something like the Chiang Ching-kuo Foundation looks like a windfall."
At Princeton University, the controversy this year was over the endowment of a chair in Turkish studies that some scholars feared could be used by the Government of Turkey to whitewash its role in the massacre of a million Armenians in World War I. At the University of Michigan, the furor followed another Taiwan institute's sudden withdrawal of a $450,000 grant after one of the university's scholars endorsed a document calling on the United States to give priority to Beijing in its policies in the region.
For scholars of Latin America, the problem is not so much one of taking money from government agencies or politically minded foundations, but of finding appropriate donors in a business elite that has become increasingly involved in that region's turbulent politics.
Some associates of the David Rockefeller Center for Latin American Studies at Harvard University have squirmed in private as a few of the powerful Latin American personages on the center's advisory committee have become enmeshed in controversy in their native countries. At some other institutes for Latin American research, professors said they have had to conduct informal background checks before even approaching foreign alumni and other potential donors abroad.
"Everybody feels their programs at risk," said Gilbert W. Merkx, who directs the Latin American Research Institute at the University of New Mexico.
"The gods are no longer smiling on us in Washington and New York, and along comes some foreign businessman who says he'll drop $1 million on a center or an endowed chair," Dr. Merkx added. "The money doesn't have to come with strings, but there is always a natural inclination to be grateful to the donor."
Polemics over the sources of foreign support for American higher education are by no means new. After World War II, the perceived villains were powerful patrons of European-studies programs who had been on or associated with the Axis side. In 1978, a furor erupted at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government over a $1 million gift in the name of an American businessman who made a fortune in mining in South Africa under the country's apartheid regime. And over the last two decades, governmental and private agencies in Japan have been especially aggressive about using grants to American colleges and universities to improve the perceptions and understanding of their country in the United States.
Part of what has shifted of late has been the areas of the world that are the hottest subjects of international studies in the United States; Asia and Latin America, in particular, are riding a new boom in popularity fueled by both their importance in the global economy and the rising number of American students who trace their roots to those regions.
As the economic ties of those areas to the United States have deepened, academic experts said, businessmen and others from countries like South Korea, Singapore and Mexico have also had a greater ability and incentive to turn to American educational institutions in order to extend their influence here.
The universities, for their part, have looked to the same sort of upwardly mobile alumni, government agencies and influential foundations that have dotted their campuses with shiny new buildings and plush endowed professorships in the past. But now, university officials said, a growing number of those alumni might be prominent business and political figures abroad. And they, like the governments and foundations, have often found themselves coming under greater political scrutiny in the United States.
Programs in Korean studies have been a notable case in point.
After struggling for years in relative penury, such programs found an important new source of help in the early 1990's. The Korea Foundation, a creation of the South Korean government, began spending millions of dollars to expand academic programs, endow professorships and sponsor conferences in the United States. But what the Koreans who dole out the grants might be seeking in return has become a question of growing controversy.
"These are not academic organizations," said Chalmers Johnson, an emeritus professor of political science at Berkeley who formerly headed the university's Center for Chinese Studies. "They are out to get over a point of view. They are paying to win support for their government."
The Korea Foundation has drawn American criticism, among other reasons, because of its steadfast refusal to follow the Japan Foundation's lead and establish a process by which grant requests are reviewed by a panel of scholars in the United States.
Instead, decisions are made by a board controlled by South Korean businessmen tied to the government, and the new head of the foundation, Joung won Kim, is a former senior official of the government's intelligence agency.
Academic experts trace the struggle to finance area-studies programs and centers to cuts and changes that both the government and private foundations have made over the last decade or so. While the overall contribution of major foundations to international studies may not have fallen, foundation officials said much of that money has been channeled away from traditional area-studies programs to research that is more thematically oriented, examines problems in a comparative perspective, or emphasizes issues of American policy.
"We are still concerned with the study of foreign cultures, but we are doing it in a different way than we did before," said Richard Ekman, secretary of the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation in New York. "We made a judgment in the late 1980's that it was no longer possible to fund every area-studies program. Relative to other areas, there are more foreign sources available to East Asian studies programs, and our funding can be more effective elsewhere."
Although the Mellon Foundation and some others have placed a greater emphasis on Latin America since the 1980's, administrators of some of the most prestigious academic programs on the region said their competition for resources has grown steadily more intense. And even Harvard's Rockefeller Center, with its relatively spectacular success in trying to build a $30 million endowment, has highlighted the delicacy of looking abroad for help.
One of the 34 members of the center's advisory committee, a powerful industrialist from Colombia, has been in the news lately as a pillar of support for that country's embattled President, Ernesto Samper, following accusations by Colombian and American officials that Mr. Samper took millions of dollars from the Cali cocaine cartel. Other committee members are politically connected Mexican businessmen who have been criticized at home for their ties to that country's widely attacked former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari.
Just as Harvard and Yale and other American universities have for the most part relished their ties to the political and business elite in Latin America, the Middle East and Asia, the University of California at Berkeley has cherished the strength of ties to Taiwan's ruling class.
The island's first elected Governor, James Soong, who is on the board of the Chiang Ching-kuo Foundation for International Scholarly Exchange, won the university's highest award for foreign alumni last year. But as the commotion continued this week over the foundation's offer, the university's Taiwan-educated chancellor, Chang-Lin Tien, was back in Taipei on what several faculty members described as something of a damage-control mission. Through an assistant, Chancellor Tien declined to comment.
The director of the foundation's North American office in McLean, Va., Hsingwei Lee, said that while it was founded in 1989 with government as well as private money, it has never applied political criteria in dispensing the roughly $23 million it has spent on American scholarship.
The head of the University of California's Center for Chinese Studies, Wen-hsin Yeh, said faculty members had put aside their draft proposal for the Chiang Ching-kuo Foundation's money while they discussed the question more fully. But like her counterparts at Columbia and Stanford, she also argued that the uproar over the offer had little to do with how the foundation had spent its money, and seemed to have been stoked as much as anything by the controversy over Asian fund raising for the Democratic Party.
The director of the East Asian Institute at Columbia, Madeline Zelin, said the university would in principle have no problem naming a center or program after the Chiang Ching-kuo Foundation.
But that issue may be more sensitive in the San Francisco Bay area, where a Chinese-American journalist, Henry Yi Liu, was murdered in 1984 on orders from Mr. Chiang's military intelligence chief after writing critically of the Taiwan leader.
"It seems to me that it's very simple and very straightforward," Professor Yeh said. "We have our own ideas about the kind of research we want to do. We write up the proposal in ways that make us happy and we submit it."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Unusual Criticism of Fed From Senate G.O.P. Leader
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican majority leader, said that he was "a little bit nervous about the degree of independence" enjoyed by the Federal Reserve, and that the central bank should push interest rates lower to stimulate growth.
Mr. Lott's statements were an unusually direct criticism of the Fed from a senior party leader. [Page D2.]
 
Mixed Signs on Airline Safety
As Death Toll Sets a Record
With three weeks to go in 1996, more passengers have died in airline crashes this year than in any other, even though statistics show that air travel is becoming safer over time. But the high death toll is in part a result of the rapid increase in the number of flights worldwide. Still, perceptions of increased risk have officials moving along a number of fronts to improve aviation safety. [A1.]
 
A lack of proficiency in English among air traffic controllers and pilots has been cited in several recent crashes. [A1.]
 
Canadian Airlines in Union Pact
The Canadian Auto Workers union has reached agreement with Canadian Airlines and the Government on a recovery plan that includes employee pay cuts. [D2.]
 
U.S. Pushes to End Tariffs
American officials pushed to negotiate details of a global pact that would end tariffs on information technology. [D2.]
 
Trouble for J. Walter Thompson
J. Walter Thompson has been hit with a double blow: Sun Microsystems has put its account in review, and Kodak had shifted responsibilities for its Advantix photography system to Ogilvy & Mather. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D12.]
 
Men's Magazines Get Makeover
Men's magazines are talking to men the way women's magazines have long been talking to women, moving beyond politics, sports and pictures of naked women to offer nuts-and-bolts information about fashion, fitness, sexual prowess, parenting, even primping. [A1.]
 
Venture Tracks Bond Market
Intervest and the Bloomberg business information service have reached an agreement to provide bond trading quotes to Bloomberg subscribers, in much the same way that stock watchers get such data. [D6.]
 
Faster Internet Video
Narrative Communications, a start-up company, is shipping software that permits the distribution and viewing of feature-length interactive multimedia over the Internet using ordinary telephone lines, which could put an end to the painfully slow process now required to download such files. [D6.]
 
Quo Vadis, Foreign Film?
Foreign-language film has hit hard times in the United States since its heyday 30 years ago. About 90 percent of the foreign-language films released in New York in the last year made less than $1 million at the American box office, the point below which it is hard for a distributor to make money. [D9.]
 
'Happy Days' Are Here Again
As cable TV keeps adding channels, all with 24-hour schedules to fill, the market for old network television shows has never been hotter. Everything from "Sanford and Son" to "Bonanza" to "Dallas" is back. Bill Carter: Television. [D9.]
 
A Warning From China
Movie industry executives said the Chinese Government's warning to Disney that releasing a movie about the Dalai Lama could cripple its efforts to expand in China gave notice to studios that China would not tolerate films about delicate issues. [C11.]

LENGTH: 1750 words

HEADLINE: A Chip Maker With Hungry Eyes For Your Toaster;
SGS-Thomson Carves Niche Outside the Computer World

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: CROLLES, France

 BODY:
From the standpoint of aeronautical design, seagulls should not be able to fly, Pasquale Pistorio likes to say, when urging his workers to greater achievement. Fortunately, he adds with a characteristic chuckle, the seagulls don't know it.
Yes, the French make good wines and cheese, and the Italians may be among the leading arbiters of the world's fashion tastes. But Franco-Italian semiconductors? Leave chips to real industrialists, like the Japanese or Americans. 
 Mr. Pistorio, the portly, mustachioed president and chief executive of SGS-Thomson Microelectronics, begs to disagree. In recent years, the 60-year-old executive has forged SGS-Thomson, a company of French and Italian pedigree, into one of the world's most diversified and innovative makers of semiconductors.
Although not even in the top 10 of the world's semiconductor companies as ranked by revenue, SGS-Thomson has carved out a lucrative niche as the leading producer of analog chips, with a big research center here on the edge of this French Alpine city.
Unlike digital chips, which process information that can be expressed only as the 1's and O's of computer code, analog chips can monitor real-world conditions like movement, temperature and sound and convert them into analogous electronic or mechanical patterns. And these patterns can instruct devices or machines to take action.
If you drive a Chrysler, you're surrounded by four or five of Mr. Pistorio's chips, which help the engine purr and soften the sway of steep curves. If you use a hand-held phone from Northern Telecom, you're holding one or two as well, helping transform voice into electrical signals or back again.
"Some of the things we do are banalities, but the difference is in execution," Mr. Pistorio said in a recent conversation over pasta and fish at an SGS-Thomson plant outside Milan.
Formed from the 1987 merger of Italy's SGS Microelettronica and Thomson Semiconducteurs of France, SGS now has 17 factories in 8 countries, including the United States (in Carrollton, Tex., Phoenix, and Rancho Bernardo, Calif.). Investing roughly $1 billion a year in new products and factories, the company maintains a balance between sales of commodity chips -- simple low-cost circuits that enter unaltered into a vast array of products -- and costlier customized chips. The custom chips are produced in close alliance with the companies that use them to make things like mobile phones, satellite television receivers and cars.
This balanced product line has enabled SGS largely to insulate itself against the cyclical swings of the semiconductor market. While more narrowly focused competitors were battered by the recent sales slump in semiconductors, SGS increased earnings in the first nine months of this year by 35 percent, to $483.5 million.
To accelerate the momentum, SGS raised $1.3 billion of fresh capital through two additional offerings of stock in the last two years, and has become the darling of Wall Street, where investment advisers search frantically for slump-resistant high technology stocks. [The shares closed Friday at $67.375 on the New York Stock Exchange, just off the 52-week high reached three days earlier -- and more than double their value this time last year.]
"This company outperformed by a tremendous margin," said William J. Milton Jr., who follows SGS for Brown Brothers Harriman & Company in New York, which ranks SGS outperform/buy. While global sales of semiconductors are expected to drop 10.5 percent this year to $129 billion, he noted, the outlook is for SGS to increase revenues by almost 19 percent.
Yet the going is risky for SGS, whose forecasted $4.1 billion of revenues this year will rank it only 12th among global chip makers. For a relatively small company like SGS, the danger in trying to be strong in a variety of microchip types is that it will spread itself too thin, and fail to keep pace with specialist companies that rely on one or a few types of semiconductors for their growth.
Take mixed-signal technology, for instance -- semiconductors capable of such tasks as storing speech or images on chips. In this field, SGS runs up against not only specialists like Symbios Logic, a unit of Hyundai Electronics Industry, in the United States and Alcatel Mietec of France, a unit of Alcatel Alsthom, but also big, broad-based manufacturers like Texas Instruments and AT&T.
"With so many products spread so thin," Mr. Milton said, "maybe you don't spot and develop growth markets."
So far, though, that has not been a problem, thanks to a strategy Mr. Pistorio has consistently followed since 1987. It was then, as chief executive of Microelettronica, that he engineered the merger of his company with Thomson after recognizing how well the two organizations and product lines might fit together.
Microelettronica was strong in smart power chips used for, say, running several electrical motors at once, while Thomson was a leader in mixed-signal technology. Microelettronica, moreover, was strong in telecommunications chips, while Thomson's semiconductors were well known in consumer products like televisions and video recorders. And Microelettronica had a toehold in Asia through a factory in Singapore, while Thomson was active in the United States, thanks to its acquisition in 1985 of Mostek, an American company specializing in memory chips.
But each company was also saddled with an array of small, inefficient factories and bloated purchasing and logistics divisions. So within a year of the merger, Mr. Pistorio closed five plants -- three in France and two in East Asia -- integrated all sales offices worldwide, and shed 2,000 jobs, to less than 21,000. (Profitable growth has allowed the work force to expand to 25,500 today.)
Mr. Pistorio's best-placed strategic bet was to develop SGS-Thomson's expertise in analog chips. Rather than losing ground in recent years against digital circuitry, analog is actually gaining, as the applications for chips multiply in industrial and consumer products from trucks to toasters.
Traditionally, analog and digital functions were handled by separate chips, but as applications for chips blossomed, an immense market has emerged for mixed-signal integrated circuits that combine both functions: thinking like a computer, but also performing analog functions like controlling the speed of electrical motors or producing sound. Crucial for such applications are so-called smart-power circuits, which can perform several such functions at once.
SGS's forerunner companies both pioneered these technologies. But Mr. Pistorio recalls that both organizations tended to be "satisfied when a prototype came out," but seemed to consider it "undignified" to actually manufacture and sell chips.
He quickly recalibrated the priorities. And while the newly merged venture lost $68 million in 1988, the following year it managed a $3 million profit and has seen profits grow steadily since.
Raised in Sicily, the son of a government employee, Mr. Pistorio was trained as an electrical engineer. Yet his real skill always seemed to lay in persuasion. As a student at Turin's Technical University, he spent many hours working as a substitute high school teacher, honing a gift for motivating people. Then, after getting his degree in electrical engineering, he joined the Italian distributor for Motorola Semiconductors, before moving into sales at Motorola itself, eventually making his way to the United States.
In 1980, at the age of 44, Mr. Pistorio was general manager of Motorola Semiconductors' Phoenix-based international operations when he was tapped by Stet, the Italian telecommunications group, to bail out its unprofitable semiconductor subsidiary, Microelettronica.
To this day, executives involved in hiring Mr. Pistorio puzzle at how he succeeded in applying tough American management rules in what was essentially a flabby and protected government-run business.
"He threw himself against the windmills, went with his head against the wall," said Umberto Silvestri, the president of Telecom Italia, Italy's national telecommunications group, who at the time was running Stet.
Mr. Pistorio also brought with him a keen analysis of the semiconductor business that many say has not altered over the years. Jean-Philippe Dauvin, SGS's chief economist, sums up his boss's strategy as, "low-cost development and global distribution."
To achieve the first, Mr. Dauvin says, Mr. Pistorio assiduously sought long-term alliances with companies that were potential consumers of chips -- makers of computer peripherals, like the Silicon Valley disk drive manufacturer Seagate Technologies, telecommunications giants like Northern Telecom of Canada and Nokia of Finland, and makers and users of auto parts like Bosch of Germany or the Chrysler Corporation.
The alliance with Northern Telecom is typical.
In 1993, as part of a plan to move away from cumbersome vertical integration, Northern Telecom sought a partner to take some of its semiconductor operations off its hands, at the same time sharing the cost of new microchip development for its products. In a subsequent agreement, Northern Telecom agreed to sell to SGS a semiconductor factory in San Diego, thereby affording the chip maker a chance to increase its presence in the United States, while both companies would share the cost of developing new silicon technology for the chips Northern Telecom required.
Peter Scovell, the vice president of Northern Telecom's advanced components division, said the alliance produced live card circuits for digital phone switching systems and is now focused on developing bipolar technology used in very high frequency mobile phone systems.
But can a company the modest size of SGS keep up against the giants of the industry, big manufacturers like Intel and NEC, which are many times its size?
Among the world's semiconductor manufacturers, SGS is now lodged in a second tier of companies whose global market shares average about 2 percent each. To succeed, SGS sees itself needing the revenue growth that will move the company into the top 10 club with giants like Motorola and Texas Instruments, with market shares averaging about 5.5 percent.
Mr. Pistorio said that SGS must continue to specialize in a broad range of semiconductor technologies, based on strategic alliances.
But, he added, with a logic that even a seagull might understand, "If you want to be a specialist, you must be big."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Pasquale Pistorio, the president and chief executive of SGS-Thomson Microelectronics. (Robert Burroughs for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "A Big Business From Tiny Transistors"
SGS-Thomson's diversified semiconductor business includes being the world's largest producer of analog chips, which are used in a variety of automotive, industrial and consumer products. Unlike digital chips, which process information that can be expressed only as the 1's and 0's of computer code, analog chips can translate real-world conditions -- like motion, sound, temperature, pressure and light -- into analogous electronic or mechanical patterns. These patterns can instruct devices to perform tasks like the following:
 
MOTION -- Anitlock brakes
INPUT Driver presses on the brake pedal.
WHAT THE CHIP DOES The chip monitors the wheels and prevents the brakes from locking.
RESULT The car stops without skidding.
 
SOUND -- Telephones
INPUT Someone speaks into the phone.
WHAT THE CHIP DOES The chip converts sound from an analog signal to a digital one -- then back again on the other end.
RESULT Electronic signal mimics sound waves in phone receiver.
 
TEMPERATURE -- Coffee maker
INPUT Coffee is brewed.
WHAT THE CHIP DOES The chip measures the temperature of the coffee as water evaporates and the remaining coffee heats up.
RESULT Coffee maker turns off before the pot burns.
 
PRESSURE -- Computer joystick
INPUT A joystick directs a character to move.
WHAT THE CHIP DOES The analog chip measures the pressure against the joystick, which is converted to a digital command in the game.
RESULT On-screen character makes a hard or soft turn, depending on the pressure.
 
LIGHT -- Robot on an assembly line
INPUT An assembly-line robot examines the products.
WHAT THE CHIP DOES Sensors detect a flaw, a bad weave in textile for example, and translate this to an analog signal light.
RESULT A warning light alerts human operators. (Source: SGS-Thomson)
