HEADLINE: Republican Senate Chief Questions the Fed

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican majority leader, said today that he was "a little bit nervous about the degree of independence" enjoyed by the Federal Reserve, and that the central bank should push interest rates lower to stimulate more economic growth.
Mr. Lott's statements were an unusually direct criticism of the Fed from a senior political leader of either party, and a sharp departure from usual Republican support for the tough anti-inflation policies followed by the central bank under its chairman for the last nine years, Alan Greenspan. 
 The Senator's comments could stimulate further debate about the Federal Reserve's role, coming a few days after Mr. Greenspan raised questions in a speech here about whether stock levels had gotten too high. Reports of the speech sent international markets down sharply.
It is doubtful that Mr. Lott's comments reflect a changed consensus among Republicans about Mr. Greenspan's conduct of monetary policy. But they suggested that the Fed might not be able to take for granted the broad-based political support it has had in recent years, especially if signs of incipient inflation force it to raise rates at a time growth is less than robust.
Mr. Lott, though known as a pragmatist, has been closely identified with his party's tax-cutting camp, which argues that the economy is capable of faster growth without inflation if taxes and regulation are reduced. Yet Republican tax cutters have steered clear of openly criticizing the Federal Reserve, and one of Mr. Lott's closest Republican colleagues, Senator Connie Mack of Florida, has introduced a bill to grant the Fed additional protection from political interference by requiring that the central bank's only mandate be to pursue price stability.
Mr. Lott's remarks were made on the television interview program "Fox News Sunday."
He was first asked about Mr. Greenspan's suggestion in a speech on Thursday night that financial markets sometimes succumb to "irrational exuberance," a phrase that sent stocks falling sharply on Friday in markets in Asia, Europe and, to a lesser extent, the United States.
"Yeah, that rattles people," Senator Lott replied. He was then asked if it scared him that one man had so much power.
"You know, I've always been a little nervous about the Fed, quite frankly," he said. "I try not to be a Fed-basher, but I sometimes think they focus too much on one side of the equation rather than the broader basket of things," he continued, apparently referring to the Fed's policy of concentrating on low inflation rather than on using interest rates to spur growth and employment.
"And I'm a little nervous about the degree of independence they have," Mr. Lott said. "But at the same time, I realize that's very important. Now I guess I'm, you know, tiptoeing around here."
Asked if he was saying that he was scared but did not know what to do about it, he replied: "Well, yeah. I don't want to bash them, and I think that over all they've done a pretty good job. I mean, you can't complain too much about the last few years in terms of interest rates. I think that interest rates should be lower even than what they are, certainly."
Mr. Lott went on to say that the Fed makes mistakes "like we do," and that Mr. Greenspan probably wished that he had "chosen some other words" when he talked about market valuations last week.
Earlier in the program, the Senator called the economy's growth, which has been running at 2 percent to 2.5 percent in recent years, "anemic," and warned there were signs that it could slip lower.
In addition to calling for lower interest rates, Mr. Lott reiterated his support for cutting the capital gains tax.
The economy has substantially slowed in the last five months, and there are few signals that inflation is building. Economists are divided whether growth might accelerate, leaving the Federal Reserve to consider if a rate increase is needed, or the economy is in danger of stalling, requiring a rate cut to energize it.
Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin, a former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs, said today that he interpreted Mr. Greenspan's remarks "as simply raising a question -- not suggesting an answer" about whether stock prices had become too high.
Mr. Rubin, speaking on NBC's "Meet the Press," would not say if he thought the market was overvalued, urging investors to make decisions based on economic fundamentals.
He also reiterated the Administration's position that it would consider changing the way the Government adjusts Social Security and other benefit programs for inflation if there were a broad consensus on the matter.
A panel of economists appointed by Congress reported last week that the Consumer Price Index overstates increases in the cost of living by 1.1 percentage points, resulting in billions of dollars a year in excessive benefit payments.
Mr. Rubin said there was general agreement that the index was an imperfect gauge of inflation, but he declined to endorse the 1.1-point figure, saying that the matter needed more study.

HEADLINE: U.S. Negotiating Information Technology Pact

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Dec. 8

 BODY:
United States officials pushed to negotiate final language for a global pact today that would eliminate tariffs on information technology, an accord that they hoped would be the crowning achievement of the World Trade Organization's first high-level meeting this week.
American and European Union officials met on the eve of the five-day trade meeting to thrash out differences that remain on the Information Technology Agreement, which would eliminate tariffs on a wide range of computer and telecommunications technology by the year 2000. 
 "We are making some very important progress," the acting United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, said. But she declined to say whether a deal is near.
Officials on both sides said that a series of discussions would be held this week in hopes of reaching a deal. Trade officials from 128 nations are to meet here beginning Monday.
 [In Singapore Monday, officials of the European Union accused American companies including Corning Inc. and the Xerox Corporation of hampering the information technology trade agreement by seeking exemptions for their products, Bloomberg Business News reported.]
Ms. Barshefsky expressed concern about Europe's commitment to the agreement. She said that there were indications the Europeans felt completion of the agreement hinged upon an acceptable final declaration by the W.T.O. ministers at the end of this week's meeting. She said she saw no linkage between the agreement and the W.T.O. declaration.
United States negotiators say that they want a broad agreement covering a wide range of products, estimated to be worth up to $1 trillion a year in world trade.
But they want to exclude fiber optics, graphic display tubes, photocopiers and capacitors -- components used in electronic goods. The Europeans have balked at those exclusions, but feel a deal can be done.
"We both hope this is going to be a really concrete thing, a nugget, if not finally agreed, then laid out to be agreed later," said a European Union official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

HEADLINE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
A Rematch in New Orleans; An Alliance Snub for B.Y.U.

BYLINE: By MALCOLM MORAN 

 BODY:
His team had won a conference championship game on Saturday, Brigham Young University's 13th victory in a season that was soon to become a bitter disappointment. Yesterday, LaVell Edwards sat in a control room at CBS, listening to other coaches talking about the major bowl bids. When the official announcements were complete and the six spots in the bowl alliance had been filled without B.Y.U., Edwards removed the microphone he had worn just in case, flipped it on a console and leaned back in a chair.
And as representatives from other schools accepted congratulations, Edwards listened to condolences for a 13-1 season. 
 "It's just obvious that rankings don't mean anything," Edwards said after 10-2 Penn State and 10-2 Nebraska, teams ranked beneath B.Y.U. in the two polls used by alliance officials, had received the two available at-large bids and B.Y.U. was left with a berth in the less prestigious Cotton Bowl against 9-2 Kansas State.
"What criteria they set up, obviously they can still go ahead and do what they think is right, which is fine," Edwards said. "But obviously you're very disappointed. It's very tough when you're in the Western Athletic Conference, I guess. We're not part of the alliance. It's pretty tough to crash the party."
Actually, there were no surprises yesterday when the Sugar, Fiesta and Orange Bowls formalized their picks, just an increasing frustration that extended beyond Edwards.
The Sugar Bowl, the game that alliance officials had hoped would match the No. 1 and No. 2 teams, produced a rematch between Florida State and Florida that did not reach the stated goal.
The Seminoles and the Gators were the two top-ranked teams when they met on Nov. 30. Florida State moved into the No. 1 position after narrowly defeating Florida, while the Gators are currently in the No. 3 position behind undefeated Arizona State, which will play Ohio State in the Rose Bowl.
As a result, for the second time in three years the two major undefeated teams in the country will not meet on the field to decide the national championship. In 1994, Penn State went unbeaten right through the Rose Bowl but lost out to Nebraska in the polls. Now the same fate almost certainly awaits Arizona State if it wins the Rose Bowl on Jan. 1 only to see Florida State beat Florida, again, the next night in New Orleans.
Two seasons from now, when the Big Ten, Pacific-10 and Rose Bowl join the alliance, a Florida State-Arizona State game would become a possibility. But that's then. The Cornhuskers, the two-time defending national champions, would have been Florida State's intriguing opponent in this year's Sugar Bowl had they not suffered a shocking loss to Texas in the inaugural Big 12 championship on Saturday. Still, the process was kinder to Nebraska than it was to B.Y.U. yesterday.
The Sugar, Orange and Fiesta Bowls, the three games currently included in the alliance, fill the six berths with champions of the Big East, Southeastern Conference, Atlantic Coast Conference, Big 12, and two at-large teams. The Sugar Bowl, picking first and second, took Florida and Florida State.
The Fiesta Bowl, choosing third, picked Penn State. The Orange Bowl used the fourth pick to take Nebraska. The Fiesta then chose 8-4 Texas, leaving Virginia Tech of the Big East to face the Cornhuskers in Miami.
In the New York Times computer ranking, Nebraska's loss to Texas dropped the Cornhuskers from first to fourth, still ahead of B.Y.U. (7) as well as Penn State (10). But in the Associated Press media poll and the CNN/USA Today poll of coaches, B.Y.U. was ranked fifth, ahead of Nebraska (6) and Penn State (7).
Texas, which earned the Big 12 bid with its victory, was 16th in the Times's ranking and 20th in the two polls. The complexity, and questionable credibility, of the bowl selection process can also be found in the fact that Notre Dame, which is not even going to a bowl in an 8-3 season with two overtime defeats, is ahead of Texas by all three measures -- 13th in the Times's ranking and 18th in each of the two polls -- and defeated the Longhorns at Austin on Sept. 21.
Roy Kramer, the commissioner of the Southeastern Conference and the coordinator of the alliance, said that rankings are the major determination only in the attempt to create a championship game. "The rest of it," Kramer said, "is a continuation of the bowl process as we know it."
John Junker, the executive director of the Fiesta Bowl, said its choice of Penn State was based on the need to have what he called an anchor team to build a marketing effort around.
"The anchor team is the team that simply does the most for you all up and down the board," Junker said. "TV ratings. Fans. Tradition. Attention. Marquee value of players or coaches. It's whoever addresses the most needs that you have. And we looked and looked and looked, and worked very hard on it.
"We seriously considered Brigham Young. They have a fine program, fine team, tremendous coach.
"We made that pick of Penn State not knowing what other bowls would do. We didn't have discussions as to would they take this or that. We made that pick based on our anchor to fill our most needs. When the Orange Bowl selected Nebraska they closed the door to other at-large teams."
The snubbing of B.Y.U. had been anticipated by the presidents of the W.A.C. schools. Rondo Fehlberg, B.Y.U.'s athletic director, said last night that the presidents held a conference call last week in which they decided they would not initiate legal action against the alliance during the current bowl season but might consider it as an option at a future date. As it stands, B.Y.U. will be going to its first-ever Jan. 1 bowl.
Edwards, meanwhile, said he was not involved in any discussions with alliance officials. But when asked for a possible explanation for his team's absence from an $8.486 million game (the Cotton Bowl has a projected payout of $2 million), the coach brought up the perception that B.Y.U.'s Mormon fans would spend less than other fans.
"I don't know," Edwards said quietly. "I guess the image thing. I don't know."
Keith Tribble, the executive director of the Orange Bowl, laughed quietly when the issue was raised in a conference call. "That was not something that was on our priority list," he said when asked about the economic issue.
"We've got a great following," Edwards said. "We'd bring a great crowd. But . . ."
He did not finish the sentence. Arrangements were being made, and someone else's trips to an alliance bowl were taking shape.

It will be the first appearance of a Pacific-10 team in the Holiday Bowl since 1985, when Arizona State lost to Arkansas, 18-17.

HEADLINE: Microsoft Plans 300% Increase in Spending for Basic Research in 1997

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: REDMOND, Wash., Dec. 8

 BODY:
Defying a trend away from unfettered corporate scientific research, the Microsoft Corporation plans to increase spending for basic research by 300 percent in 1997.
The increase, which will create the world's largest computer science laboratory within the next two years, comes at a time when other computer research giants notably Bell Laboratories, are generally cutting back on fundamental research and focusing more on practical, product-oriented projects. 
 Microsoft is making the basic research investment, which could run as high as $330 million during the next five years, at least in part to make a symbolic statement about its executives' concern about changing national scientific research priorities.
The executives view as short-sighted moves to shrink corporate research budgets and to aim Government financing at projects that offer an immediate payoff.
"I think this is a disastrous mistake," Nathan Myhrvold, the company's chief technology officer, said in an interview over the weekend. "We disagree with many of these national trends and we're putting our money where our mouth is."
Microsoft, which is based here, is a relative latecomer to basic scientific research. Although it is the world's largest software company and it now spends $1.4 billion annually on research and development activities, the company set up Microsoft Research only five years ago to pursue general computer science problems.
But the organization, which now has 170 scientists, has been rapidly gaining credibility within the industry as Microsoft has hired some leading researchers. Well-known scientists who have joined Microsoft recently include two leading computer designers, Gordon Bell and Butler Lampson, as well as some of the nation's best-known computer graphics researchers, Jim Blinn, Jim Kajiya and Alvy Ray Smith.
Microsoft Research now has a dozen research groups focusing on areas ranging from speech technology to computer vision and decision theory.
Mr. Myhrvold said he planned to increase rapidly the number of scientists working at the laboratory to 450 or 500 and to broaden the group's research focus.
"It makes sense for us to do stuff that is quite far out," he said. Microsoft will now begin financing work in which there are few obvious immediate paybacks, a decision that runs counter to the national trend.
At Bell Labs, for example, scientists say that a fundamental shift has occurred toward more applied research and away from fundamental research. Bell Labs is part of Lucent Technologies, the spinoff from the AT&T Corporation.
On the Federal level, financing for basic research has grown only marginally through the 1995 fiscal year, and, after accounting for inflation, it has essentially stagnated, according to figures from the National Science Foundation. And Mr. Myhrvold said the Government and corporate researchers faced rising restrictions on their work in an era of tighter budgets and stiffer competition.
Arguing against this trend, he pointed to the benefits that flowed from the Pentagon's Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, which, beginning in the 1960's, permitted researchers wide latitude to pursue their interests.
In particular, he said that Microsoft would now begin research efforts aimed at fundamentally reinventing entire components of the computer industry.
He cited work that was begun at Xerox's Palo Alto Research Center in the early 1970's as a model of the kind of risk that corporations should be willing to take and criticized those who have said that the Xerox effort was a failure because the copier maker stumbled in its effort to break into the computer industry.
Xerox spent a decade developing technologies like desktop personal computers, advanced computer interfaces and office networks in an era when computers were large devices shared by entire organizations.
"People forget that Xerox also invented the laser printer" at the Palo Alto center, he said.
By extending the research vision of the company outward on projects that might not have an impact for a decade or even longer, Mr. Myhrvold acknowledged, the payoff might actually go to other companies besides Microsoft.
"Some of our good ideas will be stolen, but we will learn in the process," he said.
Mr. Myhrvold said that he was opposed to the view that only incremental changes could occur as a result of working in areas that were not directly linked to products. "I believe in revolutionary research," he said.
The decision to increase basic research spending, which has actually lagged behind Microsoft's overall growth in recent years, was made over the last several months in discussions between Mr. Myhrvold and William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman and founder.
A number of the software giant's competitors said they applauded the decision to increase spending and said it would have a positive impact both inside and outside the computer industry. The real challenge Microsoft will face, they said, is getting its divisions to accept innovations that might threaten vested interests and established product lines.
"The real trouble with doing radical research is to get it accepted in your organization," John Seeley Brown, director of Xerox's Palo Alto Research Center, said. "If you have to wait for the chairman to support something, it's a fundamental restraint."
Mr. Myhrvold, however, insists that the increase in spending will be beneficial. A 37-year-old physicist who once studied with the cosmologist Stephen Hawking, Mr. Myhrvold is a good representative of the more wide open research style he said he wanted Microsoft to foster. He said he had recently developed an interest in paleontology and had written a research paper focusing on the mating rituals of sauropods, giant dinosuars.
By examining fossil evidence and creating a computer simulation, he said, he was able to discover that male sauropods used their tails as whips, accelerating the tip of the tail to speeds exceeding the speed of sound. The resulting sonic boom would have been several hundred decibels, he said, and would have been heard for miles.
How this fact would be related to the giant dinosaurs' mating habits -- or to the future of computing -- is not clear. Which, basically, is the point. 

CORRECTION-DATE: December 12, 1996, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Monday about plans by the Microsoft Corporation to increase spending for basic research misstated the extent of the planned expansion. It will not create the world's largest computer science laboratory; I.B.M., with 1,100 people working on basic research, has the largest one.

HEADLINE: Are the French Determined to Oppose U.S.?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "The Price of Dumping Boutros-Ghali" (Op-Ed, Dec. 3), William Shawcross expressed the view that the manner in which the United States opposed the reappointment of Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali of the United Nations made it "inevitable" that the world would react against it. But, he said, it was "less predictable" that "the French would so gleefully and irresponsibly use the issue to embarrass the United States."
French attempts to embarrass the United States are not that unpredictable. For France, opposing the United States seems to be an almost knee-jerk reaction. 
 When I headed the United States delegation to negotiations on a treaty on terrorism on the high seas, proposed by Austria, Egypt and Italy after the seizure of the cruise ship Achille Lauro in 1985, I suggested adding the state of nationality of the victim to the two bases of jurisdiction already in the draft (the state of nationality of the offender and the flag state).
I explained that even though nationality of the victim was not widely accepted as a basis of jurisdiction, insofar as terrorist offenses were concerned, the state of nationality of the offender often encouraged or at least condoned the act, and the flag state, given the wide use of flags of convenience, might be a small state, unable or unwilling to prosecute for economic or political reasons. But the state of nationality of the victim had a strong interest in prosecuting because the victim in terrorist acts was often picked because he was a national of that state. I argued that since United States nationals had been killed in terrorist attacks precisely because they were Americans, the United States considered it important to include nationality of the victim as a basis of jurisdiction.
My suggestion was rejected by the French delegate with the sarcastic comment: "You Americans want to control the world. Just because an American is killed, you want the right to try the offender."
Fortunately, I remembered that I had seen in the casebook I used to teach international law a note that France had adopted a law several years earlier giving French courts jurisdiction to try anyone who killed a Frenchman anywhere, far broader than the jurisdiction limited to terrorism that I was suggesting.
After I handed him a copy of that law the following day, he withdrew his objection to the inclusion of jurisdiction based on the victim's nationality.
 
MALVINA HALBERSTAM
New York, Dec. 5, 1996
 
The writer is a professor of international law at Yeshiva University.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Registers a Recovery, Along With the Stock Market

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose yesterday against the Japanese yen and the German mark, recovering along with American stocks as traders concluded that the selloff on Friday was overdone.
The climb by the dollar put it ahead of levels reached before Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, made remarks on Thursday night questioning whether central bankers should be concerned about the dizzying height that stock prices have reached. 
 The Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, on Sunday played down Mr. Greenspan's statements, which some had taken as a sign that the central bank might raise interest rates to squeeze out speculation from stock markets. Yesterday, traders were nudged further away from Friday's frantic selling by comments from British and German central bankers, who suggested that the markets had overreacted.
"It was a one-day knee jerk," said Tom Benfer, director of foreign exchange in the New York office of the Bank of Montreal. "There's not a chance the Fed will raise rates to take the air out of the stock market."
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 113.51 Japanese yen, up from 112.89 late on Friday. The dollar was changing hands at 1.5575 German marks, up from 1.5463.
Both Eddie George, governor of the Bank of England, and Hans Tietmeyer, president of the German Bundesbank, said in Basel, Switzerland, that markets had gone down too far Friday in response to Mr. Greenspan's speech. The two spoke before a meeting yesterday of central bankers.
In his speech, Mr. Greenspan questioned whether stock prices had run up too high, creating a speculative bubble.
"It took a couple days to digest his remarks; once digested, the market has reverted back to its bullish mode," Mr. Benfer said.
Analysts said the foreign exchange market was also moving back to its assumptions that European governments want the Continent's currencies to trade weaker against the dollar. Traders are coming to believe that European governments want a higher dollar to protect their exports as they near a monetary union.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Cheering predictions of increased and sustained growth.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
TWO forecasters are presenting holiday gifts to Madison Avenue: twin predictions of sustained -- as well as sustainable -- growth in advertising spending for 1997 and the rest of the decade.
Robert J. Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at McCann-Erickson U.S.A. in New York, and John Perriss, chairman of Zenith Media Worldwide in London, offered their tidings of comfort and joy at the opening session of the 24th annual Paine Webber Media Conference. The conference began yesterday morning in midtown Manhattan and continues through Friday. 
 "I don't think the recovery is going to end in just three years," said Mr. Coen of McCann, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, referring to the rebound in ad spending that began in 1993. "We've got some more to go."
And Mr. Perriss of Zenith, owned by Cordiant P.L.C., said: "Our outlook is a pretty positive one as well, I'm pleased to say. No one is signaling to us that there is any sudden, horrid slowdown, as we saw in the early 90's."
The optimistic attitudes of Mr. Coen and Mr. Perriss are significant because their forecasts, which they issue every June and December, are closely followed. Although Mr. Coen's predictions tend to be a tad rosier than Mr. Perriss's, both executives agreed yesterday that marketers were preparing to increase their ad budgets, in part because of what Mr. Perriss described as growing consumer confidence.
The predictions are also notable because they assert that ad spending will continue to grow, albeit at a slower pace, after the special stimuli from spending connected with the Summer Olympics in Atlanta and the Presidential and Congressional elections. Mr. Coen estimated those one-time gains were at least $1.5 billion.
Mr. Coen predicted that advertisers would spend a record $182.9 billion in the United States next year. That would mean an increase of 5.6 percent from the $173.2 billion that he now sees for 1996. The 1996 figure is a 7.6 percent gain from the $160.9 billion that was spent in 1995.
Fueling those increases, Mr. Coen said, are double-digit percentage gains in ad spending categories like drugs, brokerage firms and mutual funds, computers, banks and other financial institutions, and cigarettes.
Among the national media that are in line for strong gains in 1997 ad revenue, Mr. Coen said, are cable and syndicated television, Yellow Pages directories and magazines.
Mr. Coen's 1996 figure of $173.2 billion has been adjusted slightly upward from a forecast of $172.8 billion he made in June. Mr. Coen, who has been tracking media and marketing trends since 1948, often revises his figures from one presentation to the next, based on additional economic or spending data.
Mr. Coen's prediction that domestic ad spending in 1997 will total $182.9 billion has also been adjusted, dropping slightly from an initial estimate of $183 billion in June.
On the overseas ad-spending front, Mr. Coen forecast $230.9 billion for 1997, up 6.1 percent from a revised figure of $217.6 billion for 1996. He cited robust ad-spending plans in countries like China, the Czech Republic, Mexico, Poland and Thailand. (That overseas figure is also revised; in June he predicted a total of $229 billion for 1997.)
Mr. Coen's worldwide total for 1997, then, is $413.8 billion. That would represent a gain of 5.9 percent from a revised worldwide total for 1996 of $390.8 billion. If his forecast holds, it will be the first time that worldwide ad spending tops $400 billion.
Mr. Perriss, who was fighting the flu, focused his presentation on ad spending in major media like television, print, radio and outdoor. Thus, his spending totals are different from Mr. Coen's.
For 1997, ad spending in North American major media will total $110.3 billion, Mr. Perriss said, an increase of 4.6 percent from the $105.4 billion that he expects for 1996. For 1998, he projected a total of $115.2 billion, up 4.5 percent from his 1997 forecast. And for 1999, he projected a total of $120 billion, an increase of 4.2 percent from 1998.
While 1996 is likely to mark the high point of growth in percentage terms, Mr. Perriss said, the annual growth-rate forecasts for the rest of the decade have been raised about five-tenths of 1 percent above previous estimates "in the light of steady economic fundamentals and rising consumption," particularly in the United States.
As for overseas ad spending, Mr. Perriss projected that $201.4 billion would be spent in major media in 1997, an increase of 8.2 percent from the $186.1 billion that he expects for 1996. The booming ad-spending markets next year, he said, will include China, Indonesia and the Philippines.
For 1998, his forecast was for $218.2 billion, up 8.3 percent from 1997. And for 1999, his figures call for spending of $237.9 billion, a gain of 9 percent from 1998.
Mr. Perriss's worldwide total for 1997, then, is $311.7 billion, an increase of 6.9 percent from $291.5 billion for 1996. His 1998 worldwide total is $333.4 billion, up 7 percent from 1997. And his worldwide total for 1999 is $357.9 billion, a gain of 7.4 percent from 1998.
A third prediction for ad spending in the United States next year -- from the Myers Report advertising newsletter, published by Myers Group L.L.C. in Parsippany, N.J. -- projects an increase of 7.8 percent.
That forecast was tempered, however, by a prediction that ad spending would begin to fall in the fourth quarter of 1997, which may be the beginning "of a pronounced and potentially long-term downturn."

HEADLINE: Casual Remarks? Hardly, Mr. Greenspan

BYLINE: By Gary Krist; Gary Krist is the author of two collections of short stories, "The Garden State" and "Bone by Bone."

DATELINE: CHEVY CHASE, Md.

 BODY:
World markets roiled last week after a few offhand remarks by Alan Greenspan, reminding us of a simple but undeniable fact: namely, that when the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board speaks, the markets listen. Major institutional investors have learned to read the subtext behind his most innocuous-seeming comments and to respond accordingly. But until now the small investor has just had to endure the resulting market turmoil without a clue.
Here, then, as a public service, is a listener's guide to Mr. Greenspan's next speech. Listen carefully, because the chairman always means a lot more than he actually says.
 "Good evening." 
 A clear sell signal. By characterizing the evening as "good," the chairman is immediately indicating his belief that because the economy is doing well (perhaps too well), rising consumer demand and its resulting upward pressure on prices will probably force the Fed to nudge interest rates higher in the near future.
"Thank for you that most flattering introduction, which I will certainly try to live up to."
Ambiguous, but probably a buy signal. By trying "to live up to" a "flattering" characterization of himself, the chairman is hinting that he plans to act in a way that will endear him to the markets -- that is, refrain from any immediate tightening of credit, allowing businesses to borrow more easily and cheaply.
"I'd like to thank the hard-working people who planned this event and made it run so smoothly."
Bearish for stocks. Indicative of a pro-labor shift in stance on the Fed's part. The resulting upward pressure on labor costs (larger raises, increased benefits, etc.) could cut into corporate earnings and decrease stock dividends.
"There are too many people to thank individually, but you know who you are."
Definitely bullish for stocks and bonds. A sign that the labor market has grown to its upper limit ("too many people to thank"). Multi-industry downsizing and higher unemployment lie ahead, producing a downward pressure on prices and wages, allowing the Fed to lower interest rates without fear of igniting inflation.
"I promise not to go on too long, since everyone is eager to sit back and enjoy this wonderful-looking dessert."
Buy bonds, sell stocks. This comment indicates an awareness that the public's priorities may be changing. Small investors and institutions alike may be tired of Fed-watching and the bull market's roller-coaster ride, and may soon turn to more conservative investments like bonds.
"These are interesting times for the U.S. economy."
Sell domestic equities, buy foreign equities and bonds. By drawing attention to the "interesting" character of our economy (vis-a-vis, by implication, other economies), Mr. Greenspan is hinting that the domestic economy is in danger of overheating in the near future, forcing the Fed to tighten credit. Higher interest rates would strengthen the dollar, making foreign goods cheaper for Americans to buy and providing a boon to foreign manufacturers -- and, by extension, to foreign equity prices.
"But I've learned that it is best for the Fed chairman to say as little as possible on this or any other topic."
A strong bearish indication for all types of investment. Mr. Greenspan is telegraphing an acute dissatisfaction with the volatility of world markets. Begin a gradual but systematic selling of stocks and bonds.
"So let me conclude by expressing my gratitude to you for being here tonight."
Translation: All good things must come to an end. Convert all holdings to gold and other precious metals. Consider early liquidation of all I.R.A.'s and 401(k)'s.
"Thank you, good night and happy new year to you all."
Sell! Sell! Sell! Hoard gasoline and canned goods. Head to the storm cellar and lock the door behind you.

HEADLINE: The Split on Social Security

 BODY:
A Federal advisory panel on Social Security ended its deliberations without coming to agreement on a plan to shore up the system's financial future. Instead it will present three different plans, none with majority support. Fortunately, a good plan can be stitched together from the best parts of two of the three plans. But the lack of consensus probably will delay the date that Congress solves the entire Social Security problem.
The members did agree to invest Social Security taxes in stocks and other private securities, as well as the low-yield government bonds that are the only existing investment option. That change will make Social Security a better deal for workers. But the impact on the overall economy will be minor. The Social Security Trust Fund would substitute stocks for some of the bonds it used to buy from the Treasury. But the Treasury will then have to sell more of its bonds to private investors. The change is unlikely to affect how quickly the economy grows. 
 The commission faced two distinct Social Security problems. The system will be depleted by around 2030, which has scared millions of Americans into believing they will never collect their scheduled benefits. This problem is real, but relatively easy to fix. Congress needs to trim benefits, bring government workers into the system, gradually postpone retirement age or modestly raise taxes -- or combine all of these ideas. No radical reform is needed.
The second problem is subtle and not easily solved. By providing workers "ironclad" retirement benefits, Social Security relieves the need for them to save for themselves. Many economists argue that Social Security has thereby driven down national savings. Over decades, smaller savings leads to less investment and lower living standards. When the baby boomers retire early next century, they will continue to buy food, clothing and shelter, but the money will come from taxpayers. If living standards are high, taxpayers will not mind. But if living standards are low, the tax transfer will hurt.
The panel split three ways on how to fix these problems. One group proposes a needlessly radical privatization. Workers would in effect deposit a substantial part of their payroll tax into a private investment account and buy securities of their own choosing. This would expose individuals to considerable risk of bad investment decisions and be hugely expensive to administer, because millions of workers would be making investment decisions. Worse, it would probably eviscerate over time the system's capacity to disproportionately benefit low-wage workers, a feature that has been America's best anti-poverty weapon since the 1930's.
The panel's two other plans provide better guidance. One group anticipates investing payroll taxes in stocks, but the investment decisions would be made by a government agency completely insulated from politics. The third group would impose a small additional payroll tax, which would boost national savings and the future health of the economy.
Passive investment of Social Security revenues in stocks would make the system look much better to the workers, and taxpayers, whose political support is crucial for the system's survival. Boosting payroll taxes as a way to boost savings also makes sense, as long as precautions are taken to make sure the overall system protects low-wage workers.
The commission's inability to reach consensus makes it likely that Congress will tinker and solve the bankruptcy threat, but not address the more subtle economic threat.

HEADLINE: Monsanto Chooses a Spinoff Of Its Chemical Operations

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 9

 BODY:
The Monsanto Company, which announced in October that it was considering shedding its $3 billion chemicals business, said today that it would spin the unit off to Monsanto's shareholders and in the process cut up to 2,500 jobs, 9 percent of the company's work force.
Monsanto, which is based in St. Louis, said it also expected to take a one-time after-tax charge of $400 million to $600 million to cover severance payments, write-offs of equipment and other assets and the shutdown of some offices or manufacturing operations. Although Monsanto is not counting on receiving all necessary Government approvals quickly enough to complete the spinoff before the end of next year, it is moving immediately to operate as two separate companies, and it plans to notify employees of their job status by the end of March. 
 Monsanto said that Robert G. Potter, the executive vice president who runs the chemical business, would be the chemical unit's chairman and chief executive after the spinoff.
"We haven't made any decision on which company will keep the Monsanto name," Robert B. Shapiro, Monsanto's chairman and chief executive, said.
The spinoff, which is expected to be tax-free, had been seen by Wall Street as a likely strategic move for Monsanto even before the company confirmed two months ago that it planned to concentrate on its faster-growing agricultural, nutrition and health businesses.
The more mature chemicals business makes products like plastics used in auto windshields, flame retardants and synthetic fibers for carpet. It is solidly profitable, having produced operating income of $242 million on sales of $2.28 billion in the first nine months of this year. But strong growth is unlikely without heavy capital investments, and the sector is far more subject to swings in the economy than Monsanto's other businesses. Thus, the chemical business tends to attract a different type of investor than other parts of the company.
"The spinoff makes perfect sense," said William R. Young, who follows Monsanto for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York.
Monsanto's agriculture portfolio includes Roundup, the world's best-selling herbicide, as well as pioneering biotechnology products that include crops genetically altered to produce their own pesticides and manufactured hormones that raise a cow's milk production. The food ingredients business includes Nutrasweet, the world's leading artificial sweetener, and G. D. Searle, Monsanto's drug subsidiary, is strong in several niches, including insomnia and arthritis drugs.
The three "life sciences" businesses together had operating earnings of just over $1 billion on sales of $4.78 billion in the first nine months of the year. But Monsanto's decision to concentrate on them is not attributable entirely to the better record in recent years of these businesses. Monsanto sees the science and technology underlying all three converging in areas like genetic engineering, which could open up tremendous opportunities to redesign crops to produce more nutritious foods and drugs.
"Integrating these areas provides several trillion dollars worth of market opportunity," Mr. Shapiro said.
Wall Street has been enamored of Monsanto's progress toward that vision for some time. Monsanto's stock jumped 74 percent last year and has risen nearly as much this year. "Monsanto is moving into a class all its own in terms of business focus," said Sano Shimoda of Bioscience Securities Inc., a San Francisco brokerage firm. "They could be the monster on the block in agricultural biotechnology."
But other big competitors are moving the same direction, including Novartis, the Swiss giant being formed by the merger of Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz; Agrevo, which is a joint venture of Hoechst and Schering A.G., ; Dow-Elanco, which is a joint venture of Dow Chemical and Eli Lilly, and E.I. duPont de Nemours & Company.
Monsanto also faces a challenge in expanding the food ingredient business. Nutrasweet has maintained its leadership of the artificial sweetener market since coming off patent, but its profit margins have tumbled, and several new products are beginning to compete for parts of its market. And while Searle is no longer regarded as an underperformer in the pharmaceutical world, its $600 million research budget is still "second tier," Mr. Shapiro conceded.
"There will be a continued drive toward consolidation in that business," Mr. Shapiro said. "Everyone is in more or less in a permanent state of negotiations."
Monsanto's announcement today of its specific plan did not excite Wall Street as much as its original disclosure of its intentions in October. Monsanto's shares drifted down 75 cents in heavy trading on the Big Board today, ending at $40.50. After the October announcement, they gained 50 cents, to $41.125.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices End Higher In Calm Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended higher yesterday, bolstered by buying overseas and by expectations that the Federal Reserve would keep interest rates steady.
Yesterday's calm gains stood in stark contrast to trading on Friday, when comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, sent bond and stock markets around the world into a tailspin. Mr. Greenspan's comments were taken to mean that he thought American stock prices were overvalued, which would build a case for an increase in short-term interest rates. But the bond market on Friday was reassured by a weak November employment report, and continued its recovery yesterday. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond ended up 20/32, to 100 17/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.46 percent, from 6.51 percent on Friday.
The volatility of last week faded yesterday. Some traders said an article in The Washington Post on Sunday furthered the market's sense of Mr. Greenspan's comments. The article interpreted Mr. Greenspan's comments as a warning of excesses in the stock market, and said that they were not a signal that he was prepared to raise interest rates.
Carroll J. Delaney, director of research at Stires, O'Donnell & Company, said, "The question that seemed to ripple throughout all financial markets on Friday and the debate that will ensue this week is, just what was Mr. Greenspan saying or trying to do, anyway?"
The most logical reason, he said, seems to be that Mr. Greenspan is "essentially trying to keep all his options open as the U.S. economy moves forward into 1997."
Although the market faces some key numbers this week, the volume of trading is expected to remain light into the inflation data this week. Trading will be cautious and many market participants are merely content to take the profits made over the last couple of weeks, especially with so much uncertainty swirling.
Tomorrow brings the November producer price report, and estimates are currently running at a two-tenths of 1 percent rise for the overall and core rates. This report will be followed by Thursday's twin barrage of November consumer prices and retail sales.
Interest rates at yesterday's weekly Treasury bill auction were down, and while the results were decent, traders said they were not as strong as last week's. The average discount rate at auction for a three-month bill was 4.83 percent, down from 4.98 percent at the last auction, with the average rate for a six-month bill at 4.97 percent, down from 5.04 percent. HEADLINE: Hospitals Looking Abroad To Keep Their Beds Filled

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Not long ago, most foreign patients at the New England Medical Center were wealthy Europeans and Latin Americans. But now a patient from overseas is more likely to be someone like Gladys Soto Pilone, a 62-year-old retired schoolteacher, whose health plan in Argentina agreed to pay for breast cancer surgery in Boston last summer.
Reaching beyond their longstanding international clientele of royal potentates, celebrities and wealthy people, top-drawer medical centers including the Mayo Clinic, the Texas Heart Institute, the Cleveland Clinic and New England Medical are helping to fill their beds and pay their bills by wooing groups of less affluent foreign patients. 
 In a breakthrough deal this fall, an Argentine labor union with 1.5 million members agreed to send patients with complicated problems to New England Medical. The first beneficiary, a 58-year-old shop clerk from Buenos Aires, is now scheduled for a kidney transplant at the Boston hospital.
Famous medical centers still welcome heads of state from time to time, of course. Sheik Zayed bin Sultan al-Nahayan, president of the United Arab Emirates, checked into the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., for neck surgery in September. He brought an entourage of 140 people and stayed five weeks.
Still, a push for more foreign patients has led hundreds of research and teaching institutions to create package deals and offer other inducements to attract private and government health plans in Latin America and the Middle East, as well as a small but growing number of patients from the Pacific Rim.
The hospitals are looking abroad because of changes sweeping through the medical establishment at home. Already squeezed by managed care and reduced government payments, many are also having difficulty recruiting enough patients to support elaborate high-technology programs like harvesting stem cells for bone marrow transplants to strengthen cancer patients, said Dr. Jeffrey A. Gelfand, the physician in chief at New England Medical.
"We have a huge investment in people and facilities, while the rest of the world is hungry for American expertise," said Dr. James Thrall, a radiologist and chairman of the international committee at Massachusetts General Hospital, which has video "telemedicine" links with several Middle Eastern cities.
The competition to find foreign patients has become so heated that some Middle Eastern health officials have begun to bargain for better deals, playing one American hospital against another. European hospitals and a handful of new Asian medical centers also compete for international patients.
The economics of bringing foreigners to American doctors is attractive to both sides.
For hard-pressed hospital budgets, the rewards, measured in tens of millions of dollars, can be crucial. The average fee for an American patient at New England Medical is $8,000, Dr. Gelfand said. "The average for foreign patients, who usually come for much more serious problems, is $20,000 to $30,000," he said.
What is more, payments from foreign patients are still free, for the most part, from limitations imposed on many American patients by managed care organizations. There is no insurance company nurse, for example, telling the hospital how soon a patient must be discharged. But the hospitals say the quality of care given the foreign patients is no better or worse than that given American patients.
Profit margins on foreign patients average 25 percent to 30 percent in Houston hospitals, much higher than overall margins of about 8 percent, said Gui Leite-Ferraz, a hospital management consultant with Genesis Health Care International, a consulting firm based in Houston.
The trip can be a good value for the patients, too, even with the added expense of travel, which often involves a spouse.
"Many high-risk or very complex conditions can be treated even more cheaply in the United States than here," said Dr. Ruben A. Zito, a Buenos Aires cardiologist and former faculty member at Yale Medical School.
There are no official or even trade group statistics that monitor the flow of foreign patients, and until recently many hospitals were secretive about their international clientele, to avoid attracting notice from competitors.
But Mr. Leite-Ferraz, a former international relations executive at St. Luke's Episcopal Hospital in Houston, estimated that 60,000 foreign patients would be admitted to American hospitals this year, a 50 percent increase from five years ago. He said 350,000 more would come for outpatient treatments and consultations in doctors' offices.
Indeed, every important teaching hospital now has "some sort of international initiative," although the number of foreign patients varies widely, said David Rey, a managing partner at Andersen Consulting. Some hospitals promote programs for particular diseases, while others stress amenities like hotel accommodations, transportation, even tourism and shopping opportunities for patients and families.
Miami and New Orleans hospitals treat many South Americans, Houston is popular with Mexicans and Stanford University Hospital in California is a magnet for Asian patients.
As for promoting specialties, Johns Hopkins, for example, talks up ophthalmology, orthopedics and pediatric brain surgery, said John Hutchins, director of international services at the hospital in Baltimore. Hopkins increased its foreign patients twelvefold in two years, to 7,200, including a group of wounded soldiers from Ecuador airlifted from this year's border war with Peru.
The Cleveland Clinic expects more than 5,000 foreign patients this year, compared with 3,000 five years ago. Hoping to catch up, the University Hospitals of Cleveland recently invited medical attaches from embassies in Washington who often influence the health care choices of their compatriots, to a lecture on bone marrow transplantation.
Mayo expects 10,000 foreign patients this year, an 11 percent jump, at its centers in Rochester, Minn., Scottsdale, Ariz., and Jacksonville, Fla. The Mayo Foundation is negotiating with private insurance companies in Chile on a supplementary health plan that would provide sophisticated care at the three Mayo sites.
At New England Medical, 250 patients and $6 million to $8 million in revenues are expected to flow next year from the new arrangement with the Argentine labor union, which covers workers in retail businesses and was negotiated by Dr. Zito, the Buenos Aires cardiologist. The patients will go to Boston for such complicated procedures as bone marrow, heart, liver and lung transplants and the treatment of certain spinal cord conditions.
Under the agreement, the health plan books the flight to Boston. The hospital meets the patient at the airport and provides lodging for the patient and a spouse or companion.
St. Luke's Episcopal, one of nine Houston hospitals seeking foreign patients, has contracts with insurance companies throughout Latin America and a deal with the Caribbean island of Aruba to provide certain types of specialized care, Mr. Leite-Ferraz said. Foreign patients at St. Luke's generate "close to 20 percent of the total profit of the hospital," he added.
Also in Houston, Jose Nunez, executive director of international affairs at the Methodist Health Care System, said a number of Mexican insurance companies offer coverage for major medical expenses in the United States. "A male nonsmoker, 35 or 40 years old, probably could get one of these policies, with a high deductible -- as much as $5,000 -- for $2,000 to $2,500 a year," he said.
Miami Medical Centers USA, a health care company that deals with these and other internationally oriented insurance companies, channels patients to American hospitals that have agreed to accept discounted fees. Francisco Recio, director of international programs, said the company's business had quadrupled in the last three years, to 200 patients a month.
A growing number of American hospitals are using telemedicine consultations to diagnose the problems of overseas patients, who may decide to come to the United States for treatment. Massachusetts General, for example, has telemedicine links with Saudi Arabia, Jordan and Lebanon and plans to add Egypt, Kuwait and Russia. Dr. Thrall, the head of the international committee, said 1,500 international consultations over the last two years generated about 100 admissions for the hospital.
The Internet is another channel being mined for foreign patients. "Sophisticated patients are logging on and accessing the latest medical information," Dr. Thrall said. "Then they contact the doctor who is linked to that work."
For example, the World Wide Web site of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center was visited by 11,950 computer users in October, including about 1,200 people in foreign countries, many from Canada.
Indeed, Canadians may be the biggest foreign consumers of American medicine. According to a recent estimate in the Toronto-based Financial Post, they spend more than $1 billion a year on health care in the United States for services that are not available at home or that require long waiting periods. Health care companies in Florida and Arizona offer specially tailored coverage to Canadian "snow birds" who migrate south in cold weather.
Wherever they come from, though, the foreign patients are drawn here by the promise of America's high-tech medicine, experts say.
When Mrs. Soto Pilone in Buenos Aires learned that she had breast cancer, she took advantage of a telemedicine circuit to consult with two oncologists at New England Medical.
And when it became clear that she needed surgery, she quickly started packing for Boston. "Even though we have excellent doctors here in Buenos Aires," she said, "many hospitals lack the technological advances and resources that American hospitals have."
Mrs. Soto Pilone had her surgery on Aug. 26 and still keeps in touch with Boston, via the video link, to report on her progress.

HEADLINE: Computer Chip Sales Ratio Up

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: SAN JOSE, Calif., Dec. 9

 BODY:
The computer chip industry's book-to-bill ratio rose more than expected in November, to 1.15, from October's revised 1.11, the Semiconductor Industry Association said today.
October's ratio was revised up from a preliminary number of 1.10. The ratio measures demand in the North American market by comparing the value of chips ordered to the value of chips shipped. 
 A ratio of 1.15 means that for every $100 worth of chips shipped, manufacturers took in $115 in new orders. A ratio higher than 1.00 indicates that the market is growing. The ratio had been below 1.00 this year until October.
In April, the book-to-bill ratio fell to a 10-year low of 0.81.
Orders for November, based on a three-month rolling average, rose 6.2 percent, to $3.96 billion, from $3.73 billion in October. Shipments rose 3 percent, to $3.44 billion, from $3.34 billion in October.
The Semiconductor Industry Association has said it will discontinue reporting the book-to-bill ratio after the report for December is released in January. The ratio will be replaced with a global one.

HEADLINE: Stock Prices Surge, Led by Technology Issues

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks continued a recovery yesterday from Friday's selloff in a rally led by technology issues.
The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 82 points yesterday, to 6,463.94, and the technology-rich Nasdaq composite index jumped to a record high with its second-biggest point gain ever. 
 The day's gains more than made up for the damage remaining from Friday's plunge on fears that Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, was threatening to raise interest rates to temper the market's enthusiasm.
"What a difference a weekend makes," said Russ Labrasca, senior vice president at Principal Financial Securities of Dallas. "Everyone has had time to digest Greenspan's comments and realize that it was a word of caution, but not of an impending apocalypse."
Foreign stock markets sold off early Friday and bond prices slid, sending interest rates higher, after Mr. Greenspan gave a speech Thursday night that alluded to the inflationary potential of an "irrational exuberance" in the markets. The remarks were initially construed as hinting at a Fed rate increase.
Stocks in the United States slid at Friday morning's open, but quickly began a recovery as the latest employment data allayed fears the economy may accelerate at an inflationary pace. The Dow tumbled 145 points in the first half hour, but closed with a loss of 55.16 points. Rapid inflation would make fixed-income investments like bonds less attractive, and higher interest rates can hurt stocks by slowing consumer spending and raising corporate borrowing costs.
The strong finish Friday set a positive tone for yesterday's open, and traders quickly scoured the market for any remaining bargains.
Computer-related shares led the day's advance amid optimism the holiday selling season has been going well for the sector.
"One of the great toys of this Christmas will be computers," Mr. Labrasca said, noting that most of the latest software requires more powerful machines to operate effectively.
I.B.M. rose 4 3/8, to 160 as the Dow's second-strongest issue after Philip Morris, which jumped 5 1/8 to 115 1/2 after Goldman Sachs reportedly raised its assessment of the consumer products giant. Together, the two companies accounted for a gain of more than 27 Dow points.
Allied Signal rose 7/8, to 69 7/8, after the company announced plans to buy back up to 50 million more of its shares in addition to the 150 million shares approved for repurchase since 1985.
American depository receipts of British Airways rose 3 7/8, to 99 1/4 trading on signs that Britain would approve an alliance with American Airlines. AMR, the parent of American Airlines added 2 1/4, to 91 3/4.
 Centennial Technologies rallied 5, to 46 1/4 on news that it acquired a 12 percent stake in Via Inc. for undisclosed terms. Via is a privately held technology company that makes miniature communication and computing products.
 Among the Nasdaq's technology bellwethers, Microsoft rose 5 1/4, to 81 3/4 in its first session after a 2-for-1 stock split; Intel rose 4 7/16, to 130 1/8; and Dell Computer rose 3 3/4, to 60 1/2, also after a 2-for-1 split.
Smaller-company shares also resumed their recent resurgence. The Russell 2000 list of smaller companies jumped 4.99, to 360.49, finally creeping back within reach of its May 22 high of 364.61. Smaller stocks have lagged a blue-chip rebound from a sharp summer selloff.

HEADLINE: Serb Leader's Foes Persist, Hoping He Will Blink First

BYLINE: By CHRIS HEDGES 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Dec. 9

 BODY:
The Serbian opposition, smarting from the latest refusal by Government courts to overturn the annulment of local elections, came out today 100,000 strong to begin the third week of protests.
But the opposition, which has called on factory workers to join the movement, has been unable to organize strikes that would increase the pressure on the Government of President Slobodan Milosevic. And the protests, while continuing to draw large crowds in Belgrade and other cities, appears stuck at a plateau. Opposition leaders from the coalition called Zajedno said they would boycott the first session of the newly elected lower house of Parliament on Tuesday. 
 "We have shown the world that we will persist," the opposition leader, Zoran Djindjic, told the crowd gathered in Republic Square today.
"The reasons Serbs in their history have lost battles, from Kosovo until Nov. 17 of this year, is because our opponents waited until they could crush us while we slept," Mr. Djindjic declared, referring to the date of the disputed elections. "Can we play this last game until the end? Milosevic is waiting for us to lose patience, to give up. He is waiting for us to begin breaking windows so he can send the police and the military into the streets. Each day we persist is one more day for us and one less day for him."
While the United States and its Western allies have expressed disapproval of Mr. Milosevic's actions, saying they will retain the option to reimpose economic sanctions, most diplomats said that, barring a violent Government crackdown, such an action was unlikely.
Sanctions against Yugoslavia were imposed during the war, but most were suspended after Mr. Milosevic signed the Dayton peace accord on behalf of the Bosnian Serbs. Some sanctions, barring international bank loans to Serbia and freezing assets from the old Yugoslavia, remain in place.
The Serbian Supreme Court this weekend ruled against opposition parties, which have accused the authorities of vote-rigging, closing an opportunity for compromise.
Mr. Djindjic called on his followers to telephone friends and family outside the capital, where Government-run news outlets have blocked information about the anti-Government protests. A protest meeting by workers at a factory here today failed to muster more than a couple of dozen dispirited employees who did not, as planned, march outside the plant. The leaders of the protest said they were not allied with the political opposition and were demanding back pay and better working conditions.

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
It is sure to be a bittersweet moment for C. LOWELL HARRISS, 88, professor emeritus of economics at Columbia University, when he accepts the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science today. He is to receive the award in the name of his friend of 61 years, WILLIAM VICKREY, who died of a heart attack in October at 82, three days after learning that he had won the prize.
"We met when we were graduate students at Columbia in 1935," Professor Harriss said from Stockholm yesterday. 
 "We worked together in the United States Treasury during World War II, doing tax research, and then were both on the faculty of Columbia for many years," he said. "We saw each other every week or so."
Professor Harriss last saw his friend at a party given by the Columbia economics department on the day of the announcement. "I have never seen anyone more exuberant," he said. "He was at the top of the world and justifiably so."

HEADLINE: New Mastercard Is Aimed At Middle-Class Borrowers

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Responding to American Express's moves to lure middle-income credit card borrowers, Mastercard is introducing a travel-oriented card today aimed squarely at American Express's traditional base of people who pay their monthly bills in full.
The new World Mastercard will offer no pre-set spending limit, and lots of travel benefits. Unlike an American Express charge card, the World card will offer a credit line for those who want to pay their balances over time. The interest rate and fee are set by each bank that offers it. 
 Separately, both Mastercard and Visa have developed platinum credit cards, meant to be offered with no fee to customers who borrow large sums on their cards. These cards offer nothing more than a higher credit limit and an air of exclusivity to existing gold cards.
Mastercard said that its World card would be available from leading credit card issuers including Household International and Mellon Bank. General Motors will offer a version of the World Mastercard in conjunction with Household, which issues its very successful regular and gold credit cards.
The World Mastercard is meant to undercut moves by American Express's chairman, Harvey Golub, to have banks to offer its cards.
"This is going to make Harvey's suspenders pop," said Robert Wesley, a longtime American Express employee hired by Mastercard five months ago as senior vice president for product management and development. "Banks will have no reason to issue any other card." Mr. Wesley predicted that the World card would attract five million customers in the United States and two or three million in other countries.
American Express dismissed Mastercard's announcement as bluster. "During the past several years Visa and Mastercard have launched marketing programs that copy us only to have those services debut and disintegrate," Gail Wasserman of American Express said.
American Express has been sparring with Mastercard and Visa on several fronts. Most recently the two card associations sued to block the Advanta Corporation from issuing a credit card linked to American Express's frequent-flier program.
So far, Mastercard and Visa rules have prevented banks in the United States from offering American Express cards, but banks in several other countries have signed on. They see American Express cards as attractive for convenience users -- people who pay their bills in full and thus do not incur interest charges -- because they can charge higher fees to both card holders and merchants.
Mastercard has planned the World card so banks can profit from convenience users. The card will offer benefits like access to airline airport lounges and a telephone concierge service for making special travel and shopping arrangements, as well as a reward program that will allow users to earn trips on any airline with no blackout period. (Some cards with rewards tied to specific merchants, such as G.M., will not have the travel reward feature.)
Similarly, the card is meant to appeal to frequent travelers by allowing customers to spend more than their normal credit limits, provided they pay the overage at the end of the month.
"We want the kind of customer who takes the Concorde to London, stays in the best hotel, dines in the best restaurant and when he goes to Harrods to buy a gift for his wife doesn't worry that he has maxed his credit line," Mr. Wesley said.
Most important for the banks that issue the product, Mr. Wesley said that Mastercard was hoping to raise the fees charged merchants that are passed back to the card issuers, known as interchange, at least for travel and entertainment charges.
Industry experts said that Mastercard would have a difficult time raising the fees to merchants.
"I don't think this will work," Seamus McMahon, a consultant with First Manhattan Consulting Group, said. "The merchants will say to Mastercard, 'Prove to me that your card holders charge more, and then talk about raising the interchange. And without Amex's full interchange and annual fees, this is a harebrained thing for banks to do."
Mr. McMahon added that credit card companies underestimated the costs of serving convenience users. "People say there is no credit risk, but some of the biggest convenience users who have paid you back every month for 10 years are declaring bankruptcy with no notice," he said.
Platinum cards are also an attempt to appeal to heavy borrowers, who already have a wallet full of cards. MBNA and First USA offer a no-fee card that is in effect a cosmetic upgrade to their existing gold cards. Brittain Associates of Atlanta found in September that First USA and MBNA had already won nearly two million platinum customers.
Mastercard will introduce what it calls a platinum class card today. It offers a minimum credit line of $7,500, 24-hour customer service, and an optional travel reward program. The cards do not have to use the name platinum.
Visa recently adopted similar standards for platinum-type cards.

LENGTH: 1107 words

HEADLINE: Back in the Statehouse After 4 Decades Away

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: HUNTINGTON, W.Va., Dec. 6

 BODY:
In a campaign stressing clean government and mine safety, Cecil H. Underwood toted a stepladder around the state, using it as a metaphor for "reaching a higher level." He won almost 54 percent of the vote and, at 34, became the youngest person ever elected Governor of West Virginia.
That was in 1956. 
 Forty years later, Mr. Underwood was back on the stump this fall, but with a new prop: several feet of fiber-optic cable, a symbol, he said, of a solid economic future for West Virginia based on job opportunities from new technology.
This time he won 52 percent of the vote and, at 74, became the oldest person ever elected Governor of the state.
"I'm told that may be some kind of a record," Mr. Underwood said proudly of the four-decade interval between his first and second terms, talking with an interviewer as aides continued dismantling his campaign headquarters here in preparation for his return next month to Charleston, the state capital.
More than a political oddity, though, Mr. Underwood's victory last month stands as a vivid example of how voters leaped toward the safe center this year, embracing candidates who pledged progress along a moderate path regardless of party affiliation.
A lifelong Republican, Mr. Underwood defeated his 47-year-old Democratic opponent, Charlotte Pritt, in a year when registered Democrats in West Virginia outnumbered Republicans by more than 2 to 1, when the state's entire Congressional delegation remained Democratic, and when the departing Governor, Gaston Caperton, a two-term Democrat barred by law from running again, was hailed by leaders of both parties for improving both the state's economy and its image.
In that political environment, it was Mr. Underwood, the Republican, rather than Ms. Pritt, the Democrat, who campaigned on themes of staying the Caperton course.
A businessman with no political experience when he took office in 1989, Mr. Caperton was widely viewed as a pragmatist who recognized that West Virginia could grow only through innovative education programs and the creation of new business.
During his administration, the state's unemployment rate fell to 6.2 percent, from 9.8, and 78,000 jobs were created, many in new technology businesses. As a result of that growth, the state's population, having fallen steadily for years, to under 1.8 million in 1990, has recently begun to increase. And by the end of next year, all public schools in the state will be equipped with computers linked to the Internet.
While Ms. Pritt, a coal miner's daughter and former public-school teacher, took advantage of her strong support from union members, especially teachers and coal miners, she was widely perceived as "the labor candidate," and as lacking the skills and the experience needed to keep West Virginia's economy viable in a period of fierce competition for new businesses among the Middle Atlantic States.
Neither Mr. Caperton nor Senator Robert C. Byrd, who has served in Congress as a Democrat for 44 years, became active campaigners for her, although she was strongly supported by Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, who easily won a third term last month.
"Cecil Underwood was elected because he is a moderate Republican who ran against a person perceived by many people as being somewhat of an extremist," said Mr. Caperton, who sailed to a second term over a Republican challenger in 1992 despite a write-in campaign by Ms. Pritt. "Everything we saw in the polls indicated that people thought the state was going in the right direction, with job development and education, and it was not his interest in changing that direction."
Mr. Underwood, who had served in the State Legislature for 10 years before winning the governorship in 1956, finds echoes of that victory in his triumph last month.
Forty years ago coal mining was still the state's economic lifeline, with 150,000 miners and three-shift-a-day operations, and his Democratic opponent, Robert H. Mollohan, had the backing of the United Mine Workers and other large unions.
"But I had done my own political analysis and found a straight line from 1936 to 1952 showing the steady growth of Republicans in West Virginia," said Mr. Underwood, whose 1956 victory was the first by a Republican nominee for West Virginia governor in 28 years.
In those days, the governor could serve only one term. So Mr. Underwood ran for the United States Senate in 1960. He lost, as he did in two later campaigns for governor, in 1964 and 1976.
Yet the losses led him to positions that became assets this year, including the presidency of Bethany College and the chairmanship of a management company in Morgantown that works with new businesses. He also co-founded Software Valley, a nonprofit project near Morgantown that he developed with Mr. Byrd and others to attract high-technology research companies to West Virginia.
As late as the waning months of last year, Mr. Underwood says, he was not contemplating another campaign for public office.
"But then I began to get calls, people saying they were not happy with the options of the two parties," he said. "They were looking for someone with experience."
Mr. Underwood, the last candidate to announce, packaged his business experience and still bankable name recognition as the logical extension of Mr. Caperton's policies. Stressing continued improvement of public schools and aggressive policies to attract more businesses to the state, he defeated two opponents in the Republican primary before taking on Ms. Pritt and a Libertarian Party candidate, Wallace Johnson, in the general election. Ms. Pritt won 46 percent of the vote, Mr. Johnson 2 percent.
Now a month from inauguration, Mr. Underwood says he recognizes that governing the state will be a substantially different job from the one he undertook the first time around, when corruption was common, poverty touched most areas of the state, West Virginia had no major highways and the state budget for his last term in office was $115 million (compared with $2.5 billion in Mr. Caperton's final budget).
In addition, coal is no longer the king it once was here. The state's economy has diversified into tourism and forestry products as well as high-technology industries.
"We've got more nurses now than coal miners," said Robert Dilger, a professor of political science at the University of West Virginia.
To Mr. Underwood, a man of gentle voice who looks 10 years younger than his age, all this is reason for more of the policies of the Caperton years.
"I believe they did the things that needed to be done," he said. "We just have to keep going and accelerate."
