HEADLINE: Bank Robber Flees by Train, Takes Hostage And Is Seized

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: WYANDANCH, L.I., Dec. 9

 BODY:
For three years, commuters on the Long Island Rail Road have lived with the legacy of fear left by Colin Ferguson, the Brooklyn man who opened fire with an assault rifle on a commuter train, killing 6 people and injuring 19.
Today, that fear was renewed when a bank robbery suspect boarded a train here, took a passenger hostage and threatened to start shooting others. Before surrendering, witnesses said, the suspect shouted to police officers, "You are going to have to kill me today." 
 No one was injured in the incident, but passengers were clearly shaken.
"All I could think of was Colin Ferguson," said Christine Hammer, who fled the train with her 4-year-old daughter, Carla. Eddie Melendez, a Nynex employee, said he too was reminded of Mr. Ferguson's shooting spree, adding, "I was thinking that it was going to happen again."
The suspect was identified as Anthony Norman, 34, of Brentwood, L.I. Detective Sgt. Peter Burker of the Suffolk County robbery squad said Mr. Norman was unemployed and divorced and had eight children.
He said police records showed that Mr. Norman had been arrested once in Suffolk County on drug charges and several times in New York City on charges ranging from petty larcy to possession of stolen property. It had yet to be determined whether Mr. Norman had been convicted on any of the charges or whether he had spent any time in prison.
"He told us this was his first bank robbery," Detective Burker said.
The police said today's drama began when Mr. Norman, wearing a red shirt, camouflage-fatigue pants and combat boots, entered the European American Bank on Suffolk Avenue in Brentwood at 10:18 A.M., told the teller that he had a gun, placed a package he said was a bomb on the counter, and demanded money.
After the teller gave him $2,000 in cash, he fled on foot and headed toward the nearby railroad station, where, witnesses said, he boarded the 10:08 from Ronkonkoma, L.I., a 12-car train headed to Manhattan with 450 people on board.
The police jumped into patrol cars and raced down Suffolk Avenue to the train's next stop here at the Brentwood station, where they halted and boarded the train and began searching for the suspect.
When two officers found him in the fourth car from the rear of the train, the suspect grabbed an elderly man around the neck with his arm and threatened to shoot him. "I'll blow his head off if you don't let me go," a witness, Ernest Solomon, recalled the suspect as yelling at the police.
More than a dozen other officers entered the car and, within 20 minutes, the police had talked the suspect into letting the hostage go and giving himself up. The suspect was found to be unarmed and the supposed bomb he had used to rob the bank was a fake, according to Officer Randy Jaret, a spokesman for the Suffolk County police.
Sam Zambuto, a spokesman for the Long Island Rail Road, said service in both directions on the Ronkonkoma line was halted for nearly an hour and a half while the police investigated the incident. The 10:08 resumed its trip to Manhattan shortly before noon and arrived at Pennsylvania Station shortly after 1 P.M.
Among those who remained on the train was William Helton, 26, of Central Islip, L.I., who said he made the trip to Manhattan to buy wholesale clothing for his retail shop in Glen Cove, L.I.
Mr. Helton said he rode in the same car as the suspect and noticed that he was acting strangely.
"He was talking and moving from seat to seat," Mr. Helton said. "When we came into Wyandanch and the cops were walking down the platform, he saw them and he jumped from one side of the train to the other."
Mr. Helton said the suspect left a coat and a package on one of the seats, and when the police asked if it belonged to him, he became nervous and grabbed a passenger sitting near him from behind.
"I saw him grabbing for something, and the cops starting backing up," Mr. Helton said. "First, there were only two cops, but then, 50 or more were coming into the car."
He said that despite the tension and fear, the officers remained calm and evacuated everyone. "Passengers crawled on the floor through the aisle and into the next car," he said.
One of the passengers was a woman who said she was among the commuters on the train that Mr Ferguson rode three years ago.
"She had some kind of a panic attack," said Tom Kletecka of Ronkonkoma, a passenger who sat near her. "She was shouting like crazy, 'I just only started riding the train again.' " Mr. Kletecka said the woman refused to reboard the train after she and others left it in Wyandanch.

HEADLINE: AGENCY TO PURSUE 2 PLANS TO SHRINK PLUTONIUM SUPPLY

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Confronting one of the most intractable problems of the post-cold-war era, the Energy Department said today that it would try to dispose of plutonium from old nuclear weapons both by using it as fuel in utilities' reactors and by mixing it with nuclear waste created when the plutonium was made and solidifying the mixture in glass.
Officials said they were pursuing both options because they did not know which method could be put in operation sooner and for less cost, or even whether either was feasible. 
 The department wants to dispose of 52.5 tons of plutonium, more than half the national stockpile. Its goals are to encourage the Russians to reduce their stockpile, to prevent plutonium from falling into unauthorized hands and to reduce the available stocks of the bomb fuel should the cold war return.
But some arms control experts complained immediately that using the plutonium in civilian reactors could, because of the security problems, increase the amount of potential weapons fuel in circulation around the world. And department officials conceded that there were technical questions about the feasibility of the plan to solidify the plutonium for storage.
Department officials said it would take at least two years for them to determine whether either, both or neither method would work. The initial cost estimate was $2.3 billion no matter how the processing is divided between the two methods.
In remarks at a news conference today at which she announced the new effort, Hazel R. O'Leary, the Energy Secretary, acknowledged the extent of the problem.
"The arms race is over," she said. "Our struggle now is to get rid of this sea of plutonium."
Mrs. O'Leary, who is leaving office next month after four years, said that she considered today's announcement the capstone of her tenure and that it was a big step toward reducing the risk of nuclear war.
The department and the White House had previously declared the plutonium surplus.
Originally, dozens of options for plutonium disposal were being considered, including some that involved disposal in space. "We started out with more than 35 options for plutonium disposition," Mrs. O'Leary said. "I think I was a child when we started."
 The plutonium was created over four decades in military reactors atom by atom by extracting neutrons from one form of uranium and adding them to another. Then the plutonium was painstakingly separated from highly radioactive wastes, for use in bombs.
One of the two disposal methods the department plans to pursue -- using the plutonium in reactors -- would destroy the bomb fuel almost completely. A reactor would split each atom, in the process releasing heat that can be used to make electricity.
Under the other plan, the plutonium would be mixed back in with the wastes created when it was made, making it difficult to repurify for military use. The plutonium and wastes would be solidified in glass, which the department began doing with wastes alone earlier this year. Or it could be solidified in a ceramic.
One problem with solidification is that the solid would have to last for thousands of years because plutonium decays slowly. If the glass broke down, the plutonium could reconcentrate, form a critical mass and carry on a nuclear chain reaction. In addition, where the material would be buried is still unclear because the Energy Department has not chosen a repository.
As for the other method, it is not clear that utilities would accept the plutonium as fuel, or that people who live near nuclear power plants will stand for it.
All 109 nuclear reactors now operating in the United States produce plutonium in the course of their normal operations and then consume some of it. Arizona Public Service's three Palo Verde reactors were designed to be loaded with plutonium fuel. In the New York area, the Niagara Mohawk Power Company has expressed interest in using plutonium at its two Nine Mile Point units, near Syracuse.
But no reactors are currently licensed to be loaded with plutonium fuel, and obtaining the necessary permits would almost certainly be politically troublesome.
Another problem with the reactor method is that most utility reactors are on shaky economic ground because of cheap natural gas and deregulation of the power industry. Nine Mile Point 1, for example, is a candidate for retirement. Many others may also be retired before they could begin burning plutonium.
In addition, a full-sized power plant could handle a ton to a ton and a half of plutonium per year, so finishing off 52 tons would take several reactors many years.
The Energy Department says it would pay the utilities for these "irradiation services." It might buy an existing reactor to do the job itself, if necessary, Mrs. O'Leary said.
Energy officials say that the idea of consuming plutonium in reactors appeals to the Russians, who still believe that plutonium is an asset, not a liability. But anti-proliferation experts say it will be hard to have the Russians turn the weapons material into reactor fuel without also encouraging them to recover even more plutonium from nuclear reactor fuel.
The Russians have been doing that for years, for themselves and for Hungary and Finland, in an industry called reprocessing. The United States had a similar industry, but President Jimmy Carter banned it as a proliferation danger 20 years ago.
Russia has no plant to turn this reprocessed plutonium back into reactor fuel, and partly as a result, its reprocessing business is small and probably not profitable, experts say. But the Energy Department wants to help the Russians build a fuel fabrication plant, to turn the weapons plutonium into the physical and chemical form needed for fueling a reactor. That could stimulate the reprocessing business, some nongovernment experts say.
The Nuclear Energy Institute, the civilian industry's trade association, likes the idea of using the plutonium in its reactors. It estimates that the plutonium could make enough reactor fuel, called mixed-oxide fuel and known as MOx, to run 10 large plants for 10 to 20 years.
But some analysts also think the "irradiation services fees" to American utilities would amount to a subsidy for uneconomic reactors.
"Plutonium is one of the most serious security threats facing the world," said Arjun Makhijani, president of the Institute for Energy and Environmental Research, which has been scrutinizing the Government weapons program for more than a decade. "What D.O.E. is proposing will increase nuclear dangers by entrenching pork-barrel interests in plutonium in Russia and creating them anew in the U.S."
A coalition of eight other groups, including Greenpeace, Physicians for Social Responsibility and the Nuclear Control Institute, said using military plutonium in civilian plants would "undermine a 20-year United States policy to avoid the civilian use of plutonium." Department officials said, though, that the Federal Government taboo, dating from the "atoms for peace" era, was to avoid creating military plutonium in civilian plants, not consuming it.
John D. Holum, director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, appearing with Mrs. O'Leary this afternoon, said, "There is a dramatic difference in my mind between using the MOx fuel option, if that should be chosen, to dispose of plutonium that we wish we didn't have, and producing more plutonium."
Some of the wastes, though, are residues, scraps and other forms that are unsuitable for reactors. That material could be disposed of with the other option, mixing the plutonium back in with the wastes that were its byproduct. Those wastes are now festering in million-gallon steel tanks, some of them rusting.
Early this year, the Energy Department opened a factory at the Savannah River Site, near Aiken, S.C., that mixes these wastes with molten glass in a Pyrex-like recipe, filling a stainless steel canister, which is then sealed. Engineers are studying whether they could insert small packages of plutonium pellets, encased in aluminum, into the canisters as they are filled. The aluminum would melt and the plutonium would be mixed with the glass, making retrieval very difficult, probably as difficult as separating plutonium from spent fuel, which is where it came from in the first place.

HEADLINE: A New Breed of Power Broker;
Bankers Are Changing the Shape of the Utility Industry

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
It was minutes before midnight on Friday, Nov. 22, and John W. Barr and Jeffrey R. Holzschuh had just helped rescue the biggest deal in the hottest year for mergers in the history of the American energy utility industry -- a $7.7 billion combination of the Duke Power Company of Charlotte, N.C., and the Panenergy Corporation of Houston.
Negotiations in New York had broken down 31 hours earlier in a dispute over the exchange ratio for Panenergy stock, and the Texas company had canceled a meeting at which its board had been expected to approve the agreement. In desperation, the investment bankers for both sides had flown to their clients' headquarters for talks aimed at bridging a $4-a-share gap, finally coaxing them to settle on $50 a share at 9:20 P.M. 
 The deal done, Mr. Barr of Barr Devlin Associates and Mr. Holzschuh of Morgan Stanley & Company stopped at a store on the way to the Charlotte airport to buy a case of beer and the entire stock of cheddar-cheese popcorn.
So what happened when the bankers boarded their chartered Lear jet back to New York? "Exhaustion set in," Mr. Barr said. "People sort of passed out. It's like you're so tired on your honeymoon that nothing happens. When we landed in New York, I think everybody was still gripping their first can of beer."
Never mind; there should be more occasions for Mr. Barr and Mr. Holzschuh to celebrate. As the staid, cash-rich utility business suddenly opens up to competition in states from Massachusetts to California, a small group of merger specialists sees hundreds of millions of dollars in fees ahead as they help pull apart the wires, pipes and power plants of the industry like some kind of giant Tinker Toys castle and put the pieces together in once unimaginable combinations.
The Duke-Panenergy merger alone will generate $40 million in fees for more than two dozen investment bankers at four firms who toiled on the project day and night for three weeks. And that deal is just one of dozens negotiated in the last two years. In some cases, utilities are selling off generating plants and becoming basically marketers, buying energy from the lowest bidder. In others, power companies are acquiring adjacent utilities or moving into new businesses. In still others, they are setting up operations abroad. And some of the most ambitious utilities are marrying into the natural gas industry.
With deregulation spreading to other states, and free-market legislation under discussion in Congress, the merger activity promises to become even livelier. And in pursuit of a $270 billion retail market, every power company seems to be making plans to offer new services to customers, ranging from home-security systems to writing mortgages.
And with their direct access to nearly every address in America, some are even thinking of competing with telephone and cable companies to supply communications to homes and businesses. "It's phenomenal, and it's not over," Mr. Barr exulted. "I call it a slice and dice industry."
Stephen L. Baum, chief executive of the Enova Corporation in San Diego, which formed the largest energy-service utility in the country with its $2.9 billion acquisition of Pacific Enterprises, a natural gas company, said the industry was in a revolution. "You can either circle the wagons or, like Duke and us, decide to be a player on the national scene and go after new markets," he said.
So far this year, 52 mergers or acquisitions valued at more than $35.5 billion have been struck in the natural gas and electric utility industries, nearly double the activity last year, according to Houlihan Lokey's Mergerstat. That translates, investment bankers say, into more than $350 million in fees for 1996.
The once sleepy utility area accounted for nearly 9 percent of all merger transactions this year. second only to communications and well ahead of banking and insurance.
Of course, it can take up to four years for the deals to gain regulatory approval and close. But what is most astounding is just how suddenly the industry has been deluged in deals. In 1991, there were only 13, worth $806.5 million. But in the last two years, one-quarter of the 100 largest electric utilities in the country were party to deals of one kind or another.
"It's reinventing time," Philip Giudice, a utility consultant at Mercer Management Consulting in Boston, said. "Nobody has a crystal ball that shows the winning strategy, so people will be trying different kinds of combinations."
Six years ago, just as the first tremors of change began shaking the industry, Mr. Barr and Hugh Devlin, who had headed Morgan Stanley's utility group for more than a decade, formed their own firm to focus exclusively on gas and electric companies. Barr Devlin played an advisory role in four of the top 10 United States deals this year and as much as 40 percent of the dollar volume of deals since 1990. "We had a vision of the company," Mr. Barr said, "as opposed to a vision of the industry."
But it can be a long time between paychecks. Barr Devlin is still waiting for seven of its biggest deals in 1995 and 1996 to close.
Industry infighting can also take its toll. This spring, Western Resources Inc. of Topeka, Kan., knocked out Utilicorp United Inc.'s planned friendly merger with the Kansas City Power and Light Company by initiating a $1.9 billion hostile bid. Kansas City Power repeatedly rebuffed Western until last month, when the two companies announced they were holding talks.
Five or six years ago, few in the utility industry foresaw the seismic changes to come. One who did was Edward Tirello, a utility analyst, who created a stir at a conference by passing out T-shirts emblazoned with a cryptic message "50 & 5" and then decoding it. Within five years, he predicted, the number of utilities in America would shrink to 50 from 150. It did not happen quite that fast, but no one today disagrees about the industry's direction. "They used to call me crazy," said Mr. Tirello, now an analyst at NatWest Securities. "Now I'm a visionary."
All the activity is creating two classes of investment bankers in the utility field -- the haves and have-nots. While merger specialists enjoy a windfall, their colleagues in the bond markets are watching enviously from the side. It was not always so; in the 1970's and early 1980's, financing new gas and electric plants accounted for an estimated 10 percent of all underwriting on Wall Street, and tens of millions of dollars in fees for each investment bank.
But with a surplus of generating capacity by the mid-1980's, utilities stopped coming around so much. Construction spending by investor-owned electrical utilities fell almost 65 percent, to $8.9 billion, in 1994, from a high of $25 billion in 1982, according to Cambridge Energy Research Associates.
"It was almost an annuity for many of these investment bankers," Mr. Giudice said. But "the amount of new capital required by this industry has gone down dramatically over the past five years."
Many investment banks allowed their utility ties to wither. As a result, much of the merger work goes to the few firms that kept cultivating relationships with chief executives: Morgan Stanley, Merrill Lynch & Company, Goldman, Sachs & Company and Barr Devlin, the only boutique in the bunch.
Despite the elegiac descriptions of the new utility architecture, some analysts question how long it will take the various combinations to deliver substantive new profits. Others wonder whether a competitive system provides a strong enough incentive for utilities to develop the costly extra generating capacity needed for peak power periods; widespread brownouts might trigger a move to reregulate the industry.
"The M.& A. people have plenty of tunes to sing here," said Lowell Miller, president of Miller/Howard Investments, a fund specializing in gas and utility stocks. "They're singing to people who aren't accustomed to takeovers and buyouts. They should have a relatively easy time until people see whether these deals work out or not."
Whatever Mr. Miller's misgivings, no one is likely to short circuit a myriad of new connections in the utility industry. "At this point," Rick Gordon, vice chairman of investment banking for Merrill Lynch, said. "I can't see an end to it."
The strategies behind the deals vary. Baltimore Gas and Electric was presumably seeking economies of scale and a bulwark against a hostile takeover when it recently agreed to pay $2.5 billion for Potomac Electric Power, which serves the Washington area. The Southern Company, the nation's largest producer of electricity and the parent of five electric utilities in the Southeast, is seeking to be a global player. It bought a regional electric distributor in Britain last year for $1.8 billion and agreed in October to pay $2.7 billion for Consolidated Electric Power Asia, a company in Hong Kong that builds, owns and operates generating plants in the Philippines, China, Pakistan and Indonesia.
The New England Electric System, a holding company with four electric utilities and 1.3 million customers, is shedding its power plants to become a pure marketer -- of natural gas and energy-related products and electricity. "In five years, the local utility will be a wires and pipes management and billing company," John Rowe, New England Electric's chairman, said. "The big actors will be the largest utilities like Duke, Enron and the new companies formed to broker energy."
Duke is betting that neither state nor Federal regulators will force it to sell off power plants as it sets about creating a giant network to market power nationally to the local "pipe and wire" utilities. Duke and Panenergy, which had been on the prowl for a cross-industry partner, started informal talks last summer. Their negotiations picked up speed in October, two months after the Enron Corporation, a gas pipeline company, gave instant credence to the energy "convergence" approach by agreeing to pay $2.1 billion for the Portland General Corporation, an electric utility based in Oregon.
But on Nov. 21, Duke and Panenergy were about $600 million apart when Panenergy canceled its board meeting and the deal tumbled into a pothole. After a day of negotiations by telephone, William H. Grigg, chairman of Duke, asked Mr. Barr, Mr. Holzschuh and his others advisers whether he should raise his bid. He stepped out of the room at about 9 P.M. to call Paul M. Anderson, chief executive at Panenergy, and returned 20 minutes later with a deal.
In merging with Panenergy, Duke acquired 37,000 miles of pipeline crisscrossing the Midwest and Northeast that carry about 15 percent of the gas consumed in the United States. The combined company can provide customers with one-stop shopping for all their energy needs.
"This industry is on fire," Mr. Holzschuh said, "and it's going to stay that way."

 Deregulation is changing the face of the utility industry: Many power companies are preoccupied with finding merger partners rather than adding to existing overcapacity by building power plants. This shift has had a fallout on Wall Street, where utilities are generating far less underwriting business, but firms that specialize in utility mergers and acquisitions are busier than ever.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Test Run of Pipeline by Iraqis Sends Oil Prices Tumbling

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Crude oil prices fell sharply yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, as a test of a pipeline to Turkey removed doubts that Iraq would soon begin exporting oil for the first time since 1990.
On other markets, wheat surged on expectations that Iraq would buy grain with proceeds from the oil it exports under a United Nations-governed aid plan. 
 Iraq began to pump oil yesterday into a pipeline that will deliver its oil to terminals on the Turkish coast as a test for the oil it will ship under the plan, which the United Nations approved on Monday.
The plan allows Iraq to sell as much as $2 billion of oil the next six months to pay for food and medicine. The United Nations imposed an oil embargo against Iraq after that country invaded Kuwait in 1990.
While full volumes of about 500,000 barrels a day are not expected to begin for at least a few days, the test signaled that Iraqi oil is close at hand after months of delays.
"As we move further and further along," said William Brown, president of W. H. Brown & Company, a consulting firm in New York, "this oil is going to put more and more pressure on prices."
Crude oil for January delivery sank 88 cents, to $24.42 a barrel, the lowest price since Nov. 27.
The United Nations yesterday received the first two company contracts to buy the Iraqi crude, and many more are expected.
"Iraqi crude is going to be on the market soon and obviously the market is reacting to it," Michael Busby, trading manager at Northville Industries in Melville, L.I., said.
From the $2 billion of revenue Iraq generates from the oil exports, it is expected to have enough cash to buy 1.5 million metric tons of wheat, or 55.1 million bushels, traders said.
The United Nations will place the oil proceeds in an escrow account.
While any grain Iraq buys is expected to come from Australia or Argentina, the increase in overall global demand should filter through to American grain prices.
March wheat rose 5 cents, to $3.7925 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Slips in Slow Trading Ahead of European Meeting

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most European currencies in slow trading yesterday as nervousness over the direction of German interest rates set in ahead of a meeting of European leaders this week.
Currency traders speculated yesterday that Italy might not become a full-fledged member of Europe's proposed monetary union. Such speculation aided the German mark against the dollar because it reduces the pressure on Germany to lower its interest rates. 
 Such speculation came as leaders of European Union member-nations prepare for a summit meeting in Dublin this weekend.
"I think people became less convinced this morning that the Bundesbank is going to ease rates to help form one European currency going into 1997," said Mark Gargano, managing director of currency derivatives at First Union National Bank.
"I think the market going into the summit is trading on rumors and expectations."
In late trading in New York yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5524 marks, from 1.5575 marks on Monday. The dollar was quoted at 113.41 Japanese yen, down from 113.51 yen. The British pound rose to $1.6537 from $1.6469.
Slow trading activity and little movement in exchange rates frustrated currency traders, especially in comparison with the dollar's tumble and recovery on Friday on comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and lackluster United States employment data.
"We've been in a real narrow dollar range today with not a lot of interest outside of the parameters of 1.5520 and 1.5560 marks," said Kevin Lawrie, global manager of foreign exchange at Mellon Bank.
The dollar briefly jumped yesterday after the midmorning release of the National Association of Purchasing Management's latest semiannual survey, which indicated that most of its members see better United States economic growth in the first half of 1997 versus the second half of 1996.
In trading in Asia, the dollar eased off session highs against the yen amid speculation that Kampo, the giant Japanese postal fund, would start hedging its foreign bond risk. Such a move would likely entail the selling of dollars and European currencies for yen, traders said.

HEADLINE: Journal;
101 Evitas

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
At the Sony Lincoln Square on Sunday, the packed house that had come to see Woody Allen's glorious new movie musical, "Everyone Says I Love You," was laughing even before it began. The source of the titters was a trailer for another movie musical, "Evita" -- "the story of the love between a girl and her dream," intoned the narrator -- in which Madonna, dripping in Dior, declared to the adoring multitudes, "I'm only a simple woman!"
But across town at Bloomingdale's on Monday no one was laughing. Business was brisk at the Evita boutique on three. "In 20 years I've never seen such a huge response," said Kal Ruttenstein, the store's fashion director, as we examined a beaded coronation dress (at $660 the most expensive item) and workmen behind us busily pumped up the volume of the inevitable background music, "Don't Cry for Me Argentina." Not even the sales at the still-hot "Rent" boutique on two -- fashions inspired by the transvestites, junkies and AIDS patients of the Broadway hit -- could match this Bloomingdale's exclusive. 
 Mr. Ruttenstein points out that the Evita collection is "bridge, not top of the line." Earlier in the day a woman had nonetheless managed to run up a nearly $1,000 tab on a complete look, with red hat, earrings, necklace and Nicole Miller tango dress. A store makeup artist had applied the Estee Lauder "Face of Evita" cosmetics, which include the new "Evita Red Hot Nail Lacquer," not to mention "Evita Flame Lips" lipstick.
Don't cry for me Estee Lauder! So what if the real Eva Peron "was an admirer of Hitler, Mussolini and Franco," as Michael Owen wrote in The Times when the stage version of "Evita" first sanitized its heroine for popular consumption? Who cares if jail cells in Buenos Aires were filled with her opponents, or if she shut down any newspaper or radio station that dared criticize the Peron regime, or if she may have helped the Nazis spirit away their loot?
I asked Mr. Ruttenstein, who has seen only 20 minutes of the film version, exactly what the appeal of Evita fashions is to Americans. No one, he included, knows if the movie is any good, and Madonna has yet to carry any movie to the box-office stratosphere. Coronation and tango dresses are unlikely to play well at the office or on the sidelines of the kids' soccer field. Do Americans even know who Evita is? Could Eva Braun ready-to-wear be far behind? What's it all about?
"You tell me," he said with a bemused shrug. "Evita was a woman of great power and beauty who wore expensive clothes and who had an international fashion reputation," he continued, then added sotto voce, "Some say she was mean."
Across the country -- in Superior, Ariz., where he's shooting a new film -- Oliver Stone spoke by phone about the incipient Evita rage. Mr. Stone took a lot of heat from historians last year for his movie "Nixon" -- which presented the former President occasionally slurring his words when drinking, a view since vindicated by recently released Nixon tapes. Mr. Stone also wrote an early draft of "Evita," enough of which survives in the finished movie for him to have been awarded co-credit for its screenplay by the Writers Guild.
But no historians are hounding him about Eva Peron; unlike the sartorially challenged Nixon, she gets a free pass.
Though not unsympathetic to Evita, Mr. Stone points out that she was "a whore -- a high-class whore." She "despoiled the country and ruined it economically," he added. "She was pretty much a Socialist. She hated the rich." Is this a fashion idol for affluent America in the 90's?
"What do Americans care about substance?" the director asked rhetorically. "The look is more important. Fashion becomes the idea, and that's what is sold."
Perhaps if "Evita" does as well as another Disney holiday release, "101 Dalmatians" (which itself is prompting a fashion craze for black-and-white spotted prints, USA Today reports), there will be "Evita" fashions for the whole family: Barbie-like Evita dolls laid out in little clear-plastic caskets, or, for that special man, a Fascist-chic line inspired by Eva's strongarm husband, Juan. A sash and jackboots, I've often felt, might be just the thing for New Year's Eve.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Big Mac II

SERIES: Sunday's column explored why no two countries that both have a McDonald's have ever fought a war against each other. This examines why McDonald's became a "glocal" company -- both global and local.

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: OAK BROOK, Ill.

 BODY:
The folks at McDonald's like to tell the story about the young Japanese girl who arrived in Los Angeles, looked around and said to her mother: "Look, mom, they have McDonald's here too."
You could excuse her for being surprised that McDonald's was an American company. With 2,000 restaurants in Japan, McDonald's Japan, a.k.a. "Makadonaldo," is the biggest McDonald's franchise outside the U.S. The McDonald's folks even renamed Ronald McDonald in Japan "Donald McDonald" because there's no "R" sound in Japanese. 
 "You don't have 2,000 stores in Japan by being seen as an American company," said James Cantalupo, head of McDonald's International. "Look, McDonald's serves meat, bread and potatoes. They eat meat, bread and potatoes in most of the world. It's how you package it and the experience you offer that counts."
The way McDonald's has packaged itself is to be a "multi-local" company. That is, by insisting on a high degree of local ownership, and by tailoring its products just enough for local cultures, McDonald's has avoided the worst cultural backlashes that some other U.S. companies have encountered. Not only do localities now feel a stake in McDonald's success, but more important, countries do. Poland for instance has emerged as one of the largest regional suppliers of meat, potatoes and bread for McDonald's in Central Europe. That is real power. Because McDonald's is gradually moving from local sourcing of its raw materials to regional sourcing to global sourcing. One day soon, all McDonald's meat in Asia might come from Australia, all its potatoes from China. Already, every sesame seed on every McDonald's bun in the world comes from Mexico. That's as good as a country discovering oil.
This balance between local and global that McDonald's has found is worth reflecting upon. Because this phenomenon we call "globalization" -- the integration of markets, trade, finance, information and corporate ownership around the globe -- is actually a very American phenomenon: it wears Mickey Mouse ears, eats Big Mac's, drinks Coke, speaks on a Motorola phone and tracks its investments with Merrill Lynch using Windows 95. In other words, countries that plug into globalization are really plugging into a high degree of Americanization.
People will only take so much of that. Therefore, to the extent that U.S.-origin companies are able to become multi-local, able to integrate around the globe economically without people feeling that they are being culturally assaulted, they will be successful. To the extent they don't, they will trigger a real backlash that will slam not only them but all symbols of U.S. power. Iran now calls the U.S. "the capital of global arrogance."
People in other cultures cannot always distinguish between American power, American exports, American cultural assaults and globalization. That's why you already see terrorists lashing out at U.S. targets not for any instrumental reason, but simply to reject this steamroller of globalization/Americanization, which has become so inescapable. (The McDonald's people have a saying: Sooner or later McDonald's is in every story. Where did O. J. eat just before the murder of Nicole? McDonald's. What did Commerce Secretary Ron Brown serve U.S. troops just before he died? McDonald's . . .)
"You try to shut the door and it comes in through the window," says the historian Ronald Steel about globalization. "You try to shut the window and it comes in on the cable. You cut the cable, it comes in on the Internet. And it's not only in the room with you. You eat it. It gets inside you."
The only answer is multi-localism -- democratizing globalization so that people everywhere feel some stake in how it impacts their lives. "McDonald's stands for a lot more than just hamburgers and American fast food," argued Mr. Cantalupo. "Cultural sensitivity is part of it too. There is no 'Euroburger.' . . . We have a different chicken sandwich in England than we do in Germany. We are trying not to think as a cookie cutter."

HEADLINE: Ford Returning to Suburb, Souring Detroit Real Estate Shift

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Dealing a blow to this city's hopes of an economic revival, the Ford Motor Company announced today that it was moving 2,500 office workers out of the downtown area and back to its base in suburban Dearborn.
Ford plans to transfer all of its workers out of the Renaissance Center, a complex of five skyscrapers that the General Motors Corporation bought this autumn, by the end of 1998. G.M. is moving its headquarters from a 74-year-old midtown office building to the downtown center. 
 Ford had a lease through 2005 on one 39-story tower and part of another at the Renaissance Center. The company will sell the lease to G.M., along with 26 acres of adjacent riverfront land that Ford has used for employee parking, Ford officials said.
The deal is a setback for Detroit because the city does not want to lose to the suburbs the 6,600 workers, including Ford employees, who now work in the Renaissance Center. Detroit, the nation's poorest big city, according to average household income, needs high-paying office jobs, partly because it levies a 1.5 percent income tax on commuters and a 3 percent income tax on residents.
Mayor Dennis Archer of Detroit has already announced plans to move the city government out of the downtown City Hall and into G.M.'s old headquarters in midtown Detroit. The hope is to make space available downtown for Renaissance Center tenants.
But Wayne S. Doran, the chairman of Ford's real estate subsidiary, said the City Hall building did not have enough room for the 2,500 employees. And he said Ford already had a lot of space becoming available at a building it owns in Dearborn across the street from its headquarters. The company's sales, marketing and customer-assistance operations will move there.
Robert L. Rewey, Ford's group vice president for sales and marketing, said that the company was encouraging its advertising agencies to stay in Detroit.
Mr. Rewey said that while no modern office buildings available in the city had the space to hold Ford's huge staff, there was plenty of space for smaller businesses.
Mayor Archer said in a telephone interview this afternoon that he understood Ford's reasons for moving but hoped that the company would build its next assembly plant in the city. In a separate shift, the Ford family is moving the Detroit Lions football team downtown from suburban Pontiac, and Ford Motor has bought the right to name the new stadium.
G.M.'s decision to buy the Renaissance Center was hailed at the time as a sign that Detroit was showing signs of revitalization. By transferring workers from all over Michigan, G.M. will eventually have nearly 9,000 workers in the complex, compared with only 5,400 at the current midtown headquarters.
But if all of the 6,600 people now in the partly full center end up working in the suburbs, the city would wind up with fewer high-paying office jobs than it had before the real estate shuffle began.
G.M. plans to build parking decks on part of the 26 acres of land where Ford has had huge swaths of pavement next to the Detroit River. The parking decks will allow G.M. to open up the riverfront to the public, perhaps by building a promenade along the water, said Peter C. Rowe, a G.M. spokesman.
G.M.'s purchase of the Renaissance Center has been a financial coup as well as a public relations bonanza for the company, the nation's biggest.
Using an intermediary to disguise its intentions, G.M. paid just $73 million for the steel and glass complex, which cost Ford and its other investors $350 million to build in the late 1970's.
Mr. Rowe said that in buying the Ford lease and the 26 acres, G.M. had paid "a fraction of what we paid for the building."

HEADLINE: Administration Renews Efforts on Prevention of Repetitive Motion Injuries

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
With Congressional restrictions removed in the new budget year, the Clinton Administration said today that it planned to renew its efforts to set mandatory rules to prevent repetitive motion injuries at work.
 Ailments caused by repeated motions are the fastest-growing category of workplace injury. Hundreds of thousands of American workers, from meatpackers to computer programmers, are afflicted each year. 
 The economic cost of repetitive motion injuries is estimated at $20 billion annually in payments of compensation claims, according to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. Related costs, like absenteeism, could lift the total to $100 billion, the agency says.
The Administration's plan, outlined in a session with reporters attended by Robert B. Reich, the Secretary of Labor, and Joseph A. Dear, the Assistant Secretary of Labor who heads OSHA, is another sign of revived activism by the Government and the courts to deal with repetitive motion injuries.
Last month, California regulators approved the nation's first law intended to ease the growing problem of repetitive motion injuries. And it was announced on Monday that a Federal jury in Brooklyn had awarded nearly $6 million to three women who suffered arm, wrist and hand injuries while working on computer keyboards made by the Digital Equipment Corporation.
Most business groups agree that repetitive motion injuries are costly, but they have opposed Federal standards. Since 1990, OSHA has been working on an ergonomic standard to protect workers. But until now, the effort was bogged down by the heated politics surrounding the field of ergonomics, a discipline that tries to design jobs and tools to fit the physical limits of workers.
Supporting business groups, conservative Republicans last summer attached an amendment to the budget bill that would have eliminated money for OSHA's ergonomic effort and barred collection of information on the problem. The amendment was defeated after some Republicans, who had supported earlier cuts, joined Democrats in opposing it. In the current fiscal year, which began Oct. 1, the safety agency no longer faces Congressional prohibitions on setting ergonomic standards.
"We can now proceed," Mr. Reich said, "and the Administration is 100 percent behind moving forward."
Yet the Administration appears to be taking a more conciliatory approach toward the rule-writing process than it had a few years ago. Mr. Reich would not predict when OSHA might issue ergonomic rules.
The new plan, Mr. Reich said, emphasizes building a consensus among business groups, workers and medical experts. An earlier draft proposal covered much of industry, but now, he said, OSHA is considering different standards for different activities, like computer keyboard typing, lifting and assembly-line work.
"Certainly, one of the things we are looking at is moving step by step," Mr. Reich said.
An early move in the consensus-building effort will be a two-day conference in Chicago early next year, sponsored by OSHA and the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health, a research agency. The conference, Jan. 8 and 9, will include companies and ergonomic experts, who will discuss programs for preventing repetitive motion injuries.
Soon after the conference, the Government will compile, publish and distribute a "technical assistance manual of best practices by companies," said Mr. Dear of OSHA. "We want to make the successes of companies that have made real progress available to other companies."
This time, Mr. Dear said, the rule-writing process will be focused on workplace environments "where the problems are most severe and where the solutions are well-known."
A new research effort will guide the rule-writing. OSHA's research arm is doing a scientific review on injuries from repetitive activity. That review is seeking cause-and-effect links between certain kinds of work and injuries, and it is expected to be completed early next year.
The Administration's new emphasis on seeking common ground with business on the ergonomic issue is a political necessity, given the power of business lobbyists in Washington.
"If we don't have the cooperation of the American business community," Mr. Reich said, "it is anybody's guess when we would have a standard. It could be years."
Some experts say that enlisting the support of business is worthwhile, but that OSHA will have to take the lead in setting ergonomic standards.
"If you wait around for the business community to give its blessing, it's not going to happen," said Dr. David Rempel, a professor of occupational medicine at the University of California at San Francisco.
Business groups support the education and research side of OSHA's plan, but say mandatory Government rules have yet to be justified.
"We don't have the kind of certainty from the medical community yet that would justify imposing a costly regulation on business," said Albert Lundeen, a spokesman for the National Coalition on Ergonomics, a group, supported by business, that opposes Federal standards.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Fall as Data Are Awaited

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities slumped yesterday in light, choppy trading as investors waited for reports on inflation and retail sales that are to be released in the next few days.
The 30-year bond dropped 12/32 in price, to a 1005/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, rose to 6.49 percent, from 6.46 percent on Monday. 
 Analysts said that there was a modest negative reaction in the morning to a weekly report on sales at chain stores, issued by the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi and Schroder Wertheim, which showed a 1 percent jump in the week ended Dec. 7. Signs of strong sales alarm bond traders because they hint at possible inflation, which erodes the value of bonds.
In the afternoon, though, the LJR Redbook Research report, which tracks national retail sales, drew only a negligible response despite showing a rise of eight-tenths of 1 percent in December's first week.
The market also largely ignored comments suggesting a healthy economy by Thomas M. Hoenig, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City and a nonvoting member of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's rate-setting panel, which meets again next Tuesday. Mr. Hoenig said that he expected growth of around 2 percent to 2.5 percent and that a low unemployment rate could be maintained.
Several other indicators were also somewhat bearish for the market. A regional business survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond indicated somewhat higher inflation. Prices of retail goods rose at an annual rate of 1.4 percent, the survey showed, compared with a gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent the previous month.
The dollar was down yesterday, making bonds less attractive to foreign investors. The price of oil, which traders watch closely for signs of inflation, did not fall as much as expected.
Jack Regan, chief derivative strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said trading was quiet in what he called a "nonevent day."
Mr. Regan said traders were waiting to see the Producer Price Index, to be issued today, and the Consumer Price Index tomorrow along with the monthly report on retail sales for November. Wall Street is looking for an increase of three-tenths of 1 percent to four-tenths of 1 percent in the Producer Price Index and an increase of two-tenths of 1 percent to four-tenths of 1 percent in the core index, excluding the volatile food and energy categories, he said.
Mr. Regan said that despite the relative calm of the bond market yesterday, undercurrents of concern remained from comments last week by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, who questioned the high valuation of the stock market.
"The Fed chairman's remarks last week are still in the back of traders' minds," Mr. Regan said. "They know he doesn't shoot from the hip, he doesn't make off-the-cuff remarks, and he doesn't have to answer to anybody for the next four years."

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Worsened in Third Quarter

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
The United States trade deficit surged to $48 billion from July through September, the highest quarterly total in history, the Commerce Department reported today.
The imbalance in the current account, the broadest measure of trade, increased by 19.3 percent from a second-quarter deficit of $40.2 billion, as American exports fell for the first time in three years. 
 The results reflected an increase of seven-tenths of a percent in merchandise imports, which rose to $201.5 billion in the third quarter.
At the same time, merchandise exports fell 2.1 percent, to $149.9 billion, the first quarterly setback since the summer quarter of 1993. The current account measures not only sales of goods but also services, investment flows and foreign aid.
The rise in imports and drop in exports translated into a 9.8 percent increase, to $51.6 billion, in the deficit in goods.
America also suffered a 7.8 percent rise in the deficit in investment earnings, to $4.7 billion, and a six-tenths of a percent increase in the category that tracks foreign aid payments, which rose to $9.42 billion.
Offsetting these deficits, America as usual had a surplus in services, items like airline tickets and royalty payments. But the $17.8 billion services surplus was down 3.5 percent from the second quarter even though royalty payments, reflecting fees foreigners paid to broadcast the Olympic Games in Atlanta, were up.
The $48 billion overall deficit surpassed the old record of $43.2 billion set in the fourth quarter of 1987. So far this year, the current account deficit is running at an annual rate of $164 billion, far ahead of last year's $148.1 billion deficit.
American trade deficits have risen every year of President Clinton's term despite the fact that he has made reducing trade imbalances a key foreign policy priority.
The Administration has said that the deficit reflects the fact that the United States economy is growing much faster than that of other countries, lifting import demand.
Administration officials had pointed out that despite the sluggishness overseas, American export sales were rising to new records.
American exports of goods had turned in a string of gains, but the $3.2 billion dip in the third quarter was certain to raise concerns that continued sluggishness overseas and the rising value of the dollar were starting to cut into export gains.
A higher foreign exchange value for the dollar makes United States goods more expensive abroad.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Japan's Deficit Narrows
 TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 11 (Bloomberg Business News) -- Japan's current account surplus shrank 19.6 percent in October from a year earlier as Japanese investors sought higher returns overseas, the Ministry of Finance said today.
The narrowing, which was slightly more than expected, was the 22d decline in the last 23 months, as Japan's deficit in services continued to grow. Japan spent 657.9 billion yen more on services than it sold.
The merchandise trade portion of the current account contracted 11.7 percent from a year earlier as imports increased for the 27th consecutive month. The decline was within expectations.

HEADLINE: Democrats Seek to Shrink Size of Albany's Tax Cut

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Democratic state legislators began laying the groundwork today for a campaign to scale back the final phase of the state's three-year income tax cut, releasing a study showing that increases in property taxes and other local fees in 1995 far outpaced savings from the tax cut.
Using statistics collected from a variety of state and local government agencies, the report shows that local fees and taxes took an additional $1.54 billion from taxpayers in 1995, while the first phase of the income tax cut that year gave them back $515 million. The study took into consideration increases in property taxes, tuition for state and city colleges, bus and subway fares and fees for things like sewer permits and fire inspections. 
 The report's author, State Senator Franz S. Leichter, a Democrat of Manhattan, said the study bolstered the contention of many urban Democrats and labor unions that the income tax cut had increased pressure on local governments to raise taxes and fees to compensate for reductions in state aid.
Though Mr. Leichter acknowledged that many local governments were increasing taxes and fees before 1995, he contended that the state had fallen into a worse position to bail out distressed towns, cities and school districts because of the tax cut.
"It is really a great-load shifting," he said in an interview. "The Feds are shifting cost onto the state, and the state is shifting that onto localities, who have no way to pay for it other than by raising taxes and fees."
With the state facing as much as a $3 billion budget shortfall next year and the prospect of having to reduce services, Senator Leichter and a group of Democratic legislators, mostly from New York City, said they would resume their effort to push the Legislature to roll back the income tax cut. The final phase of that cut, which is scheduled to take affect on Jan. 1, is expected to reduce state revenues by $1.8 billion.
Mr. Leichter said he would introduce legislation in January that would repeal the final phase of the tax cut for families with incomes over $100,000 and end a variety of tax shelters for corporations. He said the two measures would save the state $1.1 billion that could be used to close the projected budget shortfall.
The bill would also increase taxes on people making over $150,000 a year and use the revenues, estimated at $1 billion a year, for school repairs and construction.
Senator Leichter's group faces a steep uphill battle, since even Democratic legislative leaders, including the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver of Manhattan, have said they will oppose any changes to the tax cut. The Republican Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, and Gov. George E. Pataki, who pushed the tax cut through the Legislature, have also vowed to block any attempts to scale it back.
Aides to Mr. Pataki called Mr. Leichter's report misleading. They said that increases in local taxes and fees in 1995 resulted from the policies of former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and not the 1995 tax cut.
"Governor Pataki has reversed these damaging polices," said Patricia A. Woodworth, the budget director, "by implementing job-creating tax cuts, cutting red tape and dramatically reforming the workers' compensation system."
According to Senator Leichter's report, revenues from local fees and fines increased by $930 million in 1995. Tuition increases for the state and city university systems of New York cost students an additional $211 million. Increases in transit fares around the state cost bus and subway riders an additional $311 million.
The report found that New York City and many counties did not raise local taxes in 1995. But towns, villages and upstate cities collected $132 million in additional revenue from property taxes in 1995, which represented a sharp increase over previous years.
The third phase of the tax cut will give back $367 a year, or $30 a month, to a family of four with an annual income of $50,000.
Aides to Mr. Pataki said that the fact that many local governments were collecting more money from local taxes and fees might simply be an indication of an improving economy -- and not higher tax rates. But officials with groups representing local governments said that many cities, towns, counties and villages had been raising taxes and fees in recent years -- and some of them blamed the trend in part on the income tax cut.
"Cutting state income taxes has limited the state's ability to fund revenue sharing," said Peter Baynes, deputy director of the New York State Conference of Mayors, referring to a type of unrestricted state aid to local governments. "The property tax is the only place to turn to offset it."
But Peter D. Salins, a professor of urban planning at Hunter College and senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute, a politically conservative policy group, said there was little evidence that state tax cuts caused local governments and school districts to raise taxes and fees.
"That doesn't mean local taxes can't go up for other reasons," said Professor Salins, who has studied the impact of state tax cuts on local property taxes in New Jersey. "But our model showed there is no link to changes in state taxes."

HEADLINE: Clinton's Chief Economist Accepts Post at World Bank

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Joseph E. Stiglitz, who served for the last year and a half as chairman of the White House's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that he would leave the Clinton Administration early next year to become chief economist at the World Bank.
Mr. Stiglitz's departure, which had been expected, leaves President Clinton with another post to fill as he continues to consider possible choices to lead the Commerce, Labor, Energy, Transportation and Housing Departments as well as the National Economic Council. 
 White House officials said it was possible that Mr. Clinton would be ready to name most of his second-term economic team at a news conference scheduled for Friday, although it is unclear whether the White House has a replacement in mind already for Mr. Stiglitz, who formally told the President on Monday of his decision to leave.
Administration officials said there would probably be a number of candidates. One possibility, they said, is Alicia H. Munnell, a former top Treasury official who because of a vacancy is currently the only other member of the Council of Economic Advisers.
Mr. Clinton had considered naming her to the Federal Reserve several years ago but backed down after a fierce protest from the banking industry over her co-authorship of a study that found widespread discrimination in mortgage lending. But because she has already been confirmed by the Senate as a member of the council, she would not have to undergo confirmation to become its chairwoman.
Two Administration officials said tonight, however, that the job was not likely to go to Ms. Munnell. It was unclear whether Ms. Munnell wanted the job and she did not return a phone call seeking comment.
Another possibility, officials said, is Alan S. Blinder, an economist at Princeton University who was previously vice chairman of the Fed and before that a member of the council under Mr. Clinton.
Mr. Stiglitz's job made him the President's chief economist, providing both an overview of the economy's performance as well as analysis of the economic implications of policy options.
But although he had a hand in shaping Administration policy on a wide range of issues, from simplifying pensions to deregulating the telecommunications industry, he was never part of the Administration's inner circle. Moreover, he chose to keep a relatively low public profile, never taking on a big role as a spokesman for the Administration's economic policies.
Mr. Stiglitz, 53, holds a doctorate in economics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and was a professor at Stanford University before coming to Washington in 1993 as a member of the Council of Economic Advisers under his predecessor, Laura D'Andrea Tyson. He replaced Ms. Tyson as chairman in mid-1995 when she was named to head the National Economic Council, a job she is now leaving.
In leaving for the World Bank, Mr. Stiglitz will be joining an institution undergoing a sweeping re-examination of its role in promoting development in the world's poor nations at a time when private investment is overshadowing the more limited public aid traditionally supplied by multilateral lending institutions.
Mr. Stiglitz, who has long studied development issues and who worked in Africa years early in his career, said he hoped to combine his practical experience in government with his scholarly interest in how to promote economic growth to help make the World Bank a more effective resource for developing nations.
"My job here was one of the most interesting you could imagine," Mr. Stiglitz said in an interview, adding that he at first was not interested when he was approached about the World Bank job over the summer.
"Then I thought about it some more and decided that on the issues I'm most concerned with -- problems of poverty, problems of growth -- the challenges in less developed countries were much greater," he said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS SUMMARY

 BODY:

Iraq Reopens Pipeline To Send Oil Abroad
Iraq began to pump oil abroad for the first time in six years as President Saddam Hussein reopened a 616-mile pipeline that will deliver Iraqi crude to terminals on the Turkish coast.
But experts said that the first oil to emerge from the pipeline would be suitable only for asphalt. They said it could be weeks before the limited quantity of oil Iraq will be permitted to sell under a United Nations plan reaches the world market. [Page A3.]
 
Crude oil prices fell sharply on news that Iraqi oil was likely to return to the market. [D9.]
 
Rebound in Stocks Slows
Investors took profits after Monday's big stock market rally. The Dow industrials eked out a gain of 9.31 points, to 6,473.25, but broader indexes were mostly lower. [D10.]
 
Hardware Co-ops Plan to Merge
Seeking to compete with giants like Home Depot, two of the largest hardware co-ops -- Cotter & Company, which is owned by Truevalue hardware dealers, and Servistar -- announced plans to merge. [D2.]
 
Trade Deficit Hits Record
The United States trade deficit surged 19.3 percent in the third quarter, to the highest quarterly total in history. The current account deficit, the broadest measure of trade, increased to $48 billion from $40.2 billion in the second quarter, as American exports fell for the first time in three years. [D10.]
 
Sun Announces Backing for Java
Sun Microsystems said that more than 100 companies -- with the conspicuous exception of Microsoft, which apparently was not invited to join in -- agreed to adhere to rules meant to make Sun's Java programming language the lingua franca of network applications. [D2.]
 
High-Technology Trade Deal Near
The United States and the European Union appeared to come within striking distance on an accord that would pave the way for a global pact to liberalize trade in information technology. [D4.]
 
New Push on Workplace Ailment
One day after it was announced that a jury had awarded nearly $6 million to three women who suffered arm, wrist and hand injuries while working on computer keyboards made by Digital Equipment, the Clinton Administration said that it planned to renew its efforts to set rules to prevent such injuries at work. [A24.]
 
Clinton Adviser
To World Bank
Joseph E. Stiglitz, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers for the last year and a half, said that he would leave the Clinton Administration early next year to become chief economist at the World Bank. [D2.]
 
TV Ratings Plan Is Criticized
As a television industry group puts the finishing touches on its proposed ratings system, opposition is growing among educational and parents' organizations that say the system will not provide the information parents need. [A1.]
 
Enron Promotes Energy Trader
Enron named as its No. 2 executive Jeffrey K. Skilling, who built up a huge business trading natural gas and electricity. The move shows how quickly the trading and marketing of gas and electricity are growing in importance because of utility deregulation and how hard companies are scrambling to keep up. [D6.]

Ford Moving Workers to Suburbs
Ford Motor said it was moving 2,500 office workers from downtown Detroit to its base in suburban Dearborn, Mich., a blow to the city's hopes of an economic revival. [B14.]

HEADLINE: New York City Hears of Surplus, But Big Budget Gaps Lie Ahead

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
Heady profits on Wall Street are generating so much extra revenue from income and business taxes that New York City may end its fiscal year with a surplus of nearly $350 million, city officials said yesterday. But even with this unanticipated boon, the city still faces huge projected gaps in its budgets for the next several years because its spending continues to grow faster than its revenues.
That jarring juxtaposition presents Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani with a weighty series of choices as he begins his re-election campaign, forcing him to balance his political needs and his fiscal ones. 
 Should he spend the surplus to try to bolster his standing with voters who may be weary from years of steep budget cuts? Or should he save it to close future shortfalls?
The projected surplus of nearly $350 million comes on top of another $450 million in unexpected revenue that Mayor Giuliani last month said the city would reap because its economy, which had been anemic, has been rebounding.
Yet even as the Mayor was mulling over how to use these windfalls, his aides disclosed yesterday that he had ordered $400 million in new spending reductions for the next fiscal year, which begins on July 1.
The contrast underscores a sobering truth about the city's financial condition: its current good fortune has done little to cure its long-term ills. So if and when the stock market boom wanes, the city will be left with the same longstanding financial difficulties.
"We have not solved the deficit problem," said the City Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi. "We are getting a good boost from the tremendous Wall Street growth, but I don't know how long that can be sustained."
Next year, in fact, the city must patch a projected gap of $1.2 billion to $2 billion in its $34 billion budget, all but insuring that Mr. Giuliani will have to cut money for a range of services, anything from street cleaning to free concerts to community centers for the elderly.
The projected shortfall for the year 2000 could be as big as $5 billion, the largest in the city's history.
Randy M. Mastro, the Deputy Mayor for Operations, acknowledged that the projected shortfalls for the next few years were large, but he said the Mayor had made "sensible reductions" to close them.
"You cannot address a structural budget deficit problem that occurred over many, many years overnight," Mr. Mastro said. "You have to do it in a responsible, phased-in way over time."
Mr. Mastro said Mr. Giuliani would not take politics into consideration when allocating the extra revenue. "You can't made decisions on that basis," Mr. Mastro said. "This Mayor makes decisions based on what is in the city's best interests."
The Mayor's aides said it was too early to discuss what the administration would do with the nearly $350 million that Mr. Hevesi said the city would probably have when the 1997 fiscal year ends on June 30.
The aides noted that in the last two years the administration has recorded smaller year-end surpluses after undertaking heavy cuts, largely because of accounting methods. It then essentially rolled that money into the next fiscal year. But this year, with the election looming, Mr. Giuliani might feel more pressure to spend now.
In his plans for the $450 million in additional tax revenues that he announced last month, Mr. Giuliani appeared to balance political and fiscal imperatives.
He allocated $70 million for textbooks for the public schools, seeking to improve his record on education, which his Democratic opponents have contended was one of his weaknesses. But he said he would use the rest of the $450 million for closing budget gaps.
The city's projected budget gaps in the coming years stem from its inability to tame expenditures, which are rising faster than revenues, people who study municipal finances say. The increased taxes from Wall Street earnings helped the city cover those rising costs this year, but officials concede that they cannot always count on a soaring stock market to balance their books.
"The gods of Wall Street smiled on us this year, but we don't know if they will do so next year," said Councilman Herbert E. Berman, a Brooklyn Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee.'
While the Mayor and his aides discount the role of politics in shaping the budget, one of the major reasons for the large projected gaps is the labor contract that Mr. Giuliani negotiated with the city's municipal unions in 1995. Under that agreement, the unions accepted the first two years without wage increases, with the raises put off until the end of next year.
So the Mayor does not have to grapple with billions of dollars in costs to the budget from the contract until the 1999 and 2000 fiscal years -- after his re-election campaign.
In calculating the projected budget shortfalls in future years, the Giuliani administration assumes that Wall Street will have an average year. If the financial sector continues its strong earnings next year, the gap could be reduced for the 1998 fiscal year, but not nearly enough to close it, administration officials said.
The administration has emphasized in recent weeks to both city workers and the public that the recent good news from Wall Street should not bring complacency.
Giuliani aides said they feared that if people thought that the city's hard times were behind it, they would have trouble pushing through cuts that they said were necessary to balance the budget next year. The Mayor has ruled out raising taxes to bring in more revenue.
The Mayor's budget director, Joseph J. Lhota, recently sent a memo to agency heads asking them to come up with $400 million in new cuts for the next fiscal year. That amount is in addition to another $300 million in cuts the Mayor ordered last month for the next fiscal year.
"Although the changes for 1997 included a one-time infusion of revenue from increased economic activity," Mr. Lhota wrote, "we should not be misled into believing that the budget gap for fiscal year 1998 has been solved. Serious work needs to be done to balance fiscal year 1998."

HEADLINE: Acrimony at Hearing on Revising Rules for Liver Transplants

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA 

DATELINE: BETHESDA, Md., Dec. 10

 BODY:
A Government hearing on proposed changes in the way livers are allocated for lifesaving transplants offered a rare glimpse today of acrimony among transplant centers.
The three-day hearing was called by the Department of Health and Human Services to discuss the changes proposed by the group that sets national rules for the allocation of organs, the United Network for Organ Sharing. The department oversees the group and could alter or scuttle the proposal. 
 The organ group set off a storm of protest last month when it proposed giving preference to patients whose livers suddenly failed and who would die within days without a transplant. In doing so, the group would put chronically ill patients, who are also on the verge of death, second in line behind those who suddenly face liver failure.
It would thus impose rationing, giving livers to those among the most needy who are most likely to survive rather than those who are sickest. In addition, the group proposed adjusting the criteria for determining how urgently patients need livers, and it encouraged regions to share organs among themselves.
The organ group's board argued that its new policies would help insure that livers were distributed more equitably. But several large transplant centers, like the University of Pittsburgh and Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York City, were outraged, saying patients would suffer and die.
For medical centers, a successful transplant program is a mark of prestige and often an economic lifeline. Changes in the liver allocation rules can influence which program flourishes and which withers.
Two things are driving the disputes: a shortage of livers for transplants, and what some view as an unfair system in which how long a patient waits for a liver can depend on where the patient's liver transplant center is and how the patient's doctors decide to describe his or her illness. In 1995, the organ group reported, 44,101 people were on regional waiting lists for livers. But just 3,923 transplants were performed.
Dr. Goram Klintmalm, who is at Baylor University Medical Center in Dallas and who was the liver surgeon for the baseball star Mickey Mantle, noted that patients at his center who were not literally within weeks of death waited 300 days on average for a liver. In Houston, Dr. Klintmalm said, the average wait was 132 days, and in San Antonio it was 123 days.
Liver transplant surgeons contended today at the first day of the hearing that some centers purposely stretched the truth when they reported on how sick a patient was, pushing their patients up the waiting list. And that, said Dr. Mitchell Shiffman, a liver specialist at the Medical College of Virginia in Richmond, has made some centers reluctant to want to share organs on a national basis, which is the reason waiting times can vary so much by region. Surgeons, Dr. Shiffman said, do not always trust doctors they do not know well to be honest about their patients' needs.
Dr. John Fung, a liver surgeon at the University of Pittsburgh, said other medical centers, which he did not name, transplanted livers into patients whose chances of survival were not improved by the operation. Dr. Fung said such patients might have a 90 percent chance of surviving a year without a new liver and the same chance of surviving a year with one.
Underlying many of the debates is a rapidly changing medical arena, liver experts said. Liver transplants began to emerge as a strikingly successful procedure in the late 1980's, when the field was dominated by the University of Pittsburgh, the pioneer in liver transplantation. Eight years ago, Dr. Shiffman said, 10 medical centers did 80 percent of the transplants. Now, he said, 50 centers do 80 percent of the transplants.
And the largest centers are losing business fast, said Dr. Roger Evans, an economist at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. In Pittsburgh, he said, the number of transplants fell to 298 in 1995 from 569 in 1990. Not only are there many more centers, he said, but also some centers like Pittsburgh are not part of managed care networks. They are losing business because managed-care companies have struck deals elsewhere.
One speaker at today's hearing, Dr. Anthony D'Alessandro, a transplant surgeon at the University of Wisconsin, said, "We are here because of a very vocal minority of transplant centers who are well connected." They hope, he said, that the rules can be made to "allow them to flourish as they once did."
Dr. Evans said part of the argument over the proposed new allocation rules was simply an effort by some large centers to advance their own interests. For example, Dr. Evans said, large and well-known centers tend to have large waiting lists consisting of very sick people. Under the old policies, those patients had the same priority for livers as patients who suddenly became ill and were rushed to the nearest center.
But Dr. Fung said he opposed the new rules because his patients would be cheated.
"Patients feel they can't win the Lotto game if they can't get a Lotto ticket," he said. And, he said, it makes sense to direct livers to Pittsburgh because his center gets better results.
Some patients, family members and others also said they were upset by the proposed changes. One patient, Nathaniel Semple, who had three liver transplants at the University of Pittsburgh in 1989, said the new policies would be "horrendous." He said the organ group "has to give doctors some sense of an opportunity to decide who would do well."
Yet, said many who support the proposed new policies, since the total number of livers is the same, there will always be some who win and some who lose in the scramble for the precious organs.
What the organ group is trying to do, Dr. Evans said, is shift the emphasis so that the livers will go to those who are most likely to survive.
Addressing his colleagues, Dr. D'Alessandro, the Wisconsin transplant surgeon, said: "Over the next three days, you will hear from patients. Their stories will certainly touch you. These are people facing certain death without transplants. We all care deeply for our patients, but changes in allocations at this time only change the address where a patient dies."
Within three months, Dr. Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, will submit final rules for allocating livers.
