HEADLINE: Bank Robbery Suspect Says He Got Inspiration From TV

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: CENTRAL ISLIP, L.I., Dec. 10

 BODY:
Anthony Norman has served time for several petty crimes, but when he decided to rob a bank on Monday, he says in a statement to the police, he drew his inspiration from a television program.
The police said Mr. Norman, who was arrested after trying to get away on a commuter train, where he took a passenger hostage, said in his six-page confession that he was watching "Renegade" on television last week on the USA cable channel. 
 "It was about a guy who was robbing banks and getting away with it," Mr. Norman said. "He was putting an empty suitcase on the bank teller's counter and telling the tellers that there was a bomb in it."
And that, the police said, is exactly what Mr. Norman did on Monday morning at the European American Bank in Brentwood, L.I. Except he used a grocery bag from his kitchen and filled it with books.
Dan Martinsen, vice president of media relations for USA Networks, confirmed that an episode of "Renegade" on Friday night involved a series of bank robberies and commented on "the irony of life imitating art." But he added: "Obviously, this guy didn't pay very close attention to the end of the episode, because he does get caught."
Mr. Martinsen has more than an academic interest in the case. He was on the same train, in the same car, when the police say Mr. Norman took a hostage. Mr. Norman later surrendered to a hostage negotiator and proved to be unarmed.
Mr. Martinsen, who sat several rows behind Mr. Norman, said he immediately thought of Colin Ferguson, who opened fire on a Long Island Rail Road train three years ago, killing 6 people and injuring 19. "That all flashed through my mind in a second," he said. "Anyone who rides the railroad and starts seeing guns has to think of that. When the guns came out, I was among those who got out of there fast. Luckily, this time, only the good guys had guns."
Mr. Anthony, 34, is unemployed, with a long record of arrests on Long Island and in New York City. He was arraigned today on one count of bank robbery and held on $75,000 bail.
"I was broke," he said in his statement. "I wanted some money for my girlfriend who lives in Wyandanch, and my eight children. I wanted to buy Christmas presents."
Mr. Norman said he entered the bank at 10:10 A.M. "I scanned the tellers quickly and decided to rob the one closest to the door," he said. "I gave her the note and I put the bag on the counter. She got all panicky and froze. I said to her, 'No floor buzzers, no silent alarms and we'll all be O.K.' "
He fled with $1,949, which he stuffed into his pockets. Witnesses saw him board the 10:18 train and told the police, who met it at Wyandanch, where they cornered him in the eighth car of the 12-car train.
"I got panicky and stuck my hand behind my jacket and backed up," he said in his statement. "The next thing I realized I was sitting on this guy's lap. I put my arm around the guy's shoulder and I told the police that I wasn't going anywhere.
"The cops had their guns drawn. I told them I had a gun. The officers told everybody to get off the train. The officers kept asking me to let the guy go and give myself up. I kept telling them: 'No, I'm not going back to jail. If you want me, you're going to have to take men.' "
The hostage, Jerry Maldanado, 32, a computer analyst, later told the police he thought Mr. Norman was about to shoot him.
Mr. Norman eventually let Mr. Maldanado go, and after long talks with police officers, he surrendered.
Detective Sgt. Peter Burker of the Suffolk robbery squad said it was not unusual for a suspect to say he was inspired to commit a crime by a movie or television program.
"Once or twice every five or six years it happens," Detective Burker said. "But they've been making movies about bank robberies for years. I don't blame the TV show for this robbery."
Dr. Naftali G. Berrill, a professor of forensic psychology at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice in Manhattan, said studies over the last 20 years have shown that violence on television and in movies can amplify impressions in the minds of children, but, he said, it is rare when it causes an adult to act out something he sees on television.
"There would have to be a defect in an adult's judgment or character to act out a fictional fantasy," he said. "The vast population of adults has the ability and intelligence to differentiate between fantasy and reality."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Anthony Norman, who is accused of robbing a bank, fleeing by train and taking a hostage, was escorted to court yesterday by a police officer. (Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Council Vows Defeat of Giuliani's Superstore Plan

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
City Council leaders declared yesterday that they would defeat Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan to make it easier for superstores to open in the city, dealing a bitter blow to his most ambitious effort to eliminate regulations that he said discouraged investment in New York.
On the eve of the Council's vote on the plan, the Mayor, who has repeatedly said that his proposed zoning changes were vital for the city's continued economic revitalization, harshly criticized the Council's position, saying it was tantamount to a vote against the poor. Those people, he said, stand to benefit the most from the broader selection and lower prices that superstores offer. 
 The superstore plan, which would have allowed an estimated 57 of the giant warehouse-style stores to open in industrial areas, has been an extremely contentious issue in many neighborhoods where local merchants feared that the stores would put them out of business.
But the biggest issue in the failed negotiations with the City Council was a provision in the plan that would have eliminated neighborhood review of the store proposals and removed the Council from the approval process.
The expected defeat does not mean that superstores will not be built in New York; in fact, several have opened in Brooklyn and Queens in the last few years. But without the Mayor's proposed zoning changes, the stores could not open nearly so fast nor in the numbers that the Mayor had wanted.
"The vote against it would be a vote for maintaining the high prices that exist in the city of New York," Mr. Giuliani said. "The City Council is seeking to preserve the status quo, which is harm and injury to people of moderate and low incomes."
Despite the Council's expected vote, Peter F. Vallone, its Speaker, said it was prepared to discuss another plan for attracting more superstores to the city.
"The only thing dead on the issue of megastores is the Mayor's proposal to keep the public's voice completely out of the process," he said.
Responding to the Mayor's accusations that the Council's rejection would hurt the poor, Mr. Vallone said: "His gutter-level rhetoric does not deserve a response. They are simply a smokescreen used to obscure the real issues over public review and treating all superstores equally."
Council leaders have suggested that the administration and the Council jointly propose a scaled-down version of the Mayor's plan next year. But the Mayor said that chances for such a plan were slim.
Mr. Giuliani said he had already agreed to substantial compromises and refused to whittle down his plan any more, adding that the Council's proposals ultimately would not create so many jobs or lower prices so much as he had predicted.
"To allow this debate to continue for another five or six months would have this proposal virtually disappear as anything that really helps someone," he said. "There are times in which it is better not to create the illusion of reform than to go along with being asked for too much."
Mr. Giuliani said he never considered withdrawing his proposal, as the Council repeatedly urged him to do. "This is the time to make your decision on this," he said, "and I'd like it clear as to where and how this plan was rejected."
But even though this plan, which the city's Planning Department started working on when David N. Dinkins was Mayor, will probably not be revived soon, planning officials said they would consider other ways to help encourage retail development in the city.
"This administration will continue to fight for opportunities to bring retail stores into the city of New York," said Joseph B. Rose, director of City Planning. "We're not going to give up on the effort to do that."
Mr. Rose would not elaborate on what other methods could be used, but many megastores have opened across the city by finding large sites in commercial zones, where they are not prohibited, or by taking advantage of loopholes in the existing zoning law. Home Depot, for example, has opened stores in manufacturing areas by calling them hardware stores, a kind of store that is permitted in industrial zones.
Proponents for the Mayor's plan said they were disappointed by the Council's intended vote.
"Had the Mayor's bill gone through, I think it's obvious you would have seen economic activity as a result of it," said Jesse Masyr, a lawyer who has represented megastores like Kmart, Home Depot and Price-Costco.
Kathy Goldman, executive director of the Community Food Resource Center, said that while the Mayor's plan would have encouraged discount retailers and other superstores to open in the city, its biggest benefit would have been an increase in large-scale supermarkets.
Chains like Pathmark and Waldbaum's tend to open stores as large as 60,000 square feet, much larger than the typical New York supermarket's 10,000 square feet.
"Rejecting the Mayor's proposal is a disaster for the city," she said. "There's no question that modern supermarkets would have made a major difference for poor people and for most people who don't have access to these stores."
But Richard Lipsky, a lobbyist for small-business owners and supermarket operators, disputed her arguments and those of the Mayor that existing supermarkets were overpriced and served New Yorkers poorly. "Food stores in low-income neighborhoods are as competitive as national chains in the same markets," he said.
Even with the Council's vote, superstores will probably continue to be a controversial topic throughout next year's mayoral campaign. As the Council debated the issue last month, Ruth W. Messinger, Manhattan's Borough President and a likely mayoral candidate, ran radio commercials condemning the plan, and Mr. Giuliani immediately responded with his own ads.
Ms. Messinger yesterday attributed the defeat of the Mayor's plan to what she described as his bad-faith negotiations with the Council.
"The Mayor lost a great opportunity to advance the interests of New Yorkers as consumers, without denying them their rights as citizens," she said. "But then, neither negotiation nor compromise has ever been his strong suit."
Officials estimated that the Mayor's proposal would have brought in 57 new superstores in the next 10 years. Stores of up to 200,000 square feet -- roughly the size of four football fields -- would have been allowed to open in certain industrial areas "as of right," which means without public review or Council approval.
The Council, in turn, had proposed a plan that would have reduced the estimated number of stores to about 25 and would have limited stores to no more than 125,000 square feet.
The Mayor had agreed to lower the size limit to 140,000 square feet, but Mr. Rose said that the administration could not agree to other Council recommendations.
Mr. Rose said that the Council's plan would have eliminated about 70 percent of the land area the Mayor had proposed.
He also said it included unreasonable restrictions that would have made it "virtually impossible to build in Brooklyn" and would have prohibited sites near elevated subways, thus making the stores inaccessible to mass transit.

HEADLINE: Controlling the Risks of Plutonium

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is taking a reasonable if controversial approach toward solving a worrisome problem caused by the dismantling of nuclear weapons in Russia and the United States -- how to get rid of thousands of plutonium "pits" from the warheads that are rapidly accumulating in each country. America will need to dispose of more than 50 tons of excess plutonium. Russia has an even greater stockpile. Until these softball-shaped nuclear cores, now under guard at selected sites in each country, are somehow neutralized, they pose a double threat. Either nation could reverse the course of disarmament and stick the plutonium right back into new weapons. Or thieves, especially in economically distressed Russia, might steal some pits for use in bombs by terrorists or renegade nations.
The Administration has been reviewing dozens of possible solutions, ranging from firing the plutonium into space to burying it in holes so deep as to make the material virtually irretrievable. This week the Energy Department announced two preferred alternatives that will be explored more thoroughly in a "dual-track" approach over the next two years. One approach is to mix the plutonium with highly radioactive nuclear wastes and vitrify the material into glass or ceramic logs, making it difficult, costly and dangerous to extract the plutonium. The other approach is to convert the plutonium into a mixed-oxide fuel that can be burned in nuclear power reactors, a process that leaves a form of spent fuel that is also difficult, costly and dangerous to reprocess. 
 The department's announcement ignited fierce opposition from some private anti-nuclear groups that see an unwarranted retreat from a two-decade-old American policy against the use of plutonium in civilian reactors. That policy was designed to discourage widespread trafficking in plutonium lest it fall into the hands of rogue bomb makers. The critical groups believe that the United States should pursue only a single approach, mixing the plutonium with wastes in molten glass for ultimate burial. They oppose the creation of any fuel-fabrication plants in Russia or America that would create long-term momentum toward a plutonium fuel cycle. They urge Washington to send a strong signal to the rest of the world that plutonium should be treated as a dangerous waste, not a valuable fuel.
But this is a complex and difficult issue for which there is no perfect answer. Indeed, many arms-control experts and groups that were architects of the longstanding American policy against plutonium as a reactor fuel now favor the Energy Department's dual approach. They argue, persuasively, that the risks can be controlled and that the goal of getting rid of surplus warhead material in Russia, which refuses to bury its own plutonium in the form of waste, is of overriding importance.
The rationale for pursuing the dual-track approach is partly technical, to provide insurance in case one approach or the other fails to pan out. But it is also based on diplomatic considerations of how best to influence the Russians. Leaders of the Russian nuclear establishment regard their plutonium as a national energy resource and are adamantly opposed to burying it as waste. There is a real danger that they will either sit on the plutonium indefinitely, leaving it vulnerable to theft or reconstitution into weapons, or will turn it into reactor fuel with the help of European nations that are dedicated to spreading plutonium technology and not much worried about the bomb-making implications. The best way to insure that the Russians handle their plutonium responsibly may be to pursue a parallel and cooperative approach with them.
But before venturing too far down this path, the Administration needs to build in adequate protections. The United States must make it clear that using reactors to rid the world of loose military warheads does not signal an end to American opposition to a plutonium fuel cycle for power reactors. That historic opposition is aimed at preventing the creation of separated plutonium that could be used in weapons. But in this case, the warhead plutonium is already separated and could easily be made into weapons. The urgent task is to neutralize it.
The United States should insist that the Russians burn off their separated warhead material before pursuing their quixotic dream of creating even more separated plutonium for reactor fuel. America should also encourage, and perhaps help to finance, a demonstration plant for vitrification in Russia and explore the feasibility of buying some of the Russian plutonium for disposal as waste. It will take a good two decades or more to get rid of the surplus military plutonium in each country. There is time to fine-tune the approaches.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Academic Freedom Is Key to Foreign Funds;
Korea Fund's Goals

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re your Dec. 9 front-page article: As chairman of the Korea Society, a nonprofit organization that has received support from the Korea Foundation for the past four years, I wish to report that we have been under no pressure whatsoever from that organization with regard to the programs we have conducted or the views we have expressed.
From the outset, the aim of the Korea Foundation appears to have been to increase American awareness and understanding of modern Korea, its culture and traditions. 
 Similar motives have been behind the Korea Foundation's support of Korean studies at several of America's leading universities where little or nothing about Korea had been taught previously. The effect of the Korean Foundation's efforts has been healthy. More about Korea is now being taught, and more young American scholars are entering that field. Results will include better scholarship and better American understanding of a dynamic new economic power in Asia.
 
DONALD P. GREGG
New York, Dec. 9, 1996

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Worries on Securities Prices Send Dollar Falling vs. Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended lower against most leading currencies yesterday, hurt by a selloff on Wall Street that reflected anxieties about a possible pullback by foreign investors from American securities. Further hurting the dollar was a suggestion that German interest rates would remain steady and a little more uncertainty about the planned European single currency.
But traders said the main force at work in the currency market was the direction of United States stock and bond prices, which fell when trading opened. The Dow Jones average ended with a 70-point loss, and bond declines pushed long-term yields to the highest level in a month. 
 "I think the dollar's decline is directly related to our asset markets, and foreign capital leaving," said Talbott Young, vice president for foreign exchange at the Signet Banking Corporation in Richmond.
Late in New York yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.5376 German marks from 1.5505 marks on Tuesday and to 112.97 Japanese yen from 113.41. The British pound traded at $1.6515, down from $1.6537.
Currency dealers have been largely focused on the American securities markets since Friday, when they plunged after comments by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, asking if Wall Street's run-up reflected "irrational exuberance."
Mr. Greenspan's remarks have continued to haunt a sharply up-and-down market since then. Traders said the anxieties were compounded by an article yesterday in The Wall Street Journal raising the possibility of a drop in Treasury bond prices in the event of a selloff by Japanese investors, the main foreign purchasers. Falling bond prices would diminish the demand for dollars.
The mark derived further strength yesterday after Ernst Welteke, a member of the policy council of the Bundesbank, said in a German on-line business weekly that he saw no immediate reason for a cut in German interest rates.
Also helping the mark was Peter Schmidhuber, another member of the council, who said the European single currency should be delayed if a "critical mass" of countries failed to meet the strict fiscal criteria. Any suggestion of a delay in the currency tends to help the mark, Europe's currency of choice.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
To Concentrate Milosevic's Mind

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
Two snapshots of the crisis over Slobodan Milosevic's tyranny:
In Belgrade, one of the thousands of peaceful demonstrators, Dejan Bulatovic, held up an effigy of President Milosevic as a convict. Police arrested him, beat him with clubs, jammed a baton up his rectum, put a rifle in his mouth and threatened to shoot, then put him in an unheated cell with the window fixed open to serve a 25-day sentence for disorderly conduct. 
 In Brussels, the North Atlantic Council said it was "dismayed that the Serbian authorities have ignored the calls of the international community to respect . . . democratic principles." Secretary of State Warren Christopher said he hoped Mr. Milosevic would be as "pragmatic and flexible" as he was at the Dayton peace conference last year.
Those two scenes tell us that the United States and its allies still do not understand the menace of Mr. Milosevic -- or do not want to understand. He makes clear that he has no intention of giving up a gram of his illegitimate power and we go harrumph.
Mr. Milosevic has been playing games, with his own people and the world, over his brazen annulling of opposition victories in Serbian municipal elections. He hinted that he would restore the real results. He told a foreign visitor that he would respect what the Serbian supreme court decided about the issue. Then his stooges on the court upheld his cooking of the elections.
The British Ambassador in Belgrade, Ivor Roberts, allowed himself to be diddled by Mr. Milosevic. He tried to be an intermediary between the Serbian President and the opposition. Mr. Milosevic signaled that he would play, then spurned the Ambassador's efforts at compromise.
By now anyone should see that Mr. Milosevic is not interested in compromise when it comes to his power. He is a classic dictator, reluctant to yield even a little to democracy and the rule of law because he fears his whole network of corruption and intimidation would unravel.
Rigidity has its dangers. Nicolae Ceausescu rejected any change in his Communist dictatorship of Romania until a popular revolution ended in his execution.
Like Ceausescu, too, it appears, Mr. Milosevic is out of touch with reality. Reports from Serbia say that he has no sense of the resentment against him in a country where there is 50 percent unemployment and per capita income has fallen by more than half in the years of his rule.
The U.S. State Department, to its credit, has lately taken a tougher line on Mr. Milosevic. When he shut down the independent radio station B-92, the Voice of America took the bold step of broadcasting B-92's reports. Faced with an effective counter-measure, Mr. Milosevic let B-92 go back on the air.
Nicholas Burns, the State Department spokesman, said: "We don't share the conventional wisdom that somehow we need Milosevic more than he needs us." But those strong words do not seem to be reflected in policy: ours or our allies'.
We still treat Mr. Milosevic as a guarantor of peace in Bosnia. He was crucial at Dayton. But we have to understand that his motive there, after the failure of the genocidal war he instigated, was simply to stay in power. He is not at all a key to maintaining the peace now.
What, then, can we do to end a tyranny that could destabilize the Balkans? The first thing is to make clear that we are not going back to Milosevic as usual. That means ending the pretense that he is to be valued as a peacemaker. It means making fundamental political change in Serbia our public, committed objective.
Even more important is getting serious, at last, about war crimes. The North Atlantic Council has just ended another meeting without changing the cynical mandate of international forces in Bosnia: to arrest suspects only if our soldiers happen upon them.
Mr. Milosevic was named as a possible war criminal himself in 1992 by Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger, who said we had information on the chain of military and political responsibility for the savageries committed in Bosnia. The arrest of some indicted war criminals could concentrate Mr. Milosevic's mind wonderfully.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Tainted by Corruption, Colombian President Is Ceding Power

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Six months after the Colombian Congress absolved President Ernesto Samper of charges that drug dealers pumped $6 million into his election campaign, the travails of the President and this country of 36 million have grown only more desperate.
Still stigmatized by the corruption charges and with little power or credibility, Mr. Samper appears to have surrendered much of his mandate to the sectors and politicians whose support he has had to rely on to stay in office. As a result, his presidency seems paralyzed. 
 Business leaders fret that the State Department, in its annual review in March of global anti-narcotics efforts, will again find that Colombia has not done enough to fight drugs, and that this time Washington will impose economic sanctions rather than giving Colombia a waiver.
Exporters, most notably in the flower industry, which provides one-fifth of the cut flowers sold in the United States, complain of shipments being held up at entry points in what they suspect is one of Washington's ways of showing its disapproval of Mr. Samper's rule.
An economic recession has increased unemployment by 50 percent over the past year, to figures ranging from 12.4 percent to 18.6 percent. And the arrest of 12 union leaders accused of terrorism threatens to trigger a strike that could shut down pipelines carrying the oil that has become this country's biggest legal source of income.
"The important thing is to apply the law," Luis Carlos Villegas, the president of the National Association of Industrialists, said in an interview Sunday in El Tiempo, a Bogota daily. "Here there is a law of the guerrilla, a law of the drug trafficker, a law of some sectors of government, a law of the delinquent and a law of the jungle. And this has to stop."
The alarm among business leaders is matched by bitterness in the armed forces -- a potentially explosive combination given the vacuum in political authority. Though the military has traditionally not sought to usurp political power, thriving instead as a parallel authority, military leaders have grown increasingly impatient with allegations of human rights violations, and complain of an "attorney general syndrome," a fear that soldiers will be called to account for actions in the field.
The military is particularly irritated by the arrest of a general, Faruk Yanine, on charges that he formed paramilitary groups and took part in the execution of 19 shopkeepers in the central Magdalena region. Though the case against General Yanine is backed by incriminating videotapes, he enjoys the support of Gen. Harold Bedoya, chief of the armed forces.
Paramilitary death squads have assassinated nearly 100 people whom they accused of being leftist guerrillas or sympathizers. Last weekend alone, 17 people, many found with their hands tied behind their backs, were killed this way.
The military has also been upset with the President's decision to order the armed forces to withdraw from 5,600 square miles in southern Colombia, ostensibly to allow leftist guerrillas to surrender 60 soldiers held as prisoners of war.
Landowners are no happier. Several weeks ago, at the annual meeting of the Colombian Society of Farmers, its president lectured a symbolic empty seat to dramatize Mr. Samper's lack of leadership in agricultural policy. In a debate later that day, the governor of Antioquia state, Alvaro Uribe Velez, argued for arming the rural equivalent of the auxiliary police, who ostensibly are to rather intelligence, with long-range weapons and machine guns.
The landowners applauded the proposal.

HEADLINE: U.S. Ex-General Lavish in Praising Mexican Allies in Drug War

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 11

 BODY:
In his nine months as director of national drug control policy, Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey has used broad praise to try to improve the diplomatic cooperation between the United States and Mexico in the war against drugs.
But at the close today of the third meeting this year between narcotics officials of both countries, it remained unclear whether any substantive gains have accompanied the retired Army general's approach. 
 General McCaffrey's determination to improve relations has made him many friends among Mexico's senior officials, partly because he has been unsparing and sometimes even extravagant in his praise. After a meeting in March with Antonio Lozano, then Mexico's Attorney General, General McCaffrey said Mr. Lozano was "a man of tremendous courage and integrity."
In the same speech, he extolled President Ernesto Zedillo, as "a brilliant, patriotic, dedicated man," and then offered a pledge unusual for an American: "I would like to publicly announce that I view myself not only as a public servant of President Clinton, but place myself in that same responsiblity to President Zedillo."
If General McCaffrey sounded enthusiastic, several working-level American narcotics agents have been less so. In recent interviews, many have said they have seen little or no improvement in practical cooperation between the two countries on drug matters.
Among an array of other problems, corruption among low-paid Mexican police officers, and the Mexican Government's unwillingness to support antidrug operations with more resources, continue as major irritants. A recent study by the United States General Accounting Office also drew dismal conclusions about bilateral anti-narcotics efforts in Mexico.
But General McCaffrey today defended the two countries' progress, and he said the meetings held here since Sunday amounted to more than self-congratulations.
"It wasn't just love-ins," General McCaffrey said. "We're trying to build stuff that's real. We're going to do training, evidence, intelligence, equipment. We're going to do real stuff. In nine months, have we moved the ball forward? Absolutely!"
He cited as examples Mexico's recent approval of legislation aimed at combatting organized crime, cracking down on money laundering and controlling chemicals used to make methamphetamines. But his assessment contrasted with the findings of a General Accounting Office study released in June.
"U.S. and Mexican interdiction efforts have had little, if any, impact on the overall flow of drugs through Mexico to the United States," it said. "The amount of cocaine seized and the number of drug-related arrests in Mexico have declined. The current Government of Mexico appears committed to fighting drug trafficking, but, according to United States officials, its efforts are hampered by pervasive corruption of key institutions, economic and political problems, and limited counternarcotics and law enforcement capabilities."
There were problems with continuity at this meeting, since President Zedillo earlier this month summarily dismissed Mr. Lozano and most of his top aides for incompetence, including most of the antidrug officials with whom General McCaffrey had previously worked.
After his first encounters with the new Mexican Attorney General, Jorge Madrazo, and the new Mexican anti-drug coordinator, Gen. Jose Gutierrez Rebollo, General McCaffrey offered his initial assessment:
"My own view, categorically, is that the first factor affecting both of them is integrity. These are patriotic, honest, dedicated men."

HEADLINE: Another Sign Fed May Not Raise Rates

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Except for a surge in energy prices, inflation at the producer level remained benign in November, more reassurance that Federal Reserve policy makers will likely find no need to raise interest rates at their final 1996 meeting next week.
The Labor Department's report on the Producer Price Index showed today that prices of finished goods climbed four-tenths of 1 percent for the second consecutive month, but the bulk of the increase reflected higher energy prices that have already begun to subside and could fall further with the resumption of limited oil exports from Iraq. 
 Producer prices are the prices that manufacturers and farmers charge for the products they sell to retailers, distributors or other buyers. Economists focused on the performance of the so-called core of the index -- which excludes the energy and food components because of their volatility -- and saw little cause for concern about accelerating inflation. They said that the report contributed only slightly, if at all, to today's swoon in stocks and bonds.
"The underlying story on producer price inflation remains quite favorable," said Sherry Cooper, chief economist at Nesbitt Burns Securities.
The core Producer Price Index rose just one-tenth of 1 percent in November and a remarkably low six-tenths of 1 percent for the latest 12 months, the department reported.
And prices were contained not only at the finished level -- goods ready for sale to the ultimate consumer or business user -- but at the intermediate and crude stages as well.
"When you strip out the crude, intermediate and finished-level energy increases, you find prices behaving themselves quite nicely at all three stages of processing," said Ron Schreibman, vice president of the National Association of Wholesaler-Distributors, a trade group.
A 2.3 percent jump in the price of energy dominated today's report, with residential gas rising 3.8 percent after showing no change in October and gasoline up 2.8 percent, a significant advance though only half its increase in October.
But food, which has shown hefty increases of late, edged down one-tenth of 1 percent last month, the first decline since April. Prices for dairy products tumbled 4.5 percent and fresh fruits and melons also fell; analysts pointed to good harvests that should keep food prices contained following run-ups earlier in the year. Prices for fresh and dry vegetables, though, soared 16.6 percent in November.
Among intermediate goods, such as sacks of cement, prices inched up two-tenths of 1 percent last month -- one-tenth of 1 percent for goods other than food and energy.
Durable items used in manufacturing advanced four-tenths of 1 percent, reversing an October decline of that size, as the rise in the closely watched prices for copper accelerated to 7.1 percent and various kinds of steel turned higher.
Nondurable goods used in factories edged up one-tenth of 1 percent, with paperboard up 1 percent after falling that much in October and basic organic chemicals also turning up.

HEADLINE: Learning to Love Superstores

BYLINE: By Susan Shapiro; Susan Shapiro, a book critic, is the author of "The Male-to-Female Dictionary."

 BODY:
Growing up as a mall rat in suburban Michigan, I spent long afternoons at the Tel-12 mall, shopping at the cool clothes boutiques and music emporiums. But I always ignored the Kmart. What good was anything so cheap and generic? My beloved Aunt Ettie shopped there, but only because she'd get great discounts on huge Hershey bars and cartons of Chesterfields.
After college I moved to downtown Manhattan. My first day I sat on a bench in Washington Square Park, mesmerized by all the black-clad artists and long-haired guitarists playing Bob Dylan songs. I thought, "Why had my New York-born and bred parents cursed me by moving, before my birth, to the big and bland Middle West?" 
 I swore I'd die in Manhattan, preferably below 14th Street. So imagine my dismay this fall, when I looked out of my fifth-floor apartment on Eighth Street and saw two big red K's for the first time. The new Kmart store took up a whole block. I hated it, and complained as if it was the country's most pressing political issue: Artistic culture marred by crass mass-market materialism. Was Mayor Giuliani trying to turn this beautiful mosaic of a city into a vulgar mall of superstores? A Kmart in Greenwich Village was like McDonald's on the Champs-Elysees.
For weeks, I avoided the store, hoping it would go away. Then, over a quiet Thanksgiving weekend, I ran out to get a caffeine-free Diet Coke. Both delis that usually carried it were out. I walked by Kmart's glass windows, and decided to confront my past along the way. I entered the store slowly, like a tourist who didn't speak the language.
It was huge, clean and virtually empty. On the first floor, I saw inexpensive makeup and clothes in primary colors. Aha! Just what I'd expected: Middle America was invading! I went downstairs. Aisles of brand-name products. But no crowds, no lines. Several rows of uniformed employees, smiling and saying, "How are you today?"
A six-pack of my diet soda, which cost more than $5 at the tiny, charming Indian-owned deli, cost $2.89 at Kmart. Cookies, napkins, a six-pack of toilet paper, everything was in the 89-cent range. For my $10 bill, I got six items, a free bottle of mouthwash and even change. Maybe this was what the Mayor meant when he defended superstores as vital for the city's economic revitalization.
This Kmart was different from the one from my childhood. It was three floors, not one low-rise box. No huge parking lot. I was different, too. Now I was the one paying. After 15 years of watching my money being eaten up by overpriced little stores at every corner, it was refreshing to find so many millions of things I could easily afford. Exciting even.
For a second I saw the store though my parents' eyes. Forty years earlier they couldn't wait to leave Delancey Street, a dozen blocks from where I'd settled in the East Village. ("It's the Lower East Side," My father screamed when I told him where I lived. "The realtors are lying.") The Midwest in the 1950's must have seemed spacious to them. Inviting, affordable. Easy to raise a family. With nothing of their old New York in sight.

HEADLINE: In Jockeying to Lead U.N., Ghanaian Is Moving Ahead

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 11

 BODY:
Kofi Annan, the Ghanaian in charge of United Nations peacekeeping operations, emerged the clear leader today in the race for a new Secretary General. But even as his support was solidifying, there were indications that France, which has veto power, would deny him the job.
With barely three weeks to go until Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali's term expires on Dec. 31, the contest has begun to turn almost entirely on big-power politics, with the qualifications and personalities of candidates for the high-profile job relegated to virtual irrelevance. 
 Diplomats familiar with the negotiations among the 15 members of the Security Council say the French, still annoyed at the United States for its veto on a second term for Mr. Boutros-Ghali, do not want the Americans replace him with an English-speaking candidate.
The French are also distressed by informal American and British votes against three other candidates, all from French-speaking countries. No formal vote has been scheduled since Nov. 19, when the United States vetoed Mr. Boutros-Ghali.
The Security Council conducted straw polls today for the second day. After three rounds, in which each member was asked to "encourage" or "discourage" a candidacy, Mr. Annan had settled into a comfortable lead, with 11 positive votes and 4 negative. But one negative vote was from France, which as a permanent member has veto power. A candidate needs nine votes (with no vetoes) to win Security Council approval; the General Assembly formally elects the Secretary General.
Amara Essy, Foreign Minister of the Ivory Coast, remained in second place, but his yes votes had dropped to six, with four countries opposed (including the United States and Britain, both holding vetoes) and four abstaining. Two other candidates, Hamid Algabid of Niger and Ahmedou Ould Abdallah of Mauritania, lost more ground, diplomats said. But they are still in the race, along with Mr. Boutros-Ghali.
Security Council members have promised to consider African candidates first because Africa, following an informal tradition, wants to keep the position of Secretary General in its region for two terms.
Suggestions that some council members, including the United States and Britain, will soon be ready to start looking outside Africa are dismissed by other diplomats, who say China, which portrays itself as a champion of third-world countries, may be prepared to use its veto to block any non-African candidate.
China has so far stayed largely on the sidelines, although it effectively ended the candidacy of Senegal's Foreign Minister, Moustapha Niasse, because Senegal has ties with Taiwan.
France has indicated that it would prevent any serious consideration of a Tanzanian, Salim A. Salim, who was about to be nominated by President Nelson Mandela of South Africa. Mr. Salim, Secretary General of the Organization of African Unity, does not speak French. He has been vetoed repeatedly by the United States in the past, primarily because he led the campaign to have Taiwan evicted from China's United Nations seat in the early 1970's.
Several other Africans are assumed to be viable candidates if needed. First among them is Olara A. Otunnu, a Ugandan-born citizen of the Ivory Coast who is president of the International Peace Academy, an independent conflict-resolution organization in New York, and has many supporters. He has not been nominated, but diplomats are beginning to say he could become a compromise candidate. Lakhdar Brahimi, an Algerian, and James Jonah of Sierra Leone -- both with diplomatic and United Nations experience -- are mentioned as long shots.
A few delegations, including Russia, according to some diplomats, continue to nurture hopes that a deadlock will reopen the possibility of keeping Mr. Boutros-Ghali in office for another year or two. The United States dismisses such hopes at every opportunity.
There is some urgency to the selection process: the General Assembly is to adjourn its current session on Tuesday.

GRAPHIC: Chart/Photos: "SNAPSHOTS: In the World Arena, Five Antagonists"
 
KOFI ANNAN, 58, of Ghana, has been a career United Nations official since 1962, when he became an administrative officer at the World Health Organization in Geneva. He took a break in 1974-1976 to return to Ghana to take charge of its tourism development, but his long absence from Africa has made him a stranger to many from his home continent. But Mr. Annan, who is now Under Secretary General for peacekeeping operations, enjoys considerable popularity in the United Nations. The perception that he is an American or Western candidate has hurt him somewhat, particularly in French-speaking nations, although he speaks French well. He has a B.A. in economics from Macalester College in St. Paul, Minn., and a masters degree in management from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He also studied at the Institute Universitaire de Hautes Etudes Internationales in Geneva.
 
AMARA ESSY, 51, is Foreign Minister of the Ivory Coast, and the candidate most actively being promoted by France, which has close ties to his country. Now Foreign Minister, Mr. Essy has been a diplomat since 1971, serving in Europe, Latin America and New York. He recently began to undertake diplomatic efforts in Africa, helping to bring about a cease-fire in Sierre Leone and perhaps burnishing his image as a pan-African figure at a time when Africans are having difficulty uniting around one candidate for Secretary General. A lawyer with degrees from Abidjan University in the Ivory Coast and Poitiers University in France, Mr. Essy served as president of the United Nations General Assembly two years ago.
 
AHMEDOU OULD ABDALLAH, 55, was a government minister in Mauritania, a diplomat and for two years, from 1993 to 1995, the representative of the United Nations Secretary General in Burundi, where he won praise from diplomats for his handling of a volatile political situation. A critic of Mr. Boutros-Ghali's administration, he left the United Nations last year to become executive secretary of the Coalition for Africa, an economic and political development forum in Washington, D.C., where he was once Mauritania's ambassador. He got his undergraduate degree from Grenoble University in France and a masters from the University of Paris.
 
HAMID ALGABID, 55, was Prime Minister of Niger from 1983 to 1988 and is now secretary general of the Islamic Conference, a position that has given him high visibility in the Muslim world. But he is perhaps least well known in New York of all the candidates. His government background is in commerce and finance. He holds a doctorate in law from the University of Paris.
 
OLARA A. OTUNNU, 46, was born in Uganda and was a diplomat and government minister there, but renounced his citizenship a decade ago and became a citizen of the Ivory Coast. He is president of the International Peace Academy in New York, a study center devoted to conflict resolution and peacemaking. Mr. Otunnu has a wide circle of unofficial supporters and is thought of as a potential compromise candidate, with one foot in the Francophone world and the other in English-speaking circles, if the stalemate between France and the United States continues. A lawyer who has practiced with the New York firm of Chadbourne and Park and taught at Albany University, Mr. Otunnu was educated at Makerere University in Kampala, before going to Oxford University as an Overseas Scholar to study jurisprudence. He later studied law at Harvard, where he was a Fulbright Scholar.

HEADLINE: Tinkering With Europe

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration is barreling toward an eastward expansion of NATO by the end of the decade without adequate discussion with the American people and Congress. Though the issue seems remote and abstract to many citizens, and tends to come larded with the highfalutin terminology of the foreign-policy priesthood, it is exceedingly important. NATO expansion would involve a crucial political and military realignment of Europe, the continent still most directly linked to the national security of the United States. The consequences are likely to be great and unpredictable.
Propelled by American leadership, NATO this week essentially committed itself to expansion. President Clinton and leaders of the other NATO members will meet next July in Madrid to issue an invitation to Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic, plus possibly one or two other Central European countries, but that is now a formality. The White House hopes enlargement can be consummated by 1999, the 50th anniversary of the alliance. 
 NATO expansion, among other things, would commit American conventional and nuclear forces to the defense of newly independent European nations and require the costly modernization of their armed services. It would also move the alliance's boundaries considerably closer to Russia, a step sure to strengthen nationalists and Communists in an insecure country still traumatized by two German invasions this century.
Fortunately, as part of an international treaty, none of this can happen without the approval of a two-thirds majority in the Senate, as well as the endorsement of the parliaments of the alliance's 15 European members. There is still time for Americans and their representatives in Congress to consider the implications of NATO expansion and to slow the stampede until the potential consequences can be more carefully considered and the need for enlargement more clearly demonstrated.
The Administration has dressed up its plans with rhetoric about consolidating democracy and free markets in the lands of the former Soviet empire, but it has yet to make a good case why a cold-war military alliance, rather than the European Union, is the best way to secure those aims.
The more credible case for expansion rests on more practical principles, namely maintaining a strong American leadership role in Europe and preserving an alliance that could defend against an aggressive and militarily resurgent Russia in the future. The Russian threat, still painfully familiar in Eastern Europe, is the visceral and understandable reason countries like Poland and Hungary seek sanctuary in NATO.
But planning the future of Europe with the blueprints from the cold war is a mistake. With a shattered, impoverished military and faltering economy, Russia presents no military threat to its neighbors now and will not for years to come. The prospect of NATO expansion, if anything, is likely to push Moscow toward precisely the kind of rearmament the West fears. Diverting money and resources back to defense is just what the Russian economy does not need as it struggles to shake off decades of deadening Communist management.
By anchoring NATO expansion on the needs of Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic, as important as those countries are, the Administration has obscured the most important issue for European peace and prosperity. That issue is the consolidation of reform in Russia. The timing, shape and even need for NATO expansion should be determined by how much it helps or hinders Russia's reform. Washington has not given nearly enough attention to that question.
Responsible Russian leaders, anxious to avoid the potentially destructive domestic consequences of NATO expansion, are now talking less about trying to block enlargement than modifying it in ways that do not upset the political and economic balance in Russia. Yevgeny Primakov, the Russian Foreign Minister, told his NATO counterparts this week that Moscow, for starters, wants guarantees that NATO nuclear forces will not be stationed in Eastern Europe and assurance that Russia will have a working partnership with the alliance.
These overtures, which the Administration welcomed, will require careful study and hard negotiation. They are just the kinds of issues Americans should be weighing in the months ahead. The debate should not be driven by artificial deadlines and a manufactured sense of urgency. Tinkering with the balance of power on a continent that has been the site of so much conflict and violence should be done with great caution and a strong sense of humility.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: From Dayton to Sarajevo: Spirit of Giving and Eye for Deals

BYLINE: By MIKE O'CONNOR 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Dec. 11

 BODY:
On one of the dreariest days so far of this Balkan winter, when only half the city at a time has natural gas for heating, and drinking water comes intermittently, the people from Dayton, Ohio, hit Sarajevo bearing stuffed animals and offers of help and, in some cases, keeping an eye out for commercial opportunities.
There are 35 of them, from a Midwestern city that did not know much about Bosnia, and was itself unknown here until a year ago when it made history as the place where the peace treaty that stopped the war here was negotiated. The delegation from Dayton came to see how the peace was faring, and whether they could be of help. "We can show people here we care about them," said Pat Carter, a retired accountant. "Maybe that will help them care for each other again." 
 Just before they arrived on Monday on a four-day visit, a European diplomat said that the peace agreement was holding only because NATO troops will not let local armies fight.
That might be the big picture, but the visitors from Dayton are focused on other things. Speaking of sponsoring cultural and educational exchanges, Dayton's Mayor, Michael Turner, said, "We want to be a friend."
It would an unusual friendship. Sarajevo, though now smashed by war, has been a center where the strains of various civilizations have competed or merged for more than eight centuries. But there are mutual interests nonetheless. Residents of Sarajevo believe the future of their country depends on economic and technical assistance from the West. And so does Dayton. The visitors decided it was time to see the place first hand. They brought toys and warm clothes for school children, plans to arrange for student pen pals as well as for contacts between community and professional groups. Mayor Turner said he believed Dayton businesses could win some of the contracts for reconstruction.
"Somebody has got to rebuild Bosnia," he said, "Why not Dayton?"
The Mayor carried with him through the cold a chipper attitude and a 54-page "Dayton-Balkans Business Directory" listing all the companies that could sell products or services to Bosnia.
But Bosnian officials aren't looking for things to buy from America. They want Americans who will invest in businesses here.
After the Mayor explained what goods Dayton could sell, Prime Minister Hasan Muratovic offered details of Bosnian industries seeking investors. "We are willing to sell parts of these businesses at reasonable prices," said Mr. Muratovic.
Undaunted, the Mayor later said his visit was part of a larger effort that he expects will bring six or eight substantial contracts. He said the good will generated by this trip will be important. But good will is not a concept normally found in Balkan business circles.
Even so, other visitors have said they experienced remarkable goodwill. Mrs. Carter, who is in her 60's, slipped on the thick ice that covers most of the city's sidewalks and broke her arm in three places.
Like the 40 other people who slipped and suffered fractures yesterday, Mrs. Carter was taken to a Government hospital, where the staff is partly on strike because they have not been paid since October. Her arm was set without anesthesia, in keeping with current medical standards here.
Still, she was so impressed by the people of Sarajevo that this morning in one of the private houses where the visitors have been staying, she said, "I've never been treated better anywhere."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Drop Sharply; Yield Up to 6.62%

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities dropped sharply yesterday amid concern that the economy was not slowing fast enough and that interest rates could rise if foreign investors slow their buying. And traders kept in the backs of their minds comments last week by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, in which he questioned the high valuation of the stock market.
The 30-year bond fell 1 15/32, to 98 13/32, and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.62 percent from 6.49 on Tuesday. 
 For bond investors, the day's losses amounted to about $14.70 for $1,000 invested.
Traders said the market's weakness nearly matched that of last Thursday, when the dollar tumbled, eroding the attractiveness of bonds to foreign investors. One day later, Mr. Greenspan warned that the stock market might be showing "irrational exuberance," further alarming bond traders, who feared that his comments might have been a signal of an increase in interest rates.
The volume of issues traded yesterday nearly matched that of Thursday and Friday. Yesterday was the fifth day in this quarter that volume has exceeded $100 billion, considered a benchmark of heavy trading.
Treasuries extended overseas losses in bond trading, even after a report showing that the November Producer Price Index was tame, up only four-tenths of a percent, with the core rate, excluding the volatile food and energy prices, up one-tenth of a percent. Economists had expected gains of three-tenths of a percent and two-tenths of a percent, respectively.
Traders said that after the bond market's decline on Tuesday, United States Treasury securities fell in London and Tokyo on fears that the recent increase in purchases by large Japanese investors could slow. The fear may have been generated by an article in The Wall Street Journal that quoted Robert Hormats, the vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, as saying that Japanese buying would slow.
Also pressuring bonds was the continued heavy issuance of corporate debt, as investors sold Treasury securities in favor of corporate paper.
Chase Manhattan yesterday priced $997 million of asset-backed securities. These securities, rated triple-A and backed by autoloans, were offered in various classes and various average lives. A security with an average life of 0.35 of a year was priced to yield 5.489 percent, or seven-hundredths of a percentage point under the London interbank offered rate, while a security with an average life of 3.52 years was priced to yield 6.270 percent, or about 30-hundredths more than than the 5 7/8 percent Treasury note of 2000.
Thomas F. Carpenter, chief economist and managing director at ASB Capital Management in Washington, said he thought that beyond any new information learned by the market yesterday, the primary reason for the drop was continued unease about Mr. Greenspan's comments. He said traders felt "fear of more Federal Reserve officials talking out loud, and the thought that Greenspan & Company may be talking to the Japanese, German, and French central banks suggesting that they also talk tough to their markets in order to cool off investors."
Nonetheless, some important data favor the bond market, Mr. Carpenter said. Iraqi oil is close to reaching the market again, which has had the effect of dropping oil prices about $2 a barrel, he said, implying significantly lower inflation in early 1997.
The Treasury announced the size of next week's auction of notes, which will take place after the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making panel of the Federal Reserve, meets on Tuesday. The Government plans to sell $18.25 billion of two-year notes on Wednesday and $12.5 billion of five-year notes on Thursday.
In when-issued trading late yesterday, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.81 percent and the five-year at a price to yield 6.15 percent.

HEADLINE: Seeking Contract, N.Y.U. Workers Walk Out

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
New York University's clerical and technical workers staged a half-day walkout yesterday that drew several hundred workers and a few of students and other supporters to a rally across from Washington Square Park that later moved to Washington Square Church.
The workers, members of the United Staff Association of N.Y.U., a unit of the American Federation of Teachers, are in the midst of negotiations with the university. Their three-year contract expired on Oct. 31, but talks broke off in mid-October when the union refused the university's request that it drop certain demands to upgrade the status of the union. 
 Trudy Rudnick, an N.Y.U. secretary and president of the union, said that yesterday's walkout was aimed at bringing university officials back to negotiations. "Otherwise we will increase the pressure," she said.
Unlike Barnard's five-month clerical union strike earlier this year, which was over wages and health benefits, the N.Y.U. dispute centers on the union itself.
Ms. Rudnick said that unlike other unions at N.Y.U., the clerical workers do not have a union shop, so workers covered by their contract are not required to join the union or pay union dues. About 1,550 workers are covered by the contract, but only about 900 are union members.
Ms. Rudnick said the union would also like a chance to talk to new workers during their orientation, not two or three months later; the opportunity for union officials to deal with union business during their workday, and some preference given to members in hiring and promotion.
The university has offered an annual raise of 3.5 percent or $18.50 a week, whichever is greater, and 3 percent a year for the next two years. Union members now earn a minimum of $445.50 a week, or $23,166 a year, with the average salary $27,200. Richard Semeraro, director of labor relations at N.Y.U., said the increase is comparable to that given the faculty and other unions.
The union and university say there is general agreement on the economic issues, but that the university has been unwilling to accept the union's noneconomic demands.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Maris Abelson, a graduate student, marched in chains yesterday to dramatize a union demand for a contract. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Closing the 'Doorway to Fame';
Longtime Guide to Broadway Actors Ends Publication

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

 BODY:
Terese Hayden threw open the doors to a dusty office in an old brownstone in Times Square in the 1940's and soon the city's actors were crowding in, clutching their black-and-white portraits and their dreams of making it big.
There was that young Kirk Douglas, fresh from the Navy and with only a few Broadway credits under his belt in 1944. There was that velvet-voiced James Earl Jones (skinny then) and that funny guy Walter Matthau (in a bow tie and tweeds) in the 1950's. There were employed actors and unemployed ones, haughty actors and jittery ones, but they all shared the same goal: getting their photographs into Ms. Hayden's Players' Guide, New York City's annual listing of the pictures and credits of the city's theater performers. 
 The slender volume, which originally appeared in 1944, offered theater and film directors their first one-stop shopping list of local talent. And as the years passed, the guide became a hefty and venerable New York institution, cherished by directors on Broadway and in Hollywood for capturing some of the acting world's most famous faces, its newest faces and the older faces that had slipped from public memory.
"It was the doorway to fame," said Heywood Hale Broun, the 78-year-old retired Broadway actor and sports broadcaster who was plucked from obscurity when a casting director saw him in the guide and cast him in a bit part in the 1993 film "House Sitter," along with Steve Martin and Goldie Hawn.
"If you were in the Players' Guide," he said, "you knew you would always be remembered."
After chronicling the careers of two generations of actors for 52 years, the Players' Guide published its final edition this year. And all across the city, actors, agents and directors are mourning its passing.
"I can't believe it's gone!" said Ellen Chenoweth, a casting director who recruited an actor from the guide for the 1993 film "Six Degrees of Separation." "It was such an institution. I'm so sorry to see one of New York's traditions go by the boards."
In its heyday, the guide introduced newcomers and re-introduced forgotten faces to directors hoping to fill bit parts or minor roles, offering actors the kind of break that might launch a career or jump-start a waning one.
But in recent years, as actors began to create their own videotapes and web sites and as similar directories began to provide photographs and resumes on computerized databases, the guide began to fall from favor. Run by an aging husband and wife team in a tiny office in Times Square, it simply could not compete.
But what it did offer was priceless: a vivid documentary of New York's topsy-turvy acting world.
There, in the volumes of black-and-white snapshots and the lists of credits and agents, is a portrait of the careers that rose and fell, the theaters that opened and closed, the pompadours that gave way to crew cuts and the great migration that swept so many actors from Broadway to Hollywood as New York ceded its role as America's entertainment center to California.
Latin dancers, their shoulders frozen in mid-shimmy, appeared in the 1940's along with the names of those actors who fought in World War II. Mr. Douglas, for instance, proudly noted his "recent honorable discharge from U.S. Navy" right alongside his Broadway credits in 1944.
And in the 1950's, the guide carried the plea of black actors who longed for serious roles on Broadway, not just bit parts as singers, servants or cooks. "Just as in American life, the Negro citizen's role now extends from the kitchen to the United Nations," the Coordinating Council of Negro Performers reminded the city's theater directors in 1954.
John Lyons, the casting director who discovered Mr. Broun in the directory, said: "The guide was a window into what the theater community had been. It was a real link to that kind of old-time Broadway community that is disappearing."
It was born in the 1940's, when soldiers were crawling through World War II trenches abroad and the Government was rationing beef at home. "Oklahoma!" was on its way to becoming the longest-running musical on Broadway, and Times Square was filled with neon and glamour and performers dreaming of that big break.
In London, actors could put their photographs in the The Spotlight, the acting directory that was created in 1927. In Hollywood, performers had the Academy Players Directory, which was first published in 1937.
"In New York, we had nothing," said Ms. Hayden, who was a struggling actress herself in the 1940's.
And so it began.
Ms. Hayden borrowed space on the top floor of a brownstone occupied by the Actors Equity Association, hung fliers announcing her project in the local theaters and collected hundreds of photographs from her fellow performers. She called the final product The Players' Guide: A Pictorial Directory for the Legitimate Theater.
It divided the city's actors into categories: leading men and women, character actors, ingenues and children. Most important, it listed their phone numbers.
Soon, anybody who was anybody was in the book. Butterfly McQueen, of "Gone With the Wind," appeared in 1947. Paul Newman and Vincent Price showed up in 1957. And for young actors particularly, the guide became a rite of passage, proof that one had truly joined the acting community.
"I was so excited and worried at the same time," said Eleanor Reissa, an Off Broadway producer who appeared as an actress in the guide in the 1970's. "I kept asking myself: 'Am I a comedian? Am I an ingenue? Should I be smiling? Should I be serious?' "
Every February, the actors crowded into the Times Square office to renew their entries, and Paul L. Ross, who inherited the guide from Ms. Hayden, offered advice from behind a wooden counter, suggesting this photo or that one, these credits or none at all.
"It was sort of charming," said David Margulies, an actor who still appears in the guide. "You would join a small line on 46th Street in the Equity office building and you would see that man Ross growing older as you grew older and still looking much the same."
But did the guide actually help actors find jobs?
More and more actors began to ask that question as fewer casting directors relied on the guide. Redman Maxfield got a bit part in "Six Degrees of Separation" after Ms. Chenoweth saw his photo. ("I needed some Waspy guys," she explained. "He looked very Waspy. And he could act.")
"A chance in a million," Mr. Maxfield said.
But other actors, doubtful that the guide did any good, decided not to enter their photographs.
And when Mr. Ross learned that the acting directories in Hollywood and London were moving their services on line, he decided it was time to retire.
Mr. Ross will keep his office open for about six months. And Ms. Hayden, who is 75 now, says she cannot help but pray that someone will lead the guide into the next century before the office closes for good.
"It was flesh of my flesh," she said. "I will always be heartsick that it's gone."

HEADLINE: Markets Get Jitters, and Dow Falls 70.73

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Markets showed what they could do yesterday when investors get nervous.
A case of the jitters is the best explanation from traders and analysts for why stock prices around the world plunged, interest rates surged higher and the dollar fell even though the economic fundamentals that underlie market performance in the United States and Europe still seem generally positive. 
 Such behavior is not unusual near the end of a year, when investors and money managers are worried about protecting their profits after a good year. Anxiety could also be expected after markets moved so high after the elections.
"I think the market is beginning to show that it can be spooked at these levels," Charles Clough, the chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch, said of the American stock market. "This kind of volatility shows that there is as much risk as reward at these levels."
And jitters are not surprising because investors are probably still wondering about the implications of last week's comments from the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, who asked if the stock market was rising because of "irrational exuberance." Because Mr. Greenspan's question indicated that he was worried about the possibility of a speculatively driven market, world stock markets fell sharply Friday, although major stocks indexes in the United States regained on Monday what they had lost.
By the end of a volatile session yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average, which fell as much as 129 points, was down 70.73 points, or 1.1 percent, to 6,402.52, and off 1.8 percent in the last week and a half. All but four of the 30 Dow stocks fell, led by Du Pont, which lost 2 1/2, to 92 5/8; Union Carbide, down 2 5/8, to 42 1/4, and I.B.M., off 1 5/8, to 156 1/8.
And 447 of the 500 stocks in the Standard & Poor's index, including General Electric and Hewlett-Packard, declined, pulling that index down 6.81 points, to 740.73. In Europe and Asia, major stock markets were off more than 1 percent. G.E. lost 1 1/8, to 97, and Hewlett-Packard fell 3/4, to 53 5/8.
Intel, Microsoft and Philip Morris led a rally at the end of the day that helped pull the major stock indexes from their lows. The Nasdaq composite index, which the two computer stocks dominate, ended down just 3.43 points at 1,309.12, only a quarter of what the Dow fell. Intel leaped 7 3/4, to 136 7/8, while Microsoft gained 1 1/2, to 88 3/8, and Philip Morris added 2 3/8, to 118 3/4.
The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond plunged more than a point as the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, jumped to 6.62 percent, its highest since the post-election rally sent it down to 6.35 percent at the end of last month. The dollar fell against the German mark and tumbled nearly half a percent against the Japanese yen.
"It was a big move with no obvious trigger," said John Lipsky, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers, of yesterday's market declines. "The rallies of the last year have left people apprehensive rather than optimistic about the future. Because markets have moved so far so fast investors fear something could trigger a downdraft."
Traders and analysts were able to point to several events that they thought set off the nervous selling. But it was the fact that investors were already anxious that allowed the reports to have any impact.
"The market is still skittish from last week," said Byron R. Wien, United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company. Noting that the year-end is near and portfolio managers want to keep their profits, he said that investors "are probably more disposed to precipitous action than at other times."
"Even if bond yields go up for the wrong reason, stocks will respond because the linkage between stocks and bonds is very tight," he said.
Melissa R. Brown, the director of quantitative research at Prudential Securities, said another factor worrying investors was the outlook for earnings. She said that the market had tended to slump ahead of earnings reports in several of the recent quarters, only to see the reports come out better than expected.
Some traders said the selling was prompted by an article in The Wall Street Journal that said Japanese investors might slow their purchases of American bonds, a move that could send interest rates higher. Others analysts argued that a slowdown in Japanese purchases would not have a major impact.
The declines continued despite some benign news on inflation as the Government reported that the Producer Price Index, excluding the volatile food and energy components, was up just one-tenth of 1 percent in November. And, at the same time, oil prices in the futures market fell $1.04, to $23.38 a barrel, their third consecutive decline.
"This is the time of year when it is often sound advice to ignore the rampant noise in the financial markets," Abby Joseph Cohen, the co-chairwoman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company, wrote in a recent market analysis. "Portfolio adjustments related to tax considerations, futures positions established for asset reallocations, and old-fashioned window dressing can drive up daily volatility and make a (temporary) mockery of fundamental analysis."
But if yesterday's rise in interest rates continues, then the fundamentals would change. Higher rates would quickly change the outlook for the valuations of stocks, making them look more expensive. And that could discourage investors at a time when the outlook for profits is mixed.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
From the ivory tower, a tough economist for the World Bank.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
ON first impression, Joseph E. Stiglitz seems to fit the part of distracted ivory tower genius better than Washington mover and shaker.
But the scraggly beard, disarming grin and slept-in-his-clothes look camouflage a tough, practical thinker. Mr. Stiglitz -- who resigned yesterday as chairman of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers to become chief economist of the World Bank -- picked his battles and won most of them. More important, he helped to fashion a coherent, centrist economic policy as backbone to the President's aimless New Democrat rhetoric. 
 Mr. Stiglitz, by the way, was indeed a distracted ivory tower genius. With three decades of acclaimed research to his credit and professorships at Oxford, Princeton and Stanford, he is viewed by many as the economic theorist of his generation and a shoo-in for a Nobel Prize.
The surprise is that Mr. Stiglitz made the transition to the corridors of power with such grace. Originally hired in 1993 to add some academic patina to the council, he became chairman at an inauspicious moment when the future of his office itself was at stake. "I took over in the spring of 1995, just when the House Republicans were threatening to zero out our budget," he recalled.
His defense alone was not what saved the day. After all, the Republicans' attempt to micromanage the White House's own budget was an early sign of the hubris that played into the President's strengths as a politician. But that does not undermine the case that Mr. Stiglitz made: that the council provides a valuable perspective because it draws on "citizen bureaucrats" who do not plan to make a career in Government. Council economists serve for only a few years, he reminded the Republicans, and academics were hardly inclined to partisan stands that would embarrass them after they returned to the faculty club.
The council does not have the influence it did in the 1960's, when economists were hailed as scientists hot on the trail of a cure for unemployment. The profession has never recovered from the stagflation of the late 1970's, not to mention the barely concealed contempt of the assorted supply-siders who roamed the Reagan White House.
But under Michael J. Boskin in the Bush Administration, the council did establish itself as a reality check on the flakier initiatives of the executive line agencies, a role that also suited his successor, Laura D'Andrea Tyson. And though he doesn't take credit, Mr. Stiglitz continued the tradition. For example, he fought a lonely (and thus far successful) battle to stop the privatization of the Government's two nuclear fuel plants under terms that would undermine efforts to safely liquidate Russia's bomb-grade uranium.
Mr. Stiglitz, though, is happy to share the credit for the application of economic incentives to Government regulation. Take the case of rent vouchers, now Washington's only serious effort to improve housing. Mr. Stiglitz pointed out that waiting lists confined to single cities undermined incentives of the poor to look for work elsewhere. Allowing someone to move without losing his place in line for subsidized housing may seem a small, even obvious, reform. But from such acorns does better government grow.
Other council initiatives have been more substantial. Thanks in part to Mr. Stiglitz, Washington is now pressing for a cost-effective attack on global warming. The approach, a nation-to-nation market in "tradable emission permits," would create incentives to do the job as cheaply as possible -- say, by paying the Chinese to convert their coal-fired power plants to natural gas rather than spending even more money building mass transit in America no one wants to use.
By the same token, the Administration has come down on the side of the economist-angels on a variety of other issues. These include incentives to avoid expensive construction in hurricane- and earthquake-prone areas, incentives to rotate crops to avoid erosion and reforms that apply cost-benefit tests to toxic waste cleanups.
The World Bank, which is only a couple of blocks away from the Executive Office Building, where he occupied a large corner office, may seem an odd fit for Mr. Stiglitz, whose self-appointed task at the White House was fine-tuning regulation. In fact, the 53-year-old economist asserts that his passion for efficient government makes him the right man for the job at the right time.
The World Bank is in a deep funk, no longer able to justify its half-century-old role as a source of capital for poor countries now that private markets are providing substantial resources for growth. But unlike more conservative economists, Mr. Stiglitz argues that the bank should be redirected, not consigned to the scrap heap of history.
What might this new mission be? As a clearing house for research on what works in developing countries and what doesn't, he suggests, with the specialized lending functions aimed at transforming the losers into winners. Stay tuned for details.
