HEADLINE: In Retailing, Biggest Gains Come From Big Spenders

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
Hermes has a waiting list for its $4,000 Kelly bags. Neiman Marcus sold all 50 of the $75,000 Jaguars featured in its Christmas catalogue in eight days. Patek Philippe has back orders for a $44,500 watch.
Luxury is selling, and at a growth rate faster than that for goods and services as a whole. 
 Luxury goods from Gucci handbags to Montblanc pens saw sales grow about 18 percent last year, to $30 billion, according to Tactical Retail Monitor, a newsletter that tracks retail spending and consumer trends for retailers, manufacturers and shopping centers nationwide. By contrast, overall sales of merchandise from tennis shoes to compact disks increased just 5 percent, to $630 billion.
And the gap is widening. Sales of luxury goods, defined as the most expensive items in a category, will increase 30 percent this quarter from a year earlier because of brisk holiday spending, while sales of mass merchandise will increase just 5 percent, Tactical Retail Monitor says. For the year, the luxury segment is projected to grow more than 21 percent, while the overall sales should equal last year's growth.
The luxury business has been fueled by sharply rising incomes among the wealthiest American families, a surge in the stock market last year and much of this year and an increase in the numbers of people in their peak earning years.
The faster growth in luxury spending can be seen in the sales numbers for many products and services, from expensive cruises and jewelry to cars, apparel and televisions. And from Rodeo Drive to Madison Avenue, upscale retailers and brokers have stories about how the market for luxury goods and services has grown. After sales were relatively flat in the first part of the 1990's, luxury products are now selling at a rate reminiscent of the late 1980's.
"In the 80's there was a progressive buildup of wealth and the need to flaunt it, whether it be a wine collection or your cuff links," Isaac Lagnado, publisher of Tactical Retail Monitor, said. But white-collar downsizing, the savings and loan debacle and fortunes lost in real estate put spending on hold for a lot of people. "There was sort of an austerity and almost embarrassment at flaunting prosperity."
But memories are short, and consumer confidence has rebounded. "People are in the mood to spend," Mr. Lagnado said.
Travcoa World Tours of Newport Beach, Calif., for instance, this year sold all 84 seats on a $38,000-a-person world tour six months in advance. In fact, some 160 travel agencies that specialize in luxury travel -- defined as trips in which per diem spending is at least $350 -- booked more than $300 million in such trips for American travelers last year, according to their marketing organization, API Travel Consultants. The amount, which does not include air fare, is a 35 percent increase from 1994 and a 130 percent increase in the last five years.
"Top of the line anything seems to be selling out fast," said John Morris, who retired in 1990 as vice president of corporate development for the Campbell Soup Company and took his wife, Virginia, on the 25-day Travcoa tour as a birthday present this year. "I think people are rewarding themselves."
At Tiffany & Company, the Atlas line of high-end jewelry introduced last year, which includes items costing up to $19,000, has become the company's most successful product introduction at a time when sales of expensive jewelry in general are on the increase. According to a survey conducted by Jewelers of America Inc, 55 percent of consumers who bought premium jewelry last year, items costing at least $1,500, spent more than they did in 1994; only 24 percent of bargain shoppers, those who bought items costing less than $300, reported a gain in spending.
And there is a waiting list of up to three months for Prada designer-label $400 gray flannel pants. That is indicative of the recent uptick in overall apparel sales, with designer labels driven in part by recent interest in accessories like Gucci belts and Hermes scarves. Consumers with household incomes of $60,000 and up increased spending on apparel 11.1 percent last year -- more than double the increase in spending the year before -- while those with household incomes of $40,000 to $59,999 decreased spending 4.7 percent, the NPD Group, a research firm in Port Washington, L.I., said. Meanwhile, shoppers in the $25,000 to $39,999 category decreased spending 2.4 percent, while those with household incomes of $15,000 to $24,999 reported virtually no change in spending. Those with household incomes below $15,000 increased spending on apparel 1.7 percent.
The Silversteins of Glencoe, Ill., a suburb of Chicago, are an example of the kind of shoppers contributing to the upsurge in spending among the affluent.
"I would say we are spending more than we have in the past," said Gerry Silverstein, a stay-at-home mother whose husband, Michael, is a consultant with Boston Consulting Group. "We've been fortunate that if you look over the time span of the 80's, our income increased. My husband and I are in our early 40's, and we've reached a level where we have more discretionary income to spend."
This year, the Silversteins bought a house nearly double the size of their former home, took a vacation to Hawaii and bought new wardrobes from Neiman Marcus, part of Harcourt General Inc., where they are members of the Incircle club, Neiman's equivalent of a frequent-flier program.
"This has been a banner year," Mrs. Silverstein said, adding, "The stock market has been very good to people this year."
Luxury cars -- starting at about $30,000 -- are hot, including European brands like BMW, Mercedes-Benz and Audi, all of whose American sales peaked in the mid-1980's then plunged before recovering in recent years. Over all, in the first 11 months of 1996, consumers have bought 945,125 luxury cars -- about 11.9 percent of all cars sold in the United States and up from 7 percent a decade earlier, according to data compiled by Ford Motor.
People are also buying many household appliances like high-priced toasters and TV's. Williams-Sonoma Inc., the retailer based in San Francisco, has repeatedly sold out this year of a $250 stainless steel commercial-grade toasters that only hold two pieces of bread. Sales of projection televisions, with screens 50 inches and larger, have grown 127 percent in the last five years to 4 percent of all sets sold in this country, NPD Group says. The projection sets cost around $2,000.
Wall Street is rewarding public companies that are cashing in on all of this spending. The Furman Selz luxury goods index, which measures the stock performance of luxury retailers, including Tiffany and Neiman Marcus, is outperforming the Standard & Poor's general merchandise retail index, which includes Dayton Hudson, and Wal-Mart. While the Furman Selz index has risen 26 percent so far this year, the S.& P. general merchandise index has risen only 18.9 percent.
The persistent bull market, of course, is helping. The stock market rose nearly 35 percent last year and continued the surge this year, with the Dow Jones industrial average up 27 percent in the first 11 months.
"The people who have large investment earnings are doing extremely well right now," said Robert H. Frank, an economist at Cornell University's Johnson Graduate School of Management and a co-author of "The Winner Take All Society." He added, "There is a lot of paper wealth out there, and that has got to be driving at least some of the new spending."
Moreover, the rich are simply getting richer and rewarding themselves with those gains. According to the Census Bureau, the average household income of the top 20 percent of households grew 17 percent the last 10 years to $109,411 last year, when adjusted for inflation. In contrast, the bottom 20 percent of households had just a 2 percent income gain in that time to $8,350.
"The amount of income in the hands of people at the top went up, so they spend more on the kinds of goods that wealthy people usually spend money on," Mr. Frank said. "That shifted the standards of acceptable consumption levels for the people just below them, which made them start spending more."
To be sure, affluent customers can afford to buy in good times and bad. Nonetheless, the current spending frenzy is typical of spending in years of an upbeat economy after recessions and downturns in the stock market, according to Dan Phillips, associate publisher of the Robb Report, a magazine that focuses on luxury life styles.
But the social climate, too, has changed, some experts said, with it now being all right to spend money on one's self and one's family.
"It's acceptable to be well off again," Mr. Phillips said.
The aging of the big baby-boomer generation is a factor, too. The bulk of the baby boomers are in their peak earning years.
"This is the time when people have the most discretionary income and spend the most on luxury," said Harry Dent Jr., an economic forecaster and author of "The Great Boom Ahead."
Retailers also see a shift in spending among some consumers.
While designer-label goods, particularly accessories, are indeed selling, many retailers notice that some of their more affluent customers these days, particularly aging baby boomers, are seeking function instead of flash. Or at least the form of function.
Una Baker, the wife of the president of Tommy Hilfiger's women's clothing division, said she fitted the mold. "I did have some excesses, I must say," said Ms. Baker, who now would rather shop for furniture for her Upper East Side home in Manhattan than search for designer- label outfits.
"Flash is out," she said emphatically. "People do not want other people to know what they have, who they are or how much they have. I think subtlety is much more elegant today."
She is not alone. A trendy Soho furniture boutique called C.I.T.E has had a run on stainless steel furniture, like a $10,000 steel picnic table that came from a convent in France and sold in a week.
The Blocktons of Mamaroneck, N.Y., were in the market for a wet bar when they paid $5,000 for a recycled steel medicine chest there that was originally used in a field hospital in France during World War II. "It has these pullout trays that we'll use to mix drinks, and these are trays that were used to put medicine and syringes on," noted Kathy Blockton, a fashion designer who liked the cabinet's durability.
For William Blockton, a 52-year-old chief executive officer of a Madison Avenue fabric company, the cabinet is perfect for who he is today but just the sort of thing he might have turned his nose up at a decade ago. "We choose to live our lives a little more conservatively than we did before," he said, noting that a decade ago his idea of indulgent spending was on things like original art.

 BODY:

U.S. and Europe Agree On Technology Trade Deal
The United States and the European Union reached agreement on a deal to liberalize trade in information technology, paving the way for a broader pact incorporating most of the world's big trading nations.
After several days of intense negotiations at a meeting of the World Trade Organization in Singapore, the United States and Europe resolved a host of differences over a proposal to eliminate tariffs within three years on computers, software, telecommunications equipment and other products. [Page A1.]
 
VW Executive Charged in Germany
German prosecutors have indicted Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua, the former General Motors executive who switched to Volkswagen, on charges of embezzlement and theft of confidential documents from G.M., the auto makers said. [D9.]
 
Bond Market in Big Slump
The prices of Treasury securities dropped sharply yesterday amid concern that interest rates could rise if foreign investors slowed their buying. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond, which rises when the price falls, increased to 6.62 percent from 6.49 percent, despite favorable reports on inflation and a drop in oil prices. [D20.]
 
The Producer Price Index was up only four-tenths of 1 percent last month, even less when volatile energy costs were excluded. [D2.]
 
The price of crude oil fell sharply for a third consecutive session on signs that supplies appeared to be more ample just as Iraq was beginning to export oil. [D17.]
 
Microsoft's Latest Deal
Microsoft and Pointcast have become allies in the fast-growing area known as Internet broadcasting. In return for a featured position in Microsoft's operating system software, Pointcast, a customized information provider, will embrace Microsoft technology and distribute the MSNBC news service. [D4.]
 
More Women Hold Directorships
Women passed a milestone in the board room in 1996, for the first time holding more than 10 percent of the directors' seats at the nation's 500 largest companies, a survey showed. [D4.]

Du Pont Farms Out Its Computing
Du Pont joined a growing list of companies that have contracted out their computing operations to giant technology-service specialists. [D4.]

Answering a Rage to Spend
Fueled in part by sharply rising incomes of the wealthiest Americans and a rise in the number of people in their peak earning years, luxury goods are selling at a growth rate faster than that for goods and services as a whole. [A1.]

A Live Big Board Ticker for TV
The New York Stock Exchange has made a deal with CNNFN to transmit its ticker live instead of on a delayed basis; the service will be offered to other television channels as well, exchange officials said. [D8.]

Panel Supports Diabetes Drug
An advisory panel recommended that the Food and Drug Administration approve a new type of diabetes drug that could help some diabetics reduce or stop their daily insulin injections. The drug, Rezulin, is being produced and tested by the Parke-Davis division of Warner-Lambert. [A25.]
 
Fight Over Tobacco Ads in Canada
The Canadian Parliament is on the brink of endorsing stringent curbs on cigarette marketing, but tobacco companies are sure to fight back. Advertising. [D8.]

HEADLINE: U.S. AND EUROPE AGREE ON FREEING TECHNOLOGY TRADE

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

 BODY:
The United States and the European Union reached agreement early today on a deal to liberalize trade in information technology, paving the way for a broader pact incorporating most of the world's big trading nations.
After several days of intense negotiations at a meeting of the World Trade Organization in Singapore, the United States and Europe resolved a host of differences about a proposal to eliminate tariffs within three years on computers, software, telecommunications equipment and other technology products. 
 The agreement between the United States and the Europeans removed the last hurdle to extending the pact to the fast-growing nations of Asia, where some governments still maintain objections, and to other countries around the world.
Japan and Canada had already thrown their support behind the deal, which was expected to spur trade in information technology, one of the biggest international industries, and to provide new opportunities to American companies.
"I believe that the basis of what we have agreed with the U.S. provides for an agreement that will be a huge advance for the world economy," Sir Leon Brittan, the chief European negotiator, said at a news conference in Singapore.
The breakthrough came only after both sides gave in on a number of issues. The Europeans agreed, for example, to include digital photocopiers in the agreement, a victory for the American negotiators, who had been strongly pressed by the Eastman Kodak Company not to let those products be excluded. Electric components known as capacitors, which the United States wanted excluded, will be covered by the pact, American officials said.
As many as 35 more countries are expected to join the technology agreement, though some, like Malaysia and Indonesia, have continued to press for delays in tariff reductions to allow their industries time to prepare for open competition.
Other countries will have until March 15 to join the agreement, which will take effect only if nations representing 90 percent of the world's production of technological goods sign up, a target that American officials said was now likely, though not certain, to be met.
The 15 European Union nations, the United States, Japan and Canada, along with Singapore and Hong Kong, which have also agreed to join, together account for about 75 percent of world production.
"It is very encouraging," said an American official, who declined to be identified. "We are heading toward a real critical mass, but we do need some more Asians."
The agreement would cover hundreds of products that have worldwide sales estimated at $500 billion to $600 billion. American companies have strongly supported a deal, which would presumably help them gain easier access to markets worldwide.
"What we're hearing is certainly giving us cause for cautious optimism," Greg Garcia, who monitors trade issues for the American Electronics Association, a lobbying organization, said yesterday, as negotiators made progress toward a deal. "What we're expecting is that we're going to see enough countries joining in that, in total, they will represent 90 percent of the trade in information technology."
Mr. Garcia said the United States last year exported $80 billion worth of computers and related equipment, semiconductors, software, telephone switches and other products that would be covered by the agreement. Tariffs on those exports amounted to $5 billion, he said, and eliminating them would help not just American companies, which in many cases are dominant competitors in the industry, but foreign customers as well.
Moreover, after failed or postponed international efforts to reduce trade barriers in telecommunications, financial services and shipping, analysts said a technology accord could lend impetus to other free-trade negotiations.
"With all those companies loving it and benefiting from it, it gives you significant renewed support in the U.S. and in other countries for the trade liberalization process," said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
Still, there would be limits to the benefits of a pact. Because it deals with tariff reduction, it would not address other less obvious barriers that make it difficult for competitors to break into foreign markets. In Japan, for example, American technology companies still face difficulties finding distributors for their products to retailers and in convincing big companies to purchase goods from non-Japanese producers.
And while a deal on technology would enhance the credibility of the World Trade Organization, the organization's members remain deeply divided on other issues, such as whether workers' rights should be linked to trade agreements. Poorer nations are resisting calls from the United States, among others, for agreements to restrict child labor and to insure the right of workers to unionize.
There were also disputes among the organization's diverse membership about government procurement practices, environmental regulations and other potentially sensitive issues. Members continued to haggle over the wording of a broad communique that the organization is to release on Friday.
The deal on technology trade would be the main accomplishment of the first meeting of the World Trade Organization, which was established to encourage and police free trade agreements among its now 127 members.
At a meeting of heads of Asian and Pacific Rim governments in the Philippines last month, President Clinton won support for the effort to "substantially eliminate" tariffs on technology products, providing some momentum for long-running negotiations on the issue.
Japan has generally been in agreement with the United States over how to proceed, and reports from Singapore today said that India was dropping its opposition. While the inclusion of other big Asian economies is critical to any long-term success, the immediate roadblock to a deal had been the differences between the United States and Europe.
After several sets of talks over the last several days involving the acting United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, and her European counterpart, Sir Leon, the two sides had compromised on almost all the issues dividing them. Among the last ones still on the table was how quickly tariffs on semiconductors should be eliminated, with the United States seeking an accelerated schedule and the Europeans wanting a slower process.
France had also sought to have CD-ROM's containing music or movies classified as entertainment, not technology, keeping them out of the pact. American officials in Singapore said they had agreed to drop all audio-visual products, except interactive ones, from the agreement.
France has long sought to limit competition to its arts industries from American movies, television shows and music, though it has not usually used tariffs to do so, relying instead on quotas and on subsidies for domestic producers.
It was unclear if the French had made any headway toward winning agreement on delaying beyond next year separate talks on liberalizing agricultural tradee, a very sensitive domestic issue in France.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
At Shea, Cost of Cheering Rises

BYLINE: By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
Has anyone here seen the Mets? Do they still reside in New York City? Are they still in the National League? If they are, are they relieved that the Philadelphia Phillies are still in their division?
There were a couple of reported sightings last month when they engaged in bullpen renovation, but the Mets seem to have conceded the city to the Yankees and the role of division challenger to the Florida Marlins. The Mets of great promise and little delivery aren't even going through the pretense of creating promise this winter. 
 That's what makes their decision to increase ticket prices so ludicrous.
"Our commitment to the goal of developing a championship-caliber team in the economics of our industry require that we take steps to price our tickets more competitively," the co-owners, Fred Wilpon and Nelson Doubleday, said this week in a letter to season ticket-holders.
The commitment they talk about, though, is phantasmic. It's also too bad the Mets' owners act to be competitive with their ticket prices but not with their team. Is someone giving out trophies and rings for having the highest ticket prices?
That's right: the Mets' highest ticket price has surpassed the Yankees' highest. At least when customers spend $23 for a box seat at Yankee Stadium they get a competitive, if not championship, team as well as the adventure known as the Bronx. For $25, Shea Stadium customers get to see another disappointing team.
Several years ago, when the Mets added Bobby Bonilla, Eddie Murray and Bret Saberhagen to their roster, they raised the fans' hopes, then dashed them against the shores of Flushing Bay. A year ago they touted their young pitchers and other young players and had the audacity to whisper wild card. Their fans took it in the solar plexus again.
As they sleep their way through this winter, the Mets aren't touting anyone or suggesting anything. They don't even know if the three neophytes who were going to be the second coming of Tom Seaver, Jerry Koosman and Jon Matlack will be ready for the start of next season. They don't know if they can get major league production at the infield corners out of Butch Huskey and Edgardo Alfonzo. They don't know if they can get a major league right fielder out of Carl Everett, Alex Ochoa and Jay Payton.
But they know they don't need Moises Alou, an outfielder of proven production and the object of desire of many other teams.
"Everybody could be interested in Alou," General Manager Joe McIlvaine said last week when asked about the Mets' interest in him. "It's a question of money and terms. I think our bigger urgency has been the bullpen and maybe a hitter at first or third rather than right field."
But surely the Mets have money to spend. They spent only $25 million on their payroll last season (the Yankees spent $61 million). If fans have to pay more to see the Mets play, they certainly are entitled to see the Mets pay more for better players.
McIlvaine has long disdained signing ranking free agents because he doesn't want to relinquish precious draft choices as compensation.
But the Marlins have signed five free agents in the past three weeks and won't lose a draft choice for any of them.
As repeat free agents, Bobby Bonilla, Jim Eisenreich and John Cangelosi don't require compensation. Neither does Alex Fernandez, a service-time free agent. If the Marlins sign Alou, they won't lose a draft choice there either because he is in Fernandez's category. Dennis Cook was a Type B relief pitcher, but Texas didn't offer him salary arbitration so he won't cost the Marlins a draft choice.
The Marlins finished nine games ahead of the Mets last season. They appear to have significantly improved their team. They have spent money with the stated purpose of becoming a contender and luring more fans to their park. The Mets have made no statement other than the one about a commitment to higher ticket prices.
Oh yes, the Mets did inquire about a free-agent closer, Mel Rojas, Alou's teammate and cousin. Why they inquired wasn't clear because they already had re-enlisted John Franco for two more years at a price that had general managers of other clubs wondering, considering Franco has become an inconsistent closer, last season failing in more than a fifth of his save opportunities.
But after McIlvaine's initial inquiry about Rojas, the pitcher's agent never heard from him again. Rojas is now the Cubs' closer.
The Mets have supposedly shored up their relief corps with Greg McMichael, Toby Borland, Ricardo Jordan and maybe Armando Reynoso, if they don't need him as a starter. Fans will surely find it worthwhile to pay extra to watch them pitch.
Efforts to find Wilpon, Doubleday and McIlvaine by telephone yesterday, while the Yankees were creating more attention with another free-agent signing and their heated pursuit of Roger Clemens, were unsuccessful. They did not return the calls.
Maybe they are hibernating for the winter.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 14, 1996, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday about Mets ticket prices for 1997 misstated the comparison with the cost of Yankees tickets. For comparable seats the Mets are less expensive, not more.

HEADLINE: DESIGN REVIEW;
Dior's Look, 50 Years Ago And Now

BYLINE: By AMY M. SPINDLER 

 BODY:
AS famous as the placid Irving Penn photos of Christian Dior's revolutionary New Look are the New Look photos from the dark side: women in postwar Paris angrily ripping the extravagant clothes off one of the first women presumptive enough to wear it amid poverty.
A woman wearing a real New Look dress today might be tempted to make those violent gestures on herself. Descriptions of Dior's early constructions -- scaffolding, tulle, silk, padding, pleats, bodice, bones and corsets -- make it sound as comfortable as wearing an ant farm. 
 Yet Christian Dior, the subject of an exhibition now at the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is arguably not only the template for current French fashion, but also the template for the designer as a celebrity. He was on the cover of Time magazine, invented the notion of licensing a designer name for fees, catered to publicity-generating clients like Marlene Dietrich and Lauren Bacall and was the first designer to insist on changes in fashion with an eye on generating front-page articles and forcing women to buy more clothes.
His career, which began in 1947 when he was 42 and ended when he died at 52, is uniquely suited to the sort of exhibition the Costume Institute does well. As concise as it is captivating, the show comes on the 50th anniversary of the House of Dior and the New Look, and at a moment when new blood in the form of the British designer John Galliano promises to revitalize the name.
Dior is also in the spotlight because one of his best customers, Eva Peron, is, too, in the musical "Evita," which stars Madonna and opens on Christmas Day. In an uncharacteristic nod to pop culture's pressures, the Costume Institute exhibition features four Peron outfits: a green tulle tiered evening gown, a pink satin gold-embroidered cape, a flamenco-influenced strapless gown and a midnight-blue velvet ensemble. Three were lent by her family and sent from Argentina.
It is a sign of the unimpeachable style conferred by the Dior label that when Eva Peron wanted to be admired by Europe, she gave herself over to his atelier.
Eva Peron may not have given it a thought, but what the marauding women tearing apart the New Look in 1947 were doing is questioning the morality of decadent clothes in a time of poverty. It was hardly a new concept -- the French Revolution was partly about that -- and it hasn't gone away yet. Giving up furs during the recession had something to do with distaste at stepping over the homeless on the way to the gala, a la "Barbarians at the Gate." The fact that so many people today believe that those New Look "news" photos were set up only shows that Dior discovered early on something American designers have never forgotten: there is nothing like a controversy to sell clothes.
And he provided many of them. He was accused of being a dictator by critics around the world, particularly when he changed hem lengths and silhouettes. But what the Met show, which is not chronological, demonstrates is that his style never shifted too much. Certainly, changes are glacial through his decade compared with those in recent years, where the look of the moment can go from dirty grunge to glossy glamour to vacant minimalism before clothes have even endured the dry cleaner.
In 1956, when Dior lowered skirt lengths to make them Edwardian, Vogue magazine asked, "Is it a stunt or a serious development?"
The answer to the question was that it was both. Dior visited the United States just after the New Look was introduced and met with Stanley Marcus of Neiman Marcus, who tutored him in the concept of marketing and hype. Fashion has never been the same.
But within the work of the inventor of fashion's system of outdating and innovating are some of the most intelligent, thought-provoking, cleverly constructed clothes ever made. It is doubtful that most designers working today could deconstruct even the patterns of many of the pieces in the show. For instance, there is a series dedicated to adapting the men's tuxedo for women. One dress has a sort of cummerbund that becomes a draping, dramatic sash. Another borrows the crumb-catching pleating of a cummerbund, using it as decoration.
These tuxedo ideas of Dior's became the base of the most important 1960's and 70's fashion, after Yves Saint Laurent, who trained with Dior, had gone out on his own. What would modern fashion be without those smoky Helmut Newton photos of "le smoking" by Saint Laurent? Saint Laurent also took from Dior the idea of A-line dresses, and of what was called the H-line, a flat-chested silhouette that would be deemed "waiflike" today.
What is interesting about all the problem solving and cleverness in Dior's clothes is that the problems were all created by the designer himself. He denied the body's form, and the natural drape of fabric, and instead built women into the body he wanted and wrangled fabrics into unlikely positions. So for all the genius of his invention, there is also a perversity. Had he been less a taskmaster, forcing fabrics and bodies to his will, his clothes would have demanded less of him.
Which is why it is somewhat amusing that Philippe de Montebello, the director of the Met, said in the catalogue that the exhibition sought to show Dior as "a genial creator."
The work attests to just the opposite.
"His idealized conceptualization of woman must be understood as a campaign of hope and optimism in which, in fact, most women of his time participated willingly," Mr. de Montebello said.
That pretty much takes the pressure off the museum to make sense out of why women willingly subjected themselves to some of Dior's more tortured creations. History has proved that women tend to be complicit in designers' desires to put them on the rack of fashion and tug them every which way. Dior was more demanding than most, and the show offers dozens of examples of his nature-defying garments.
Famously, Dior's contribution to fashion was a revival of an Edwardian romance just after Paris had emerged from World War II. All the "petites mains" of the couture studios, still during the war, were put back to work to pleat 25 yards of fabric for a skirt and weave details like tiny curlicues of wire into lace to make it stand pertly. As striking as the so-called grand-entrance gowns that close the Met show -- a plum velvet dress with gunmetal beads flowering across it, from 1955, or a pink satin dress covered in tulle, beaded scallops and pendant crystals, from 1953 -- are the most sober pieces that open it.
Considering that Dior's collection was hailed as the return of the joy of fashion, there is much sobriety here, in the use of men's-wear fabrics for suits, in the Hildegarde-esque silhouettes and in the dark colors throughout.
In fact, even the touchstones of the New Look sound oppressive, as described by Richard Martin, the curator of the Costume Institute. "Narrow corseted waist, padded hips, full voluminous skirt that comes well below the knee and a structured torso that gives a prominent bust," he recently ticked off.
Once in a while a sexual element is tossed in, often weirdly, like the bust of one dress with windows of tiny pleats in the front, described by Mr. Martin as "more primitive art rather than dressmaking." But what sexual elements there are in the show are pure fetishism. Dior's work is largely a fleshless feast, with nothing to do with the body's natural shape. In fact, the institute's associate curator, Harold Koda, calls it "not modern, but post-modern," since it is so much about refiguring identity, and the body.
Every fashion historian has a guess about where Dior would have taken his silhouette had he not died. Evidence suggests it ended near where he wanted it; he had already singled out Saint Laurent and Marc Bohan as possible successors, and chosen his retirement home.
What the Met show refutes more than anything is the notion that Dior was a man with one look -- a new one. Every piece in the show is a testament to his stronger inclination: that of making women look beautiful in an archetypal way. As his latest successor, Mr. Galliano said, "the waist, the bust, the hips -- he knew how to do it."
"Christian Dior" remains at the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82d Street, through March 23. The exhibition was financed by Christian Dior and LVMH-Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A dinner dress from the 1949 Dior fall collection. (Karin Willis) (pg. C1); A Christian Dior "New Look" ensemble from the spring of 1947. (Karin Willis/Metropolitan Museum) (pg. C31)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Selling the First Nuggets Of a Nation's Collection

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK 

 BODY:
One of the best customers of Knoedler & Company, whose current show celebrates its 150th anniversary, was the industrialist Henry Clay Frick. Between 1894 and 1919, he bought more than 225 paintings from the celebrated gallery, paying for at least some of them in Pennsylvania Railroad stock that at the time amounted to less than the value of the works.
"If you hold this stock it seems to me you are bound to realize ere long the full value of your pictures," the canny Frick wrote to the gallery in 1914. It is not recorded who got the better of the deal. (By way of salute, the Frick Collection, up the block from Knoedler's, has put rosettes on all its Knoedler-purchased paintings.) But not to worry. There was no shortage of other deep-pocket clients, among them Frick's picture-buying pal Andrew Mellon. In the early 1930's, Knoedler sold Mellon $6.5 million worth of Old Masters acquired in a coup from the Hermitage in Leningrad; the paintings helped found Mellon's National Gallery of Art in Washington. 
 On the barren American art scene of the mid-19th to early-20th century, Knoedler & Company was a transforming presence. In fact, it helped bring the American art world into being.
The oldest living art dealership in New York although not in the country (that distinction goes to Vose Galleries in Boston), it was founded in 1846 by the Bavarian-born Michel Knoedler, representing Goupil, a firm of engravers in Paris. From a tiny space at Broadway and Duane Street, the gallery expanded, moving uptown as the nation's economy boomed. As nouveau millionaires emerged with a yen to acquire Art, Knoedler played a key role in shaping their collections as well as those of burgeoning museums.
The gallery placed more than 150 works by Cezanne, for instance, and no fewer than 7 of the dozen Vermeers now in this country's art institutions. What's more, it was a leading supporter of American artists, promoting such stellar talents as Frederick E. Church, Winslow Homer, George Inness, George Caleb Bingham, William Sidney Mount, George Bellows and John Singer Sargent. And in 1916 it mounted the only solo show of work by the inimitable Florine Stettheimer during her lifetime, allowing the artist to recreate her home environment in the gallery.
Knoedler had its detractors. "A bazaar," wrote Rene Gimpel, a rival French dealer, in his diary for 1918, "an old name, a long reputation for honesty, but no real intelligence." Grudgingly crediting Knoedler's staff with a feeling for "modern" art, he added: "An Old Master? They're less well provided there; they know less, they are a bit lacking in taste, but don't worry, they'll get you what you think you want."
The first part of this two-part anniversary show, organized by Sam Hunter, professor emeritus of art history at Princeton, presents a selection of 18 paintings -- by artists as well known as Copley, Corot and Renoir and as forgettable as the salon painter Hughes Merle -- that were sold to American museums, from the mighty Metropolitan to Tennessee's finest, the Memphis Brooks Museum of Art. Although it's a little late for critical judgments, it can be said that not all of the works are masterpieces.
Among the more illustrious, however, are a version of John Singleton Copley's "Watson and the Shark" (1782), a grisly scene of a man attacked by a shark in the water as his boat mates try to save him, bought in 1946 by the Detroit Institute of Arts. A fine Degas portrait of his younger brother, "Rene de Gas" (1855), was sold directly to the Smith College Museum of Art in 1935. Manet's haunting "Plum," from around 1877, depicting a sad-eyed waif of a woman at a cafe table, was acquired by Paul Mellon in 1961 and later donated to the National Gallery. A superb Braque still life, "Le Gueridon" (1921-22), was bought by Louise Reinhardt Smith in 1961 and given to the Metropolitan in 1979.
Much more fun is the second part of the show, in a downstairs gallery. Assembled by Melissa De Medeiros, the gallery's librarian, from Knoedler's voluminous archives, it includes letters, photographs, sale records, stock books, catalogues, news clippings and so on, dating back to 1863. A captivating miscellany, they trace not only the history of the gallery but also the rise of the art market, the way dealers buy, the building of collections and the crotchets of artists and acquisitors.
An early accounting from Knoedler to Frederick Church, for instance, reveals that he traded artworks for art supplies. Two handwritten ledger pages from February 1909 record the sale of 83 watercolors by John Singer Sargent to the Brooklyn Museum in one swoop, for prices as low as $170. News clippings from 1910 detail the successful efforts of Benjamin Altman, a client, to dislodge Knoedler from its premises at 34th Street and Fifth Avenue so he could build a department store there. (The Altman-Knoedler relationship did not survive the battle.)
A letter from Sarah Bernhardt in 1919 offers a portrait of herself in the role of Gismonda, to help pay her debts. Writing to Knoedler in 1929, the well-known collector Stephen C. Clark tries to knock down the price of a Cezanne to $50,000. And Winslow Homer, complaining about a request for photographs in 1908, lambastes "women working for the press," who "expect and want everything they can get."
Of course, there are things not mentioned, like the time in the mid-1950's when an official of Wildenstein & Company was caught tapping Knoedler's telephones to learn what its arch-rival was up to. And the show's title is something of a misnomer. Although it supposedly covers 150 years, what it really celebrates is the dynastic Knoedler's, the gallery that existed before it began to pass out of family ownership with the death of Charles Henschel, Michel's grandson, in 1956. (In 1971, on the verge of bankruptcy, the gallery was acquired by the financier Armand Hammer, whose foundation still holds a controlling interest.)
But, as a richly detailed sketch of how Knoedler's and its big-time cast of players helped to shape the American art world, the show is something to see. Come to think of it, it's nothing less than mini-series material.
"The Rise of the Art World in America: Knoedler at 150" remains at Knoedler & Company, 19 East 70th Street, Manhattan, through Jan. 12.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Knoedler Gallery circa 1900, at Fifth Avenue and 34th Street. (Knoedler & Company)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Edges Mostly Higher, Seeming to Avoid Stock Jitters

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Helped by weakness in the mark, the dollar was mostly higher yesterday, overcoming sharp declines in stock markets in the United States.
Still, the dollar remained somewhat vulnerable to the action on Wall Street, tending to follow the Dow Jones industrial average as it rallied in the morning and dropped in the afternoon. 
 The markets have been nervous since last Friday after comments by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, expressing concern that stocks might be overvalued.
"Whatever has been happening in the stocks and bonds, the dollar is reacting to that," said Augie Floro, assistant vice president for foreign exchange at Bank Austria's New York branch. "It really doesn't follow logic. When people see the stock market falling, they get a little nervous."
Late in New York yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.5423 German marks from 1.5376 marks on Wednesday and to 113.27 Japanese yen from 112.97 yen. The British pound rose to $1.6576 from $1.6515.
The dollar initially fell in Asian dealings, partly in reaction to a report in Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's leading financial newspaper, that some Japanese central bank officials were considering a rise in interest rates as early as the spring.
The dollar rebounded as traders discounted the report. In addition, the central bank's governor, Yasuo Matsushita, defended Japanese monetary policy, saying it had lowered the cost of lending and helped provide the basis for a recovery.
Traders said the mark's weakness stemmed from a conference of European Union finance ministers in Dublin over a proposed deal to insure the stability of the planned single currency, which is to be introduced in 1999.
"It appears they're going to put through some compromise agreement," said Stephen Flanagan, senior foreign-exchange trader at Credit Agricole in New York. "The mark could continue to weaken if we get some positive news from Dublin."
Any news of progress in the single-currency plan has tended to hurt the mark, which would lose its position as Europe's dominant currency once the Euro was in use.

HEADLINE: On the Ropes, Chirac Fights Back in French Television Interview

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 12

 BODY:
His popularity plummeting, his Prime Minister under attack even from within his own party, and his compatriots fed up with high unemployment, President Jacques Chirac of France went on television tonight in an effort to regain voter confidence.
Choosing an interview format with four journalists approved by his staff, Mr. Chirac tried to counter the impression that France was falling apart under his presidency. 
 Asked why he had apparently failed so far to make good on his campaign promises to bring "fundamental change" to a country whose people often seem mired in the past, Mr. Chirac said, "The reality is that we are in a very profoundly conservative country, and it's very difficult to change things."
Almost nothing has gone right lately for Mr. Chirac, who turned 64 at the end of last month, or his 51-year-old Prime Minister, Alain Juppe, who is under instructions to carry out austerity budget policies in the face of an unemployment rate that stands at 12.6 percent and has been inching upward for a year.
Mr. Chirac's popularity has plunged since his election in May 1995 with 52 percent of the vote, and is now hovering between 27 and 37 percent, according to various public opinion polls. Mr. Juppe, dismissed in public recently as nothing more than "a good chief of staff for Chirac" by a fellow-Gaullist, is even more unpopular.
"Alain Juppe is conducting a difficult and courageous policy," Mr. Chirac said tonight, putting an end to weeks of rumors that he was about to dump his Prime Minister to give his Rally for the Republic party a better chance of winning the 1998 parliamentary elections.
"I have great admiration for a man who, despite the criticism, carries on without fear and without losing his morale," Mr. Chirac said of his Prime Minister. "Running a country at a time when you have to change things, and ways of thinking, takes a great deal of courage."
Mr. Juppe is trying to slash the deficit because the President has ordered him to make the French economy fit to join the German-designed common European currency that is planned for the end of the decade.
Only a European currency, Mr. Chirac said tonight, could put France and the rest of Europe on a level playing field with the United States and the Asian economies in an increasingly competitive global marketplace.
"We need a means to struggle against American hegemony," he said. "There is a problem of the dollar. The only way is to be strong, to have a common currency. There is no other way."
As for the strikes that have disrupted the Government's attempts to reduce the budget deficit to qualify France under the rules for the common currency, Mr. Chirac said: "We are a country that is not responsible, from this point of view. I'm not against the right to strike. I am appealing to people's responsibility."
Aside from the reference to "American hegemony" there was no mention of growing tensions between France and the United States in more than two hours of discussion and debate. Domestic concerns dominated the discussion, including the recent resurgence of terrorism in Paris with an explosion on a commuter train last week that killed four people.
Mr. Chirac told his audience that there were still no clear leads in the case, though it appeared to bear the hallmarks of an Algerian terrorist group dedicated to forcing France to cut its economic ties with the military-backed Government in Algeria.

HEADLINE: $148 Million Renewal Plan Announced for New Rochelle

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Dec. 12

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki announced today a $148 million revitalization plan for the troubled downtown here, including the construction of up to 1,000 apartments, stores, skating rinks and a 20-screen movie theater.
Mr. Pataki described the plan, which relies primarily on private developers, as a model for the revival of small cities throughout the state that "like New Rochelle, have seen their downtowns erode over the last two decades" He said the project would generate 1,500 construction jobs and more than 600 permanent jobs. 
 Under the plan, the state would provide a $4 million low-interest loan for a $48 million retail complex called the New Rochelle Center. It is to be developed by New Roc Associates of White Plains on the site of Macy's, which closed in 1992.
A $100 million apartment development, Avalon on the Sound, would be privately financed and built by Avalon Properties of Wilton, Conn. The apartments, in walking distance of the Metro-North station, would rent at market rates and would be aimed at high-income people.
A vice president of Avalon Properties, Alexander Twining, estimated that a one-bedroom unit would rent for $1,200 a month.
New Rochelle officials said they were thrilled. "It's a big Christmas present," Deputy Mayor Rhoda Quash said. "We've been working on this for a long time."
Mayor Timothy C. Idoni had praise for the stores. "It's more of an antimall," he said. "The emphasis is on entertainment. We're looking to draw from White Plains south to the north Bronx."
Downtown had seemed on a downhill. Traditional stores were replaced by less fancy retailers, and some stores closed entirely, leaving Main Street lifeless at times. Plans for an extensive housing complex on nearby Davids Island that Donald J. Trump was to have built fell through, as did an invitation for Unicef to move its headquarters here. Hope for a resurgence in this city of 67,265, with large Italian, black, Hispanic and Jewish representation, has been pegged to the arrival of big discounters like the Price Club and Home Depot, both close to downtown.
New Roc bought the Macy's site two years ago for $10 million. The company said it had commitments for a Stop & Shop supermarket, a 20-screen theater and a two-rink ice center. The rest would be leased to restaurants and stores. Construction would begin early next year.
"These three tenants will attract five million people who have no reason to come to the downtown today," Robert Greene, a co-managing general partner of New Roc, said. "We expect that they will spend well in excess of $100 million annually."
Mr. Twining said, "We hope that some of those five million people who are coming to shop downtown will want to live there."
He added that the company was buying the site from the city and would enjoy abatements on its city property taxes.
Charles Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, which helped put the projects together, said they are examples of "what government can do in partnership with the private sector."
Doyle G. Hyett, chairman of Hyett Palma, an urban renewal consulting business in Alexandria, Va., said there was a national trend to revitalize downtowns.
"Downtowns are really hot right now," Mr. Hyett said. "One of the reasons is that the American buying public is speaking pretty loudly about how tired it is with the sameness of malls. Every downtown can be unique. Another reason is value. Downtowns are a good buy. The idea sounds very progressive. The retail is fine. The housing is the really exciting step."

HEADLINE: Vance Packard, 82, Challenger of Consumerism, Dies

BYLINE: By RICHARD SEVERO 

 BODY:
Vance Packard, a journalist turned social critic whose best-selling books -- "The Hidden Persuaders," "The Status Seekers" and "The Waste Makers" -- warned Americans in the late 1950's about the excesses of advertising, social climbing and planned obsolescence, died yesterday at Martha's Vineyard Hospital. He was 82 and had homes in New Canaan, Conn., and Martha's Vineyard.,
Mr. Packard was a highly successful popularizer of serious ideas raised by America's postwar prosperity and the explosion of consumerism. He was skilled as well in coining titles for his books that endured in the national vocabulary. His vision of an America beset by manipulative forces and dominated by vast bureaucratic organizations struck a responsive chord with the public and regularly put him atop the best-seller lists. 
 His work also helped lay the ground for the muckraking works of the more turbulent 1960's, like Rachel Carson's "Silent Spring" in 1962 and Ralph Nader's "Unsafe at Any Speed" in 1965.
Mr. Packard first gained national attention with the publication in 1957 of "The Hidden Persuaders," which exposed what he saw as the growing and not entirely benign influence of the nation's advertising industry. Alarmed by new techniques that convinced people to run out and buy things, he detailed advertising's fascination with the school of consumer analysis known as motivational research.
"Many of us are being influenced and manipulated, far more than we realize, in the patterns of our everyday lives," he wrote. He compared motivational research to "the chilling world of George Orwell and his Big Brother."
Mr. Packard emphasized the dangers of "subliminal projection," in which, he said, messages were flashed so quickly on television or movie screens that consumers could not recall seeing or hearing them though they responded to them. In "Hidden Persuaders" he reports that a New Jersey drive-in flashed the words "eat popcorn" on the movie screen for a split second to boost sales at its food stand. Marketing executives disputed his account.
Writing in The New York Times Book Review, A. C. Spectorsky called the book "frightening, entertaining and thought-stimulating." The work remained on The New York Times best-seller list for a year. "Hidden Persuaders" became all the rage; many readers claimed they were being subjected to subliminal advertising every time they noticed a glitch in their television reception.
The advertising business hit back; its representatives took to public forums everywhere to declare that motivational research helped advertisers better serve the American people. To this day, leaders in the industry deny that subliminal devices have been used to sell products in the marketplace. They denounced Mr. Packard's book as "malicious" because in their view, it made them seem needlessly sinister.
Mr. Packard did not anticipate the industry reaction, and he was stung by the attack on his work. But he became even more determined to take on other subjects about the nature of life in postwar America. He was of a generation of journalistic generalists, writers who were willing to address any number of topics, as long as they did the hard reporting that was needed.
In his next book, "The Status Seekers"(1959), Mr. Packard argued that "under its gloss of prosperity," the nation was becoming more socially divided as Americans tried desperately "to find new ways to draw lines that will separate the elect from the non-elect."
According to Daniel Horowitz, author of "Vance Packard and American Social Criticism" (1994), Mr. Packard blamed the consumer culture developed by capitalists for intensifying a striving for status and set out to debunk the notion that prosperity was helping to achieve the dream of a classless, egalitarian society.
Mr. Horowitz said that although Mr. Packard borrowed many ideas from others, he "went farther in asking his readers to question basic assumptions about the beneficence of the American society and economy."
In his third successive best seller, "The Waste Makers" (1960), Mr. Packard asserted that American business was so determined to sell at full tilt that it was encouraging consumers to use up or prematurely discard whatever they purchased. He outlined the ways manufacturers and advertisers persuaded consumers to buy expensive goods they did not really need.
The book set off a storm of criticism. Printers' Ink, a trade publication, declared that Mr. Packard's work reviled "an economic system which, for all its shortcomings," had given the United States "the world's highest standard of living."
Ernest Dichter, viewed as a leading force in motivational research and a target of "Hidden Persuaders," denounced Mr. Packard and other critics as "morality hucksters," writers who collected their royalties and retreated "to their Connecticut homes to cool off with a drink iced from a 1961 refrigerator engineered by the waste makers."
Over the next four decades Mr. Packard seemed to mellow a bit, writing books that were relatively hopeful in tone as well as some more in keeping with his past work. Mr. Horowitz said Mr. Packard's "optimism tempered his outrage" and that by the mid-1960's he "found himself outflanked on the left by the college students he helped bring to political awareness." Still, Mr. Packard continued to command a substantial audience for his work.
"The Pyramid Climbers" (1962) examined corporations and their executives. Mr. Packard saw success in corporate life being attained by those who were loyal, adaptable, deferential and nonantagonizing. This was followed in 1964 by "The Naked Society," which discussed how new technologies and new attitudes allowed a growing invasion of the privacy of the average American.
Other books included "The Sexual Wilderness" (1968), which chronicled changes in relationships between men and women, especially the increase in premarital sex; "A Nation of Strangers" (1972), which argued that corporate transfers had created a rootless, lonely nation; "Our Endangered Children" (1983), which maintained that a national preoccupation with money, status, sex and power was reinforcing an inherent bias against children, and "Ultra Rich: How Much Is Too Much" (1989), which explored the lives of 30 Americans whose average net worth was $330 million.
Among those influenced by his ideas was Betty Friedan, who after hearing one of his lectures decided to turn some magazine articles she was planning into a book that eventually became "The Feminine Mystique."
Vance Oakley Packard was born on May 22, 1914, in Granville Summit, Pa., one of three children of Philip J. and Mabel Case Packard. He was reared in State College, Pa., where his father worked for Penn State as a superintendent of the college farm.
After his graduation from high school in 1932, he attended Penn State, majoring in English and working for the literary magazine. He graduated in 1936 and got a $15-a-week job as a cub reporter for the Center Daily Times in State College. He won a scholarship to Columbia University's Graduate School of Journalism, where he earned a master's degree in 1937.
Before writing his books, he worked for The Boston Daily Record and The Associated Press. In 1942 he left The Associated Press and joined American magazine. When it folded in 1956, Mr. Packard moved over to Collier's and wrote articles until 1956, when it, too, ceased publication.
He is survived by his wife, the former Virginia Matthews; a daughter, Cynthia Richmond of Annandale, Va.; two sons, Randall, a professor of history at Emory University in Atlanta, and Vance Philip of Thornhurst, Pa., and four grandchildren.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Obituary (Obit); Biography

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%);

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Can't get data on securities fraud suits? Try the Internet.

BYLINE: By Leslie Eaton 

 BODY:
IT is the investing world's version of "Godzilla vs. Megalon," a titanic struggle over the fate of the planet, watched from afar by hand-wringing government officials and hordes of small investors.
The battle between some class-action lawyers and the corporations they sue for securities fraud pits one side, which says that greedy corporations are defrauding small investors whose only recourse is to take them to court, against the other, which argues that evil litigators are stifling the American economy. The two sides disagree about everything, even such basic facts as how many suits get filed and how many get settled. 
 This ideological argument, filled with enough hot air to float all the balloons in the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade, is not about to end. But perhaps the debate can be brought more down to earth by a proposal of a group of judges and law professors in and around San Francisco.
Their plan is simply to post all the major documents from all securities class-action lawsuits in at least one site on the Internet. That way they can be read and counted and studied by lawyers and reporters, regulators and legislators, academics and -- most importantly -- investors.
"Our Federal securities markets have always had a philosophy of open disclosure," said Joseph A. Grundfest, a former commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission who is now a professor at Stanford Law School. "Shouldn't it be the same way when it comes to allegations of fraud at public companies?"
With the encouragement of the S.E.C., Stanford has set up an Internet site to serve as a clearinghouse (http://securities.stanford.edu) and has been collecting legal documents.
And in a move that other courts may copy, the Federal District Court for the Northern District of California -- where many of these lawsuits are filed -- has proposed requiring lawyers on all sides in such suits to send many legal documents to a site like Stanford's. The new rule may be adopted as early as next month, after the public has a chance to comment on it, Federal District Judge Vaughn R. Walker said.
"We have had some lack of enthusiasm from some lawyers, who as a general rule tend to be pretty conservative and tend not to react terribly favorably to new ideas," the judge said, adding that the cost should be minimal because lawyers have to file only documents that are already prepared on word processors.
One criticism of class-action securities lawsuits has been that their intended beneficiaries -- investors who feel they have been defrauded -- cannot monitor the progress of legal proceedings.
In fact, they may well be unaware that a lawsuit has been filed at all. "Notification to class members traditionally involves a combination of mailings and newspaper advertisements that are expensive, employ small type, convey little substantive information and may be difficult for members of the class to locate," the California court said in its commentary on its proposed rule.
But now, unhappy investors in Solv-Ex or Presstek or even the Fidelity Magellan Fund, a unit of the FMR Corporation, can go on line and read the complaints filed by lawyers on their behalf. They will also be able to keep an eye on settlements, and decide whether these deals are likely to benefit them or simply to line their lawyers' pockets (as the corporate targets often contend).
Meanwhile, interested individuals, as well as policy makers and the professors who advise them, can get a better handle on the reality, rather than the rhetoric, of securities class-action suits. How many are frivolous? How often are companies winning or losing? And how much? And how are the lawsuits being changed by last year's act, which set new hurdles for charging fraud?
Professor Grundfest has already calculated that of the 96 companies sued in Federal court, 61 percent of the cases involved charges of accounting fraud and 49 percent involved insider sales. Only 5 percent included neither claim, he said.
Investors can do some interesting research on their own. For example, a quick examination of Stanford's site shows that the vast majority of suits there are against companies that trade on Nasdaq and its outer reaches.
And in close to half the roughly 60 cases in which documents are already available on line, lawyers for the plaintiffs included one firm, Milberg Weiss Bershad Hynes & Lerach of San Diego. A partner of that firm, William S. Lerach, was the main supporter of the failed California referendum that would have made it easier for investors to sue companies; Mr. Lerach did not return telephone calls this week.
None of this will put an end to the bigger debate over class actions and the subsidiary issue of whether these statistics simply reflect the firm's skill or are proof that it, above all others, is exploiting the legal system. But Professor Grundfest hopes the Internet project will at least help ground the arguments in fact.
The two sides "will still be on separate planets," he said. "But at least they will all be in the same solar system."

HEADLINE: Retail Spending Off a Bit; Price Index Up 0.3%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
Shoppers kept a wary eye on spending in November as this year's late holiday shopping season got under way, the Government indicated today in a report that seemed to confirm indications of only modest improvement from last year's poor sales.
Dragged down by weak automotive business, retail spending slumped four-tenths of 1 percent last month, as spending on goods other than cars and trucks rose only enough to keep pace with inflation, which remained mild. 
 "Consumers continue to pause," James E. Annable, chief economist at the First National Bank of Chicago, said. He predicted a "moderate Christmas" in which retailers would pull in about 6 percent more money, without allowing for inflation.
Inflation clearly is not to blame for the sluggish spending. The Labor Department reported today that the Consumer Price Index rose only three-tenths of 1 percent for the third straight month and that core inflation -- which excludes the volatile energy and food categories -- rose only two-tenths of 1 percent.
Neither set of figures was expected to have much effect on the Federal Reserve policy meeting next Tuesday, which is widely expected to leave short-term interest rates unchanged.
A third Government report released today showed that first-time claims for unemployment insurance fell by 13,000, to 317,000, in the week ended last Saturday, suggesting that the labor market remained tight despite a recent moderation in job growth.
Sluggish income growth has kept a damper on spending, most analysts agree, even as unemployment flirts with quarter-century lows and investors enjoy a second straight year of hefty stock market gains.
The sales report, compiled by the Commerce Department, showed that consumers thrust $206.1 billion across retail counters last month, $700 million less, seasonally adjusted, than in October.
Excluding automobiles, a volatile category in which sales dropped 2.6 percent, retail sales climbed three-tenths of 1 percent, just enough to keep pace with the Consumer Price Index.
Analysts warned, however, that the report, an estimate compiled from a small number of retailers, might not have been entirely accurate because Thanksgiving was so late this year, skewing the usual seasonal adjustments.
October's sales, however, were revised only slightly, to an advance of three-tenths of 1 percent instead of two-tenths of 1 percent.
In other categories of durable goods besides autos, merchants selling furniture and other equipment for the home saw a 1.2 percent increase last month while those selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes showed no change.
For nondurables -- items expected to last less than three years -- sales inched ahead a disappointing one-tenth of 1 percent; revenues slumped six-tenths of 1 percent at department stores and other stores selling general merchandise, and nine-tenths of 1 percent at apparel and accessory stores.
Sales also fell four-tenths of 1 percent at restaurants and bars and two-tenths of 1 percent at food stores, the report showed.
Sales jumped eight-tenths of 1 percent at drugstores and 1.2 percent at gasoline service stations, but the latter gain merely reflected higher oil prices.
"This kind of rise in retail sales we don't need," said Kenneth Mayland, chief economist for Keycorp, the Cleveland-based banking group. "It accrues mostly to foreigners and diverts spending from malls, restaurants and a variety of local merchants."
A Congressional committee said Dec. 4 that the Consumer Price Index might overstate inflation by 1.1 percentage points.
The index reflected the higher costs of energy last month. Gasoline climbed 1.8 percent and heating oil and natural gas jumped even more as the energy index advanced for the second straight month to offset moderation in other prices, including dairy products and fruits and vegetables.
Excluding food and energy, the index rose two-tenths of 1 percent in November, the same as in October.
In the New York metropolitan area, prices edged up one-tenth of 1 percent in November, and four-tenths of 1 percent in Chicago. San Francisco showed no change, and Los Angeles and Philadelphia had moderate declines.

HEADLINE: Clinton Is Said to Have Asked Attorney General to Stay On

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
As he wrestles to fill top domestic posts for a second term, President Clinton met with Attorney General Janet Reno this evening intending to ask her to stay on for a second term in his Cabinet, and he might announce other decisions on Friday, senior Administration officials said tonight.
Ms. Reno's aides said she would stay on if asked. 
 But after the meeting tonight senior White House aides said the President would only tell them that he had had a "wonderful meeting with Ms. Reno," and they insisted that they did not know its outcome.
For days, White House aides have said Mr. Clinton hoped to announce his economic team, or other Cabinet choices, at a news conference scheduled for Friday at 2 P.M. But if posts remain unfilled, the encounter could devolve into a series of nettlesome questions. Asked today what Mr. Clinton's goal for the news conference was, the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said simply, "Get out alive."
So far this much seemed certain, according to various officials:
Representative Bill Richardson of New Mexico has told people that the White House has assured him he will either be the chief United States delegate to the United Nations or Secretary of Commerce. Some officials said tonight that the United Nations job appeared most likely because the Secretary of State-designate, Madeleine K. Albright, had raised objections to the other leading candidate for that job, former Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke.
If Mr. Richardson gets the United Nations post, William M. Daley, a Chicago lawyer and member of the Daley political family, could take the Commerce job, officials said, and the Federal Highway Administrator, Rodney Slater, could be Secretary of Transportation.
The new White House chief of staff, Erskine B. Bowles, has chosen Sylvia Matthews, now chief of staff at the Treasury Department, and John Podesta, a former White House staff secretary, as his two deputies, replacing Evelyn S. Lieberman and Harold M. Ickes.
Also still up in the air is the post of Labor Secretary. Former Senator Harris Wofford of Pennsylvania and Alexis Herman, the White House director of public liaison, remain the leading candidates.
For weeks, the President has passed up repeated chances to say anything that could be interpreted as an endorsement of Ms. Reno, whose independent-minded actions in appointing special prosecutors to investigate various Administraion officials has drawn the anonymous sniping of some White House aides.
Aides said Mr. Clinton had resisted making any public comment about Ms. Reno because he did not want to be seen as trying to influence her decision on whether to appoint a special prosecutor to look into disputed Democratic Party fund-raising practices. She decided last month not to seek an outside inquiry, and aides said the President now felt free to resolve her future.
Mr. Clinton finds himself in a particular bind concerning the National Economic Council, an institution he created to act as an honest broker among competiting Cabinet departments on economic issues.
Many in the White House have urged the President to reward Gene Sperling, the deputy head of the council, with the chairmanship, replacing Laura D'Andrea Tyson. But other members of his Cabinet have urged the appointment of someone with more experience and political weight than Mr. Sperling.

HEADLINE: Plan Revamps Hospital Care For Uninsured

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
To help control the cost of providing medical treatment to the poor, the Whitman administration announced today a plan that requires hospitals to manage the care of uninsured patients, who now have little choice but to go to emergency rooms.
Under the plan announced by the State Health Commissioner, Len Fishman, New Jersey and the Federal Government would continue to reimburse hospitals for the uninsured patients who walk through their doors. But the hospitals would be able to send those patients to doctors, clinics and treatment centers that may be able to provide better care for less money. For example, a hospital could help a person with a chronic illness like asthma find a doctor who would provide regular care, reducing the need for emergency-room treatment. 
 "This will allow hospitals to provide care in the most appropriate setting, which has not been possible in the past," Mr. Fishman said.
For years, New Jersey has been one of the leaders in the nation in creating innovative health care financing plans. And some national health care plans have drawn heavily from New Jersey's experience.
New Jersey is one of only a handful of states committed to reimbursing hospitals for treatment of the uninsured, a system known in the state as charity care. This year, the state distributed $310 million to 75 hospitals to help pay for the medical care of more than 100,000 uninsured people.
The plan requires approval by Federal health care officials. If the plan wins Federal backing, Mr. Fishman said, "we will be making history."
Officials of hospitals in the state said today that they support the plan. Gary Carter, president of the New Jersey Hospital Association, said hospitals in the state had long wanted more options for treating the uninsured. "We see this as an important and positive step forward," Mr. Carter said. "There is no reason to have someone with a substance-abuse problem to be cared for only in a hospital setting."
Although administration officials said they hoped the plan would reduce the costs of caring for the uninsured, they did not say today how the state would pay for charity care when the current financing system expires at the end of next year.
Paying for medical care for the uninsured has long perplexed state officials. It took five months this year for state officials to decide to continue to rely on payroll taxes designated for the state's unemployment fund to cover most of the cost. In the meantime, hospitals had to wait for the state aid. Legislators and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman have promised business leaders and organized labor that they will find an alternative to the unemployment fund and a permanent financing solution next year.
New Jersey officials feel confident that Federal health care financing officials will approve the plan. Many states have received Federal waivers for plans that increase the use of managed-care practices. New Jersey, like many other states, has already set up a managed-care system for poor people who qualify for the Federal Medicaid program. Under the program announced today, which is expected to begin on Jan. 1, 1998, each hospital must submit a plan to the state with a list of clinics and doctors. Because many hospitals in the state already participate in managed-care programs, some hospitals already have affiliations with neighborhood clinics.
The state will also require each hospital to have a substance-abuse treatment program for uninsured patients. And each year, the state will review the quality of care provided to the uninsured by each hospital and its network of providers.
If a hospital fails to meet state performance standards, the state will use part of the hospital's subsidy to hire an outside contractor to work with the hospital to improve care.
"This is a plan that holds hospitals accountable but gives them the flexibility to use other providers," Mr. Fishman said. "It benefits the charity-care patient who will have access to the medical care he or she needs. And it helps the taxpayer because it gets the best value for every charity care dollar."
State officials hope the plan will help get more people who are addicted to drugs or alcohol into substance-abuse treatment centers since the hospitals will be allowed to refer their uninsured patients to the programs, and then will reimburse the treatment centers with some of the money they get from the state and the Federal Government.
But the State Assembly Democratic leader, Joseph V. Doria Jr., called the Republican administration's proposal a "concept without details."
"Before we could support the Federal waiver required to implement this plan, we would need more information," he said. "We don't even know how much this system will cost, how much it will save, or how it will be funded."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Trade Forum to Take Note Of Issue of Labor Standards

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Dec. 12

 BODY:
As the end of the World Trade Organization's first meeting neared, national representatives compromised today over the question of whether the group should be involved in improving standards for workers, officials said.
They said the ministers had agreed to include a mention of labor rights, the most contentious issue at the five-day conference, in the group's final declaration on Friday. 
 Earlier today, the United States and the European Union reached agreement on a deal to liberalize trade in information technology. The agreement removed the last barrier to extending the pact to Asian nations, some of which still object to its provisions. The trade pact would phase out tariffs on a range of goods like computers, software and telecommunications equipment.
But on labor standards, the talks were in doubt. Early in the day, Pakistan declared victory in its effort to keep the trade group's communique free of a statement on the matter. But Commerce Minister Mohammed Zubair Khan, conceded later that it would be mentioned.
That would be a success for the United States, which, conference officials said, had threatened to block the declaration unless labor rights were mentioned. Washington argued that a key area of human rights had to be mentioned in connection with world trade, aware of rising concern at home about sweatshops and child labor, mostly in the third world.
But nations like Pakistan, India and Malaysia, which led the arguments, said the push to link labor rights and trade was merely a disguised attempt to use the trade organization to undermine their low-cost labor advantage.
They said that the International Labor Organization, a United Nations specialized agency, was the right forum for the issue and that the World Trade Organization had no role.
Officials at the conference said the final declaration would refer to the labor organization as "the competent body" to set and promote good labor standards and that it and the World Trade Organization would "continue their existing collaboration" on the issue. The message, they said, would "reject the use of labor standards for protectionist purposes." The ministers will also declare that they "agree that the comparative advantage of countries, particularly developing countries, must be in no way put into question."
