HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Ovitz Leaving Disney To Start Own Business
Disney said Michael S. Ovitz, one of the top power brokers in Hollywood despite being only second in command at the company, would depart.
Mr. Ovitz was known to be unhappy at Disney and had been talking privately with Sony about possible top jobs. But after the announcement of his departure, he said he was not planning to move to another company but would seek to start his own business instead. [Page A1.]
 
In the bistros and bungalows of Hollywood, the announcement that Mr. Ovitz would leave Disney was big news. But his departure will have little effect on day-to-day business of Disney, analysts said. [D5.]
 
Mr. Ovitz joins a list of Hollywood executives who have left top jobs in the last two years, including Time Warner's Michael Fuchs, Viacom's Frank Biondi, MCA's Tom Pollock and Disney's Jeffrey Katzenberg. [D5.]
 
BankAmerica Plans Big Cuts
BankAmerica said that it would eliminate 3,700 of its 92,700 jobs and close 120 of its 1,017 branches in California. To pay for the cuts, the bank will take a $260 million pretax charge against earnings. [D2.]
 
Spending Is Down and Inflation Mild
Shoppers kept a wary eye on spending as this year's late holiday shopping season got under way; retail sales were down four-tenths of 1 percent in November. Inflation remained in check, with the Consumer Price Index rising only three-tenths of 1 percent. [D5.]
 
The Congressional Budget Office raised its projection of economic growth for next year, helping to narrow the differences between Congress and the White House over the size of the budget deficit. The projections are used to help set tax and spending proposals. [A27.]
 
A Vow to Fight Tougher TV Ratings
A spokesman for the television industry vowed that the networks would fight any effort to toughen a proposed system for rating programs. [A1.]
 
Pension Shortfalls Grow
The Federal pension insurance agency said that the shortfall last year between promised pension benefits and the money set aside to pay for them grew to $64 billion, more than doubling the gap in 1994. [D6.]
 
Siemens to Dismiss 6,000
Siemens of Germany, which has already made big cuts in its work force, said that it would dismiss 6,000 more employees in an effort to return to earnings growth. [D4.]
 
Utility in Pipeline Deal
Western Resources, the expansion-minded Kansas utility, said it would sell its natural gas pipelines and plants to Oneok for $660 million in stock, a deal that will give Western access to Oneok customers across Oklahoma. [D2.]
 
Trade Forum Addresses Labor Issue
As the end of the World Trade Organization's first meeting neared, representatives compromised over whether the group should push for better standards for workers. [D4.]
 
Schwab Expands Availability
Charles Schwab said it would make a program that sells 600 mutual funds, at no fee, available to other financial institutions. Two banks, Keycorp and First Union, will offer the program, Mutual Fund Onesource. [D2.]
 
State Backs Owner
In Takeover Fight
A takeover battle for a New Hampshire company that makes devices that fold and seal cardboard boxes has taken on broad interest because of the state's response to the hostile bid for the company. Never before, experts say, has a state gone so far as to side with management in a corporate battle for control. [D2.]
 
Disclosure Sought in Fraud Suits
A group of judges and law professors is seeking to have major documents from all securities class-action lawsuits posted in at least one place on the Internet. That way they could be read by lawyers and reporters, regulators and legislators, academics and investors. Market Place. [D6.]

HEADLINE: New Whitewater Aide Had Troubles From Failed Business

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 12

 BODY:
A lawyer-lobbyist hired this week to be a high White House official handling Whitewater issues has only recently emerged from his own significant legal and financial problems arising from a small publishing business he helped to run before it collapsed three years ago.
Lanny J. Davis began working on Monday as a special White House counsel supervising Congressional and media relations on Whitewater and a variety of other investigations of the Clinton Administration. Mr. Davis, 51, an old friend of Hillary Rodham Clinton, was hired after spending the last year defending the President and his wife on television and radio programs. He had been a partner at the law firm of Patton Boggs, and is well-known in Washington and its suburbs as a radio commentator and an unsuccessful candidate for a Congressional seat in nearby Montgomery County, Md. 
 Less well known, however, is how Mr. Davis, with three other investors, embarked on a small business venture in 1988 that failed five years later, leaving behind a trail of acrimony and lawsuits that eventually were settled. Mr. Davis was a senior executive at the publishing company, as well as one of its largest shareholders and its lawyer. The business was seized by a bank in 1993 after being delinquent on loans and on payroll taxes, which it had failed to withhold from employees' paychecks nearly from the outset.
The collapse of the company left Mr. Davis near financial ruin and contemplating the possibility of personal bankruptcy. Instead, five months ago Mr. Davis settled the last of two lawsuits, which had accused him of mismanagement and negligence.
But the court settlements left unresolved Mr. Davis's actual role in the collapse of the company. And the White House never attempted to sort out those issues. Rather, the White House relied on the facts outlined in the court papers and Mr. Davis's explanation of events.
Jack Quinn, the White House counsel, said that his staff had examined the court papers describing the lawsuits against Mr. Davis, and had questioned him. Since Mr. Davis had settled the suits, Mr. Quinn said the accusations in them would not impinge on Mr. Davis's ability to perform his job or represent the Clintons on Whitewater issues that, like Mr. Davis's problems, involved delinquent loans, failed businesses, unpaid taxes, and dissatisfied business partners who say they have had to bear a disproportionate share of the venture's losses.
"We have no reason to believe this commercial dispute will in any way affect his ability to perform his duties on this staff," Mr. Quinn said in a prepared statement that he issued on Wednesday.
In performing their review of Mr. Davis, White House officials never tried to contact his three former business partners, some of whom are still angry about his role in the affair. In court papers, one investor blames Mr. Davis for mismanaging the business and misrepresenting its financial condition, being negligent in allowing payroll checks to be issued without tax being withheld, and failing to take steps to safeguard the company's books and records.
Mr. Davis said he sees some similarities between the failure of his business and Whitewater. In both cases, he said, allegations have been made that were unfounded. In both cases, a real estate recession and the savings and loan crisis took a heavy toll on the businesses.
But, he said, there were also important differences. His was a publishing venture and not a real estate one.
"My business partners were never accused or convicted of any crimes," Mr. Davis said. "No taxpayer money was ever lost by the loans."
Moreover, he said, unlike the Clintons, he was far more heavily involved in the early stages of the business.
"I was much more active in the business than either of the Clintons and therefore had much more responsibility," Mr. Davis said. "I feel proud that I ultimately stepped up to the line at great expense and pain to me and my family and paid a heavy price to settle all my obligations."
In a $5.5 million leveraged buyout in 1988, Mr. Davis and three other investors bought the Record Company, a small newspaper and printing business in Silver Spring, Md., from the Mahaffeys, a family that had run the company for 50 years. Mr. Davis was one of the three largest shareholders of the company, served as its lawyer, was a member of its board and a senior corporate officer.
 
The Partners
Business Venture Dissolves in Failure
The group put together by Mr. Davis initially consisted of Vicki L. Bagley, a Washington businesswoman, and Theodore J. Venetoulis, a former Baltimore County executive who had run unsuccessfully for governor of Maryland. The fourth investor, Stanley Cohen, joined the group after the bank complained that there was not enough capital in the venture.
After the company collapsed five years later, lawsuits were filed against Mr. Davis and Ms. Bagley by the bank and by Mr. Cohen. Mr. Venetoulis sought shelter under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy code. During negotiations over how to resolve the competing claims, Mr. Davis said he also might seek bankruptcy, but he never did.
Instead, last June he agreed to pay $40,000 to settle the suit filed by Mr. Cohen, who had guaranteed a $100,000 bank loan to Mr. Davis for the venture. By the time of the settlement, the loan had been reduced to about $60,000. The lawsuit accused Mr. Davis of mismanagement, misrepresenting the financial condition, and of negligence in failing to make sure that the company had paid its payroll taxes.
Mr. Davis also successfully contested a $300,000 tax lien that the Internal Revenue Service had placed on his home for the payroll taxes that the Record Company had failed to withhold. Mr. Davis said that the I.R.S. concluded that he was not the responsible party.
In addition, last year Mr. Davis paid $127,500 to Nationsbank to resolve the $400,000 personal guarantee he had given for a $3.2 million loan to make the acquisition. At the time, the bank claimed it was owed $1.8 million on the loan; it collected $268,000 from Ms. Bagley and $254,000 from Lynn M. Venetoulis, the wife of Mr. Venetoulis.
The Mahaffeys, who received a $2.3 million promissory note from Mr. Davis, Mr. Venetoulis and Ms. Bagley, had to make do with about $1 million less than they had been promised, lawyers said.
Mr. Davis acknowledged in interviews that he had over-extended himself in taking out such large loans, and that he and Mr. Venetoulis, the two investors most heavily involved in running the company, had made business mistakes, but did nothing venal.
"Mistakes were made by all of us, but certainly by Ted and myself," he said. He said he ultimately lost $232,500 in loan repayments and settlements, wiping out most of his savings. (The calculation does not include $145,000 in salary and other payments Mr. Davis received from the company.)
 
The Accusations
Assessing Blame For Collapse
In court documents Mr. Davis denied the accusations in the lawsuit he settled in June that had been brought by Mr. Cohen. The complaint said that because of Mr. Davis's negligence, the company had failed to pay hundreds of thousands of dollars in payroll taxes, corporate assets were wasted, and some of the company's books and records were not kept in an orderly way. After the bank had seized the company, it complained that it was unable to find some important records.
"Cohen understood that Davis remained intricately involved in the Record Company's business and financial affairs," Mr. Cohen said in court papers. "It is disingenuous at best for Davis to plead a lack of responsibility for the financial failure of the Record Company."
Mr. Davis denied Mr. Cohen's accusations.
"Stanley Cohen was very bitter," Mr. Davis said. "He threw in a lot of charges in his complaint that were totally without foundation. His charges are totally unfair."
Mr. Cohen initially declined to discuss the failure of the Record Company. But he changed his mind after hearing Mr. Davis's comments about him.
"The court record speaks for itself and is accurate," Mr. Cohen said.
Mr. Davis said in court papers that Mr. Venetoulis was responsible for the Record Company's failure to make the payroll taxes.
"I was not aware that payroll taxes were not paid," Mr. Davis said. "When I found out about it, I was shocked by it. I was made aware of it after the fact. Ted Venetoulis was in charge."
He also said it was Mr. Venetoulis who was responsible for safeguarding the books and records. "Ted Venetoulis was in charge at the time and I had no knowledge of what happened," Mr. Davis said. "There clearly was a problem with the books and records."
In court papers, Mr. Cohen said that Mr. Davis's professed ignorance of these matters "is either inconceivable or demonstrates his complete ineptitude as a director and officer of the Record Company."
Mr. Venetoulis declined to discuss the Record Company. His lawyer, Judith Sturtz Karp, said the payroll taxes became a problem because a bookkeeper whom she would not identify had failed to withhold the taxes. Ms. Karp said that at the time, Mr. Davis was acting as a senior financial officer of the company. Mr. Davis denied that.
Court records show that Mr. Davis's title was president and associate publisher of the publishing unit of the Record Company and executive vice president of the composition unit of the company.
Ms. Karp said that the breakup of the Record Company was "a nasty, nasty, nasty situation."
"Lanny was slinging the most mud," she said. "He accused everybody of everything except he never looked in the mirror. He would say, 'my wife didn't sign anything, so I've got nothing to lose.' Lanny thought he was untouchable under Maryland law," which protects the assets owned jointly by a husband and wife from the creditors of them individually.
Ms. Karp said that although the bank complained when it seized the company's assets that it could not find some of the books and records, neither Mr. Venetoulis nor Mr. Davis removed or destroyed any records.
Joanne Stevens, a spokeswoman for Nationsbank in Maryland, declined to comment.
Mr. Davis said that when he became involved in the Record Company and pledged to guarantee $400,000 of a $3.2 million bank loan, he was told by his banker that he was pledging his entire net worth. Still, two years later he borrowed heavily again, buying a townhouse with Mr. Venetoulis on Fenwick Island, Del., for $425,000, which required a $375,000 mortgage. After Mr. Venetoulis went into bankruptcy, Mr. Davis said he could not meet the payments on the house and he sold it for $315,000. Rather than surrender the house, he said, he decided to take out a new $90,000, 10-year loan from Citibank to make up the shortfall.
 
The Career
A Tough Time As a Politician
Mr. Davis has been a partner at Patton Boggs since 1978 and has long been active in politics as a Maryland representative on the Democratic National Committee.
After graduating from Yale Law School, Mr. Davis decided to make his own run at politics, twice running for Congress. He did not have an easy time. In 1974, as political scandals cast dark clouds over Washington, he reported that important campaign files had been stolen from his office. The papers later turned up in a storage room. Mr. Davis's critics accused him of a publicity stunt. Mr. Davis has said the incident might have been staged by a disgruntled campaign aide.
When he ran again two years later, he was criticized for campaign literature that said he had graduated cum laude from Yale Law School even though Yale did not use that distinction. He apologized at the time and said the error was inadvertent. He also failed to report properly to the Federal Election Commission that he had received $8,500 in loans from colleagues at Patton Boggs and family members. He said that mistake was based on a misunderstanding of Federal election law.

HEADLINE: Stocks Plunge Again as Dow Falls by 98.81

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Stocks continued their December swoon yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 1.5 percent in a daylong decline that was capped with a 46-point plunge in the last half-hour of trading.
Other indexes dropped as well, with the Standard and Poor's index of 500 stocks also off 1.5 percent and the Nasdaq composite index down eight-tenths of 1 percent. The Dow fell 98.81 points, to 6,303.71, its sharpest one-day drop in terms of points since July 15. 
 The declines were sharper than they were on Wednesday, when world markets plunged and American interest rates shot sharply higher in a sign of investor nervousness after strong rallies in both stocks and bonds since the American elections.
Yesterday, global stock markets were up or down only slightly. And the American bond market finished the day little changed. But it was the reversal of an early rally in the bond market that helped propel the decline in stocks. And a further rise in interest rates could push stock prices even lower in the near term. It was the sharp drop in long-term interest rates in November that helped propel the Dow and the S.& P. to their highs.
"If you introduce any kind of interest rate threat you have some real vulnerability," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley & Company.
The nervousness on Wall Street spilled over into the Asian markets early today, with stocks in Tokyo tumbling at the opening. The Nikkei index of 225 issues fell more than 500 points, or 2.5 percent, in hectic morning trading to less than the psychologically important level of 20,000.
But the Nikkei rebounded to close down 159.81 points, or 0.78 percent, at 20,341.39. Stock markets in Hong Kong and Australia were also sharply lower.
The decline overseas was prompted largely by a sharp drop in a S.& P. 500 futures contract, which trades around the clock on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
The March S.& P. contract fell to a low of 725.95 in early trading in Tokyo, down from its close in the United States at 734.50, and down from the actual S.& P. 500 index of 729.30. Typically, the futures price is slightly higher than the actual index. At midnight in New York, the contract had recovered to 734.50.
The selloff in Asia may further rattle nerves on Wall Street today, given that yesterday's tumble in the Dow came largely in the last 15 minutes of trading.
And after the market closed, a leading technology stock on the Nasdaq market, the Oracle Corporation reported earnings that were lower than expected. The company reported earnings of 27 cents a share in the second quarter, a penny shy of Wall Street estimates. In after-hours trading, shares of Oracle fell 2 1/4 from its close of 47 1/4..
Still, several analysts were not worried late yesterday about Wall Street's recent slump.
Alfred Goldman, the director of market analysis at A. G. Edwards Inc. in St Louis, said yesterday that the selloff was positive. "This is a very normal correction," he said, alluding to the kind of breather markets take after strong rallies. And referring to the comments of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, last week, he added, "This is removing some of the greed that Greenspan was worried about."
In a speech Dec. 5, the Fed chairman asked whether the stock market was rising because of "irrational exuberance." He did not answer the question but his comments set off a stock selloff last Friday. Investors are still talking about what his comment meant for the stock and bond markets.
The Dow is now down 3.73 percent since it set a closing high of 6,547.79 on Nov. 25. That is half in percentage terms of the fall the Dow took from its closing high in May -- then the record -- when fears of a too-strong economy and a Federal Reserve interest rate increase sent stocks plunging in July. In December, the Dow is off 3.34 percent, which has eaten up about 40 percent of its spectacular November rally.
Nearly 30 percent of the Dow's decline was accounted for by two stocks, Philip Morris, which was off 3 3/4, to 113 3/4, and I.B.M., which fell 4 1/2, to 151 5/8. Philip Morris and I.B.M. helped lead the November rally and the selling now seemed to indicate that some investors and money managers were trying to lock in their gains at a time when the near-term market outlook has been clouded by Mr. Greenspan's comments, the rise in interest rates and the outlook for the economy.
Another unknown is how mutual fund investors will respond if the declines continue. There are preliminary indications that the flow of money into stock funds slowed considerably in the first week of December.
"Whether 6,500 on the Dow was too much or 6,300 is the bottom, I don't know," said Joseph V. Battipaglia, chief investment strategist at Gruntal & Company. But, he added, the economic fundamentals that have helped push the stock market higher have not changed.
The decline in the Dow was the first since January in which the Dow fell more than 1 percent on each of two consecutive days.
Laszlo Birinyi, the head of Greenwich Associates, a market analysis firm in Greenwich, Conn.said that after the bond rally failed yesterday morning, there were numerous computer-driven sell programs that hit the market, with many coming in the final minutes. He estimated that but for those programs the Dow would have been up for the day.
David Shulman, the chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers, said that there was no clear cause of the selloff, other than a failed bond rally.
Hugh Johnson, an investment strategist at First Albany, also said that there was no obvious reason for the selling, but that it reflected investor nervousness after the big rally that pushed up the Dow more than 500 points during November. "When they start to sell stocks, it can look like a race to the exit," he said. "That's what it looked like today."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Higher After an Accord To Stabilize the Planned Euro

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar seesawed in global foreign exchange trading yesterday before shooting higher on news of an agreement among European Union finance ministers to stabilize the proposed single European currency.
New hope for a viable single European currency, called the Euro, undermined the mark. Traders who had incorrectly bet on a falling dollar scrambled to buy the dollar to minimize losses. That pushed the dollar even higher in what is known as a short-covering rally. 
 "There was a rush to get in and buy some dollars," said Victor Polce, corporate foreign exchange manager at the New York branch of Commerzbank.
In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.5558 marks, up sharply from 1.5423 marks Thursday. The dollar traded at 113.95 Japanese yen, up from 113.27. The British pound fell to $1.6554 from $1.6576.
The dollar initially strengthened in early Asian trading on rumors that Japanese officials want an exchange rate of 120 yen to the dollar, a level of yen weakness last seen nearly four years ago, in order to make Japan's exports more affordable abroad and help its economic recovery.
The rumors were said to come from the newsletter of Johnson Smick International, a Washington consulting firm founded by Manuel H. Johnson, a former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, and a former Congressional aide, David M. Smick. But the firm denied it was reporting such information.
In New York trading, the dollar fell, rose and fell again, mimicking the stock market in a pattern that has been repeated most of the week. But currency traders diverted their attention from the stock market when European Union finance ministers reached an agreement aimed at insuring the Euro's stability after it makes its debut on Jan. 1, 1999. Word of the pact at a European meeting in Dublin, led to a selloff in the mark, which would be replaced by the Euro as Europe's dominant currency.
"When the stock market started off down we sold the dollar, when it came back we bought the dollar, when it went down we sold the dollar again," said Thomas Lapinski, chief dealer at the MTB Bank Corporation in New York. "When the stability pact was announced, the dollar just took off, and it was pretty much one way up after that."

HEADLINE: Treasury Securities Higher As Firm Dollar Aids Bonds

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Government securities traded higher yesterday, aided by weak economic data and a firm dollar.
Shorter maturities attracted investors who were shifting from the stock market, while a strong dollar, which makes United States investments more attractive to foreign investors, helped underpin bond prices. 
 The 30-year bond rose 21/32 , to a price of 993/32 ; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, slipped to 6.57 percent, from 6.62 percent on Thursday.
For the last few sessions, the market has largely ignored economic data, with technical factors dominating trade. But yields declined yesterday after the Government reported that business inventories in October had increased a larger-than-expected half-percent -- matching the gain in July. While inventory buildups can help the economy in the short term, they threaten an economic slowdown if not matched by sales.
Investors also reacted to a University of Michigan survey that indicated consumer sentiment fell in December to 98.8 from 99.2 in November. Most had expected a rise of two-tenths of 1 percent.
James Padinha, an economist with MMS International in San Francisco, said that consumer expectations had been rising for a long time and that the University of Michigan index was indicating "there was not much of a slowdown in the economy."
"The inventory increase," he added, "on the other hand is stronger than expected, but not threatening."
Steven Landis, director of fixed- income investments at Bull and Bear Advisors Inc., said he saw value in the market. "All of the news this week has been market friendly," he said, "and the market has reached levels where you will be glad you bought securities."
He said the Treasury auction of two-year and five-year notes next week, along with coupon payments and payments on maturing issues, would put about $4.5 billion in cash back into the market by the time the year is out.
Mr. Landis attributed the positive ending to the market's week to short- covering by dealers and overseas buying spurred by a strong dollar.
"The dollar firmed," he said "on news that the European Union finance ministers had reached agreement on penalties to protect the future European common currency from being wrecked by excessive borrowing by national governments. And the agreement seems to have clout behind it."
Next week, the Federal Reserve's monetary policy arm will meet on Tuesday for a one-day meeting; few expect the central bank to adjust interest rates in the last meeting of the year. On Wednesday and Thursday, the Treasury will auction $30.75 billion of new two-year and five-year notes.
In when-issued trading, the two-year note is being offered at a price to yield 5.74 percent and the five-year at a price to yield 6.05 percent.

HEADLINE: Anti-Apartheid Fighter Charged With Defrauding Relief Funds

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 13

 BODY:
A former clergyman who was once a prominent anti-apartheid activist and became a high-level official in the African National Congress was charged today with fraud and theft involving the misuse of half a million dollars contributed to his nonprofit organization.
The investigation of the ex-clergyman, Allan Boesak, took nearly two years, and the case has often been cited as an example of the new Government's failure to deal swiftly with charges of corruption and misconduct leveled against its own. 
 But today in a Cape Town courtroom, Mr. Boesak was charged with 9 counts of fraud and 21 counts of theft involving the disappearance of more than $500,000 -- mostly money donated to his Foundation for Peace and Justice by Danish and Swedish aid organizations.
Mr. Boesak, who has been living in Berkeley, Calif., for the past year as a fellow at the American Baptist Seminary of the West, was not in court. But lawyers for his accountant, Freddie Steenkamp, who was also charged, said Mr. Boesak would return in January to face charges. Mr. Steenkamp appeared in court today and was released on $500 bail.
Mr. Boesak did not return telephone calls to his office in Berkeley. He has denied any wrongdoing.
Back when challenging apartheid was dangerous, Mr. Boesak was a minister in Cape Town who won international fame for leading the charge to have the Dutch Reformed Church condemn apartheid.
When the charges of misusing funds first surfaced in late 1993, Mr. Boesak had become the A.N.C.'s provincial leader in the Cape Town area and was South Africa's representative-designate to the United Nations.
At first, African National Congress officials tried to brush aside the charges. Lawyers assembled to investigate the incident under the direction of Deputy President Thabo Mbeki issued a report clearing Mr. Boesak of all wrongdoing.
Mr. Mbeki did say Mr. Boesak's accounting practices were extremely poor, but he found that it was Mr. Boesak who was actually owed money -- about $65,000.
Mr. Boesak demanded apologies, retractions and reparations from the aid agencies that had made the accusations. But the donors scoffed at Mr. Mbeki's findings.
Lawyers for DanChurch Aid, a Danish church group, said Mr. Boesak had diverted as much as $835,000 from helping victims of apartheid to buy a luxurious home in Cape Town and to settle his wife's debts.
The aid agencies turned their findings over to the Office for Serious Economic Offenses in South Africa, which took more than a year to turn its findings over to the Attorney General for Cape Town.
The allegations over misappropriation of funds were not Mr. Boesak's first brush with scandal: He had been forced to resign his ministry in 1990 after acknowledging an extramarital affair with the woman who is now his second wife.

HEADLINE: THE SECOND TERM;
Remarks From Nominee for Commerce Secretary

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
Following is a transcript of William M. Daley's remarks today after being chosen as Commerce Secretary, as recorded by the Federal Document Clearing House, a transcription company:
Thank you very much, Mr. President, for your kind words and particularly for your confidence. Let me extend my deep appreciation to you and the Vice President. I am honored to join such a strong team and a distinguished economic team. 
 I believe there has never been a more vigorous commitment to the creation and expansion of markets for American businesses large and small than the one which we have seen under this Administration.
President Clinton understands the economic challenges of our times. He understands the new world in which America must compete if we are to meet, make, the next century as promising and as prosperous for our nation and its people as the one that's about to end.
I was privileged to witness firsthand his leadership, and his leadership of Secretaries Brown and Kantor, when we launched unprecedented efforts to aid American business by identifying opportunities and lowering barriers at home and abroad. And that's one major reason that we have seen steady economic growth and robust job creation for the past four years.
I deeply believe in the ingenuity, creative energy and productive capacity of this great nation. In the nearly 100 years since the Commerce Department was inaugurated, these qualities have helped America become the economic engine and envy of the world.
I should not let this moment pass without noting the tremendous efforts and dedication of the department's staff and the workers of that department throughout the world.
We live in a very different world today, a world in which competition is all around us. And more is required of us to maintain that economic leadership.
My commitment to you, Mr. President, and to our fellow Americans, is to work day and night in partnership with American businesses, from Fortune 500 companies to small businesses, in our inner cities and rural America, to help face the challenges and seize the opportunities which lie ahead for us.
And if you'll permit me one note, one final note, Mr. President, public service often is demeaned and denigrated in these days. But I have a very different view. I come a family in which we were taught, by word and example, that there is no higher calling or greater trust. If the Senate will honor me with their confirmation, it is my intent to serve in that spirit.
Mr. President, I can think of no greater distinction than to serve you and our country. On behalf of my family, my wife, Loretta, my daughters Lauren, Moira, and my son, William, who's here, I thank you immensely. And congratulations to my new colleagues. And, again, I thank you for this great opportunity.

HEADLINE: Salesman For Unity Kofi Atta Annan

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 13

 BODY:
A year ago, Kofi Annan flew to the war-battered capital of Bosnia to preside as the United Nations handed over a foundering peacekeeping mission to NATO.
His eloquent litany of the West's failings there was a performance, many say, that helped establish him as the leading contender for the job he won today: Secretary General of the United Nations. 
 "The world cannot claim ignorance of what those who live here have endured," Mr. Annan, a Ghanaian who was then the representative of the Secretary General in Bosnia, said that day in Sarajevo. "In looking back, we should all recall how we responded to the escalating horrors of the last four years. And, as we do, there are questions which each of us must ask: What did I do? Could I have done more? Did I let my prejudice, or my fear, overwhelm my reasoning? And, above all, how would I react next time?"
A diplomat known for candor and clear speaking, Mr. Annan is regarded as particularly suited for one job that defeated the departing Boutros Boutros-Ghali: selling the United Nations to skeptics, especially in the United States Congress.
Where Mr. Boutros-Ghali is an intellectual, private to the point of being reclusive, and sometimes prickly, Mr. Annan is considered accessible, affable and astute in the public politics of the job. Where Mr. Boutros-Ghali is admired, Mr. Annan is liked.
This evening, after the soft-spoken descendant of a family of paramount chieftains was named the next Secretary General -- the first black African to hold the job -- diplomats recalled how skillfully he negotiated his way among the four contentious outside powers in Bosnia: the United States, Britain, France and Russia.
"He is the only top official of the U.N. who came out of the Bosnia experience with dignity and without having harmed the organization or relations with any one of the great powers," an American official said. "That's what a great diplomat's about."
The United States vetoed Mr. Boutros-Ghali's pursuit of a second term, contending that without a new face the United Nations would never persuade a dubious Congress that it was on a serious course of reform. Of Mr. Annan, the American official said, "He has the right skills and credentials to bring this organization into the 21st century."
In choosing Mr. Annan, the Security Council has selected a consummate insider, a lifelong international civil servant.
Among his critics, especially the French, who would have preferred a candidate with political and ministerial experience (and from a French-speaking nation), there is concern that Mr. Annan may lack the stature or clout of his predecessor.
Mr. Boutros-Ghali, a former Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of State for Foreign Affairs in his native Egypt, came to the United Nations from a career in international diplomacy, much of it in the tough world of Middle Eastern and African peacemaking.
Mr. Annan's resume is more administrative: Assistant Secretary General for Program Planning, Budget and Finance, head of human resources and security coordinator, director of the budget, chief of personnel for the High Commissioner for Refugees, administrative officer for the Economic Commission for Africa.
He was named Under Secretary General for Peacekeeping Operations on March 1, 1993, just in time to watch the debacle in Somalia the following fall and the genocide in Rwanda the next spring. He stood by in frustration as the major nations of the world, led by the United States, refused to intervene in Rwanda.
But over the years Mr. Annan has been given assignments in difficult moments, and has undertaken risky diplomatic missions and managed them with quiet success. After the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in 1990, he was sent to Iraq to negotiate the release of hostages and the safe passage of 500,000 Asian workers stranded in the region.
His handover of the United Nations operation in Bosnia impressed officials of several major countries.
Back in New York in 1996, he brought the same clear language to renewed threats of genocide in Central Africa.
In July, with a crisis looming in Burundi, he said: "We have to move very quickly before everything blows up in our faces. As it is, history will judge us rather severely for Rwanda. I don't think we can repeat that experience in Burundi."
His calls for a multinational force went unheeded, however. No United Nations official, not even a Secretary General, can force an action beyond what leading member nations are willing to authorize and support.
Kofi Atta Annan was born into a prominent family in Kumasi, Ghana -- a British colony then called the Gold Coast -- on April 8, 1938. His father was the elected Governor of Ashanti Province and a hereditary paramount chief of the Fante people. The young Mr. Annan began his education at a local university of science and technology, then went on to Macalester College in St. Paul for a degree in economics.
Graduate studies at the Institut Universitaire de Hautes Etudes Internationales in Geneva followed. In 1971-72, he was a Sloan Fellow at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he received a master of science degree in management.
By then he had joined the United Nations, first in Geneva at the World Health Organization. He remained with the organization -- except for two years in the mid-1970's when he returned to Ghana to take over national tourism development -- for the rest of his career, serving in Europe, Africa and New York.
Mr. Annan's first marriage, to a Nigerian, ended in divorce. In 1984, he married Nane Lagergren, a Swedish lawyer and judge whose mother was the sister of Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish diplomat who died, apparently in Russian hands, trying to save the lives of Jews in World War II. The couple, who have been living on Roosevelt Island but will soon move to the Secretary General's official residence on Sutton Place, have three children: a daughter, Ama, 27, and a son, Kojo, 23, from his first marriage, and a daughter, Nina, 26, from his wife's first marriage.
Mr. Annan is popular with the United Nations staff, and today a colleague told a story to illustrate why.
Once this official got in trouble for an unguarded comment to the press. Mr. Annan endured the tongue-lashing himself, then called in the offending colleague, who was sure his job was lost, and delivered a short, sweet message, "Don't let the turkeys get you down."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kofi Annan, center, at the ceremony at which Adm. Leighton W. Smith, left, the NATO commander in Bosnia, took over the peacekeeping mission there from Lieut. Gen. Bernard Janvier, of the United Nations. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Often-Criticized Bridge Agency Votes to Increase the Only Toll on L.I.

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

DATELINE: ATLANTIC BEACH, L.I., Dec. 13

 BODY:
In the world of bridges, the Nassau County Bridge Authority, whose sole purpose is to operate a drawbridge here, is one of a kind.
Vehicles cross the bridge 7.5 million times a year, filling the authority's coffers with toll revenues. It is the only toll on any road or bridge on Long Island. 
 Over the years, its operations have been denounced by District Attorney Denis Dillon as a Republican Party patronage mill, criticized by State Comptroller Edward Regan as wasteful and investigated by several county grand juries for things like toll skimming and no-show jobs.
The bridge connects Atlantic Beach, at the western tip of the Long Beach barrier island, with the main body of Long Island. The north end of the bridge is where Nassau meets Queens and the Nassau Expressway begins. Lawrence is on one side of the border and the Rockaways on the other.
Many critics contend that the tolls should be abolished, along with the authority itself. They call the agency a self-perpetuating expense, because it spends most of its $3 million annual toll revenue to pay the collectors and for administrative overhead, rather than for bridge operations.
Nevertheless, the authority's three-member commission voted unanimously today to raise the passenger-car toll to $1.25 each way, from 75 cents, despite a protest by 200 angry drivers at a hearing last week. But the authority scaled back the increase proposed for discounted frequent-user passes, a tactic it has used in the past to mollify those who use the bridge the most. A round trip for those who buy a 40-trip ticket book will increase to 75 cents.
"Instead of highway robbery, these guys have figured out a new crime," said the County Legislature's Democratic minority leader, Bruce Nyman. "It's called bridge robbery." The bridge divides his district from that of the Republican majority leader, Bruce A. Blakeman, who also opposed the toll increases.
Although its construction bonds were paid off long ago, the authority says it needs more money to offset inflation since the last increase a decade ago. For three years, the agency has been operating in the red. It says it also needs $14 million for overdue repairs of wear, rust, rot, corrosion, cracking and deterioration of the bridge and its underwater electric cables.
"This is what we need to move ahead," a bridge commissioner, Les Hecht, said at the meeting, in the cramped basement cafeteria of the authority's headquarters.
Many residents in this wealthy community, where bayfront homes can cost $1 million, say they prize the battery of 10 gated tollbooths as a barrier to unwanted outsiders. The bridge property abuts the New York City boundary at Rockaway.
"We do not mind paying a reasonable toll," said Barry Ringelheim, president of the Atlantic Beach Estates Civic Association. "People feel it's a protection. God forbid somebody will come over to rob and have to go back over the bridge and be seen" by toll collectors.
The bridge has long been a target of scrutiny. In the 1980's, a county grand jury recommended eliminating the authority and tolls and turning over the bridge to the County Public Works Department, which operates two other drawbridges.
"The authority operates not as a business, but as a base to keep a relative handful of people in jobs that are largely make-work," the investigators' report said. "Supporting this patronage is a highly inequitable system of charges that subsidizes local residents to the detriment" of other bridge users.
One of the authority's biggest critics is its own former executive director, Edward J. Walpole, who left in September and has filed a $2.5 million wrongful discharge claim. He accused politicians of padding the payroll with useless jobs and forcing him out when he tried to cut costs by laying off 9 of the 38 full-time workers. He said he had also planned to cut the hours of the 65 part timers.
Even the authority's last chairman, Peter DeSibio, once proposed doing away with the agency. Skeptics pointed out, however, that he had regularly recommended relatives and other job applicants to the authority. Mr. Walpole is his son-in-law.
Despite such calls for change, the authority and its tolls have endured. County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, who appoints the commissioners, has his own budget problems and is not looking to add an aging bridge to the county's portfolio.
Critics say the bridge symbolizes the persistence of fiefs, even in the era of downsizing, that have endowed Long Island with the nation's highest local taxes. The Island has two counties, two cities, 13 towns, dozens of villages and school districts and nearly 1,000 other districts for libraries, sewers and other purposes.
"The bridge is really the lifeline of this community," said the Mayor of Atlantic Beach, Stephen R. Mahler.
Long Beach Island has two other drawbridges, a county-operated bridge at mid-island and the state-operated Loop Parkway Bridge at the east end. Both are free, but using them to avoid the toll could mean a detour of up to 15 miles.
When New York City residents commit misdeeds in Nassau, at least one weekly newspaper labels them "crossover crimes." Underscoring the security concern, an unoccupied county police car is often parked prominently by the tollbooths.
Some residents are said to make disparaging racial remarks about "those people" coming over the bridge. The beach is restricted to village residents and beach club members.
Most of the traffic consists of regular commuters, plus beach users in the summer. The daily number of trips doubled from a low of 13,594 in February to a high of 27,130 in June.
For frequent users, 40-ticket books will go to $15 in January, from $10 now, instead of the initial proposal of $25. A decal that provides unlimited passage for a year will go to $75 from $60, instead of the proposed $100. The discount users make up about two-thirds of the trips over the bridge but pay a little over a third of the toll charges, a disparity that will grow under the new rates.
The authority is exempting two small groups from the new tolls. Pedestrians and bicyclists, who now pay a nickel, will cross free.
The steel and concrete bridge, 1,173 feet long and 68 feet wide, carries three lanes of traffic in each direction. The center decks raise to allow tall boats to pass. Last year, the bridge opened 2,300 times, with a daily average ranging from 4 in February to 9 in July. The control tower is staffed 24 hours a day.
Under Federal law, boats pay no tolls. Most are oil tankers and barges headed for the Oil City depot near Island Park. The others are fishing and pleasure boats.
The bridge originated with the dream of Stephen P. Pettit, a developer, to transform the fragile sandbar here into a luxury seaside community. He once envisioned the world's longest boardwalk, linking Long Beach and the Rockaways.
In the 1920's, he organized work crews and teams of horses to dredge and fill. He won Federal permission to build a private toll bridge, which opened in 1927. With his death, the bridge passed to a new company. In 1945 the State Legislature and county officials created the authority to take over the old bridge and replace it with the current one in 1952.
Although bridge officials hinted today that they would try to curb costs through attrition, the critics are doubtful. Phoebe Goodman, director of the Nassau Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit watchdog group, said traditions die hard. "Around here," she said, "we do what we do because we've always done it this way."

HEADLINE: THE SECOND TERM: Man in the News;
The Patient Nominee: William Michael Daley

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 13

 BODY:
The appointment of William M. Daley to President Clinton's Cabinet was supposed to have been a done deal four years ago, or at least that was the way people around here saw it.
Back then, Mr. Daley, who was nominated today as Secretary of Commerce, was the odds-on choice to be named the Secretary of Transportation, his reward for all the work he and his big brother, Mayor Richard M. Daley, had done to help send the Governor of Arkansas to the White House. 
 But Mr. Clinton chose Federico F. Pena, the Mayor of Denver, and Mr. Daley stayed home in Chicago, where a lot of the Daley brothers' political allies fumed over the President's decision. Two years later, when the Republicans buried the Democrats in the 1994 Congressional elections, the wounds were still raw.
"They don't know what they are doing at the White House," the younger Daley said at the time.
Still, the brothers remained loyal supporters of President Clinton, even if they worried that he was moving too far from their beloved middle. William Daley, a lawyer and former banker, commuted to Washington and helped push the North American Free Trade Agreement through Congress, using the political skills he learned at the feet of his father, Richard J. Daley, the legendary and longtime mayor.
He also played an important role in managing the Democratic National Convention here last summer, helping to insure the party's successful return to the city where its 1968 convention ended in tear gas and protests. And last month, he helped deliver to Mr. Clinton 80 percent of the vote in Chicago, and nearly 55 percent of the vote across the state.
As it turns out, said Paul Green, a political science professor at Governors State University in Illinois, Mr. Daley is probably a better choice as Secretary of Commerce than he would have been as Transportation Secretary.
"He's very comfortable working with the Republican business community," Professor Green said. "He'll work as smoothly with the Republicans in Congress as anyone you've ever seen. He's a coalition builder. He's very smart, very professional. Summing up, Bill Daley is a winner."
In Chicago, when one's last name is Daley, winning, especially at politics, is like a family heirloom, handed down from generation to generation. But by most accounts, Mr. Daley, 48, is a formidable talent in his own right.
James R. Thompson, the former Republican Governor of Illinois, described Mr. Daley as "a good thing for the President, because Bill Daley is a smart, savvy guy and he's the kind of guy who belongs in the President's Cabinet."
Mr. Thompson said Mr. Daley would be an aggressive representative of American business and would help shine a spotlight on business Chicago and Illinois.
"Believe it or not," Mr. Thompson said, "we're still relatively unknown in Europe and Asia, which focuses on the East Coast and the West Coast. A lot of European businessmen have never been to Chicago. The appointment of a Chicagoan at Commerce is going to raise our visibility around the world."
Representative Bobby L. Rush, a Chicago Democrat who rarely sees eye to eye with the much more conservative Mayor Daley, was more cautious in praising the President's nominee. But Mr. Rush praised him for his political shrewdness.
"He knows the art of the deal," Mr. Rush said. "He's a moderate Democrat. Part of his philosophy is what's good for Chicago is good for the nation. Another part is what's Daley's is good for Chicago."
William Michael Daley was one of seven children -- four boys and three girls -- born to Richard and Eleanor Daley. He grew up in the working-class South Side Bridgeport neighborhood, his father's political power base, attending De La Salle High School.
Mr. Daley graduated from Loyola University, on the city's North Side, and obtained a law degree from the John Marshall Law School here. He began practicing law in Chicago in 1975, and two years later was appointed by President Jimmy Carter to a post on the Advisory Council on Economic Development.
Unlike his father and older brother, Mr. Daley has never been elected to public office, but he has advised a number of campaigns for others, including those for his brother and Carol Moseley-Braun, who in 1992 became the first black woman elected to the United States Senate. He also worked on the Presidential campaigns of Walter F. Mondale and Michael S. Dukakis.
In recent years, Mr. Daley has served as a partner in one of Chicago's biggest law firms, Mayer, Brown & Platt, where he has spent much of his time on corporate and government relations.
Mr. Daley was the president and chief operating officer of the Amalgamated Bank of Chicago from 1990 to 1993 and sits on several civic and corporate boards, including the board of the Federal National Mortgage Association and the board of the Field Museum.
Mr. Daley and his wife, Loretta, have three children.
Today, Mr. Daley's older brother, the Mayor, was beaming.
"Bill has had a great career in his own right," the Mayor said. "He's earned this. Our family is very proud of Bill and excited for him. It's an early Christmas present for our family."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Clinton Fills Economic Jobs, Bolstering Rubin's Powers
President Clinton rounded out his team of senior economic advisers, nominating William Daley, a lawyer and scion of the legendary Chicago Democratic family, as Commerce Secretary, and making several appointments that effectively consolidated the power of Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin as the dominant Cabinet officer.
To head the National Economic Council, Mr. Clinton picked his longtime domestic adviser, Gene Sperling. He named Daniel K. Tarullo, Mr. Sperling's co-deputy under the outgoing chairwoman, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, to oversee international economic affairs. Lawrence Summers, Mr. Rubin's deputy at Treasury, was given a seat on the Economic Council. All are allies of Mr. Rubin. [Page 1.]
 
William Daley's nomination as Secretary of Commerce comes as a reward for many services, from lobbying for the North American Free Trade Act to helping deliver 80 percent of the vote in Chicago. [11.]

Debut of the Euro's Design
The design for the Euro, the proposed single European currency, was introduced in a news conference that highlighted how sensitive the matter is to some member nations. The bills will have no images of historic figures, or even of identifiable landmarks. Its sweeping bridges and stone gateways are fictitious. In a concession to national loyalties, though, a small space has been reserved for nations to insert their own national symbols. [36.]
 
Swiss Bank Discloses Nazi Profit
The Swiss National Bank publicly acknowledged that it had made a profit, which it estimated at 20 million Swiss francs, on its wartime dealings in gold bullion with Nazi Germany's central bank. But it denied there was any evidence it held gold stolen from individual Holocaust victims. [3.]
 
Boeing 747 Fuel Problem Identified
The National Transportation Safety Board says it has identified a fuel-system piping problem on Boeing 747's that can ignite explosions like the one that destroyed T.W.A. Flight 800 last July, and it issued an urgent recommendation that airlines be required to take steps to address the problem. [1.]
 
Chances End for Data Base Pact
Prospects died for an early agreement on an international treaty extending copyright protection for computerized data bases, with the chief American negotiator acknowledging that many countries needed more time to debate it. But discussions continued on two other proposals on intellectual property. In Singapore 28 nations endorsed an Information Technology Agreement. [36.]

Inventories Grew in October
Business inventories rose half of 1 percent in October, the biggest growth in three months, the Commerce Department said. It was the biggest rise since a half-percent advance in July and topped the three-tenths of 1 percent forecast of many analysts. [37.]

Dollar Strengthens
Against Mark
The dollar shot higher on news of an agreement among European Union finance ministers to stabilize the Euro, whose improving prospects particularly undermined the German mark. In New York, the dollar rose to 1.5558 marks, up sharply from 1.5423 marks Thursday. The dollar also traded at 113.95 Japanese yen, up from 113.27. [38.]

Prices of Treasuries Climb
The strong dollar, aided by weak economic data, helped underpin bond prices. The 30-year bond rose 21/32 to a price of 993/32 , pushing its yield down to 6.57 percent. [37.]

Heating Oil and Gas Prices Rise
Heating oil and natural gas futures prices surged, as traders reacted to forecasts of unusually cold weather in the Midwest and Northeast this winter that could leave the fuels in short supply. [38.]
 
A Fast Trip to the Slots
Atlantic City and Foxwoods are closer than Las Vegas to New York. But gamblers from the metropolitan region still face a trip. So next week, a start-up company in Brooklyn plans to offer daily cruises to the high seas -- where gambling is unregulated. [27.]

HEADLINE: THE SECOND TERM: THE OVERVIEW;
Clinton Fills Top Posts, Keeping Reno

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 13

 BODY:
President Clinton rounded out his team of senior economic advisers today, nominating William M. Daley, a Chicago lawyer and scion of his city's legendary Democratic family, as Commerce Secretary, and selecting several others whose appointments effectively consolidated the powers of Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin as the dominant Cabinet officer of a second term.
Mr. Clinton also nominated Representative Bill Richardson, an eight-term New Mexico Democrat who has made a specialty of amateur diplomacy in recent years, to be chief delegate to the United Nations. He made the appointments at a news conference in the Old Executive Office Building, adjacent to the White House. [Excerpts, page 12.] 
 Mr. Clinton also settled a personnel question that has lingered since his re-election. After meeting with his outspoken Attorney General, Janet Reno, on Thursday night, he announced today that she would stay on for a second term. But he did so without a word of praise for her work and in the context of announcing that two officials whose fate was not in doubt -- Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, and Carol M. Browner, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency -- would stay on.
To head the National Economic Council, which Mr. Clinton created with Mr. Rubin as its first chairman, the President elevated his longtime domestic economic adviser, Gene Sperling, also a close ally of the Treasury Secretary.
The President straddled a long-running dispute over how to replace the outgoing chairwoman, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, by also elevating Daniel K. Tarullo, Mr. Sperling's co-deputy under Ms. Tyson, to a new rank overseeing international economic affairs.
Lawrence H. Summers, Mr. Rubin's deputy at Treasury, was given a seat on the Economic Council, effectively assuring Mr. Rubin three votes in deliberations of the panel, which is intended to mediate economic disputes within the Administration. The number of votes on the panel varies according to the issue being decided.
Together, those moves consolidated the already enormous influence of Mr. Rubin, who is not only one of the President's most trusted private advisers but now becomes, more clearly than ever, the Cabinet officer with the biggest, most clear-cut public reputation as a forceful advocate of fiscal moderation and a balanced budget.
Of the major economic posts, only Labor Secretary remains open.
Officials said Mr. Clinton was still weighing various candidates, including former Senator Harris Wofford of Pennsylvania and Alexis M. Herman, the White House director of public liaison.
Today's announcements were marred by one moment of unintended drama. Minutes after Mr. Daley accepted the President's nomination, saying he came from a family in which "there is no greater calling than public service," he stumbled forward and collapsed, falling off the small stage into a row of poinsettias and hitting his head on a television equipment box. He was helped out of the crowded auditorium but later returned, a bit pale but apparently all right. White House officials said a medical team had found his vital signs normal. They said he had not eaten lunch and had apparently fainted from the heat.
In Chicago, a spokesman for Mayor Richard M. Daley, Jim Williams, said that William Daley had been commuting from Washington to be with an ill sister in Chicago. "Bill has spent a few overnights at the hospital," Mr. Williams said. "The whole family has been deeply concerned and pretty exhausted."
In the hourlong session, Mr. Clinton dropped the tightly worded style of his recent campaign for a series of ruminative answers on a wide range of topics, including these:
*Mr. Clinton said that it was "time to quit killing" campaign finance reform with filibusters and that he was "prepared to do my part" to pass it.
*He promised an unspecified but "more serious effort" to solve the District of Columbia's fiscal problems, calling the capital "not quite a state, not quite a city, not quite dependent, not quite independent."
*He said the State Department had asked his wife, Hillary, to continue her efforts to promote "human rights around the world" by traveling abroad and said she would do so.
*He indicated that he would not propose a capital gains tax cut in his budget next winter "because we have other priorities," but he again declined to rule out the possibility of supporting one someday in the context of negotiating a balanced budget.
*He said the television industry's proposed rating system should be tried for 10 months and "we'll see where they are."
The appointments of Mr. Richardson and Mr. Daley to some senior posts had been virtually assured for some time. The question was only whether Mr. Richardson, an amateur diplomat who has helped negotiate the release of Americans captured in rogue states like Sudan and North Korea, would take the United Nations job or Commerce. After meeting with Mr. Richardson this week, Mr. Clinton settled on him for the United Nations post.
Some senior Administration officials have said that Secretary of State-designate Madeleine K. Albright had objected to the other leading candidate for the post, former Assistant Secretary of State Richard C. Holbrooke. But Ms. Albright's spokesman in New York, James Rubin, said today that she "categorically denied" that she opposed Mr. Holbrooke, saying she thought highly of both candidates and looked forward to working with Mr. Richardson.
Mr. Clinton also announced today that he would nominate Charlene Barshefsky, the acting United States Trade Representative, to take the post full time.
Officials said that with Mr. Daley at Commerce, the way now appeared open for Mr. Clinton's old friend, Rodney Slater, the Federal Highway Administrator, to become Secretary of Transportation, the other post for which Mr. Daley had been considered. Mr. Slater, who is black, would help Mr. Clinton make the Cabinet more racially diverse.
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican majority leader, praised Mr. Richardson's nomination. But he warned that Mr. Daley would need to "restore the credibility" of the Commerce Department, which was rattled in the final weeks of the Presidential campaign by reports that one of its former officials, John Huang, had later engaged in questionable fund-raising practices for the Democratic Party.
"To accomplish that, he will need to restore a chain of command and accountability, remove domestic and international political fund raising from the job descriptions of Commerce's employees and cooperate with the Congress in the investigation of allegations that employees of the Commerce Department solicited illegal foreign political contributions," Mr. Lott said.
For weeks, Ms. Reno's fate had been in some dispute. Up until late Thursday night, various senior White House officials said they expected Mr. Clinton to reappoint her, even as they continued to suggest anonymously that he was far from keen on doing so. They intimated that he was annoyed at her past willingness to appoint special prosecutors to investigate allegations of wrongdoing by Administration officials. Four independent counsels have been appointed on her recommendation.
But with the Justice Department still overseeing an inquiry into the Democrats' fund raising, officials said, Mr. Clinton realized that if he sought to replace Ms. Reno, he would be accused of seeking retribution and would doubtless face a Senate confirmation fight over almost any successor he chose.
The President kept his options open until the last minute, refusing on Thursday evening to tell even two of his most senior aides what he and Ms. Reno had decided in their meeting at the White House before repairing together to a black-tie holiday party in the residence.
Today, Mr. Clinton again seemed to go out of his way to avoid any comment on Ms. Reno's stewardship, relegating her name to a list of others who would stay on. White House and Justice Department officials said he was eager to avoid offering either a ringing endorsement of Ms. Reno or to draw criticism from Republicans by appearing to curry her favor as the department's investigations proceed.
