HEADLINE: The Rediscovered Modernist

BYLINE: By Holly Brubach; Holly Brubach is the style editor of The New York Times Magazine.

 BODY:
"Charlotte Perriand? Isn't she a furniture designer?" ONE prominent architect, a man, responded when told that I was writing about her. And, indeed, that is the way she has usually been characterized, if not dismissed -- on those rare occasions when she has been mentioned at all. The distinction is taken for granted. Men design the buildings; women furnish them. Men work in concrete and steel; women, in fabrics and occasionally wood. Men organize the public spaces; women feather the nest, presiding over the realm of domestic interiors. That Perriand, despite the buildings she has designed, should be known as a furniture designer while Philippe Starck and Ettore Sottsass, whose fame is based primarily on their furniture and household objects, should be known as architects is only one indication of the bias at work in a field that is notoriously and to this day overwhelmingly male.
In a photograph from 1927, Perriand stands at Le Corbusier's side -- a girl who felt most at home in the mountains of eastern France, about to be inducted into the ranks of men who have taken the future of urban life into their own hands. Now 93, she has lived long enough to see the furniture she designed with Le Corbusier and others become so famous that it is copied with impunity, sold to collectors and exhibited in museums. (At a New York furniture gallery, 1950, a mahogany dining table is priced at $45,000. At the Design Museum, in London, "Charlotte Perriand: Modernist Pioneer," a retrospective, is on view through April 13. And the Architectural League is planning an exhibition of her work for late next year in New York.) Perriand has watched the modernist movement, which she joined in its earliest stages, give way to post-modernism and subsequently make a comeback. Lately, as one of the last surviving members of the first generation of modernists, she has been present at her own apotheosis, looking on as she and her contemporaries have been consigned to history. She has also, as it happens, lived long enough to witness the aftermath of the revolution they brought about. 
 She seems an unlikely revolutionary -- this rotund grandmother with sparkling eyes and a pixie's smile, her white hair wound in a topknot. Some 70 years after she and Le Corbusier and their fellow visionaries proclaimed a new era that would be the culmination of our evolution as a species -- an era in which houses and chairs and even clothes would be logical, functional and efficient, and people would be high-minded and happy as a result -- Perriand sits in her apartment, surveying the congested cityscape of Paris through a black veil of pollution, and reflects on the outcome of their efforts. "It's a little disappointing," she says.
 PERRIAND ARRIVED IN PARIS in 1920, as a scholarship student at the School of Decorative Arts, housed in the attic of the Louvre. To supplement her training, she enrolled in design courses taught by Maurice Dufrene, the artistic director of Galeries Lafayette, the department store. In 1925, still a student, she was selected to display several projects at the Exposition Internationale des Arts Decoratifs -- among them a fresco depicting the nine muses, for a music room, and an upholstery fabric produced by Galeries Lafayette and incorporated in Dufrene's display. After graduation, with his encouragement, Perriand continued to participate in trade exhibitions, where she was singled out by the critics.
Soon, however, she broke with the style instilled by her teachers -- the patterned wallpaper, the swollen furniture that typified Art Deco -- and struck out in a new direction, embracing the machine age. The aerodynamic chrome-and-aluminum bar she created in 1927, for the Salon d'Automne, caused a sensation, announcing the esthetic potential of new materials that were already transforming life outside the home. The photograph of Perriand and Le Corbusier was taken there, in front of that bar: the master has come to see for himself, conferring his interest; she makes no attempt to conceal her elation. That October, Perriand was hired to work in his studio, where she remained for 10 years.
It was an auspicious start to a career that has turned out to be distinguished and so diverse as to encompass prefabricated aluminum bivouacs, Air France ticket offices and a pavilion made from live bamboo, at the Unesco headquarters. An extended sojourn in Japan -- where she found herself trapped by the war, having served, at the Government's invitation, as a consultant on industrial design -- inspired her to incorporate certain aspects of the Japanese tradition into the practice of modernism. With Jean Prouve, in the late 40's and 50's, she produced more landmark furniture. When Le Corbusier was commissioned to do a housing project in Marseilles, he recruited Perriand in 1950 to design the prototype for the kitchens.
Perriand believes that her early years with Le Corbusier laid the foundation for everything that followed. She speaks of her first encounter with his ideas, in 1927, as a kind of conversion experience, brought on by reading his books, in which he exhorts mankind in general and architects in particular to overthrow the tyranny of convention. Perriand claims that Le Corbusier tore down the "wall" that had been obstructing her view of the future. From then on, she was consumed by the desire to participate in the moment at hand, and by an acute sense of urgency. "I'm aware and in tune with my own age," she exulted at the time. "It is mechanical: the cars in the street . . . are polished, shiny. I wear chrome beads around my neck, a belt of metal links. My studio is chromed steel; and I wear my hair a la Josephine Baker."
An air of excitement pervaded Le Corbusier's studio, with its staff of young idealists who had come from all over the world to work for the man they considered the master. "We believed in what we were doing," Perriand says, "and we would have sacrificed everything for it." She describes the atmosphere as a cultivated one in which the design of buildings was considered in the context of new developments in other fields -- it was Le Corbusier, Perriand recalls, who sent her off to listen to Stravinsky's music.
Together, Perriand, Le Corbusier and his cousin Pierre Jeanneret, with whom he shared his practice, conceived furniture that would serve as elements in the architecture of a building's interior. Chairs were constructed on a chassis of chrome tubing, as light and sturdy as the frame of a bicycle. For carrying on a conversation, there was the now-classic armchair -- a low cube of fat cushions covered in leather and held in place by a chrome cage; for reading, there was the now-familiar chaise longue, its tubular-steel skeleton curved like a hammock and upholstered in pony skin. At trade exhibitions, the chairs, along with glass-and-steel tables, and storage units that took the place of armoires and chests of drawers, provoked a response that was sharply divided.
Like Le Corbusier, Perriand often wrote (in her case, primarily for magazines) in an attempt to explain to a reluctant public the principles underlying her work. "Understanding can change the way people see," she says, "and enable them to appreciate a form that is unfamiliar to them." The Western eye, she says by way of example, is predisposed to interpret empty space as a void, as the absence of things, whereas in Japan empty space is viewed as the presence of possibilities -- an alternative Perriand came to appreciate during her stay in Tokyo. Consequently, in the rooms she designs, she "affirms the emptiness." Beauty, as it turns out, is largely in the mind of the beholder.
In retrospect, modernism's detractors in its initial stages seem to have been hoping to slow the pace of change by withholding their approval. The telephone, the automobile, the airplane and any number of other inventions threatened to sweep away the routine of everyday life as people had known it. Clinging to the familiar, many critics actively opposed the modernist attempt to overhaul the world. When, in 1929, an article in an English design magazine campaigned against the use of metal for furniture, condemning it as "cold and brutally hard," Perriand rallied to its defense, in clipped sentences that suggest she had assimilated not only Le Corbusier's beliefs and his zeal but also his prose style, with its declamatory ring echoing that cadences of Scripture:
Metal plays the same part in furniture as cement has done in architecture.
IT IS A REVOLUTION.
The FUTURE will favour materials which best solve the problems propounded by the new man:
I understand by the NEW MAN the type of individual who keeps pace with scientific thought, who understands his age and lives it: The Aeroplane, the Ocean Liner and the Motor are at his service;
Sport gives him health;
His House is his resting place. . . .
UNITY IN ARCHITECTURE and yet again
POETRY
A new lyric beauty, regenerated by mathematical science.
Perriand's veneration for Le Corbusier was nothing less than total, and it is still intact, despite evidence that some of his ideas have proved impractical, or worse. His greatness as an architect, she believes, lay in the fact that he was not only an architect. He painted every morning, arriving at the office at 2 in the afternoon and working into the evening. His sense of color, of the harmony of shapes and of the balance of proportions informed the buildings he designed; Perriand calls him "a poet of right angles." He was also, she adds, a superb thinker, philosophical and analytical, concerned with human nature and society. It was to her mind his rigorous insistence on function that set him apart from many other modernists, including those of the Bauhaus. How does she reconcile that notion with Notre-Dame du Haut, the chapel he designed at Ronchamp -- a building that approaches the condition of sculpture, a stark departure from the machine-age fundamentalism that became his signature? Even in that case, she insists, the architecture is functional: it "puts you in a state of grace, and that is its purpose."
 NEVERTHELESS, FOR ALL HER admiration, Perriand is circumspect when it comes to many of modernism's consequences. Like pollution. She faults herself, Le Corbusier and their fellow idealists for failing to see that chemicals from industry would poison the soil and the rivers, that exhaust from cars and trucks would ruin the air in cities. That much, she says, should have been obvious. After the war, she continues, "we thought it was chic to have a nuclear reactor as a source of energy -- we didn't foresee the dangers." In their headlong rush to espouse the means of mass production, they helped to bring about a shortage of artisans and the loss of skills acquired and passed down over centuries. "We were utopian in the sense that we didn't see where our ideas would take us," Perriand admits. "We thought that society would change, that mankind was going to improve. That's where we made our mistake." If architecture is to find a way out of this predicament in which we now find ourselves, she contends, its practitioners must team up with sociologists, biologists, computer scientists and economists.
Perriand deplores that there is no forum for the exchange of ideas today, as there was in the early years of her career, when CIAM (the Congres Internationax d'Architecture Moderne) selected a theme, like "The Functional City," and brought together noted architects from all over the world -- Le Corbusier, Mies van der Rohe, Walter Gropius, Gerrit Rietveld and Jose Luis Sert among them -- to discuss it. In fact, she says, she finds the spirit of cooperation that prevailed among architects in those days now conspicuously lacking:"Of course I'm interested in contemporary architecture -- it's my era. But I don't see architects concerning themselves with collective housing, as Le Corbusier did. Architects today make monuments -- everywhere there are monuments. It's pointless. Meanwhile, the place that people call home is left to the taste of developers and handymen, and no one thinks it through."
The design and outfitting of a building's interior, which used to be part of the architect's job -- and part of his training -- is now left to a decorator. Chairs are conceived by furniture designers, another "specialty." "With Le Corbusier, I learned that architecture is a whole," Perriand says. "He conceived the structure, the fittings and the furniture all together. We designed a chair because, at a given moment, in a precise context, we needed a chair." Their furniture, now considered so "classic" that it exists in our minds in some Platonic vacuum, was in fact initially created as an integral part of the designs for Le Corbusier's residential projects, like the Villa Laroche and the Villa Church.
"But now there is a split," she continues. "On the one side you have the schools of architecture, and on the other the schools of decorative arts -- when all along they were meant to live together. Now, when an architect completes a project, it's just an empty building. And then the decorator is called in -- but it's already too late. Between the outside and the inside, there is no harmony. The resonance of things together is gone."

 
PREDICTABLY, PERHAPS, PERRIAND has been championed by feminist architectural historians looking to anoint some women to the modernist hall of fame. There are precious few candidates in her generation: Eileen Grey, whose career was in some respects more consistent and conspicuous; Lily Reich, who worked with Mies van der Rohe and was the subject of a small exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, in New York, last spring. The fact that until as recently as a few years ago the furniture Perriand designed in collaboration with Le Corbusier was attributed to him alone has surely enhanced the perception that she has been slighted. Like Reich, she has been portrayed as a talented woman laboring in a great man's shadow.
It is a portrayal that bears little, if any, resemblance to her experience as she recounts it. Asked if she met with any prejudice or resentment as a woman in a man's profession, she claims that she never thought about it. Confronted with ideas that dominate much of the current critical discourse about modernism -- reinterpreting it as aggressively masculine, as a renunciation of all things decorative (i.e., feminine) -- she expresses bewilderment. Legend has it that the first time Perriand approached Le Corbusier about a job, before her success at the Salon d'Automne, he responded, "We don't embroider cushions here," and sent her away. In her memory, however, that insult has been rendered harmless by the respect he subsequently showed her in their work together.
That certain avenues might be closed to her, or that she might encounter obstacles simply by virtue of being a woman seems never to have occurred to her -- possibly, she volunteers, because she grew up doing things that boys did. Introduced to exercise at an early age, as a means to correct a curvature of the spine, she learned to love physical activity. Growing up in the mountains, Perriand took up downhill skiing, slalom skiing, canoeing, white-water rafting, mountain climbing and spelunking. It is, she believes, her background as an athlete that instilled in her a sense of competence and power -- a subliminal, unshakable self-confidence that spilled over into everything else she undertook.
 LE CORBUSIER'S DICTUM THAT architecture should express its own era still meets with widespread resistance more than half a century later. In the rantings of Prince Charles and in the popular appeal of entire communities that offer a choice of Victorian, Colonial, Tudor and other styles, the impulse to take refuge in the past is alive and thriving. Post-modernism, a movement that by virtue of its name alone signaled the demise of modernism's continuous present, has ushered in the rampant use of historicisms, and Perriand has no patience with -- much less sympathy for -- its playful disregard for content, its emphasis on novelty. "It's all gadgets," she says.
In some larger sense, of course, post-modernism does indeed express its era: the longing for some semblance of continuity, forfeited when modernism broke with the past; a certain dissatisfaction with modernism's perceived constraints; the marriage of anxiety and confusion. But in Perriand's opinion, the fact that modernism didn't turn out as planned is no excuse for turning one's back on the future and resorting to pastiche. "I agree that it's necessary to be acquainted with everything that has gone before us," she concedes. "And I respect each era and all that it can express. But I think of tradition as a chain, with the last link being the previous century. And to that link, we attach another one that we make ourselves, from the century in which we live."
If modernism -- or Perriand's view of it -- can be reduced to a single tenet, it may be this insistence on articulating the time in which one lives, in the present tense. "Louis XIV and Louis XV were modern because they were true to their own eras," she says. "I don't see why I should do what has been done before. I express my era, period."
Her own apartment illustrates just how quietly subversive a notion this still proves to be. She reamed the structure, knocking down interior walls that divided the space into a rabbit warren of tiny rooms, doing away with the calculated quaintness. The result -- open and filled with light, with a stereoscopic view of the western half of Paris and privacy provided by a sliding scrim of sailcloth lashed to a teak frame -- is completely at odds with the building's stated intent. A typical bourgeois apartment house, it was built in 1956, in the style of the 30's. "This building," she says disdainfully, "was old before it was born."
The problem, as Perriand sees it, lies not in architecture but in society. "There is a saying," she recalls, "that 'every society has the architecture it deserves.' " What is it that prompts these paroxysms of nostalgia? "Fear," she says. "A failure of nerve. A lack of virility." Her own personal philosophy -- which, she is convinced, is responsible for her longevity -- is in some respects a reflection of the modernist credo, applied to the course of an individual life. "In every important decision," she explains, "there is one option that represents life, and that is what you must choose." The alternative -- a retreat from change, from the future -- is corrosive. The mere act of preparing for a retrospective exhibition, or giving an interview, or writing her memoirs -- all of which oblige her to revisit the past -- puts Perriand in a state of suspended animation that she deeply resents. "Life," Perriand asseverates, "is something in motion."
 THE MODERNIST REVIVAL IS IN full swing, and if demand is any indication, appreciation for Perriand's contribution to the modernist canon is running high. Does all this new-found attention somehow vindicate what she and her colleagues produced? No, she says. They felt vindicated at the time. "These chairs," she says matterof-factly, "will last until something better comes along to replace them."
The ironies are not lost on her. The romantic promise of the machine age resided in the notion of mass production, but much of the furniture Perriand made -- with Le Corbusier, with Prouve -- was never manufactured; the prototypes, however industrial the materials, are precious, one of a kind, crafted by hand. Many of her pieces, which set out to describe their moment, have since been declared timeless. But even more striking is that the current return to the forms of early modernism is, finally, a wave of nostalgia for a movement that forswore nostalgia. Gazing into a future that seems abstract, disembodied, a succession of technological breakthroughs unfolding in cyberspace, we are at a loss to imagine how upcoming changes in our lives might manifest themselves in the shape of a building or the design of a chair. We envy the modernists their certitude, back in the days before progress had taken leave of the material world. On the verge of the millennium, we're faced with the daunting task of inventing a style that could express the possibilities of the next hundred years. In their time, Perriand and her colleagues rose to the occasion -- a fact in which she takes evident pride. "We made our century sing," she says.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 40; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 837 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By LAUREL GRAEBER 

 BODY:

THE DEATH OF SATAN: How Americans Have Lost the Sense of Evil
By Andrew Delbanco.
Noonday/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $13.
As our culture has grown more secular, moral relativism has replaced religion, Mr. Delbanco maintains. Although he sees little value in fundamentalism, he encourages ethics that emphasize personal responsibility. His book is "brilliant, passionate, erudite and beautifully written," Wendy Doniger said here last year.
 
MRS. TED BLISS
By Stanley Elkin. Avon, $12.
In his final novel, published shortly before his death in 1995, the author focuses on an octogenarian Jewish widow in Florida who has been tied to the kitchen all her life except, perhaps, in her heart. It is this vulnerable spot that is targeted by various con men and unscrupulous types, from Latin drug traffickers to her husband's former business partner. Mrs. Bliss's story is "a smart, generous, melancholy, funny, even elegiac work by a prodigious practitioner," Walter Goodman wrote in these pages. Avon has also restored to print several of Elkin's earlier novels. In GEORGE MILLS ($14), first published in 1982, the title character, a man of about 50, contemplates his family's miserable history of servitude at the same time that he is driving his employer, an incurably ill woman, to Mexico. Our reviewer, Leslie Epstein, praised the "fine writing, flashes of humor and memorable heroine." THE LIVING END ($12) takes place largely in the afterlife, where Ellerbee, the main character, is sent by the gun-toting thieves who rob his liquor store. The result, in which God turns out to be not such a nice guy, was "a big book for Stanley Elkin, and a fine and daring novel," John Irving wrote in the Book Review in 1979. Judgment for one's deeds also pervades A BAD MAN ($12), the tale of Leo Feldman, a department store owner who has allowed the basement to be used for underworld purposes. Describing Elkin, Josh Greenfeld said here in 1967, "I know of no serious funny writer in this country who can match him."
 
OVERCOMING LAW
By Richard A. Posner. Harvard University, $17.95.
A Federal judge and legal scholar argues that economics -- the real costs and benefits of a decision -- should play more of a role in the courtroom, and that empirical evidence rather than precedent should influence justice. Selected as one of the best books of 1995 by the editors of the Book Review, this is "the most scholarly, the most thoughtful, as well as the sharpest and most provocative" of current legal commentaries, Jeremy Waldron wrote in these pages. Harvard has also reissued A NATION UNDER LAWYERS: How the Crisis in the Legal Profession Is Transforming American Society, by Mary Ann Glendon ($14.95). The author, a law professor, criticizes both litigiousness and what she sees as the tendency of judges to make law rather than interpret it. In 1994 our reviewer, David Luban, called her work "one of the most accessible and best-written books about the legal profession in the past few years."
 
IN THE CUT
By Susanna Moore. Onyx, $6.99.
Frannie, a linguist, teacher and the narrator of this novel, embarks on an odyssey of sex and secrets after she stumbles upon an intimate scene in a New York bar. One of the participants is soon dead, and Frannie becomes involved -- in several senses -- with the investigating police. The book is "a ferociously uninhibited erotic thriller," Molly Haskell said here in 1995.
 
SAVAGES
By Joe Kane. Vintage Departures, $13.
The Huaorani, a tribe of Amazonian Indians, lived undisturbed by industrial civilization until oil was discovered on their land. The author, who spent months with them, shows how they have since been exploited by both corporations and environmentalists. He offers "superb eyewitness reporting and fluent storytelling," Mark Hertsgaard wrote in these pages last year. Another sojourn in an indigenous culture is described in KABLOONA: Among the Inuit, by Gontran de Poncins (Graywolf, $14.95). Just restored to print, the book chronicles the French author's exposure to Eskimo life in the Arctic in 1938 and 1939. "He is obviously not an eccentric running away from something but a potential enthusiast running toward something," R. L. Duffus said in The New York Times in 1941.
 
THE HUNDRED SECRET SENSES
By Amy Tan. Ivy, $6.99.
The author explores the relationship between two half sisters: Olivia, a part-Chinese but thoroughly American-bred photographer, and Kwan, fully Asian in blood and sensibility, a believer in a spirit world that Olivia denies. Last year our reviewer, Claire Messud, said, "Kwan, in particular, is a memorable creation."
 
CITY LIFE
By Witold Rybczynski.
Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $12.
Why can't New York be more like Paris? The author shows how our landscape and values -- democracy and technology among them -- inspire Chrysler Buildings rather than Eiffel Towers. His book is "wonderfully informative, entertaining and nuanced," George F. Will wrote here in 1995. Laurel Graeber

HEADLINE: Hoop Dreams

BYLINE: By Charles Salzberg; Charles Salzberg's books include "From Set Shot to Slam Dunk: An Oral History of the N.B.A."

 BODY:

THE HOUSE OF MOSES ALL-STARS
By Charley Rosen.
490 pp. New York:
Seven Stories Press. $24.95.
In 1936 it wasn't easy to make a buck. But the seven enterprising young men in Charley Rosen's novel "The House of Moses All-Stars," taking advantage of their skills on the basketball court, barnstorm the country, competing against local teams for cash. 
 These guys are good, several having played college ball in the metropolitan New York area. But mere skill isn't always enough -- you need a gimmick to put people in the seats. The come-on here is for the seven stalwarts to call themselves the House of Moses All-Stars and (as with similar real-life teams) to take to the court wearing yarmulkes and long beards, letting folks in the hinterlands know what real Jews look like.
In his novel, set against the backdrop of Hitler's rise in Germany and economic hard times here, Mr. Rosen, the author of three previous basketball novels, as well as four nonfiction books on the subject, re-creates a world of basketball that has been all but forgotten amid the hype surrounding star players like Michael Jordan and Shaquille O'Neal. Yes, there was a time, before the establishment of the National Basketball Association in the late 1940's, when basketball was played in small gymnasiums as the prelude to a dance, or in wire cages (hence the nickname "cagers") to protect players from rowdy crowds who poked lighted cigarettes at members of the opposing teams. It was a time when the players drove to games, sometimes hundreds of miles apart, in station wagons and sedans hardly large enough to hold them. But the House of Moses All-Stars do this one better: they hopscotch across the country in the dead of winter in a renovated hearse, with the Star of David painted on the side.
This is not simply a novel about basketball in the dark ages. Mr. Rosen has much more on his mind here. This is a book about guilt and redemption, about the loss of innocence, about racism and bigotry, about class differences.
The seven young men on the team are all running from, or to, something. The narrator, Aaron Steiner, is the guiltiest of all -- because, with some of his teammates, he shaved points in college; because his daughter was born deformed and died shortly after birth; and because before tossing her ashes in the ocean he visited a freak show on Coney Island; because he has left his wife after sleeping with one of his high school students. And, perhaps most of all, he is guilty because he enjoyed it.
His teammates include Brooks, the Bolshevik who stops the barnstorming tour to play a benefit game for a group of striking workers; Leo (think Leo Gorcey of the original Dead End Kids), the troublemaker more interested in the point spread and any angle that can make him an extra buck than in winning; Saul, the lapsed Hasid, who loses his innocence the hard way when the boys play a game in the unfriendly confines of Sing Sing prison; Ron, the thief, who has spent most of his life on the streets; Mitchell, the somewhat priggish Zionist, who keeps the books, doles out expenses and longs to emigrate to Palestine; and Kevin, who isn't Jewish at all, but the Irish Catholic son of a New York City cop.
Mr. Rosen gets the ambiance just right: the moving from town to town, the sometimes horrid conditions under which they play, the weariness and sense of dislocation, the bigotry and ignorance they encounter.
Unfortunately, as the team reaches the middle of the country -- Oklahoma -- the book turns a little sappy. When the players find themselves on an Indian reservation, being shielded after a scrape with the law, political correctness begins to seep in, with stereotypically wise elders. And when the team plays its final game in California, things seem to happen at an alarmingly hasty pace, as if Mr. Rosen realized the clock was winding down and he'd better end the game.
Some people think most of the important action of a basketball game takes place in the last two minutes. To real fans, of course, that's heresy. It's how you got to the last deuce that really counts. And, in the end, even if the final two minutes of Mr. Rosen's novel don't satisfy, the rest of it certainly does.

GRAPHIC: Drawing. (ROB SHEPPERSON)

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%); GERMANY (79%);

HEADLINE: 6 Rms, Erth Vu

BYLINE: By Dennis Overbye; Dennis Overbye is writing a book about Albert Einstein.

 BODY:

THE CASE FOR MARS
The Plan to Settle the Red Planet and Why We Must.
By Robert Zubrin with Richard Wagner.
Illustrated. 328 pp. New York:
The Free Press. $25.
Almost 25 years have passed since humans last set foot on the moon, and a generation of young Americans who believed they were witnessing the dawn of the space age have grown gray watching space shuttles fly nowhere in circles. In the post-Vietnam, post-cold-war, post-modern era we live in it is an accepted truism that the public will no longer tolerate grand, expensive adventures without a guaranteed bottom-line return to national security or the gross domestic product. "Are we still a nation of pioneers?" ask the authors of this book, one of the most provocative and hopeful documents I have read about the space program in 20 years. "Do we choose to make the efforts required to continue as the vanguard of human progress, a people of the future, or will we allow ourselves to be a people of the past, one whose accomplishments are celebrated only in museums?" 
 Part history, part call to arms, part technical manual, part wishful thinking, "The Case for Mars" was written before last summer's announcement of evidence for past microbial life on the red planet made it the solar system's hottest tourist destination. It lays out an ingenious plan -- "Mars Direct" -- for humans to explore Mars within 10 years, using existing technology, for $20 billion or so. Robert Zubrin (formerly a senior engineer at Martin Marietta) and his colleagues invented the idea in 1990 out of frustration after NASA placed a $450 billion price tag on going to Mars. They have been barnstorming it ever since.
Mr. Zubrin compares NASA's approach to that of 19th-century Arctic explorers who set out for the Pole in expensive armadas of large ships stuffed with years' worth of supplies only to get stuck in the ice. The successful explorers traveled by dog sled and lived off the land. Martian explorers should also plan to live off the land, particularly the planet's thin atmosphere -- carbon dioxide, which can be turned into a methane-oxygen rocket fuel with the help of a very small amount of hydrogen. Being able to make fuel abroad for the trip home means astronauts will not have to lug it from Earth, and that means their spacecraft can be light enough to launch with existing rockets. No risky, expensive on-orbit assembly of "Battleship Galactica" spaceships. Economies follow like dominoes.
Part of the fun in reading this book is seeing a crack engineering mind operate. Mr. Zubrin knows how to make things work, and he sees possibilities and alternatives everywhere -- which he can't help explaining in occasional blizzards of numbers and acronyms. There are enough charts and graphs to tempt the serious student to try to design his own mission. Mr. Zubrin has already figured out the crew: two engineers and two scientists; no pilot-commander, no doctor (surely wishful thinking).
The first Martian homes will be of brick made from Martian sand. The planet's economy will be based on mining and selling deuterium (five times as abundant as on Earth) for use in nuclear reactors. At times Mr. Zubrin's can-do enthusiasm verges on chilling, as when he discusses possibly thickening Mars's atmosphere by melting the planet's polar caps and permafrost to make it more habitable (900 years -- no price tag): "I would say that failure to terraform Mars constitutes failure to live up to our human nature and a betrayal of our responsibility as members of the community of life itself."
When it comes to paying for all this, Mr. Zubrin is no less ingenious. One idea, worked out with the Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich, would be for the Government to award cash prizes for the completion of various Mars tasks: $20 billion for the whole mission, $1 billion for a working fuel plant, and so on. If such an arrangement could lead to someone like Bill Gates owning or running Mars, that is not necessarily a bad thing by Mr. Zubrin, who is fed up with how things work on Earth. Bureaucratization, economic stagnation, overregulation, irrationalism, "Malthusianism" and the stifling of diversity, he says, are sapping our spirit. Just as the necessities and opportunities of frontier America supposedly drove progress in the 19th century, he believes, Mars would be a new frontier of enterprise and innovation, a new New World where humanity can renew itself. Such romanticism, of course, overlooks other aspects of the American West, like the contribution of the railroads, built by vast land give-aways and coolie labor, or the Indians, who were here first.
But one can agree that exploring Mars would be an exciting and noble thing to do, and that Mars Direct would be a cool way to do it. There may be natives on Mars, too, in the form of those microbes famously hypothesized last summer. What if we find them still making a living somehow, under the red sands? Would we have the right to colonize the planet, reprogram its climate and kill them? There is the mother of all snail-darter controversies, awaiting us in the 21st century.

HEADLINE: In High Sumatra, Another Way of Life

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE; BARBARA CROSSETTE, chief of the United Nations bureau of The Times, is writing a book about the great hill stations of Asia.

 BODY:
FOR the price of a cup of coffee -- home grown Sumatran kopi, served in a big glass with rough brown sugar for a sweetener -- what an eyeful of glory we got! The precarious back porch of a roadside food stall clung to the rim of a deep, long valley. In the distance there were the ubiquitous green, green rice fields of Indonesia. But here, near the town of Bukittinggi in the highlands of Sumatra, a volcanic island about the size of California, there was more. Rose-red leaves atop the cinnamon trees and huge yellow daisies bobbing in the morning sun splashed unexpected color over dense tropical undergrowth. Off to one side the soaring pinnacled rooftops of a village peopled by one of Indonesia's most sophisticated cultures, the Minangkabau, could be glimpsed above a tangle of trees.
Among the great hill stations of Asia, where European colonizers went to escape the lowlands' suffocating heat and the merciless diseases that sent many white men, women and children to early graves, the name of Bukittinggi, about 50 miles north of the Indian Ocean port of Padang, never figured prominently. The Dutch built it not as a place of respite, after all, but as a fortress against 19th-century Islamic militants bent on installing a fundamentalist order.
Bukittinggi had none of the cachet of Simla, the Himalayan hill station to which the British rulers of India decamped in sedan chairs, preceded by caravans of porters with the season's household goods. Or Dalat in the highlands of Vietnam, where the French created a town that was part resort, part sanatorium.
But Bukittinggi, still a fairly small town in a rural setting -- and a few other Asian also-rans, including Murree in the hills of northern Pakistan -- may for varied reasons have brighter futures than more famous colonial hill stations, if growth does not come too fast. In West Sumatra, as in Indonesia generally, tourism is on the upswing, and Bukittinggi and the hills and lakes nearby are increasingly favored destinations. Sumatra is a steamy, rainy island. We who backdrop our images of the Islamic world with Middle Eastern deserts or barren and dusty West Asian landscapes are often surprised to encounter the ponds, lakes and pools of Muslim Southeast Asia.
The attraction goes beyond nature. The people who call themselves Minangkabau, and once enjoyed 500 years of independence as a kingdom that survived into the early 19th century, have created an unusual culture in these hills. Devoutly Muslim, they are also matrilineal, with an egalitarian social system and an economy in which women own virtually all the property. The Minang have produced poets, thinkers, novelists, educators, politicians and even revolutionaries of national stature in Indonesia.
Daily life in Minangkabau country is governed by intensely complicated and arcane rules of etiquette called baso-basi, which an outsider cannot help but breach in some way. The Minang are forgiving, however, because they are also cosmopolitan. Villagers get together to invest in satellite dishes and tap into television from other Asian and Pacific nations, including Australia. Part of growing up here, especially for young men, includes a stint abroad in the rantau -- a word that means, roughly, "anywhere but here." No wonder anthropologists are drawn to the Minang like bees to clover.
The traveler most easily enters Minangkabau country by air through the port city of Padang, the capital of the province of West Sumatra. As the plane approaches through long mountain valleys -- Sumatra is the world's fourth largest island -- Padang unfolds as a low-rise city of white walls and red-tiled roofs punctuated by those breathtaking Minangkabau spires. Shaped like buffalo horns and often tipped with silver, many of the spires are on new public buildings, evidence of a revival of interest in traditional architecture after years of modern, flat-topped concrete boxes.
The trip by winding road from Padang to Bukittinggi in the Minangkabau heartland takes about two hours by car or three hours by public bus. Although there are other towns with small hotels in Minang country, Bukittinggi is a good base in the highlands because it has a wide range of accommodations, from new luxury hotels to very basic losmen, those Indonesian-style inns well known to backpackers and other bottom-budget travelers.
I stayed about a mile out of town on the Jalan Soekarno-Hatta in the new Hotel Pusako, set in luxuriant flower gardens with water terraces. My comfortable room, decorated with Indonesian fabrics and local hardwoods, had a balcony that looked out over the small plot of a village farmer. The air was refreshingly clear by day and cool at night -- not cold, because Bukittinggi is less than 4,000 feet above sea level and barely 50 miles south of the Equator.
AN acquaintance with the Minangkabau is best established before reaching Bukittinggi. At Padang Panjang, about 12 miles south of the mountain town, a magnificent center for the study of Minangkabau culture opened less than a decade ago. Its centerpiece is a traditional rumah gadang, or great house, the center of communal life for the extended Minang family.
The large rectangular wooden structure is a kind of lofty longhouse built on stilts with six saddle-shaped sections of thatched roof, three to the left and three to the right of a central entrance. Their six soaring pinnacles, rising like three pairs of buffalo horns, are tipped in silver. Below the tiered roof, the exterior walls are intricately carved and colorfully painted in designs drawn from nature and the imagination of folk artists. The house and two small but equally ornamented rice barns in front are set in gardens planted with flowers and shrubbery native to West Sumatra.
Indoors, this exotic "big house" serves as a small museum, a gallery of historic photographs, a library, a bookstore, and the headquarters of the Center for Information and Documentation on Minangkabau Culture, a private foundation. Entrance to the complex, which is open daily from 8 to 5, costs about 22 cents.
Bukittinggi is not a particularly pretty town. Its structural landmarks are limited to a fragment of the Dutch Fort de Kock, an old Dutch-built clock tower called Jam Gadang and a Kentucky Fried Chicken, whose bright red-and-white logo is a useful pole star for locating the center of town. A sprawling indoor-outdoor market, the Pasar Atas, dominates Bukittinggi. It is a fascinating stroll, but tourists won't find too much to buy beyond the richly woven gedong, a length of silk or cotton patterned with gold or silver thread, sometimes made into sleek, dressy purses appropriate to evening wear. Locally embroidered household linens or garments are often too lavish and too fussy for many tastes. Despite its growing popularity Bukittinggi has remained small (fewer than 100,000), and walking around it (or up and down its hills) can offer certain pleasures. On the grounds of the sad little zoo near the market, there is, unexpectedly, another traditional Minang great-house museum full of the paraphernalia of common and royal daily life, including ornamented costumes for special occasions, carved furniture and utensils of all kinds.
In this rumah gadang, someone has made an effort to post explanations in English, still a rare practice in Indonesia. In front of a small diorama of a wedding scene I saw this sign:
"There are three layers of material separating the bride and groom . . . indicating that the couple must be able to control desire for one another for up to three days before the marriage is consummated."
On the way out, I passed another model of restraint: a bored cobra and an understandably neurotic white chicken sharing a small enclosure in the zoo.
From the clock tower and the market it is a short walk to a park along the Jalan Panorama overlooking Sianok Canyon, part of a rift valley running the length of Sumatra. An easy hike of about an hour or two through the canyon leads to Kota Gadang, a village of silversmiths. Apart from the pepper and spices for which it was famous, this part of Sumatra was once rich in silver and gold. Jewelry makers here specialize in silver filigree.
Although many tourists prefer to head west from Bukittinggi to Maninjau, a large volcanic lake with water sports, I chose a trip to the southeast, a voyage into myth and legend. Much of Minang lore springs from the farmland around the town of Batusangkar, where in a nearby pasture a legendary event occurred that many like to believe gave the Minangkabau their name, which translates variously as "victorious buffalo" or "sharp-horned buffalo." Versions of the story differ, but essentially it goes like this:
A king from the neighboring island of Java, threatening conquest, was persuaded by a local ruler to let the battle be fought by buffaloes, to save human life. The Javanese king agreed, and sent for his biggest bull. Meanwhile, the people of Batusangkar had been starving a nursing buffalo calf, while fitting its small head with sharp metal horns. When the calf was turned loose to face its opponent, it made a frantic dash at the bull's belly in search of milk, goring and killing the larger animal.
The Minangkabau creation myth revolves around Mount Marapi, one of two volcanoes -- the other is Mount Singgalang -- visible from Bukittinggi and many other places in the highlands. Legend says that the proto-Minang came down from Marapi to build their first earthly settlement in Pariangan, a few miles away from Batusangkar along a narrow country road climbing into the hills. Here families now struggle to keep ancestral houses in repair, and some are collapsing. But the place remains special for the Minangkabau, whose passion for these lands seems to give life to everything around.
On the grassy fields of Batusangkar there are banyan trees with spirits, a sultan's tomb that is reputed to change size every time someone measures it, and a megalith with a hole in it and a few tales to explain why. One story, the one favored by the groundskeeper, says it was used by warriors whose peaceful king told them to attack it if they felt the need to stab something. Megaliths, some with ancient inscriptions if not with holes, have been found in a number of places in the highlands.
AT Pagarruyung, a few miles outside Batusangkar, there is a fine collection of new buildings that together illustrate Minangkabau thinking. One is a reconstructed royal palace, a traditional rumah gadang of larger than usual proportions built to replace and replicate a nearby royal residence destroyed by fire in the 1970's. Close by, an imposing white mosque has arisen, and behind it a local government headquarters also constructed in traditional style. For the Minangkabau, the three are symbols of a philosophy found in few other Muslim societies, a belief that there can be a separation of religion, culture and civil authority.
The Minangkabau may rise before dawn to the call of the mosque, but they also go to secular schools by day and dance into the night in colorful costumes and headdresses of silver, their music and movement drawn from a pre-Islamic age.
And then there is the water. In the Minangkabau highlands, pools and watercourses -- simple things, not grand Mughal designs -- are all around, softening the reflections of the village mosque and cosseting small households with fish to eat, water to bathe in, and moisture for the fruit trees and gardens.
Life can be just too easy and too good to sustain a work ethic or even a cause, complained A. A. Navis, a Minang novelist and historian, when I stopped to visit him on a rainy day. Fertile ground, he says, but not for militancy.
 
What to see, where to stay, what to eat in the highlands
 
The Basics
The best time to visit is from April to August, though sudden showers can occur year round in the highlands. Coastal areas are always hot; in the highlands, cooler nights, with temperatures in the 60's or 70's, follow 80- or 90-degree days.
 The Indonesian currency is the rupiah. A dollar is worth between 2,250 and 2,300. The cheaper inns do not take credit cards.
Padang, the gateway to Minangkabau country, is connected by nonstop flights to several Indonesian cities, including Jakarta and Medan, as well as to Singapore and Kuala Lumpur. The easiest route is the Singapore-Padang flight on Silk Air, a subsidiary of Singapore Airlines ($121).
 
Accommodations
Padang has several new hotels. The most luxurious is the Hotel Sedona Bumi Minang, 20-28 Jalan Bundo Kandung, (62-751) 37555. Rooms are listed as $130 for a single and $150 for a double, but I paid about $110, including 21 percent in taxes and service charges. Ask for discounts.
Another centrally placed hotel, but a cheaper one, is the Natour Muara, 34 Jalan Gereja; (62-751) 35600, 25660 or 33751. Rooms begin at about $38, single or double.
The Andara Duta Andalas travel agency in Padang, 53A Jalan Pemuda, (62-751) 33689, fax (62-751) 29142, can arrange for a car and driver and hotels in the highlands. The trip to Bukittinggi costs about $48. Ask for Budi Agnesya, the assistant operations manager, who speaks English.
In Bukittinggi, the most attractive hotel is the new Hotel Pusako, set in luxuriant flower gardens with water terraces about a mile out of town on the Jalan Soekarno-Hatta, (62-752) 32111, fax (62-752) 32667. A room with balcony starts at about $68, plus taxes and service, for a total of $81, single or double. No tipping is expected. There is no air-conditioning, so take insect repellent, since the only effective ventilation is an open door and there are mosquitoes.
Novotel has also recently opened a hotel in Bukittinggi on the Jalan Laras Datuk Bandaro, (62-752) 35000, fax (62-752) 23800, with single or double rooms starting at $85, plus 21 percent tax and service charges. The hotel is closer to the town center than the Pusako, but has none of its natural setting.
A pleasant hotel popular with tour groups is the Denai, 26 Jalan Rivai, (62-752) 32920, fax (62-752) 33490, with non-air-conditioned rooms from $30 and air-conditioned rooms at $55 single and $65 double, plus taxes and service.
Cheap hotels abound in Bukittinggi. Near the Denai is Lima's Hotel, at 34 Jalan Kesehatan, (62-752) 22641, fax (62-752) 32570, where rooms with bath start at about $15.50.
For transportation within Bukittinggi, there are plenty of taxis that charge a flat fee of $1.20 to go anywhere. Hotels can telephone for taxis and there is no extra charge. There are also many picturesque horse-drawn carriages called bendi. Every ride has to be bargained for. I paid the standard 3,000-rupiah taxi fare, which is more than generous, but less than the 5,000 rupiah ($2.22)
that drivers try to extract from tourists.
 
Food
West Sumatra -- Padang in particular -- is well known for the hottest food in Indonesia. Most hotels tone down the chilies for tourists, but if you get a chance, sample a real beef rendang, for example -- bite-sized chunks of beef boiled down in lavishly spiced and seasoned coconut milk until the meat appears nearly black. Served with rice also flavored subtly with coconut milk, it is delicious. In hotels, a rendang will cost no more than about $4.40 tops. At food stalls, a meal may cost less than half that. But hepatitis and cholera are endemic in Indonesia, and it is wiser to stick to places where plates and cutlery are free of contamination.
A real Padang dining experience means having plate after plate of food -- lamb and fish dishes along with beef -- brought to your table automatically. You pay only for what you choose to eat.
Sate (satay) restaurants, serving grilled beef, chicken or lamb on skewers also often operate this way: a big tray of mixed sate with squares of pressed rice cakes and bowls of peanut sauce arrive at the table. The waiter counts the empty sticks after the meal. In Padang Panjang, three of us ate a lot of sate at a noisy family resturant called Sate Mak Syukur. With tea and soft drinks, the total bill came to about $4.78.
In the Minang region as everywhere in Indonesia, a safe and tasty staple is nasi goreng, fried rice served with a chunk of fried chicken or a few sticks of sate or both and crowned with a fried egg. Even in the most luxurious hotels, a good nasi goreng won't cost more than about $5.
Beer and soft drinks are available in tourist hotels and restaurants. Bottled water is sold in most towns. Never drink iced drinks or tap water.

HEADLINE: Q. & A.

 BODY:

Closing Costs on A Purchase
 
Q How can I anticipate how much I will have to pay in closing costs on the purchase of a house? Is it true that mortgage lenders are required to supply good-faith estimates of closing costs? . . . Bi-kim Liu, Manhattan
 
A Douglas F. Wasser, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said that closing costs varied widely depending on the type and amount of mortgage financing the borrower was obtaining.
"I generally advise purchasers to anticipate that they will have to pay closing costs of about 5 to 8 percent of the purchase price, including attorney's fees," Mr. Wasser said, adding that lenders were indeed required to provide borrowers with a good-faith estimate of closing costs. 
 Most lenders, Mr. Wasser said, charge origination fees, or points, when a mortgage is made. Each point, he said, is equal to 1 percent of the mortgage amount, and different mortgages carry different numbers of points. Generally, Mr. Wasser said, the higher the interest rate, the lower the number of points, and vice versa.
The cost of title insurance -- required by lenders to insure that the purchaser gets clear title to the property -- also varies with the purchase price and mortgage amount. On a $250,000 purchase with a $200,000 mortgage, Mr. Wasser said, a purchaser can expect to pay a title insurance premium of about $1,600 plus several hundred dollars more for title searches, inspections and a survey.
In New York, Mr. Wasser said, purchasers usually have to pay mortgage recording taxes that range from 1 percent to 2.75 percent of the mortgage amount, depending upon the county where the property is.
Purchasers should also anticipate being required by their lender to buy a homeowner's insurance policy, and to deposit several months' worth of real estate taxes and homeowner's insurance premiums into an escrow account maintained by the lender.
Finally, Mr. Wasser said, purchasers can also be required to pay various miscellaneous expenses associated with the mortgage, including document preparation fees, lawyer review fees and recording fees.
 
Pointing Charges In a Co-op
 
Q Can you tell me whose responsibility it is when it comes to pointing in a building? How often should a building be inspected and where does the responsibility of cost and repair fall? I live in a co-op. . . . Maria Pucci, Manhattan.

A James Samson, a Manhattan lawyer who specializes in co-op and condominium law, said that in a co-op, the co-op corporation was responsible for maintaining basic building systems and keeping the building in good repair.
"This includes the roof and facades of the building," Mr. Samson said.
Pointing, Mr. Samson said, is part of the routine process of facade maintenance by which old mortar between the bricks or masonry blocks is replaced. Such work is essential, he said, to prevent leaking and to hold the masonry in the proper position.
"There is no hard-and-fast rule as to how often repointing should be done," Mr. Samson said. "If the occupants are reporting leaks, an inspection should be performed."
Mr. Samson added that in New York City, if a building is more than six stories high, Local Law 10 of 1980 requires that all portions of the facade that are within 25 feet of a public street or sidewalk be inspected every five years by a licensed architect or professional engineer. Reports of the inspection must be filed with the Department of Buildings.
If repointing is necessary, he said, the co-op board has the power to pay for the work by using reserve funds, declaring a special assessment, raising maintenance fees or borrowing the necessary funds.

HEADLINE: A 90's Twist On Town Meeting Tradition

BYLINE: By LEONARD FELSON 

 BODY:
WHEN Richard and Doris Sugarman arrived in Hartford in 1989 the region's economy was spiraling downward. They had come from Richmond, Va., home for both of them, because Mr. Sugarman's employer, Advest Inc., had asked him to run its Connecticut division.
As Advest's division manager, part of Mr. Sugarman's job was to learn about the community. And what he saw worried him. 
 "It looked like a community struggling in a lot of respects," he said. "It appeared not to have a sense of community." There was a sense of futility, of addressing problems that many people perceived as too big to tackle, Mr. Sugarman recalled.
As newcomers, the Sugarmans wondered if they could help. So began what came to be known as the Connecticut Forum, a series of discussions on important issues of the day featuring speakers ranging from Henry Kissinger to Bill Cosby to Jackie Joyner-Kersee.
Now in its fourth season, the forum, held at The Bushnell Memorial Hall in downtown Hartford, draws a crowd not only from the Hartford region, but also from parts of Massachusetts and New York.
Just last month, the weekend before Election Day, the first session of the current season featured "A Spoof on Presidential Politics" with Rob Bartlett, the comic whose work is best known on the "Imus in the Morning" radio show; Al Franken, the political satirist who has been a regular on "Saturday Night Live"; Jeff Greenfield, the ABC News political and media analyst, and Bob Englehart, political cartoonist for The Hartford Courant. Like all the other forums, it resembled less a performance than a living room chat, in this case, a group of friends getting together for some laughs.
An earlier forum, "Heroes Among Us" was scheduled for October, but the Sugarmans agreed to reschedule it until March 18, so that the first Presidential debate could be held at The Bushnell that night.
In addition, over the years, the Sugarmans have helped create community outreach programs that have attempted to put into action forum-generated ideas.
"There was a feeling of bridge building and bringing together various elements of the community from day one," said Drew Beja, a Boston investment manager and former Advest analyst who worked with the Sugarmans when the Connecticut Forum was still just an idea.
The idea of a forum was one the Sugarmans brought with them from Richmond, which had created the Richmond Forum about 20 years ago in the midst of a school desegregation ruling that had divided the city.
Mrs. Sugarman saw Richmond and Hartford as two very similar cities, but, like her husband, one of the first things she noticed, she said, was how disconnected the different towns that make up greater Hartford were. The Sugarmans, for instance, settled in Avon, which Mrs. Sugarman discovered was isolated from neighboring Canton. Although the Sugarmans like the small-town feeling of New England, they said they saw how it got in the way of what Mr. Sugarman called "a greater sense of community."
They decided to see if there was support for a forum in Connecticut. Mr. Sugarman asked and won support from Advest. Then the couple went to The Hartford Courant and to Connecticut Public Television and Radio. There too they won a commitment. They went to about 25 businesses, seeking financial support. "The response was an enthusiastic 'yes' with a big 'but,' " recalled Mr. Sugarman. "We were told, 'It's a great idea but not in these tough times.' "
The Sugarmans' response was, "Why not? Particularly because of the tough times." The couple proceeded, and won over the Hartford Downtown Council, the Greater Hartford Chamber of Commerce, the Hartford Graduate Center and Trinity College, among others.
People signed on as volunteers to help organize the forum. "Some were new to the community and just wanted to get involved," said Mrs. Sugarman. "Some were forever looking for something new."
Because the organization was in Mrs. Sugarman's words "very grass roots," ideas were turned into action quickly, "and we all started to feel this was the start of something new and exciting."
Support grew, in part, said Mr. Sugarman, because it was so easy to get involved. "We had people say to us they were not challenged to think in their jobs, to create, to experiment, to use their imagination, their passion. Here they could."
That dare-to-experiment attitude also helped shape the character of the forums. The skepticism brought on by Hartford's economic woes led many longtime residents to think the only panelists they could attract would be local or at best, from elsewhere in Connecticut. But organizers decided to seek out the top experts in their respective fields.
The first forum, held Oct. 16, 1992, was "The Changing Political Landscape," moderated by Lesley Stahl of CBS News. Among those on the panel were Ron Brown, Pat Buchanan, William Proxmire and John Sununu.
Four months later the forum topic was "Straight Talk and Honest Answers About AIDS," which again featured a distinguished panel. One of the panelists, Arthur Ashe, was unable to attend on the advice of his doctors who had just changed his medication, trying to battle his AIDS. In his place, he sent a video he had taped a few days earlier.
At intermission, rumors floated through the theater that Mr. Ashe had died, and a call to The Associated Press revealed that the rumors were true. The announcement was made on stage at the beginning of the second part of the program, and Mr. Sugarman recalled, "There was a lot of collective grieving and a lot of coming together that night."
The experience, Mrs. Sugarman said, "elevated the importance of what we were doing."
The Sugarmans never did want the forums to be simply an alternative to theater, or just another form of entertainment. Bridge building remained their focus. At intermission during the AIDS forum, doctors from the University of Connecticut Medical Center, Hartford Hospital and St. Francis Hospital and Medical Center decided there ought to be a way to work together to provide better treatment for those with H.I.V., the AIDS-causing virus. That led to a collaborative effort to create a common database.
After a forum on race relations -- which included the rap artist Chuck D., William F. Buckley Jr., Dr. Betty Shabazz (the widow of Malcolm X) and the former Los Angeles Police Chief Daryl Gates -- a group of high school students wanted to continue the dialogue. As a result, the Connecticut Forum Student Board was created, allowing teen-agers from differing backgrounds and communities to meet monthly at each other's schools to discuss current issues and plan a variety of programs.
A ticket program was developed to insure that the forum draws residents into The Bushnell who could not otherwise afford the admission price.
The most recent outgrowth of a forum is the two-year-old Connecticut Women's Hall of Fame exhibition, which grew out of a panel titled "American Women in Focus . . . Breaking New Ground" with the help of Hartford College for Women, the University of Hartford and Fleet Bank.
Geena Clonan, the executive director of the Hall of Fame and a friend of the Sugarmans who has been involved in the forum since the early days, said the forum's success may stem from its harkening to old New England town meetings, where neighbors would gather to talk about pressing issues of the day.
"It's the same thing the Mayflower Compact was founded on," she said. " It's the whole idea of communicating once again, analyzing problems and solving them."

HEADLINE: Weighing The Ethics Of a Trip

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS; SETH MYDANS is chief of the Bangkok bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
A VACATION trip does not commonly require a moral choice, but in the case of Myanmar, the former Burma, there is no way to avoid one.
One of Asia's loveliest and least-traveled nations, Myanmar is in the grip of a military junta that has drawn condemnation from around the world for its suppression of democracy and its abuses of human rights. This month, the junta's problems have increased as campus demonstrations raised the possibility of student unrest spilling onto the streets of Yangon. On Monday, the United States Department of State issued an announcement recommending that "U.S. citizens exercise all due caution in traveling to Burma and should for the time being curtail travel to Burma (Myanmar) absent a compelling reason." 
 In a bid to build tourism and win international legitimacy, the military Government has undertaken an effort to attract visitors by inaugurating Visit Myanmar Year in November. Its opponents are urging tourists to stay away, part of a broader call for an economic boycott. The first major effort by the country in decades to open its doors to the outside world has become a test of the world's attitudes toward it.
Almost the entire leadership of the junta, known as the State Law and Order Restoration Council, turned out on Nov. 18 for the start of Visit Myanmar Year.
"Today is a red-letter day for tourism in Myanmar," said Lieut. Gen. Khin Nyunt, who is in charge of both tourism development and military intelligence. "We are celebrating not only the launching of Visit Myanmar Year but also our commitment to open our doors to the world."
The moment had been many months in preparation, involving a considerable portion of the country's limited resources. Scores of new hotels have been opened in the capital city of Yangon and other tourist areas. Two new domestic airlines have started service and a new airport arrival hall has been opened in Yangon. Tourist sites have been refurbished and visa procedures eased.
But politically, little has changed, and this year has seen an escalating crackdown on the pro-democracy forces that rally around the country's most popular and charismatic figure, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi. It is this behavior that has raised calls for a boycott.
The junta came to power in 1988 following the killings of hundreds of pro-democracy demonstrators, then clung to power after losing an election in 1990 to Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's party, the National League for Democracy. She herself was held under house arrest for six years until July 1995 and was temporarily put under house arrest again last week after the student demonstrations in the capital.
Since May of this year, the Government has arrested nearly 1,000 of her supporters -- though most have since been set free -- and is now preventing her from making the weekly addresses that had been the country's one forum for free speech.
Just nine days before the start of Visit Myanmar Year, bands of officially sanctioned thugs attacked Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi's car in the first act of violence against her. One of her aides was slightly injured.
A year ago, Yozo Yokota, then the human rights investigator in Myanmar for the United Nations, reported that forced labor was being used to refurbish tourist sites like the temple complex at Bagan.
Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi herself has asked tourists to stay away.
"We are not saying, 'Don't come to Burma forever,' " she said in a recent interview. "What we are saying now at the moment is, 'Boycott Visit Myanmar Year.' And that's not a big thing to ask, you know."
Not everyone agrees. Even some of her supporters abroad argue that visitors will bring much-needed dollars, as well as ideas of freedom and democracy, to the country's people.
"I don't bother about politics," said a Greek tourist on a recent flight into the country. "I have visited many countries with unpleasant Governments. And I think every dollar I spend here will help someone to make a living."
Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi rebuts that argument by saying that the main beneficiaries will be the generals, foreign hotel owners and the relatively well-off workers in the tourism industry. And any sacrifice of tourist dollars that the people must make, she says, is a small price to pay to oppose the junta.
But her call for a boycott has given the Government its best propaganda argument against her. In a lust for personal power, it says in newspaper commentaries, Mrs. Aung San Suu Kyi is taking food from the mouths of her fellow citizens.
Even without a boycott, the success of Visit Myanmar Year is far from assured. The country has already scaled back its 12-month target from 500,000 visitors to 250,000.
And it is not even clear that it can accommodate that many. Last year fewer than 100,000 tourists visited Myanmar, according to Government figures. There are fewer than 5,000 seats a week on international flights into the country and, despite the flurry of building, fewer than 3,500 hotel rooms in the capital.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Q&A: Donald S. Strait;
Redigging the Environmental Trenches

BYLINE: By LAUREN BROWN 

 BODY:
DONALD S. STRAIT, a native of Fairfield County, joined the Connecticut Fund for the Environment in 1990 as legal director and is now its executive director.
A 1981 graduate of Amherst College and a 1986 graduate of Harvard Law School, he returned to his home state after serving as clerk to Judge Dickinson R. Debevoise of the Federal District Court in Newark, N.J., and working in New York for the Natural Resources Defense Council. 
 Founded in 1978, the Connecticut Fund for the Environment combines the tools of the legal profession with knowledge from the scientific community to tackle such issues as clean air and water, pesticide use, wetlands protection and transportation. One project is working out alternatives to the proposed new Route 6 in eastern Connecticut, which, as currently planned, would entail the filling of 55 acres of wetlands. The fund has also intervened to protect inland wetlands in Branford, Cromwell, Middletown and Windsor. Staff lawyers often take legal action to bring polluting businesses and municipalities in line with their state permit limits.
With offices in New Haven, the fund is supported by dues from 3,500 members, individual donations and private foundations.
In a recent interview Mr. Strait discussed the current state of the environment in Connecticut and the fund's work. Following are excerpts from that conversation.
Q. How does your strategy differ from that of other environmental organizations in the state?
A. C.F.E. is the only statewide environmental organization that is staffed by lawyers. We don't lobby or go into the schools, and we don't own land. But we are prepared to go to court. We often choose cooperation over a lawsuit and we provide technical information to individuals and communities. So we think of ourselves partly as the legal arm of the environmental movement, but we also help people to understand problems themselves, to get involved and become more effective.

 Q. On the legislative level environmental protection has taken a beating. How do you deal with that?
A. We've been forced to dig the trenches again. In the 1970's and 1980's systems were put in place to deal with traditional environmental problems, like smokestacks and discharge pipes. So in the early 1990's we felt we could focus our attention on some of the tougher issues, like the serious sewage problems in Long Island Sound, contaminated runoff into waterways from pavement and lawns and the effects of traffic congestion. Unfortunately the current political situation has diverted us from these issues by forcing us to fight many of the old battles again. Right now we're working hard just to save protections that have been on the books for decades.

 Q. How about on the regulatory front? Are existing laws being enforced?
A. In Governor Rowland's first year in office, court actions against polluters were slashed by 75 percent. We are very concerned about this because some companies will not obey the law when they know that they won't be punished, even if they are caught.

 Q. Given the poor state of the economy, does it makes sense to ease up on environmental regulations?
A. We don't think it makes sense to allow the environment to got down the drain in order to give a short-term financial break to companies who claim that it will help them. Many environmental laws have encouraged companies to operate more efficiently and thereby save money, which is a benefit to the economy. When illegal pollution is tolerated, responsible companies can be hurt because unscrupulous competitors will lower their costs by dumping illegally

 Q. What are some of your current projects?
A. Here's a neat case. We are representing the Steep Rock Association, a very effective group of citizens in the Washington area who want to save the Shepaug River from its continued degradation by the city of Waterbury.
Waterbury uses the Shepaug river for its water supply. It has, even in the worst droughts, plenty of water yet it refuses to release more than a trickle down the Shepaug in the summer. So the Shepaug is basically killed every year. You can walk across the Shepaug in the summer without getting your feet wet.

 Q. With so many skirmishes going on, how do you choose the issues to become involved in?
A. We struggle with it constantly. Given our small size C.F.E. itself can only take on issues that have statewide significance. Where we can't get involved, we try to help out nevertheless, by providing legal or technical information or by referring the caller to a volunteer attorney who may be interested in helping out.

 Q. What do you consider the most pressing issues today?
A. Obviously, we need to get the state government back on track so that the laws are enforced adequately. Especially in southwestern Connecticut, traffic congestion is choking the air and beginning to change peoples' lives for the worse. Fairfield County has the third-worst smog problem in the nation. It's not that surprising when you look at all the driving that goes on.

 Q. What do you see as solutions to the traffic problem?
A. The first thing to understand is that people don't like sitting in traffic. They don't like the fact that more and more streets are inhospitable to walking because they are overrun with cars and trucks. People do need their mobility, however, and right now people have few choices other than driving their cars to get to work, shop or bring their kids to school.
That's why we think it's important to bring people together to see what approach will work. For example, C.F.E. and others convinced the Connecticut Department of Transportation to withdraw a massive bridge and highway widening proposal in favor of a cooperative process where a broadly representative committee is designing ways to reduce traffic on the Quinnipiac River Bridge. What is so exciting is that ConnDOT has committed to accept the committee's recommendations if they meet certain legal and financial constraints. We hope that the dialogue will result in a plan to reduce traffic on the bridge by improving mass transit instead of widening the bridge.

 Q. What improvements are you hoping for?
A. In mass transit? More train stations, increased frequency of the trains, interceptor parking lots with signs visible from the highway which would tell when the next train is due in.
It would allow people to get off the highway and jump on the train if they see that the bridge traffic is too much for them.

 Q. Can Long Island Sound ever really be cleaned up?
A. In the past decade, a tremendous amount of effort has gone into studying these problems. We now have set of commitments from the states to reverse the decline in the Sound and we've even begun to see some improvements. The question, in this era of cutbacks and suspicion of government programs, is whether the political will is there to follow through. We think the answer will be "yes," but people need to make their voices heard if they don't want their beaches closed and if they do want aquatic life to thrive again.

 Q. Isn't the main problem sewage? Do you think people are willing to spend the billions of dollars required to upgrade treatment plants?
A. The Sound is a regional and even a national treasure and we think that the financial burdens need to be shared by the Federal Government as well as the state and local governments. But yes, I think that if people are faced with a clear choice, and if they have faith that spending the money will get the job done, that they will say "yes." They said yes in Mystic. Voters were faced with either continuing unhealthy discharges from their sewage treatment plant or an expensive upgrade. They chose the upgrade.
Also, it's not billions of dollars or nothing. There are a lot of little things people can do. People can work to save wetlands in their own towns. Wetlands are natural water purifiers which are essential to the health of the Sound. Homeowners can pay attention to how much fertilizer they put on their lawns. People can pump out their septic systems regularly. People should write to their congressmen, write to the governor, say, "The Sound is important to me." People sometimes forget that politicians will listen to them.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Donald S. Strait, head of the Connecticut Fund for the Environment, at Mianus River Park. (Helen Neafsey for The New York Times)
