HEADLINE: Long Island Q&A: Barry Richter;
Training Brokers for Financial Planning

BYLINE: By SUSAN KONIG 

 BODY:
THE needs of today's investor are changing, and so, too, is the brokerage industry. Individuals putting children through college, caring for elderly parents and planning for their retirements -- sometimes all at once -- are seeking comprehensive financial advice.
As a result, the broker as a salesman is being replaced by the broker as financial consultant. As vice chairman of Gruntal & Company, a Manhattan-based investment firm with three Long Island offices, Barry Richter has helped develop a one-year financial education program with the National Endowment of Financial Education, formerly the College for Financial Planning, to train brokers in the widening gamut of investor needs and services. Seventy-five of Gruntal's account executives have completed the course so far, while 125 are currently enrolled.
Mr. Richter graduated from Brooklyn College in 1957 with a degree in economics. He has been with Gruntal since 1960, and has served as vice chairman for several months. Previously, he was executive vice president in charge of branch retail sales.
Mr. Richter and his wife, Fran, are longtime residents of Port Washington. They have three children and one grandchild.
Q. What is the Gruntal Forum of Achievement?
A. We give special privileges to our account executives, or brokers, who've committed themselves to higher education. To qualify, a broker must complete this one-year asset management education course. It's designed to help them recognize the best investment solutions for their clients in various situations. And it teaches them personal financial information that applies directly to their everyday work.
We reward those who complete this program with trips, seminars and other entitlements. But, the additional training also helps them develop more and better business.
Q. You say this concept differs from the current Wall Street mentality?
A. Yes, it's very different. We want people who've already reached certain goals, like getting their broker's license, to continue their education so they can understand the wide array of investment opportunities that are out there. We want them to do this before they've put in the 20 years it can take to learn these things on the job. But, to do it, they need to take a course.
Q. What is the curriculum?
A. It goes through a gamut from birth to death. There are estate plans, wills and trusts, old age care, insurance, real estate investments, derivatives, options, regular stocks and bonds, and more.
Naturally, as someone gets older and his friends get older, he'll start looking at planning for his will and his estate. But how do you focus on that early? And, it needs to be done early, unless you don't mind if most of your estate goes to Uncle Sam when you die.
That's why we developed this program, to teach our brokers to recognize these things. And we designed it to be different from Wall Street, in that our brokers are rewarded, not for the sales they make, but for this enhanced education, which lets them deal with clients at a higher level.
Q. What do you want your brokers to learn from this?
A. Most importantly, I want them to know they may not be the ones suited to handle everything. Wall Street firms traditionally tell their clients they should give them all their assets, because they have the legal department over here and the insurance department over there -- everything's under one roof. The client gets sort of locked into it, because the firm has developed a plan for him. That's not what we're doing.
I feel quite strongly that some of these services should be done by accountants, lawyers, insurance brokers and others. It benefits our clients to know that the person they entrust with most of their money knows enough to say: "There are other things to do and other directions to go. If you really want what's best for you, it's time to see your lawyer, your accountant, etc."
And, contrary to a lot of firms, we feel financial planning should not be a pre-packaged, one-size-fits-all concept. People are simply too different.
Q. How have clients' needs changed?
A. The client's needs have changed dramatically as the availability of information has gotten faster and faster. Newspapers are filled with information about every subject that we discuss as asset managers.
As a result, people have become informed, to a much greater degree, about a variety of financial subjects. Now, they need someone to help them disseminate all of this information and bring the focus back to the individual, because the media sweeps the masses.
I think a lot of Wall Street firms want to be supermarkets to the world and really package their own "home" label -- their own mutual funds, their own products, and so on. I don't think that's the way to go. Brokers should be encouraged to choose what they believe is best, not what management wants them to sell. That's why we have no proprietary products.
Q. Who needs a financial plan?
A. Everyone needs some planning. You have to know where you're going with regard to business, family, etc. Part of that is being concerned with your current expenses -- your budget, schooling for the children, a home, vacations, etc. But part of it is also knowing how you're going to fund the future. The extent to which you want to deal with the future now is the extent to which you may need certain planning aids.
Do you need a financial plan? It depends. As you budget your life, do you need a printed budget? Some people do. People who need a graphic, didactic displays of information probably should have a plan. For those whose plan is not financial, but rather about the derivative benefits they're going to get out of their lives, they may just need someone to direct them to the help they need.
Q. What about people of different financial means. Do some need planning more than others?
A. Again, it's a very individual thing. Sometimes, the role of a financial consultant is simply to help an individual organize his or her financial affairs. In this case, yearly tax returns, monthly investment statements, insurance policies and other financial information are stitched together to form a more coherent picture of the individual's current and prospective financial condition.
In other cases, it's not so easy. An individual must scale back on his financial goals or assume a greater investment risk to achieve them.
Q. What do people most often overlook when planning their finances?
A. They tend to overlook the practical reality of the day. When you make a plan, you must keep in mind both realism and need. And, as people are different, so are their needs. Everyone should be aware of their existence budget -- their weekly, monthly and yearly budgets. They should also have a contingency budget. Then they can see what is extra. They should know if they can realistically afford to go to Hawaii for two weeks, or if they'll barely make a weekend in the Poconos.
If you have money beyond your day-to-day living expenses and want to build for the future, you may want to make a plan. But, I firmly believe that, whatever you do, you should not be going to one person and saying, "Here's my money -- you handle it." You may need certain newspapers or magazines. You might need a friend, a lawyer, or a consultant. You might have a broker who is really terrific and who can suggest some good investments, but you wouldn't go to that broker and say, "I have an invalid mother to care for, what should I do?", unless you have enough faith that he's informed enough to direct you to the right people.
Q. Wall Street firms have been doing a great deal marketing to the baby boomer generation in the belief that these people are the least prepared for their retirement years. Is this a target group of yours?
A. No, and I think that assumption is unrealistic. Baby boomers get the same education in reality as everyone else, and they come to recognize what they have to do. Q. How would you advise people when choosing a financial consultant?
A. It requires a lot of care, the same kind of care you'd use in selecting anyone who will be an important part of your life. How do you pick your doctor, lawyer, accountant? You do a little research. Word of mouth is certainly one way of doing this. Try to get recommendations from a friend or someone you respect. Then, go meet with the adviser and see if there is chemistry there. Do you feel comfortable with this person? Do you feel he understands you? Can you trust him, because trust is really essential? If you can answer yes to these questions, I'd be inclined to go with that person. But, you should also make sure the individual is working out of a reputable firm. And years of experience are very important.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Architecture of Light and Remembrance

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
NEVER FORGET. BUT THERE IS A GREAT deal more than the Holocaust to remember. There is creativity: the blazing talent of 20th-century Jews, the inspiration of a people marked for extinction but not destroyed. And there is remembrance itself: the capacity of a culture to bring itself to mind. Memory, creativity: the linkage of these two ideas is the cornerstone of the Skirball Cultural Center, a museum and study center that opened in April in Los Angeles.
Designed by Moshe Safdie, the Skirball Center lies on a stretch of hilly ground beside the San Diego Freeway, halfway between the city's west side and the sprawling San Fernando Valley. Viewed from the road, the Skirball is not an easy building to decipher. It looks new. It looks old. Its walls of concrete, pink stone and steel send out a contradictory message: the building wants at once to blend into this rugged desert terrain and to attract notice. Gabled roofs echo the line of the hills above. A delicately dirty bloom on the surface of the concrete makes the walls look like old stone. Steel panels reflect the sky, dissolving sections of solid wall into framed pictures of light and space. 
 It is also apparent, even from a passing car, that the Skirball is a piece of modern architecture. It is assertive. It stands out. It grabs the eye with crisp, geometric forms of concrete and steel that catch the light. In a synthesis of modes at once strong and pliant, the Skirball announces: "Hey, there, I'm a good neighbor! And, by the way, I'm here! Pull in and see me sometime."
If you do pull in, prepare to toss negativity by the roadside. Under the direction of Uri D. Herscher, the Skirball's spirit of optimism is opulent to the point of contagion. Without diminishing the meaning or magnitude of the Holocaust, the place gathers rays of light that have penetrated through a dark century.
Distributed over a 15-acre campus, the Skirball includes a library, an auditorium, galleries and outdoor meeting places. (It was named for Jack and Audrey Skirball, major benefactors of the $90 million project.) But its core is "Visions and Values," a lesson on how to connect the eye to heart and mind. The permanent exhibition, organized by Robert Kirschner and Nancy Berman, traces 5,000 years of Jewish history, but focuses on Jewish life in 20th-century America. Anchored by a three-quarter scale replica of the Statue of Liberty's torch, the displays include a recreated kitchen from a Lower East Side tenement, a newsstand stocked with Jewish-American publications and garments by America's greatest clothing designer, Levi Strauss. The show culminates in a kaleidoscopic audiovisual presentation of achievements by writers, scientists, artists, social workers, politicians, media moguls and financiers. Building on the idea that the power to create is stronger than the will to destroy, the display adds up to the stunning proposition that the 20th century has been nothing less than a golden age of Jewish achievement.
In architecture, the point is beyond argument. This art has produced an unprecedented flowering of Jewish talent in recent years. A generation ago, Louis I. Kahn stood out not only because of his towering genius but because he worked in a profession largely dominated by the Protestant establishment. Today, Jewish architects lead the field. Besides Safdie, their ranks include Frank Gehry, Richard Meier, Peter Eisenman, Denise Scott Brown, James Ingo Freed, Stanley Tigerman Robert A. M. Stern and Eric Owen Moss. Esthetically and ideologically, this group spans a wide spectrum: from the boldly inventive forms of Gehry to the cartoon classicism of Stern, from the intellectually inquisitive designs of Eisenman and Scott Brown, to the evolutionary approach to modern architecture conducted with integrity by Meier and Freed.
Is this worth comment? There is a mine field full of reasons not to. To talk about Jews in the arts -- or, for that matter, in the media, finance, psychiatry and many other fields -- is to risk echoing anti-Semitic ravings about Zionist conspiracies. Every salute to Jewish achievement carries with it the danger of buttressing the paranoia of nut cases, as well as the discreet bigotry of polite society. Jewish contributions to the arts have long been subject to nudge-nudge, wink-winking. What was it Nixon said on those tapes? "The arts, you know -- they're Jews, they're left-wing. In other words, stay away." Shocking! But the wink-wink goes on.
Then, too, there is the risk that by talking about the particularity of any artist's background, the universality of the art is compromised. This risk has long been faced (or skirted) by critics. Forty years ago, when Abstract Expressionism was at its peak, to examine the potentially Jewish dimension in the work of Barnett Newman or Mark Rothko was to risk courting the kind of philistine reaction that ultimately surfaced in the ridiculing term "Cultureburg," coined by Tom Wolfe in his 1975 book, "The Painted Word."
There is also the fatally blase response: isn't this old news? Jewish accomplishments have long been acknowledged. Respectful silence is taken as a healthy sign of democracy's capacity to assimilate. So what is the point of making an issue of their impact? Well, why should the Skirball Center exist?
The skirball exists because the experience of Jews in America has much in common with the experience of most Americans. The particular is the universal; or rather, American cultural vitality stems from the impulse to negotiate between individual and collective experience. Culture here, to borrow Peter Gay's description of Weimar Germany, reflects the paradox that the outsider is an insider. Art is not dispensed from high to low in a fixed hierarchy. It erupts from self-invention as individuals and groups make a place for themselves on democracy's common and constantly shifting ground.
How could the story not have major implications for architecture, historically the art most directly engaged with distinguishing inside from outside? Land, shelter, stability, the impulse to find a place to stand, the envisioning of relationships between public and private realms: these are among architecture's essentials. So, to flip the coin, is the impulse to exclude, to be superior: the gated community, the restricted club. Architecture has been the gentleman's art, the vaguely creative WASP profession, the classical column raised as the barricade against undesirables. The emergence of Jewish-American architects pertains to both sides of the coin. To the extent that architecture has been an establishment art, the experience of Jewish architects differs from that of Jewish painters, writers and composers. They are insiders, blessed with the opportunity to describe outsider experience in the medium of the consummate insider art.
Louis Kahn was revered not just for his architecture but also for the reverence in which he held architecture -- and his fearlessness in saying so in words that often sounded biblical. "The beginning of any work must start from Belief," he wrote. "I distrust competitions because the design is unlikely to stem from Belief, which is of religious essence out of a commonness sensed from other men."
There is nothing specifically Jewish about his references to religion and belief; his inspirations included Christian monasteries and pagan temples. The architectural historian David G. De Long wrote, for Kahn, "places of meeting shared essential qualities that rendered differences between secular and religious use secondary in importance." This is not to say that Kahn promoted secular ideas at the expense of religious ones. His designs, whether for a synagogue, a church, a government assembly or a laboratory, came from a negotiation between secular and religious spheres. He conducted that negotiation in the context of an increasingly secular society. Indeed, his power lay in the vigor with which he resisted that context while flourishing within it. Jews are not the only people who have struggled with this problem. But Jewish identity has often hinged on the capacity to negotiate: for a place to stand, the right to dignity, the freedom to be.
On a tour of the Skirball last spring, I asked Safdie whether there was anything explicitly Jewish about its design. He answered that there was no historical "Jewish" style comparable to classical, Gothic or Moorish styles. Jewish architects, rather, worked within building traditions indigenous to the places where they settled. Nonetheless, in designing the Skirball, he said, he had in mind the image of a garden. Jews, Safdie said, were the first people to imagine a paradise on earth. His verdant image will become clearer as foliage covers the trellises over walkways connecting parts of the campus. Already the cluster of buildings resembles an encampment around an oasis.
Though Sepulveda Pass lies in the middle of Los Angeles, it is not a developed urban place. Coyotes are out there somewhere. Sagebrush barely holds the hills together. Even if the Skirball had not been designed by an Israeli, its surroundings would recall the terrain of Israel. In Los Angeles terms, of course, the pass is brilliantly urban: the freeway represents urbanity here more than buildings do. As the cars stream by they seem more deeply rooted than the Skirball. Not in space but in meaning: the city's mobile sense of place.
A generation ago, Jews were American architecture's most enlightened patrons. Now they are its most gifted practitioners too. The Roman Catholic Church recently confirmed this view. In honor of the forthcoming Jubilee Year, the Vatican organized a competition to design a Church for the Year 2000. The six finalists (the projects go on view on Friday at the Urban Center in New York, 457 Madison Avenue at 51st Street) included three Americans: Peter Eisenman, Frank Gehry and Richard Meier, who won the commission.
 
Richard Meier
Wrestling With The Symbolic
 "I do not think that anyone realizes the novelty of this," the architectural historian Bruno Zevi wrote about Meier's commission in the Italian journal L'Architettura: "You must remember that for centuries and millenniums the Jews were defined, at best, as faithless. They were accused of murder, of procuring the death of the symbol of humanity, of the Son of the Father, of the Son of God.
"Until the day upon which a Pope, motivated by a universal vision without precedents, decided to accomplish an unforseeable, unheard-of, epochal act. He decided to call the head rabbi of the Jewish people and asked permission to be received at the synagogue, in order to resume contact with his, he said, 'higher brothers.' The rabbi responded, 'Welcome.' "
A reconciliation is under way in Meier's design, too: an agreeable encounter between the formalist esthetic for which he is known and the symbolic language that modernists like Meier once so sternly rejected. The church is to be built in a working-class district near Rome, amid high-rise housing blocks. It will rise in an open space between two blocks, a passage that leads from fields to the main shopping street. Philosophically, the idea descends from Bernini's grand colonnade at St. Peter's, the arms of mother church reaching out to embrace the world.
The building's major formal gesture consists of three curving walls that rise to enfold the chapel. Skylights catch the light and diffuse it into the sanctuary below. Curves like these are unprecedented in Meier's work. So is the symbolism the walls represent. Clearly they stand for the Christian Trinity, but Meier is not likely to spell out that meaning. He is a formalist, committed to abstraction. For him to acknowledge a symbolic meaning is to commit an esthetic taboo, akin to uttering the unmentionable name of God. He would rather acknowledge his indebtedness to Alvar Aalto than confess: these walls stand for Father, Son and Holy Spirit.
This taboo is worth pausing over. In "Iconophobia," published in a 1981 collection of essays, Kenneth Clark drew a parallel between abstract painting and the Hebraic prohibition against representation. The comparison was insightful but undeveloped: Clark does not acknowledge that the impulse to shroud or blur meanings may be universal. Esthetic formalism, it should be recalled, emerged in part in an ecumenical spirit, in the belief that pure forms could transcend differences implicit in content.
In 1963, Meier organized a show on synagogue architecture at the Jewish Museum in New York. It was remarkable not just because of the caliber and variety of the designs but because it represented a rare instance in this century when an intelligent effort was made to link architectural and religious values. A Kahn drawing of his design for the unbuilt Mikveh Israel appeared on the catalogue cover, and the show itself can be seen as a tribute to the spiritual aura Kahn brought to his field. Reading the catalogue today, you can see that the architects were struggling with something momentous: the desire to free themselves from 19th-century forms and attitudes while retaining the historical idea that architecture is a sacred calling.
It's extraordinary that Meier is wrestling, perhaps for the first time in his career, with issues raised by his show 33 years ago. The church is his first explicitly religious building. Admirers of Meier's work are aware that his passions for whiteness, light, clarity and openness are in themselves spiritually symbolic. Those qualities are in full evidence here but informed by his awareness of iconography and its historical value. The result is a knowing negotiation between modern formalism and the metaphoric approach that historically preceded it. It reflects a desire for something more than esthetics to fill the void left by religion's withdrawal from a secular society.
 
Peter Eisenman
Raising a Question For Every Answer
 In his 1966 book "Frank Lloyd Wright: A Study in Architectural Content," Norris Kelly Smith characterized Jewish thought as dynamic, vigorous, passionate; classical thought, by contrast, was static, moderate and harmonious. The distinction is worth recalling: you don't have to be Jewish to engage in what Smith regarded as "Jewish thought." Wright, raised as a Unitarian, expressed it with the open floor plan, the pinwheeling interiors of prairie houses, the impulse to flee the city for new horizons.
At least in his contempt for classicism, Peter Eisenman is a match for Wright. Earlier this year, he was commissioned to design a Jewish Museum for San Francisco. Housed in an old power plant opposite Yerba Buena Gardens, the museum will take its place among the complex of museums and performance spaces that have sprung up around the Moscone Convention Center south of Market Street. As a renovation, the Jewish museum may not offer the creative scope he enjoyed in projects like the Wexner Center in Columbus, Ohio, and the Aronoff Center in Cincinnati yet he has approached the project with the same inquisitive vigor.
In a proposal that helped him gain the commission, he wrote: "It has been said of the Talmud that rather than having an answer for every question, Jewish culture and identity has a question for every answer. The question is asked, Is God good? Instead of providing the answer, the book gives no answer. Rather, it is a catalogue of the debate. The answer is the debate, the argument itself."
Eisenman's design, still in development, uses two strategies to turn the museum into a visual and spatial equivalent of this Talmudic tradition. The first visualizes the project not as a building but as an urban passage linking Market Street to Yerba Buena Gardens. This, in effect will stretch the architecture outside the building envelope. Pedestrians will be drawn through a warped Eisenman environment whether or not they intend to enter the building.
The second device is an electronic facade, an enormous screen at the rear of the power plant, that will physically upstage it. The screen can be programmed as curators see fit: coverage of chess tournaments, news from the Middle East, sacred objects from the collection, a visitor's search through cyberspace for events in Jewish history.
Layers of meaning overlap here. One is the juxtaposition of two kinds of power: the industrial model, represented by the power station, and its displacement by the information economy. Another reflects San Francisco's leadership in communications technology. Finally, the screen reflects the degree to which members of the information society have become electronic nomads, not unlike "wandering Jews," surfing the net for fragments of meaning and place.
 
Frank Gehry
A Bump and a Bow Into History
The liberation of Czechoslovakia from a totalitarian regime called for symbols. The most potent of these was the election of a dissident artist, Vaclav Havel, as political leader. Another was the choice of Frank Gehry to design a new building for a prominent riverfront location in the center of Prague. Though commissioned by a private firm, a Dutch insurance company, the building nonetheless held civic importance. Havel, as it happened, lived in the building next to the site. His support was instrumental in gaining approval for a new and somewhat rambunctious addition to one of the world's most beautiful cities.
The building, completed in May, has come to be known as Fred and Ginger -- Gehry's nickname, derived from the building's two towers, one of masonry, the other of glass with a pinch in its side. To me, though, it recalls a number Astaire performed with Rita Hayworth to the tune of "I'm Old-Fashioned" in the 1942 film "You Were Never Lovelier." The couple bump into each other while trying to pass through a doorway, then bow with exaggerated courtesy. A lot of bumping and bowing is occurring as this startlingly contemporary building tries to enter into the city's history.
The basic elements of Gehry's design -- corner towers with ornamental crown, window proportions, decorative moldings on the plaster facade -- derive from local traditions, but they are nudged into the contemporary poise of controlled disarray. Windows are staggered; moldings wave across the facade, as if of independent mind from the structure they animate; the dome atop Fred is woven of steel mesh strips.
The Czechs loathed the figuration implied by the name Fred and Ginger -- they'd had their fill of representational art in the years of Soviet domination -- so it is worth noting that Gehry had no intention of creating an oversize kitsch Hollywood figurine. The pinch was made to frame the view of Prague Castle. Still, the spirit of dance conjured by Gehry's nickname is apt: formal but breezy, deferential to the occasion but fancy-free. Gehry would be the last to deny that figuration plays a part in his architecture. The fish form that often occurs in his designs is derived in part from a childhood nickname. But it also represents something elusive: the right to assert an identity, the right to wriggle free from the identity imposed by others.
In these projects, the negotiation is not between a particular and a universal but between two universals -- one social, the other religious -- that coexist. One is what Kahn called "the commonness between men." The other is the relationship between people and the idea of transcendence. The social being has good reason to be wary of the religious; that wariness is called tolerance. The religious being is right to be wary of the social; that wariness is part of faith. Contemporary architecture is one of many forms in which people of different faiths reckon with the line between them.

HEADLINE: ON THE MAP;
Restoring Derelict Houses in Irvington, and Repairing Lives

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

 BODY:
The abandoned two-story house at 319 Olympic Terrace in Irvington had been an eyesore on one of the better-kept blocks of this crowded Essex County town of 61,000 on Newark's northern boundary. But a pair of ex-convicts turned nonprofit developers have purchased the house, and another nearby, from the Department of Housing and Urban Development, and a crew is now fixing it up for resale.
Harvey George and Richard Hochman are lifelong friends who served time together at East Jersey State Prison on convictions as accessories to murder. After their release they founded the Friends of the Lifers Youth Corporation in 1992 as a non-profit counseling and hunger-relief agency and later moved into housing development. It is an extension of the Lifers Group, a program in which prisoners bluntly counseled teen-agers, which was depicted in the documentary "Scared Straight." 
 An Irvington councilman, Brian E. Coleman, has proposed that the town sell Mr. Hochman, 51, of Toms River, and Mr. George, 52, of Jersey City, abandoned houses for $1 each in a long-term rehabilitation effort that would train and employ local residents. The two men spoke recently outside the house on Olympic Terrace.
Q. How do you do your rehabs? A. HOCHMAN We get a HUD list every two weeks and then determine which ones are best suited for us, something that we can rehabilitate at an affordable price then turn it around and sell it as affordable housing. The lowest price I've paid for a house is $2,500 and the highest is $57,000. Roughly, it costs about $40,000 per house to rehabilitate. We sell them at 10 percent above the net cost that we produce the house at.
Q. Who works on the houses? A. HOCHMAN Contractors, and they have a deal with us where they have to hire one nonskilled person who is unemployed, from the community and one skilled person who is unemployed, from the community. And they come from a pool of people that we interview.
Q. What brought you to Irvington?
A. HOCHMAN My halfway house was in Irvington. When I saw the HUD list and there were two houses in Irvington for sale I jumped on the houses. Because the town of Irvington says to Richard Hochman: Freedom. It was unbelievable. After 15 years of prison, to be free.
Q. Does "Scared Straight" lend you credibility?
A. HOCHMAN I'm in Irvington trying to get permits so we can get the building going, and these clerks are giving me a hard time. I lose my temper and say, "I'm done with this, I'm leaving Irvington." I bump into a guy in a suit [Mr. Coleman] coming out of the town clerk's office and I ask him, "Can you help me?" He says, "Well, I have a meeting in a minute. What's this all about?" I said, 'We originally had a program in prison called Scared Straight . . . " He puts his hand on my shoulder and says, "Just hold on one minute." He runs down the hall, cancels whatever meeting he's going to, comes back and says, "I want to tell you something. My friends and I went through Scared Straight. I wasn't a bad kid, but it straightened out some of my friends who were real troublemakers. I'll do anything I can to help you." He walks me through, gets me everything I need.
Q. If someone had told you what the contracting business was really like, would you have stayed out of it?
A. GEORGE If I'd have had a contractor who ran his own Scared Straight program, and he's saying, "This is what it's like! You better look out!" I'd have said, "Oh, no, I don't want to be no contractor!" STEVE STRUNSKY

LENGTH: 1459 words

HEADLINE: When the Offspring Raise Their Children in the Family Home

BYLINE: By KATE STONE LOMBARDI 

DATELINE: MOUNT KISCO

 BODY:
WHEN their house needed a new exterior paint job, Ginny Cousins approached her husband, Peter, to discuss which color they should consider. Her question was met with incredulity. The house, Mr. Cousins said patiently to his wife, was red, had always been red and would always be red.
It is not that Peter Cousins is an old curmudgeon at the age of 40, or a particularly stubborn man. It is just that his family lives in the house in which he himself grew up as a child, and certain things -- including the color of the house -- are simply traditions. 
 The Cousins are among those who defy the adage "you can't go home again." Many people have done just that and quite literally -- tucking their children in at night in their own former bedrooms, watching them climb on the very same trees and skin the very same places on their knees.
Though housing authorities do not keep official statistics on adults who return to their childhood homes, experts on history and housing patterns say that the trend is, for the most part, economically motivated. In many cases, the older generation wants to retire and move, while the younger one is ready to set up housekeeping. But with the enormous rise in the cost of housing -- particularly in places like Westchester, with its limited housing stock, easy commuting and natural beauty -- many couples cannot afford to live in the communities in which they were raised.
"Everyone used to be expected to do better economically than their parents, and in the last generation you wouldn't want to move back to your parents' house, because it was smaller," said Kenneth T. Jackson, chairman of the history department at Columbia University and a Mount Kisco resident. "But now we live in a completely different and much tougher world. The whole formula has changed. People growing up in areas like Westchester County, especially in places like Chappaqua, Katonah and Scarsdale, can only hope to do as well."
In a move that makes financial sense and also offers sentimental rewards, some young adults have rented or bought homes from their own parents, often at bargains. The older generation reaps the benefits both of keeping the house in the family and offering their children and grandchildren the advantages that they themselves enjoyed. The younger generation garners affordable housing and a profound sense of deja vu.
"It's a complete replay of history," said John Truslow, who lives in his childhood home in Chappaqua with his wife and three children. (Mr. Truslow pays rent to his parents, who retired to South Carolina, but he will ultimately inherit the house.) "My oldest son, Steve, lives in the room I lived in. When I took him to elementary school, I could see myself walking through the halls as a 5-year-old. It's like reliving your childhood through a different perspective." Mr. Cousins, too, said that re-entering his old elementary school building -- this time as a parent -- catapulted him back in time.
"It was one enormous flashback," Mr. Cousins said, when he first took his son Robert to Roaring Brook Elementary School in Chappaqua. "I could remember my first day at kindergarten, the nervous feelings, the cinder block walls. A few of the same teachers were there. But it has been so neat for me to be able to tell the boys my experiences there."
Sometimes, memories come at unexpected times. Several weeks ago, during a violent rainstorm, Christine Ferguson Donaldson, 38, who lives with her children in her childhood home here in Mount Kisco, was told by her 8-year-old daughter that the ceiling was leaking.
"I looked up at the leak, and said, 'Son of a gun, that's the same place where the stupid ceiling leaked on Christmas when I was 5 years old,"' Ms. Donaldson said. Some time before that, her son had come running in from playing outside, announcing that he had found the perfect spot to build a fort. Sure enough, it was the same spot that Ms. Donaldson had used as a fort about 30 years earlier with her girlfriend down the street.
Such moments bring reassurance and a sense of peace to those who are back home, they say. The word "comfortable" was most commonly used to describe the feeling. Such a reaction is not surprising to those who have had happy childhoods in their homes, experts say.
"When you lived in that house, and the wallpaper or the furniture or other surroundings are associated with a positive feeling, then when you're put back in that situation, it will evoke that emotion," said Linda Bastone, assistant professor of psychology at Purchase College. "It's familiar and it's comfortable, although that comfort may not be of your own doing."
Dr. Bastone said that those who have chosen to move back home are a select group who probably have good relationships with their parents and positive feelings about their childhood experiences.
"There are tons of people making the opposite choice," Dr. Bastone said. "For many people living in the home would be almost synonymous with living with the parent, and for them it would not be this pleasant experience, and anything short of dire circumstances would prevent it."
Even when it is positive, the dynamic can be a curious one. Mr. Truslow reported that moving into his parent's bedroom was "pretty strange at first." And when the older generation comes back to visit, there is a peculiar sensation about putting one's parents in their old guest room. "I don't know if my father is comfortable being there and not being lord of the manor," Mr. Cousins said.
The situation does afford an intriguing mix of the old and the new. Mr. Cousins was not alone when he wanted to keep the house its original color -- change can be a tricky thing when the status quo is steeped in childhood memories. At the Truslows, the Christmas tree is placed where it has always been placed. Ms. Donaldson said that when her fiance wanted to move some telephone books, she responded. "No! Why? They've been here all my life. Why would we move them? How would I find them?"
When things are changed, it can be traumatic for the older generation. Some spouses reported that their in-laws noted new curtains, rearranged rooms and felled trees with suspicion and general disapproval, leaving the younger generation with the feeling that the house was not truly their own. For others, the experience has been more benign.
"One thing that appalled my mother-in-law was that we used the living room all the time, but they had never used it and the children couldn't go in there," Glenda Truslow said. "But in the last two years when she has come back, she has said, 'Oh, I wish I would have used this room.' "
Tom Trotta, 44, managed the ultimate combination of old and new -- he bought the Mount Kisco house that he and his seven siblings were raised in, had it torn down and then built his own house on the same property -- a stunning piece of land overlooking the Kisco River. While his children attend the same school, crawl on the same rocks and swim in the same swimming hole as he did, they live in a house that Mr. Trotta describes as "everything I ever wanted." He said his house was "10 times bigger" than the old one, with 5 full bathrooms as opposed to the one his large family used to share.
"The anticipation of tearing down the old house was terrible," Mr. Trotta said. "But the reality was not so bad. If my mother was alive to see the house here now, she'd have gladly done it herself."
One might think someone who razed his childhood home would not be sentimental, but when Mr. Trotta's wife, Bonnie, wanted to have a tree cut down, he would not allow it -- that was the tree where his childhood swing had hung.
The person who has probably seen the most change from the windows of his childhood home is Robert Hochhauser, 75, who lives in the Hartsdale house his parents bought in 1917. Mr. Hochhauser and his brother and sister attended public school in a building that held eight grades, with several classes sharing a room. It was a town where everyone knew one another, and mail would arrive simply with the family name and "Hartsdale, New York," as the address.
Mr. Hochhauser left home to attend college and went to work for the United Nations, living in China for several years, and then on to a 30-year career with Ciba-Geigy. He never married, living with his parents until they died, and then staying on. He said the house has been modernized but "basically looks exactly the same" as it did 70 years ago.
"Over the years, I'd go off and I'd come back," Mr. Hochhauser said. "But this has always been home to me. This is my headquarters."

HEADLINE: The Mood For Merchants Is Still Optimistic

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
THE jobless rate moved upward, the highest in the last four months, and Wall Street may have a bad case of the jitters, but all that appears to be having little impact on Christmas shoppers. Like Kenneth Mendez last weekend who left Victoria's Secret here laden with gifts, many people this holiday season are optimistic and untroubled by the economic indicators. And they are spending accordingly.
"As far as I'm concerned, things couldn't be better," said Mr. Mendez, an electronics technician from the Bronx who was shopping at the Galleria mall. "Maybe it's because I have a better job this year, but from my point of view everything is wonderful." 
 Farther north in the county, concerns about the economy were also taking a back seat to the holiday spirit. Especially at the Mount Kisco Book Company, which last week reopened for business 11 days after a fire, the mood was decidedly upbeat.
"They're calling us the Miracle on Moger Avenue," said Irwin Hersch, the owner, who opened in another location on the same street. Three stores, including the bookstore, were gutted by the fire on Nov. 25, and it took 200 firefighters more than 15 hours to put out the flames
 which were most likely caused by malfunctions in electrical equipment, authorities said.
"Our shelves may be a little sparse, but everyone's spirit is full," Mr. Hersch said. "Even though we have lost some steam for Christmas, this is turning out to be a real live story with a happy ending."
At Arise Futon, less than a mile from the bookstore, Bernard Berch, the owner, was also filled with the holiday spirit -- especially since business there, as elsewhere, was better than ever. "Futons are literally flying out of the store," Mr. Berch said. "We're selling samples off the floor." He said many of his customers were preparing for an onslaught of house guests over the holidays.
The increased consumer confidence and generous holiday spirit on the part of buyers are greatly welcomed by merchants this year, especially after the dismal Christmas of 1995.
And though there are five fewer shopping days between Thanksgiving and Christmas, merchants are optimistic that sales will far surpass previous seasons.
Thanksgiving spending, as an early indication, was up 3.6 percent this year after a 2.7 percent increase in 1995, according to data compiled by Telecheck Services in Houston.
Even more heartening, the sales pace begun early in the season has continued, the check-acceptance company reported on Tuesday. Mr. Mendez, who was shopping at Victoria's Secret here, is apparently typical of buyers throughout the country.
"Consumers are more confident this year; incomes are up and more people have jobs, which should result in an improved retail picture this holiday season," said William Ford, Telecheck's senior economic adviser.
Mr. Ford also said that aggressive merchandisers, worried about this year's shortened season, deserve at least some of the credit for robust activity at the cash registers.
Consumers are being lured into stores with sales promotions and heavy advertising, and Macy's at the Galleria here was a case in point last weekend. Signs announcing deep discounts -- in some cases up to 50 percent -- were prominently displayed throughout the department store.
The chain also got a jump on the shorter holiday season on the Wednesday before Thanksgiving, featuring a one-day sale, which drew shoppers into the mall in advance of Black Friday, which is considered the traditional start of the holiday shopping season and is known as such because retailers hope that strong sales will result in black ink on their balance sheets. Those three shopping days over the Thanksgiving weekend are considered a barometer of the season to follow, even though that weekend usually represents less than 10 percent of all sales tallied before Dec. 25.
The International Council of Shopping Centers, a trade organization in Manhattan, reported that mall sales increased by 11.9 percent over that critical period, according to a national sample of 57 malls. By contrast, last year's sales, figured on a square-foot basis, were flat over the three-day weekend, compared with 1994.
"Although it is not likely that sales will remain in double digits for the season, this was an outstanding start," said John Konarski, vice president of research for the shopping center group. "It was the best three-day weekend since we began tracking mall sales in 1993."
Despite Mr. Konarski's early concern that the momentum might not last, sales activity has continued at a strong pace, building each day as Christmas nears, with the 10-day period after Thanksgiving showing a 17.4 percent increase. But the increase over last year for the entire period is projected at significantly less because of the shorter shopping season.
"In other words, this year's 10-day selling period is 5 days closer to Christmas than it was last year," Mr. Konarski said. "That makes a huge difference. Our research shows that sales increase incrementally as you get closer to Dec. 25, so right now we have strong comparisons. At the end of the season, when the 5 fewer days are factored in, we expect to see gains of between 4 percent and 5 percent as projected."
To date, the strongest showing for sales has been in jewelry, up 16.6 percent over last year; food, which gained 14.3 percent, and footwear, up 14.2 percent.
Cards, gifts and books were up 11.5 percent. Miscellaneous, which includes personal-care and toy stores, was up 13.9 percent. And the category that includes music, entertainment and software rose 8.9 percent, according to the council, which represents 32,000 members in 60 countries.
While many stores have been crowded with holiday shoppers, there appears also to be a down side to all of the activity. At Kay-Bee Toys in the Galleria, for example, frustration abounded because early shoppers had cleared the shelves of this season's hottest item for children -- a Tickle Me Elmo doll from Sesame Street, which laughs and vibrates when its $29.99 tummy is tickled.
"Forget it!" cried Lena Shkreli, one of the disappointed shoppers. "Elmo is nowhere to be found."
So Mrs. Shkreli, who drove up from the Bronx, reluctantly settled for a teacher Barbie doll and other assorted toys for the 18 nieces, nephews and other children on her shopping list.
But the Barbie doll may not have been a poor second choice, said a Santa Claus at The Westchester here. He said, "Barbies were hot" as always, along with Star Wars toys, remote-control cars and videos for the boys.
"Some things," he said, "never change." And Santa Claus, of all people, should know. The line of children waiting to see him snaked through the mall, as his fans waited to share their wishes for Christmas.
Not to be left out of the merriment, the White Plains Parking Authority announced over the Thanksgiving weekend that it would offer two free hours of holiday parking to shoppers at selected locations from Tuesday through Christmas Eve. Albert T. Moroni, executive director of the Parking Authority, said the purpose was to lure shoppers to smaller stores along Mamaroneck Avenue, which often have a difficult time competing with malls. Shoppers should look for red bags labeled "Happy Holidays" on the free meters.
All of the positive signs notwithstanding, Harold E. Vogt, chief executive officer of the Westchester County Chamber of Commerce, expressed worry that the troubling economic indicators may yet dampen the shopping ardor, which to date has been part of the holiday season.
"Yes, the initial push of Thanksgiving has been strong," he said. "But the question is whether that will hold up. The unemployment figures could in the last week send the wrong message to consumers."
At least in parts of the Northeast, there may be cause for concern. Telecheck reported that while sales were up nationally, the Northeast region overall had lagged behind the rest of the country.

HEADLINE: Backing Up Santa at the Post Office

BYLINE: By JACKIE FITZPATRICK 

 BODY:
Dear Santa Claus, I'm almost 10 years old. I have two brothers. I am very good with my Mom. I help her and take care of my baby brother. Santa, I know you are just like God. I know you could do miracles. I've been very, very good. And all I want for Christmas is happiness and to be with my family. Santa, I want you to make the best Christmas for my Mom. She needs it because she is the best Mom in the whole world. My Mom is very sad and if she is sad, I can't be happy. She takes care of me, my brother and my baby brother and her mentally retarded brother. She is the only thing we have. I don't know where my father is. He left us. My Mom has to take care of us by herself. So please Santa, make my wish come true. Make my Mommy happy for Christmas.
The letters are simply addressed "Santa Claus, North Pole," handwritten in pencil or pen. Inside the envelope are their wishes, grand and small. One child asks Santa for an Easy Bake oven, another for a bike, but many of the children whose letters pour into the Bridgeport Post Office ask for other things: health for a father who is dying, warm blankets for little brothers and sisters, a coat, a Christmas tree. 
 The letters are answered. They get responses because of the generosity of postal workers and of other volunteers in the Bridgeport area and because of the concerns of two postal employees in particular: Doug Carey and Nancy Hernandez.
Mr. Carey, the director of customer relations for the Bridgeport Post Office, has been a postal employee in Bridgeport for 23 years, as a clerk and later in management. Over the years, he watched as letters to Santa piled up, then were thrown out.
So one day, 13 years ago, he opened one of the letters, and another and another. What he read astounded him.
"As a child, I'd ask Santa for a G. I. Joe or a color TV or something, and most of these kids weren't asking for gifts for themselves at all; they wanted a lost family member back. And many children just asked Santa for food. It was very touching, and I thought these letters had to be answered."
Mr. Carey asked other postal workers for their help; clerks and carriers alike immediately embraced the idea, taking home letters to answer in the midst of their busiest time of the year.
That first year, with the help of the Big Brother/Big Sister organization, the postal workers answered 80 letters, giving each of those children a gift. The second year, Mr. Carey received help from the city's welfare department, whose employees helped them screen letters, trying to determine if a child who wrote in had brothers and sisters, so they would also receive gifts. Over the years the program has grown so that last year more than 300 letters were answered and gifts provided to more than 500 children, according to Ms. Hernandez, a postal clerk who has taken the baton from Mr. Carey and now administers the program.
Letters start arriving by the pileful in late November and early December. The postal workers open and sort them. The neediest are answered first. Letters are also placed in a box, so that people dropping off Christmas cards or other mail can pick up one or two. Usually they return with a wrapped present; sometimes they open thin envelopes of worn dollar bills and contribute a few to the children.
"We know where the very needy neighborhoods are," Ms. Hernandez said. "Most of the letters are very genuine. Every now and then we get beat and someone scams us but that's bound to happen."
As Christmas draws near, Ms. Hernandez urges people to take letters home and answer them, encourages local companies to take a bunch. "There are always letters that go unanswered and that breaks my heart," she said. Mary Ann Harp, a postal clerk, said the entire post office gets swept up into the program. "It's so nice to be able to help a child," she said. "That's what this holiday is supposed to be about."
When Ms. Hernandez comes across a particularly moving letter, she visits the home. "Sometimes I get to a home and I can't believe what I see," she said. "Last year, one little boy wrote to Santa, saying that all he wanted were blankets for his family. I got to his apartment and there were five kids there and the family literally had nothing. They had just moved to Bridgeport and all they had was the kitchen sink, two sheets on the floor to sleep on, no food, nothing."
Ms. Hernandez talked to postal employees and others, and by Christmas the children had blankets and coats, a toy each and a kitchen full of food.
By late December, she and the other postal workers are weary indeed. "Every year I say, 'I'm not going to take this on this year,' and then I think, how can't I?" she said.
As Mr. Carey explains it, the project is made possible by the belief of Bridgeport postal administrators, particularly Postmaster Michael Boccio, that they are part of the community.
"Many of our employees are single parents themselves; they're working to keep their own families going," Mr. Carey said. "This time of year they're already putting in 12-hour days and then they're out their buying gifts for a total stranger. It gives you a warm feeling to be around here at Christmas time."
Mr. Carey said they continue to see a growing need not only in Bridgeport but also in Stratford, Shelton, Trumbull and Monroe. "Supposedly the economy is better," he said, "but all of the towns we serve have some needy families."
When a child receives a package, a little yellow notice is sent to the home, asking the child to go to the main Post Office to pick it up. Tucked in the corner of the notice, the return address reads "Santa, North Pole."
Many businesses in the area take dozens of letters and answer them. Ms. Hernandez said the staff of one Bridgeport law firm regularly answers more than 50 letters.
Jeff Vogt and Mitch Wein of the Westport-based advertising firm Vogt/Wein answered 50 letters last year and plan to do more this season. "Mitch had been helping with the Bridgeport program, taking his own children out shopping to get some gifts for children in need," Mr. Vogt said. Then they decided to expand their efforts and work as a company, piling shopping carts full of Barbies and Power Rangers, but mostly clothes because that is what is needed.
"Instead of giving our clients a nice bottle of champagne, we buy a gift for a child in their honor and we give them a small token and the copy of the letter we answered in their name," Mr. Vogt said. "Our clients have been very moved by the letters, as we are, and everybody benefits."
Last year, Vogt/Wein answered the letter of a little boy who wanted a Christmas tree. When he was at the store buying an artificial tree and lights, employees at the store noticed he was reading a letter. The store wound up donating a whole cartful of decorations and tree trimmings. "It's catching," Mr. Vogt said.
The letters pour in.
Dear Santa, I am writing to tell you that my mother is in jail. We are staying with my mother's boyfriend. He is trying to be good to us but he can't walk too good. Please Santa, don't forget us please. I am 14 years old. I would like a leather coat cause we have to walk to school and it is cold in the morning. My sisters need a coat, too. My mother said she would buy us coats for Christmas but now she's not around. Love you.

 Santa, How are you? I hope you are in good health. You have a lot of work ahead of you. I am 11 years old. I live alone with my mother and I don't have many toys or friends. I like the Power Rangers. The Green Ranger is my favorite. That's what I would like for Christmas, a Talking Green Ranger. Thank you so much, Santa. I love you.

 Dear Santa, I am six years old. I want a nice big kids Bible so I can take it to church and some pretty shoes for church. Thank you Santa.
Ms. Hernandez can recall many cold, starlit nights when she delivered presents to children whose families had no means for getting to the Post Office.
One year, a letter came in from an older woman. She was caring for her own children and her grandchildren; none had coats. Ms. Hernandez went to visit. "The children were going to school in 20-degree weather in sweaters," she said.
The grandmother didn't actually ask for anything. She just knew one of her youngest grandsons wanted to see Santa Claus.
"So I went back to the post office," Ms. Hernandez, "and we got coats for every one of those kids, and toys and all kinds of food. And one of the guys, who'd never been involved in the program before, dressed up as Santa.
"We got there and this woman had the humblest of houses but it was spotless and those children were loved. You should have seen the look on the faces of the children when they saw Santa. There had to be 11 or 13 children, ranging from 1 to 15. We were about to leave and one little boy looked up and said, 'Hey Santa? Where's Rudolph parked?'
"Our guy in the Santa suit had tears in his eyes and so did I," she said. "You see their faces pressed against the door and you know that for a split second they've forgotten all about poverty, and the violence in the streets, and they believe in Santa Claus."

In this case, Laura Ambrogio, right, buys a Pooh bear from Melissa Young at the Trumbull Mall. (Helen Neafsey for The New York Times) (pg. 13)

HEADLINE: Communities Squabble Over Water Charges

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
SEVERAL central Westchester communities have recently thrown down the gauntlet in unrelated disputes over water bills. The disagreements reflect the complicated relationship between some water districts and some municipalities, which can be as bewildering as the plumbing underneath the kitchen sink.
The districts involved in the present disputes are the New Castle/ Stanwood Consolidated Water District, the Valhalla Water District, the Thornwood Water District, the Apple Hill Farm Water District and the Old Farm Water District. The municipalities are the town of New Castle, the town of Mount Pleasant and the village of Pleasantville. 
 A long-simmering conflict about water rates recently boiled over between the village of Pleasantville and the town of Mount Pleasant. The town contends that the village owes it about $500,000 for emergency water, which was supplied from last January through last June; the village asserts that the fee should be significantly lower.
The town of Mount Pleasant had supplied water to the village of Pleasantville from the Valhalla Water District. The water passed through pipes belonging to the Thornwood Water District.
"The village of Pleasantville had to rely on water sources from Hawthorne and Valhalla when the New York State Department of Health ordered us to disconnect our taps to the Catskill Aqueduct in January," said Patricia Dwyer, Administrator for the village of Pleasantville.
Ms. Dwyer added: "On average, the village of Pleasantville consumes 1.1 million gallons a day, and during the winter our consumption is traditionally low. The problem we're having in paying our claims is that while we have records of consumption, and know what we've consumed because we have water meters, Valhalla and Hawthorne historically have unmetered water. We have not been able to get information from town records that are useful."
For Mount Pleasant, the issue has to do, at least in part, with greater parity on the water rates themselves.
"We're saying we want to be treated fairly," said Robert Meehan, Supervisor of the town of Mount Pleasant. "This goes back to unfair water rates. The water rates are rising to astronomical numbers. Municipalities are unregulated, and the consumer has no remedy. Double water rates are being charged to outside customers, and that has nothing to do with costs. The water rate we charged Pleasantville was set at what Pleasantville charges Mount Pleasant."
Both sides hope to resolve the issue before the end of the year.
For its part, Mount Pleasant recently lost a court battle to contest the water rates that the town of New Castle charged to supply water to about 700 homeowners in the Apple Hill Farm Water District and the Old Farm Water District who receive their water from New Castle.
"Some people pay $2,000 a year, if they don't live in New Castle," said Mr. Meehan, who expressed frustration with a recent Appellate Court decision ordering Mount Pleasant to pay its bill of $1.5 million to New Castle. "The courts haven't been open to these arguments. The only answer is legislation to regulate this."
Water suppliers and consumers, like square dancers, are rarely static. In a decision unrelated to its dispute with Mount Pleasant, Pleasantville recently agreed to join with the town of New Castle in the Millwood Water Treatment Plant.
"We have excess capacity that we can sell to Pleasantville," said Clinton Smith, Supervisor of the town of New Castle. "We will still have excess capacity that we will be happy to sell to someone else, but we would need to do a study to determine what would need to be done to expand our capacity, and at what cost."
Mr. Smith added, "We expect the Pleasantville sale will lower our water rates by about $7 dollars per 1,000 cubic feet, and that $7 reduction would stay in place for 10 years, and then result in greater reductions."
For Pleasantville, the water partnership with New Castle solves the village's problem of how to provide filtered water to its residents. "We're under consent to have filtered drinking water," Ms. Dwyer said. "We had boiled it down to three options: building our own filtration plant, working out an agreement with New Castle and building a regional plant with Mount Pleasant. The New Castle alternative is the most economic and efficient."
Pleasantville anticipates being fully connected to the New Castle plant by the summer of 1998.

HEADLINE: VIEWS;
Newark's Slice of Italy That Survives Only in Memory

 BODY:
In 1953, the postwar wave of urban renewal swept over the old First Ward of Newark. As the tenements in the half-mile square around St. Lucy's Church fell to make way for the Christopher Columbus Homes Housing Project, so did a way of life. For the First Ward had been the heart of a community, one of the largest Little Italys in America. Thousands of Italian immigrants had settled there and had families, the first generation of Italian-Americans. Today, their countless descendants throughout the United States can still trace their roots to Newark.
Michael Immerso is one of them. A Newark native whose great-grandparents settled in the First Ward more than a century ago, Mr. Immerso began the First Ward Documentary Project, dedicated to preserving the neighborhood's Italian heritage. Since 1994, he has collected more than 60,000 photographs from the children of the First Ward, whose families lived there between 1875 and 1955. Pictures came from as far away as Florida, Texas and California. 
 Thanks to the project, the old neighborhood lives again in "The Vanished First Ward: Newark's Little Italy," an exhibition at the Newark Public Library downtown through Jan. 24. The project is also creating for the library a permanent archive of memoirs, letters, articles, dissertations and other memorabilia of Italian-American life. In addition, a companion book for the exhibition is to be published in June the library and Rutgers University Press.
The people of the First Ward lost their homes to a "renewal" that ultimately failed. (The last of the Columbus Homes buildings were demolished in June.) But they never lost sight of their heritage. These are just a few of the more than 300 images on display chronicling their lives in a time and place long gone.
"The Vanished First Ward" is on view in the second- and third-floor galleries of the Newark Public Library, 5 Washington Street. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 P.M. Information:
(201) 596-6550.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "THE VANISHED FIRST WARD" The exhibition at the Newark Public Library shows, clockwise from top left, Modesto Giordano, right, with his assistants outside his bakery at 13 Garside Street in 1936; an unidentified couple strolling in Branch Brook Park while the Cathedral of the Sacred Heart was still under construction; the Crecca sisters in their First Communion finery around 1925, and the Feast of St. Gerard at the corner of Garside Street and Sixth Avenue in 1910. The feast each October is one of the few celebrations of old First Ward life still observed today.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Speculative Offices End 7-Year Construction Drought

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
THE latest sign of a gradual improvement in New Jersey's office market is the willingness of developers to start new projects, ending a seven-year drought in speculative construction.
Evidence of that are four projects, totaling some 600,000 square feet of Class A space, under way by three separate developers. They are rising in two of the state's strongest submarkets, the Interstate 78 corridor in Somerset County and eastern Morris County. 
 The activity is redefining the term speculative construction, brokers and analysts said. During the mid-80's building boom, the term referred to offices built without leasing commitments from tenants. Now, developers premarket their buildings, often securing verbal or written commitments for a big chunk of space, leading some industry experts to tag the activity semi-speculative construction.
What the market is seeing may well be the equilavent to college sports recruitment where players commit to joining a team a few months before they sign contracts, said James W. Hughes, dean of the school of public policy and planning at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. Tenants often want to see construction start, he said.
Three of the buildings have tenants for most or all of their space. They are Hoffmann-LaRoche and Hoechst Celanese, pharmaceutical concerns, and Hewlett-Packard, a manufacturer of electronic products and systems.
In today's more cautious lending climate, developers must put up 25 to 50 percent of the cost of their projects, said Steven A. Kohn, managing director at Sonnenblick-Goldman Company, a Manhattan-based real-estate investment-banking concern. Traditional lenders will not give construction financing unless a developer has signed leases for 30 to 65 percent of the space in a building, Mr. Kohn said. Without that, developers would have to invest more of their own money or find equity partners like pension funds or real estate investment trusts, he said.
The developers of the buildings under way said they were using their own equity to at least start construction.
Still, the activity by whatever name, most brokers agree, underscores the health of the 11-county northern New Jersey market. The lack of construction has helped cut the supply of all office space, and of prime space in particular, said Mr. Kohn, adding that there was "pent-up demand."
In this year's third quarter, the Class A vacancy rate for newer, better-situated sites was 12.8 percent, down 2 percentage points from a year ago, and the rate for such space was below 10 percent in 19 of the state's 32 submarkets, according to Cushman & Wakefield, the national brokerage. Asking rents in some markets have also risen to reflect the cost of new construction, added Edwin H. Cohen, executive director at the concern's East Rutherford office. His concern puts the average rent for such space at $22.74 a square foot but said it could be as high as $26.
THERE are fewer than nine blocks of prime space of 100,000 square feet or more available in the 11-county northern New Jersey marketplace, down from 40 in 1990, according to the Saddle Brook office of Edward S. Gordon, another national brokerage.
"Demand is driving construction and that is a better sign because it will keep the market in balance with supply," said Robert J. Rudin, executive director of that office. Companies in the state are expanding again, he said, adding that the worst of the corporate downsizing was over and that what space was put back on the market could be absorbed.
The biggest threat to the market last year was AT&T's announcement that it would cut 7,000 jobs in New Jersey as it spun into three companies. But so far that move has had little impact since collectively the companies have added almost as many jobs as were eliminated, about 4,000, and occupy about the same amount of space, some 23 million square feet, said Ritch Blasi, an AT&T spokesman.
Dean Hughes said that the state, now in its 55th month of recovery, had recaptured 204,000 of the 262,000 jobs lost during the recession.
Those market forces are what the developers of the projects under construction say convinced them to move ahead.
Along the Interstate 78 corridor in the Somerset County community of Warren, the Bellemead Development Corporation of Roseland began work in the fall of 1995 on a 207,727-square-foot building, the last at its 118-acre Somerset Hills Corporate Center. By last April, before the steel frame was erected, Hoechst Celanese leased the building for its headquarters.
The company is scheduled to move into the $40 million structure by May, said Robert R. Martie, a vice president at Bellemead, a subsidiary of the Chubb Corporation. Brokers said the insurer, which is selling Bellemead, would have taken space if a tenant had not come forward.
"We were committed to go ahead with or without a tenant because the conditions of the market were so strong we were convinced the building would lease," Mr. Martie said. The vacancy rate for Class A space along Interstate 78 in Somerset County is 2.7 percent, according to Cushman & Wakefield.
In Parsippany in Morris County, the company began work last spring on a 107,000-square-foot building at its 132-acre Waterview Corporate Center at the confluence of Interstate 287 and Routes 46 and 202. At the same time, Bellemead began negotiating with tenants for space in the building and last month Hoffman-LaRoche's Vitamins and Fine Chemicals division in Paramus leased the $16 million building. It will be completed next fall, said Mr. Martie, noting that his company "is selectively looking to develop additional properties."
IN Florham Park, also in eastern Morris County, Gale & Wentworth Inc., a local real estate services and investment firm, is developing, in partnership with J. P. Morgan, a 100,000-square-foot building. It is rising at the developer's 170-acre corporate campus along Route 24, known as Park Avenue at Morris County. A division of Hewlett-Packard has leased 75,000 square feet of space in the $18 million building and will move there from elsewhere in Florham Park by next fall.
"The key in this market is being able to deliver product for tenants who typically have a lead time of 18 months," said Mark Yeager, president of Gale & Wentworth's Commercial Group. He said his company also planned to start a similar-size building before year's end and another, with up to 175,000 square feet, by next summer.
In Bridgewater, part of the Interstate 78 corridor in Somerset County, SJP Properties of Parsippany is constructing a $40 million, 240,000-square-foot building. It is the maiden project at the 118-acre Somerset Corporate Center, near the intersection of Interstates 78 and 287. SJP is developing the center in partnership with the real estate development arm of Foster Wheeler, the Perryville-based engineering concern.
The company is negotiating with several tenants for 40 to 60 percent of the space, said Peter Eppie, executive vice president at SJP. But with the limited supply of quality space on the market and the lack of developable sites, Mr. Eppie said his company was confident the building would be substantially leased before it was completed next November.
Because of those factors, he said his company would also look to start a second, similar-size building next year.
Developers, brokers and analysts said the construction activity would continue, albeit on a selective basis and barring an economic downturn. But no one is anticipating, at least in the near term, a repeat of the overbuilding of the mid-80's. Among the reasons are that banks continue to be conservative in their lending and there are fewer approved building sites in prime locations. Also, the pool of developers financially strong enough to secure loans and proceed with projects is down from what it was in the 80's.
"Banks are scrutinizing developers' balance sheets and track records," said Dean Hughes, noting that the days of anyone proclaiming himself an office builder were over.
