HEADLINE: Denver Isn't Big Enough for Both of Them;
2 Newspapers Battle for Hearts, Minds and All Those Ad Dollars

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: DENVER

 BODY:
Some executives use the backs of their business cards to promote a product line, or to print their names in Japanese. Managers of The Denver Post hand out this message with theirs: "Return for a 30-Day Free Sample of Colorado's Only Statewide Newspaper."
Neither the 104-year-old Post nor its 138-year-old rival, The Rocky Mountain News, is missing an opportunity to grab another reader or sell another line of advertising in their struggle to come out on top in one of the country's last big-city newspaper wars, where two contrasting strategies of newspaper publishing are being thrashed out in one of the richest, trendiest and fastest-growing markets in the country. The competition is so fierce that each paper regularly attacks the other's circulation claims in its news columns, each reads victory over the other in the same set of circulation figures, and neither side will admit the possibility of defeat. 
 Neither side believes that Denver will support two newspapers forever, however many Californians, Texans and New Yorkers move here for the sunshine and the scenery. Each is a flagship publication, The Post for William Dean Singleton's Medianews Group, The News for the E. W. Scripps chain. The winner will command a youthful and prosperous market that attracted 60,000 new households last year and that continues to add acres of new homes each week; the death of the loser could threaten the health of its parent company.
The rest of the newspaper industry is also gripped by the Denver story, because the struggle amounts to a test case of two competing strategies that are at play within the newspaper business these days. The Post, for one, has steadfastly maintained the broadest possible circulation and home delivery area in the war, despite the added expense of distant deliveries to parts of Wyoming, New Mexico and Kansas. The Wall Street Journal, the two Detroit papers, The News and The Free Press, and The New York Times have all followed the same strategy, reasoning that despite the potential drag on profits of sending only a few papers to distant readers, having even a toehold in many communities offers the best chance of one day dominating the region.
The News, on the other hand, cut off deliveries to 25,000 readers beyond the Front Range cities, 6 percent of its circulation, to save the $30 a month it was losing on every paper it trucked hundreds of predawn miles over mountain passes.
The Los Angeles Times, The Chicago Tribune, The Miami Herald and dozens of other papers have also cut back outlying circulation in recent years, saying it was expensive and unhelpful to advertisers. But none had cut as radically as The News.
Rural readers were angry and people in the industry were astonished, but like a gasoline price war or an air fare war, this battle of the dailies is also making winners of newspaper readers and advertisers, who are taking advantage of rates that start out lower than at any similar paper -- before the usual discounts are added.
"What's happened to advertising rates?" Larry D. Strutton, the publisher of The News, was asked. "There aren't any," he said with a laugh.
Both sides agree that Denver will not always be big enough for both papers.
"All you've got to do is look at what's happened to two-newspaper markets all around the country, and it doesn't take much imagination to figure out what the future holds," said Mr. Singleton, president and part owner of The Post's parent company, Medianews Group. "New York will always support a couple of papers, Chicago will, maybe Boston. But Dallas did not; Houston did not; San Antonio did not. So it's hard to see a future where two newspapers survive in Denver."
Mr. Strutton of The News agreed. "When there is the next significant downturn in the economy and/or the next big increase in newsprint prices, Denver will probably be a one-paper town," he said.
The competition is only heightened by the difficulty posed for the parent companies in absorbing losses in Denver. The News is the flagship publication of E. W. Scripps's chain of 22 papers and, judging by circulation, source of the biggest share of its newspaper earnings.
Mr. Singleton and his partner, Richard Scudder, own 18 papers from Vermont to Southern California, but The Post represents a kind of last stand for him at publishing a major city daily. Record newsprint prices and dominant competition defeated his Dallas Times-Herald in 1991 and his Houston Post in 1994. As The Houston Post neared its death, Mr. Singleton moved his family from Houston to Colorado and to The Denver Post, which had been a failing paper when he bought it from Times Mirror in 1987.
"This is it," said the man who got his start in newspapers as a 15-year-old sports writer, and who bought his first paper before graduating from the University of Texas. "We ain't moving again."
Mr. Singleton considers The News's retreat from rural circulation the prelude to his ultimate victory. Yet on paper, at least, the move made sense. Home delivery is usually no more than a break-even proposition for papers with compact circulation areas.
Besides, Mr. Strutton contends that Denver is hardly a typical metropolitan area. It is instead a densely populated island in a sea of prairie and mountain, an area that contains 68 percent of Colorado's 3.5 million people and, Mr. Strutton asserted, accounted for 69 percent of the state's retail sales.
"How hard are we going to fight?" asked Alan M. Horton, senior vice president for newspapers at Scripps. "Damn hard. We may be a little contrarian with our Front Range strategy, but that strategy is based on a lot of research and a lot of logic, and we don't expect it to be an overnight success and we don't want it to be, because what comes in a day can go in a day."
Though The Post surged into the overall circulation lead over the summer because of The News's strategic retreat, The News holds the overall circulation lead in its Denver redoubt, Mr. Strutton went on. That, he said, is where the paper would make its final stand.
"The thing that I have always tried to preach here and everywhere I've worked is that you have got to protect your core market," Mr. Strutton said. "You concentrate on that, you entrench, you make yourself impregnable, and then you can worry about other things."
Historically, focusing on the core at the expense of the outlying area has posed problems. The Philadelphia Bulletin, The Dallas Times-Herald and The St. Louis Globe-Democrat were all dominant papers in their urban core but all fell to more broadly circulating, suburban-centered competitors.
Cutting back saved The News $10 million, Mr. Strutton said, roughly the amount it costs The Post to maintain its regionwide circulation.
"Sure, we could save $10 million a year and pull out of the rest of the state, but that's not what The Denver Post is," Mr. Singleton said. "Look what it says right on the front page -- it says 'Voice of the Rocky Mountain Empire.' It doesn't say, 'Voice of Colfax Avenue.' "
Reducing costs allowed Mr. Strutton to cut The News's advertising rates below The Post's, which nevertheless has a slight lead in overall advertising linage. What is clear, however, is that competition has made ad bargains of both papers.
"We think this situation is very good for us and I wouldn't change it for the world," said Fran Victor, vice president for marketing for Gart Brothers, a sporting goods chain with stores throughout the Rockies, which spends "several millions" a year to advertise in both papers.
"I have dealt with one-newspaper towns and, believe me, you don't have much leverage in dealing with them," Ms. Victor went on. "So I hope they both live long and healthy lives."
Here is an example of what Ms. Victor was talking about: An open column inch of ad space in The News weekday edition costs $213.50, and the same space in The Post is $211, according to Standard Rates and Data Systems, a nationwide clearinghouse for ad rates. The same space in The Kansas City Star, in a one-paper market that in other ways resembles Denver's, is $295.
The war has also benefited readers with some of the cheapest newspapers in the country. Last year, before The News pulled back, the two papers' combined daily circulation was 635,000, in a market that ranks 21st in population.
According to the most recent circulation figures, The News now leads The Post in circulation in the six-county Denver region, mostly on the strength of its lead in the core city region. The competition is closer in the surrounding suburban counties, however. Since The News's rollback, The Post leads in overall circulation, by 334,400 to 317,000 weekdays and by 462,000 to 406,000 on Sunday.
While they fight for the loyalty of the prosperous suburbanites drawn to the region's life style and jobs in high-technology industries, the two papers have moved closer in the way they cover the news. The News, which like most tabloids has a strong appeal to men, is still more likely to lead with crime and sports, but it has softened this approach by devoting the bottom of the front page to headlines beckoning readers to inside features, particularly life style stories.
The Post, by contrast, has been trying to loosen up under its new editor, Dennis A. Britton, a former editor of The Chicago Sun-Times. He is changing movie reviewers because, he said, "we were writing about films, and our readers go to the movies, they don't go to films," and has begun to play down crime coverage in favor of making The Post a more upbeat paper.
"I am not dumbing-down the paper," Mr. Britton said in response to a question. "I am crime-ing it down and Pollyanna-ing it up, because I am looking for a positive spin on things -- because I want people to read every page of the paper."
Ultimately, the battle for Denver may be determined by the willingness of each paper's parent company to outspend the other in a slump, when advertisers pull back. The Scripps company has the deepest pockets in such a matchup, and its stock is strong following the sale of its cable subsidiary this year. But Scripps is a publicly traded company, subject to pressure from Wall Street to cut losses.
"My assumption is that The Post is economically more fragile than The News," said Mike Wirth, director of the School of Communications at the University of Denver, and an expert in media economics. "Ten years ago, The Post was almost dead, and what they have done to build the paper back up is remarkable, but even though they may be profitable, they are losing money on their out-of-area circulation while The News is taking their savings and putting it back into their paper in the counties around Denver."
Mr. Singleton predicted that eventually Scripps would have to walk away from any losses at The News. "It's O.K. for Scripps to spend money year after year on them," he said, "but one day there has to be a reckoning."
Mr. Strutton said, "I always like my opponents to underestimate me."

HEADLINE: As HUD Seeks to Avoid Cuts, Its Efforts for Homeless Are Praised

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 15

 BODY:
As he tries to fend off proposed cuts in his agency's budget, Housing and Urban Development Secretary Henry G. Cisneros has released a study by Barnard and Columbia Universities praising HUD's programs to help the homeless.
The study, conducted by the Barnard-Columbia Center for Urban Policy, determined that the housing agency's annual budget for homeless programs had risen to $1.1 billion in 1995 from $404 million in 1992. The study also found that by shifting how the money was spent, HUD had served 14 times more people last year than it did in 1992. 
 The report praised the agency for creating incentives for local governments to work with the Federal Government and to leverage Federal funds with money raised from other public and private sources. In providing money to communities, the report said, HUD gave local officials the flexibility to design their own approaches to the homeless problem.
Ester Fuchs, one of the report's authors, said, "One of the major findings of this report, as surprising as it might be to people, is that in the context of homeless service delivery, HUD has actually created a program which has helped local governments and helped localities provide more efficient and less redundant services, and also to help them encourage the creation of a comprehensive program."
In releasing the report at a news conference on Friday, Mr. Cisneros said the study, sponsored by HUD, was an "independent analysis" and not a "self-serving" report. But the study was released at a time when the agency is in a public fight with the White House Office of Management and Budget over what level of financing Congress will be asked to provide in the budget for the 1998 fiscal year.
In a telephone interview today, however, Mr. Cisneros said he had received assurances from the budget office that it would not recommend major reductions in programs for the homeless.
Last week, The Wall Street Journal carried excerpts from a memorandum from Mr. Cisneros to Franklin D. Raines, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, in which the housing secretary said that proposed reductions in financing for several of HUD's programs would be harmful.
"I sincerely believe these reductions go too far and would effectively destroy the hard-won reforms that are now being recognized and gaining momentum," Mr. Cisneros wrote.
At his news conference, Mr. Cisneros, who has already announced his intention to resign his position, declined to expand on his comments in the memorandum. But he did not deny making them, nor did he shy away from defending their intent.
"All I have wanted to do is to make sure that the future budgets, even in an era of very tight resources, and an era when a balancing will squeeze out some priorities, that those programs for poor people get a fair hearing," he said. "And that's been the nature of my intervention to date."

SECTION: Section D; Page 14; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: THE PEOPLE;
A Sense of Well-Being Among Boeing Workers

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Dec. 15

 BODY:
More than a year ago, the fortunes of nearly 70,000 people at the world's largest airplane-manufacturing complex here seemed to have hit rock bottom. The Boeing Company was in a prolonged slump and was still laying off workers. And 30,000 machinists were on strike, trying to keep their jobs from being sent to overseas contractors.
Today, after hearing that Boeing will absorb the McDonnell Douglas Corporation -- the only other large American commercial airplane maker -- workers at the major Boeing plants in the Seattle area were feeling flush. 
 There was less certainty in St. Louis and Long Beach, Calif., where McDonnell Douglas has its major operations. At least for now, though, Boeing officials said that there would be no layoffs immediately and that the combined company would have a total work force of 200,000.
Even before today's announcement, Boeing had been on a hiring binge, adding 13,500 workers in Washington State this year, for a total of 85,000.
"This is the most secure I've ever felt," said Matt Dillon, an electrician who has been with the company for 20 years. "When the company feels confident enough that it can make that kind of purchase, it makes you feel confident that things are going well locally."
By contrast, McDonnell Douglas has been reeling. In recent weeks it had lost out in competition for contracts to make an advanced fighter jet for the Pentagon and commercial planes for several longtime customers. Today's news came as a surprise, and brought some hope.
"It knocks my socks off," said Leslie W. Robbins, a city Councilman in Long Beach, where McDonnell Douglas has 20,000 workers and is the city's largest private employer. "This may be a good thing, since Boeing is the unquestioned leader."
Today's announcement did not make it clear whether McDonnell's main commercial jetliners, the MD-80 and MD-90, would still be made or whether the factories would be converted to make Boeing models. "What's important is building planes and that they are in Long Beach," Mr. Robbins said.
Boeing, the nation's leading exporter, makes more than 60 percent of all the commercial airplanes in the world. By joining forces with McDonnell Douglas, company officials say they can focus on their sole chief competitor -- the Airbus Industrie consortium in Europe.
"I figure our main competitor is Airbus, and the U.S. companies have to get together to work together," Jim Rice, a maintenance electronic technician, said.
In announcing the deal, Boeing officials said the corporate office and main manufacturing plants would remain in the Seattle area, with operations in 26 states. Boeing's total work force now is 137,000, and McDonnell Douglas has 63,000.
"The greatest strength of this combination is our people," said Philip M. Condit, the president at Boeing. He called the $13.3 billion deal to buy McDonnell Douglas, "an historic moment in aviation and aerospace."
Boeing had slumped during the general downturn in commercial business throughout most of the 1990's. By late last year, after the machinists' strike was settled, orders for new planes began to pour in. Boeing has received orders for 618 planes worth $46 billion this year, almost twice as many orders as it received all last year.
"Compared to the last two years, when everything seemed to be on a downturn, it's good to see it looking up," said Brian Talley, a maintenance dispatcher at the company's plant in Everett, Wash., where Boeing makes the jumbo 747. "It sounds great."
Local officials are optimistic. Economists here use a rule of thumb saying that each Boeing job brings with it nearly three additional jobs, in the form of service workers, side contractors and retailers. Seattle's economy has already been heating up from hiring at the Microsoft Corporation.
In addition, retailers rely on Christmas bonuses and a weeklong holiday vacation that Boeing offers its workers at the end the year, allowing the airplane factories to come to a standstill.
Before today's announcement, Washington State officials had already said that because both Boeing and Microsoft were hiring, the state would grow by 400,000 people in the next four years.
Growth has long been considered a mixed blessing here. So today's announcment was greeted by skepticism in some quarters. "It will strengthen the local economy, but it means more traffic, and housing prices will continue to rise," Ed Hanson, the Mayor of Everett, said.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: THE AEROSPACE MERGER: THE DEAL;
BOEING OFFERING $13 BILLION TO BUY McDONNELL DOUGLAS, LAST U.S. COMMERCIAL RIVAL

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
The Boeing Company announced yesterday that it planned to acquire the McDonnell Douglas Corporation in a $13.3 billion deal, the 10th-largest merger in American history and the largest ever in the aerospace industry.
The acquisition would make Boeing the only manufacturer of commercial jets in the United States while catapulting it ahead of the Lockheed Martin Corporation as the world's largest aerospace company and bolstering its status as the nation's leading exporter. 
 Boeing's proposed merger with the producer of aircraft like the MD-11 civilian airliner and the Navy F-18 fighter also underscores the growing importance of size in the aircraft and military businesses, which have little room left even for companies with the breadth and decades' worth of expertise of McDonnell Douglas.
Yesterday's announcement signals that aircraft manufacturing will increasingly be a competition among nations. Airbus Industrie, the European consortium that sold its first jet in 1974, has grown to be a formidable competitor behind Boeing.
So far this year, by some measures, Boeing has won roughly 60 percent of new commercial aircraft orders and Airbus has won 35 percent, leaving McDonnell Douglas with about 5 percent of the new orders.
Executives at Boeing and McDonnell Douglas, as well as industry experts, said the deal made sense. Boeing is predominantly a commercial aircraft builder that hopes to continue expanding its presence in military contracting while the bulk of McDonnell Douglas's business is already in the military field. With a rich history in commercial aircraft and substantial manufacturing capacity, McDonnell Douglas also can help Boeing meet increased worldwide demand for new planes.
Philip M. Condit, the chief executive of Boeing, described the merger as "an historic moment in aviation and aerospace."
At a news conference in Washington, executives of both companies referred on several occasions to the balance of military and civilian business that their merger will lend to the combined company, which will continue to be called the Boeing Company. Their emphasis clearly represented some advance salesmanship to regulators in Washington, who will be scrutinizing the merger for antitrust problems.
The Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission, which review such mergers, had no comment yesterday on the proposal. But company officials and analysts do not expect the proposed merger to face major regulatory obstacles.
The companies also sought to allay fears of layoffs in the communities where McDonnell Douglas's corporate presence is strongest, particularly in its headquarters city of St. Louis and in Southern California, where it employs a large plane-making work force.
Company executives said that their businesses were growing, not shrinking, and that the number of displaced workers would be minimal. McDonnell Douglas plans to continue making commercial airliners in California as long as customers keep ordering them.
Still, Boeing said it expected to save $1 billion in annual costs, although it did not specify how that would be achieved.
Industry analysts, who have often heard speculation about such a merger in recent years, said they were still struck by the sheer size of the combination now that it may become a reality.
"The merger creates this incredible powerhouse with massive technical, financial, manufacturing and marketing resources," said Wolfgang H. Demisch, an analyst at BT Securities. "They've got it all."
Under terms of the proposed transaction, McDonnell Douglas shareholders would receive 0.65 share of Boeing stock for each share they currently own. The deal would need to be approved by Federal regulators, as well as shareholders of both companies.
Mr. Demisch said the only problem he foresaw for the merged company, which would have combined 1997 revenues of about $48 billion and very little debt, was where it would invest all the billions of free cash it is expected to generate in profits in coming years. Still, "it is a high-class problem to have," Mr. Demisch said.
Harry C. Stonecipher, the chief executive of McDonnell Douglas who will be president of the enlarged Boeing, said in a phone interview that the two companies agreed to merge on Tuesday. The deal was sealed in a meeting at the Four Seasons Hotel in Seattle between Mr. Stonecipher and Mr. Condit, who will be the chairman of Boeing after the merger.
Mr. Stonecipher said that he flew to the meeting with parameters for a possible deal that were approved by his company's board and that he and Mr. Condit reached an accord in one hour, then spent two hours discussing broad points about how to merge the two companies.
Mr. Stonecipher said that shortly after he joined McDonnell Douglas in September 1994, he decided that if McDonnell Douglas were to merge with any other company, he wanted it to be Boeing. "This is the deal that we wanted," he said.
Executives for both companies said they had first broached the idea of a merger three years ago, and even held serious talks last year before realizing they could not agree on a price.
Since then, however, the long-term business prospects for McDonnell Douglas have dimmed significantly. Though the company has a strong backlog of orders, particularly on the military side of its business, it still became clear it was less likely to emerge as a technological leader among aerospace companies in the next century.
Last month, for example, McDonnell Douglas was knocked out of a competition for a contract to build the Joint Strike Fighter combat aircraft to serve all branches of the United States military. The news was a tremendous blow to McDonnell Douglas, which now builds many fighters, and a huge victory for Boeing, which remains in competition with Lockheed Martin for the contract, potentially worth $750 billion or more.
This fall, McDonnell Douglas also said that rather than try to compete as a company with a full range of small to very large jets, it would become a specialized player in the commercial aircraft business, acknowledging what many in the industry had already known. Still, it was a remarkable concession because the airline business increasingly demands aircraft manufacturers with a global network of sales and service offices that can meet all the needs of airlines, particularly those in developing countries.
Airlines are also moving to simplify their fleets of aircraft, committing themselves to only one manufacturer. Most airlines today, in part as a result of mergers since the industry was deregulated in 1978, have a variety of jets, which adds to the cost of housing spare parts and training mechanics and pilots.
This fall, USAir said it planned to buy up to 400 Airbus jets. And American Airlines, a longtime customer of McDonnell Douglas, committed to Boeing recently as the sole supplier of its new jets for the next 20 years.
The consolidation of the military industry has also continued as a result of a shrinking Pentagon budget, leaving fewer possible merger partners for McDonnell Douglas.
The merger announcement was foreshadowed to some extent earlier this month when Boeing effectively hired McDonnell Douglas to provide help in developing larger jumbo jets.
The frequent mention of "balance" by company executives in extolling their proposed merger yesterday spoke volumes about the ambitions and strategy of Boeing, which sees enormous potential in transferring technological expertise back and forth between its commercial and military businesses. For example, it used the expertise it developed in composites while working on the B-2 bomber to build the composite tail wing of its new 777 jetliner, which it in turn used to help develop the advanced wing design of its Joint Strike Fighter proposal.
With McDonnell Douglas's expertise from years of building fighters like the F-18 and F-15 Eagle, Boeing inevitably becomes a stronger contender in competitions to build fighters. It has not built one since the 1930's.
"The merger strengthens our competitive position for the Joint Strike Fighter, it improves our position in space transportation, and it enhances our ability to provide the best products and services to our airline customers," Mr. Condit said.
The full effect of the proposed merger on employees, communities, competitors, customers and investors will not be known for months, maybe even years. Because the companies are merging at a time when they are relatively strong, executives of both companies said there probably would not be many layoffs although some workers would be relocated. With Boeing straining to meet demand for its jets, it has advertised in the New York area for workers to move to Seattle, where Boeing is based.
But news of the merger is also bittersweet for communities like St. Louis and Long Beach, Calif., that are home to the main operations of McDonnell Douglas. While the merger provides an added measure of long-term job security for workers, at least some of the deep roots of the company in those cities will be cut under the ownership of Boeing.
For the primary customers of the two companies -- the Pentagon and the airlines -- the effect is also unclear. Industry analysts said that airlines would likely wind up paying a bit more for new planes as a result, since they are more likely to get a lower bid from three main competitors than two. But as McDonnell Douglas has won a shrinking percentage of new orders, its absence may have already been felt in recent purchase negotiations.
Chris Chiames, a spokesman for American Airlines, said the airline applauded the proposed merger because it will need ongoing support and service for the hundreds of McDonnell Douglas jets it plans to fly well into the next century. "Keeping Douglas's network viable and strengthening Boeing are wins for us," he said.
Although regulators declined to comment yesterday on the proposed merger, the Clinton Administration has long signaled its belief that the number of military companies needs to shrink to reflect declining procurement budgets and minimize the devastating impact on weapons manufacturers and their surrounding communities. Antitrust regulators, for example, approved a deal culminated last week in which Boeing acquired the military and aerospace units of the Rockwell International Corporation for $3.2 billion.
In evaluating the antitrust implications for the commercial business, regulators are expected to take note of how McDonnell Douglas has publicly scaled back its ambitions in the field.
Boeing and McDonnell Douglas executives said they hope to complete their merger by mid-1997.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Boeing Agrees to Buy McDonnell for $13.3 Billion
In a deal that would leave the United States with only one builder of big passenger jets, Boeing, maker of the 747, above, said it planned to acquire McDonnell Douglas, which specializes in military planes like the F/A-18.
The transaction, valued at $13.3 billion, would be the 10th largest merger in American history and the largest in the aerospace industry. [Page A1.]
 
The deal shows how the Clinton Administration has all but succeeded in turning the consolidating but resurgent American military contractors into instruments of one of its most important policies: making the economy more competitive globally. News Analysis. [A1.]
 
Workers at Boeing were confident about their futures. At McDonnell Douglas operations in St. Louis and in Long Beach, Calif., there was less certainty, though Boeing said there would be no layoffs for now. [D14.]
 
U.S. and Japan in Insurance Pact
American and Japanese negotiators hammered out an agreement on providing greater foreign access to Japan's insurance market. The deal puts off the threat of American trade sanctions and eliminates, at least for now, what had been a long-standing thorn in bilateral economic relations. [A8.]
 
Merger Talks End, Continental Says
Continental has ended merger talks with other airlines and has no immediate plans to restart them, the carrier's chief executive told employees. Continental was said to have been in discussions with Delta. [D2.]
 
Coke Plans Mountain Dew Rival
In an escalation of the soda wars, Coca-Cola plans to challenge Mountain Dew, a major money maker for Pepsico, by introducing a soft drink called Surge, people with knowledge of Coca-Cola's plans said. [D2.]
 
Another Blow to Power PC
In a move that shows how efforts by I.B.M. and Motorola to establish a successful competitor to Intel's Pentium computer chip are flagging, both companies are dropping support for the Windows NT operating system on computers built around their Power PC chip. [D4.]
 
The Hollywood Spotlight
Coverage of the departure of Michael Ovitz from Disney showed how the news media, the financial world and the economy have changed to focus on industries dealing with information and entertainment. News Analysis. [D11.]
 
Bennett Criticizes Bronfman
William J. Bennett, left, has unleashed a highly personal attack on MCA and its corporate overlord, Edgar Bronfman Jr., for distributing gangsta rap music with lyrics that Mr. Bennett says are violent and sexually degrading. Recording. [D11.]
 
Revamping the Re-engineers
CSC Index, the consulting firm that was the birthplace of the concept of re-engineering, is trying to re-engineer its own image, as the term has fallen out of favor. [D6.]

HEADLINE: THE AEROSPACE MERGER: THE NATIONAL POLICY;
A Swift Transformation

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15

 BODY:
With the Boeing Company's startling announcement today of a $13 billion merger with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, it signified the near-completion of one of the swiftest and most complete transformations ever of an industry -- as a matter of an explicit Government policy.
The lesson is that the Clinton Administration has largely succeeded in transforming the country's military contractors, during a span of just four years, into instruments of one of its most important goals: making the economy more competitive globally. 
 In this era of downsizing, in both the public and private sectors, the emphasis has been placed on efficiency, cost-cutting and exports -- in other words, commercial success in a Darwinian marketplace, rather than having the best weapons no matter the costs. The enemy is now perceived not as Communism but bloated office staffs and foreign weapons companies.
The announcement, one in a series of multibillion-dollar military mergers over four years, could never have taken place without a sharp change in policy initiated shortly after President Clinton took office.
Previously, the Government had prohibited most large combinations of weapons makers because it wanted to force them to compete with one another, even though that made production far more costly by duplicating research and development efforts and overhead.
But with military budgets declining sharply after the fall of the Soviet Union, the Clinton Administration decided to relax the antitrust guidelines and even encourage the huge mergers as a way of reducing weapons costs and, perhaps just as important, making American military and aerospace contractors focus on competing with other countries.
The country now has one major commercial aircraft producer, Boeing, which makes it a formidable competitor to Europe's Airbus Industrie consortium. The country also has, essentially, 3 major weapons contractors, rather than the 10 or so of a decade ago. Indeed, some major weapons, like tanks, nuclear submarines and armored vehicles, are essentially produced now by single companies, without any competition.
That is supposed to reduce costs for the Pentagon, and in many instances it clearly has. It also means the remaining companies are exporting a growing share of their fighter jets, guns, missiles and bombs. Also, the focus now is not just on the cost of building a weapon, but the costs of maintaining and operating it.
Not least, the small number of huge companies that remain are enjoying record levels of profits, a tribute to the efficiencies they have enjoyed after laying off tens of thousands of workers and eliminating redundant research efforts.
"You have one national aircraft company now," said Felix Rohatyn, an investment banker involved in some of the big mergers and a proponent of this kind of industrial policy. "It says that our policy is based on a definition of markets on a global basis. I believe that's very realistic. Ultimately, the marketplace would have demanded it, but the Clinton Administration really saw the need and responded."
Added Norman Augustine, who on Jan. 1 will become chairman of the Lockheed Martin Corporation, "You can have seven or eight half-full defense factories or two or three full ones. I think we're better off with the full ones."
Many analysts predicted that today's deal presaged a few more huge transactions, probably involving the General Motors Corporation's Hughes Electronics, the Northrop Grumman Corporation and perhaps the Raytheon Company. "The Administration realized it couldn't afford any more the artificially fragmented industry the Department of Defense had enforced for years," said Wolfgang Demisch, an analyst at BT Securities. "We don't have the money for that anymore."
Of course, there are also concerns that fewer companies will mean less innovation and that subcontractors and suppliers will be easily squeezed by the giant contractors.
The job loss has been very painful, too: The military industry work force has declined from about 3.9 million people in 1987 to about 2.6 million now, and the figure is likely to fall further.
But, as some experts point out, more innovation is taking place in the private sector now anyway, particularly in the fastest growing area of military procurement, electronics. About 45 percent of the Pentagon's procurement and research budgets are now devoted to electronics.
In addition, the creation of the huge contractors has eased a particularly tough burden that the Pentagon once had to bear, integrating all the devilishly complex components that go into modern weapons, and integrating different weapons systems so they work properly together.
This job involves heavy reliance on computers, electronics and advanced engineering. Systems integration, as these skills are known, can now be performed by the giant contractors, which may eventually allow the Pentagon to reduce further.
"The Pentagon specifically set out to do that when it changed its policies," said Mr. Augustine. "It concluded that the private sector does that a lot better. The Government has lost much of its ability to do systems integration now."
Said Howard Rubel, an analyst at Goldman Sachs: "This allows the Pentagon to do a lot less micromanaging. The Pentagon can describe what it wants in less complex terms and let Boeing or Lockheed work it all out. The companies can now do everything except fight the wars. That lets the Pentagon focus on what presumably it does best."
That, for instance, was essentially the way the Pentagon approached the bidding for what is likely to be the most expensive weapons contract ever, the Joint Strike Fighter for the Navy, Marines and Air Force.
The Pentagon eventually chose to allow Boeing and Lockheed to produce prototypes of their designs, and then will let the companies demonstrate the technological and military capabilities of each.

HEADLINE: Tourists Flock to New York To Catch Its Holiday Glitter

BYLINE: By RACHEL L. SWARNS 

 BODY:
The lights were twinkling, the carolers were warbling and war was erupting outside the glass-walled studio of the "Today" program in Rockefeller Center. Elbows jabbing and bodies slamming, hundreds of tourists pushed and shoved as they battled for a glimpse of Katie Couric. "All I got to see was the back of her coat," Sharon Bryars of Mobile, Ala., lamented.
Richard Altman, who flew in from Georgia hoping to see the stars of the Broadway musical "Chicago," only got to see the box office clerk, who told him the show was sold out for the entire month of December. 
 And Earl Edmundson, who trudged through the weekend's gloom and drizzle, found staggeringly long lines everywhere: at the Empire State Building, at Radio City Music Hall, even at the Harley-Davidson Cafe on 56th Street, where he tried to buy a burger for his son, 13.
"What is this?" grumbled Mr. Edmundson, a 40-year-old flight attendant from Jacksonville, Fla. "Is this New York or Disney World?"
Maybe it's both. Besides the jingling bells and crammed sidewalks, sold-out shows and Christmas sales, warm spirits and bad tempers, there are tourists. Millions of tourists.
Despite the lines to ogle diamonds at Tiffany's, the battles for blue jeans in Macy's, the rains that soak socks, and the drizzle that fogs eyeglasses, visitors are flocking to New York City's shops and sidewalks, looking for holiday magic. More than one million tourists are expected this month in what economists and city officials predict may be one of the busiest Decembers since 1979. And as a result, visitors and natives may find more misery than usual amid the merrymaking this year. Hotel rooms in Manhattan, which were virtually sold out this weekend, will also be scarce in coming days, particularly around New Year's Eve. Some of Broadway's biggest shows, including "Chicago" and "Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk," are booked solid for the month.
And city officials warn that midtown Manhattan's already treacherous traffic will only get worse this week as about 80,000 additional drivers a day are expected to pour into the city to shop and sightsee on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday.
The city is so busy that the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau has not even bothered to promote travel to New York City this month, focusing instead on the winter doldrums that usually follow in January. "The biggest question now is not whether the tourists will come in December, but where will we put them?" said Jason Bram, a regional economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
At the Plaza Hotel, which was completely booked this weekend, some tourists have already reserved rooms for next year's holidays. Others have given up on Manhattan, finding hotel rooms in New Jersey and the other boroughs. And Gil Slocum of Albany decided to forgo the hotel-hunting experience altogether. A white stretch limousine carried him and his wife in leather-seated luxury to Fifth Avenue for the day.
"Sure, we could complain about the crowds and the traffic," Mr. Slocum said as he watched the tourists gawking at a window display at Saks Fifth Avenue. "But we're going to Balducci's to load up on olives, bread, salads and custom coffees," he said. "Imagine the smells in the car on the way back home!"
The aromas aren't the half of it. All across the city, naked trees are blossoming with golden lights. Green wreaths with red bows cling to doorways. Shoppers shop in a frenzied hustle-bustle that astonishes outsiders accustomed to slower rhythms. And amid it all, there is the unforgettable cacophony of New York City sounds: the wailing fire engines and tinkling Salvation Army bells, the tinny carols and the clink-clink-clink of change falling into a beggar's cup.
"Ain't got nothing," sang a tuneless homeless man, who had positioned his wheelchair smack in the stream of tourist traffic on Fifth Avenue. And soon, his white mug was filling with quarters and dimes.
Heather Bernard, an engineer from Haverhill, Mass., delighted in the lights and the shows. Jo Rutledge, an accountant from Birmingham, Ala., loved the breathtaking rides in New York's taxis and the international chatter on the streets.
Mr. Edmundson's wife, Debra,marveled at the politeness of strangers who directed her to a bathroom in Grand Central Terminal.
"And the men!" Ms. Bryars sighed, citing her own New York favorite. "They look so good in those long wool coats!"
Some may call it cliche New York -- the trees, the shows, the lights -- but the traditional sights and sounds have been drawing more and more visitors and filling more and more hotel rooms.
In December 1991, tourists occupied 65.7 percent of the city's estimated 60,000 hotel rooms, according to statistics compiled by the Convention and Visitors Bureau. By last year, the December hotel occupancy rate had jumped to 80 percent. And economists, who say they believe the rate will increase slightly this year, say it would be even higher but for the slump around Christmas Day, when potential visitors choose to stay home with their families.
Economists attribute the surge in tourism to the lower value of the dollar, which has made New York relatively cheap for foreigners, and to publicity surrounding the recent drop in crime, which has convinced many visitors that the city is not as dangerous as they had imagined.
"Even those sitcoms on television, like 'Friends' and 'Seinfeld,' are helping to make New York an acceptable destination again," said John Fox, a senior vice president at PKF Consulting, a hotel industry research firm.
"I think we'll have a new record this year," he said. "The city is going crazy, good crazy." But some New Yorkers say the city is going crazy, bad crazy. Gloria Richardson, a 21-year-old college student from the Bronx, who was struggling through midtown's crush of tourists and shoppers, said she was so weary of the Christmas frenzy that she has found it impossible to garner the energy to shop. "I go home at night," she said, "and I can't bear to think about it anymore."
And Hraklis Amnaatese, a 31-year-old pretzel salesman, worries that tourists have lost sight of the real New York bargains in their search for glitter and glamour. "What about pretzels?" he asked as he stood outside Rockefeller Center trying to interest the crowds in his shopping cart of steaming, twisted delicacies.
"New Yorkers buy pretzels," he said sadly, "but tourists don't know anything about them."
Many natives, however, still cherish the holiday thrill. Charles Smoot, a 27-year-old security guard at Radio City Music Hall, said he loves the Christmas season even though it means he must endure the relentless questions from the thousands of tourists who buy tickets for the Christmas show. ("Can I walk to the Statue of Liberty from here?" some ask.)
"You get a headache sometimes answering all the questions," Mr. Smoot said as he hustled some ticket scalpers away from the crowd. "But it still gets me in the spirit. I love New York. And especially at this time of year."

Democrats at Odds in Assembly
Despite the gains Democrats made in this year's elections, liberals in the State Assembly are finding themselves pushed to the margins as the Legislature prepares to confront a host of issues they consider dear. Though Republicans are leading the charge, there are growing signs that conservative and even moderate Democrats plan to assert themselves more vigorously against the Assembly's still sizable liberal wing in a struggle for control over the party's direction.  Expanding Reach of Title IX
At Shore Regional High School in West Long Branch, the girls' field hockey team played its first night game under the lights on the football field. Coaches and athletes are increasingly invoking Title IX to challenge more subtle forms of discrimination than in the past. [B1.]

HEADLINE: Rich Areas in Miami Talk Secession

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: MIAMI, Dec. 15

 BODY:
Struck with the kind of fiscal emergency that other cities have survived and most financial experts agree is manageable, Miami instead finds itself in the throes of an identity as well as a budget crisis.
As Florida and Miami officials brainstorm to save the city, disaffected residents from several corners can be heard calling for Miami to abolish itself and merge with the government of Dade County, the metropolitan area that more accurately represents what the world knows as Miami. They say they have gathered 20,000 signatures, enough to call a referendum on the question next year, although their petition still needs to be certified by election officials. 
 The anti-cityhood drive has been fueled by anger over a corruption scandal that recently snared three top Miami officials and a $68 million deficit uncovered shortly afterward. But its roots lie in a trend that has been in evidence for most of the decade. Since 1991, unincorporated, mostly affluent areas of Dade County have lined up to form into cities, three of them successfully, and assume control of their tax dollars. If Miami's government structure were abolished, wealthier sections of the city that have been itching to break away, like Coconut Grove, would suddenly be free to do the same.
Such fragmentation is seen across the urban landscape nationwide as growing areas have formed small communities, not unlike gated neighborhoods that wall themselves off seeking a safe haven, urban geography experts say. But if the higher-income areas splinter off, Dade County will have to share its resources and services with the remains of an already poor city. Miami, with a population of about 350,000, is the fourth poorest city in the country, according to U.S. Census figures.
About 1.1 million of Dade County's 2 million residents still live in unincorporated areas, with the rest scattered among 29 municipalities.
But at least five cityhood votes are pending or being proposed for approval by Dade County Commissioners by communities that sometimes pay more in taxes than they get back in services or want to control police protection, zoning and other key matters. "One of the big negatives here is that should Miami become part of Dade County, you'll see a tremendous intensification of the movement to try to secede from Dade," said Peter Muller, an urban geographer at the University of Miami in Coral Gables. "It's hard for me to see Miami would be much better off."
Max Castro, a sociologist with the University of Miami's North-South Center, said, "The proposal to abolish Miami is part of a larger trend toward class and ethnic vulcanization of urban space and economic polarization of American society." But while critics of abolition say it would leave poorer areas in worse shape than before, proponents of doing away with Miami, led by downtown property owners and homeowners associations and residents from Coconut Grove and other higher-income neighborhoods, say every Miami resident would benefit from a tax rate in Dade County that is half what they pay Miami now.
Gene Stearns, the lawyer who successfully led the incorporation drive of Key Biscayne and who said his firm is donating "thousands" of hours to the abolition effort, said there was no question that some sections of Miami would seek to incorporate if the city dissolved itself. But he said a way to help out those sections that cannot sustain themselves through taxes would be to require cities to contribute some revenue to a countywide fund.
"Whatever the source of funding, this county will have to come up with a revenue source to provide money to these areas," he said.
If the city disappears as a legal entity, what would happen to the name Miami? Mr. Stearns said Miami would continue to be the brand name for the metropolitan area that includes cities such as Miami Beach and Coral Gables. "The city of Miami gives Miami a bad name," Mr. Stearns said.
But others are not so sure. Opposition to dissolving the city is widespread. "Dade County can run into problems, any place can run into these problems if they're not careful what they do," said David Beckford, 45, a comptroller for a downtown business. He said he opposed abolition because "It's swapping one government for another."
Dade County's Mayor, Alex Penelas, said that a revenue-sharing program would be essential if the incorporation fever continues, but he said he was philosophically opposed to dissolving Miami because the county government should be a provider of regional services such as transportation, indigent health care and environmental regulation and not become a local service provider.
Mr. Penelas shares the view of many residents who say abolition is too drastic and uncertain a step. "It's somewhat extreme," he said of the abolition drive. "I think and hope that the city can survive."
So does Gov. Lawton Chiles, who last week appointed a state oversight board to help steer Miami, the state's second-largest city after Jacksonville, toward solvency. State officials say Miami's fiscal emergency has the potential to affect the bond ratings and interest rates paid by both the state and its other cities because the financial markets are paying close attention to how Florida deals with the crisis. Lieut. Gov. Buddy MacKay, who heads the oversight board, said Friday through a spokesman that the decision to abolish the city is up to the people of Miami but should be made independently of the financial problems.
Some who oppose splitting Dade County into little fiefs say Miami nevertheless is long overdue to vote itself out of the map. The city has intractable problems that have made it "drag along like a wounded snake for years," said Dan Paul, the Miami lawyer who drafted the county charter in 1957.
Although Miami officials attribute the financial crisis to previous mismanagement, Mr. Paul and others said that the city also has suffered from a tax base that is insufficient to meet its required services and debt obligations, giving it a structural deficit despite charging the highest property taxes in the county. Mr. Paul said Dade County's metropolitan government structure, which duplicates many of the city's functions, was created largely envisioning that Miami, hobbled by financial crises and corruption even then, would someday merge with it. "We're now running two metropolitan cities within blocks of each other," he said.
But Miami is a vastly changed city from what it was in the 1950's, when waves of Cuban exiles fled Fidel Castro's government. Census figures showed that by 1990 more than 62 percent of the city's then 358,548 residents were of Hispanic origin, most of them Cubans. Many find abolition unthinkable.
"If this city disappeared it would be party time for Fidel and the people over in Cuba," said Heliodoro Coro, owner of two Little Havana restaurants. "The whole world knows that Cubans have worked hard to make this city what it is, to build businesses here, to make a life for ourselves. For those of us who came here, Miami is very important."

(He did not say "vulcanization.")

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
A Selloff in Stocks and Bonds Helps Push the Dollar Lower

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
A rally by the dollar against the Japanese yen faded yesterday, hurt by strength in the German mark and a late selloff in the American stock and bond markets.
Traders attributed the mark's rise partly to a technical rebound from Friday, when the German currency fell against the dollar after European Union finance ministers reached a stability pact for the planned Euro currency. 
 The mark's partial recovery, combined with a decline on Wall Street late in the day, diminished the appetite for dollars. The Dow Jones average reversed a 50-point gain to end with a loss of 36.52 points.
"The market got a bit overbought on dollars, and I think we're just finding a more stable level," said John Hazelton, chief currency trader at the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company in New York. "I wouldn't want to put more into it than that."
In late New York trading, the dollar traded at 1.5455 marks, down from 1.5558 marks on Friday. The dollar fell to 113.90 yen from 113.95 yen. The pound rose to $1.6669 from $1.6554.
The dollar initially strengthened to more than 114 yen following an agreement reached on Sunday by United States and Japanese negotiators that will open Japan's vast insurance market to foreign companies.
The deal was seen as a significant concession by Japan that could help improve trade relations between the world's two largest economies.
"Anytime there's a trade agreement there's always a sigh of relief it didn't turn into something unfriendly," said Ben Strauss, a currency trader at Bank Julius Baer & Company in New York. "There's always a bit of dollar buying on that."
The yen also weakened on the continued outflow of investment money from Japan, reflecting the search for higher-yielding opportunities elsewhere. Japan's record-low interest rates are not expected to rise anytime soon because the economic recovery there remains fragile.
"Japanese entities still have an appetite for foreign assets," said Dennis Pettit at the Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan Ltd.'s New York branch.
But the dollar later faded as stocks and bonds retreated.

HEADLINE: An Aerospace Colossus

 BODY:
The proposed $13 billion takeover of McDonnell Douglas by Boeing would create an aerospace behemoth that, for all its size, would do little to stifle competition in the commercial and military aircraft industries. Instead the newly merged giant would simply become a more effective global competitor.
The reality is that McDonnell Douglas no longer wins contracts from many commercial airlines and thus was not effectively competing with Boeing in that realm anyway. Nor do the two manufacturers compete head-to-head for many military contracts. The merger, therefore, would not seriously dilute competition except in a few selected markets, like rocket launchers, for which there are ample remedies. 
 Yet the merger would make Boeing a more formidable competitor against Airbus Industrie, the European manufacturer, for commercial aircraft contracts and against Lockheed Martin for military contracts. On balance, the merger seems likely to do more good than harm.
McDonnell Douglas became an easier takeover target when its price dipped following two stunning blows last month. The company lost a potentially gigantic military contract for an advanced fighter plane, and lost a major civilian contract with American Airlines. McDonnell had previously decided that it would specialize in smaller airliners and forgo building larger planes. That decision did not fit the strategy of major commercial carriers to cut maintenance costs by relying on one manufacturer to supply planes of all sizes rather than fragmenting contracts among different manufacturers. Boeing, by contrast, has a huge backlog of unfilled orders for aircraft of all sizes.
Through merger, Boeing will not only tap McDonnell Douglas's unused production lines, it will also acquire skilled engineers and other experts who can make Boeing a magnet for future military orders. The combined company will employ about 200,000 workers and generate almost $50 billion in revenue each year -- more than many countries. Because of Boeing's backlog of orders for civilian aircraft and McDonnell Douglas's future jet and other military orders, the merger is not expected to produce sizable layoffs or plant closings.
The Boeing-McDonnell merger is the latest in a series of defense industry consolidations. Lockheed merged with Martin Marietta. Boeing took over Rockwell's defense businesses. Northrop merged with Grumman. Defense planners in the Clinton Administration welcome the trends. As defense procurement has shriveled in the aftermath of the cold war, contractors have been saddled with hugely expensive yet idle production lines. Ultimately the Defense Department covers these costs when it entertains bids for new weapons systems. The only way to reduce the costs is to wring out the excess capacity through consolidation.
The question is how far to go. At some point the savings from further consolidation will be outweighed by the stifled innovation and price hikes that accompany monopolization. The implicit answer that defense planners seem to have settled upon is that two major competitors in any line of military work are enough to keep costs low.
If the planners are right, then Boeing's purchase of McDonnell Douglas is good for the military. But the Defense Department must wonder whether the recent bidding for the advanced fighter jet would have been less vigorous and less innovative had McDonnell Douglas not been around to push the other two bidders, Boeing and Lockheed. Commercial airlines would surely prefer to keep McDonnell, perhaps aligned with an Asian partner, bidding to sell them aircraft rather than disappearing inside Boeing. But there is no Asian partner in sight. Boeing is there, and that is probably good enough.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: NYC;
Time Again For Old Idea: 51st State?

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN

 BODY:
SENATOR JOSEPH L. BRUNO took time the other day from the horses and swimming pool on his estate in Rensselaer County to visit New York City and inform the locals that their way of life would soon change.
It was nice of the State Senate majority leader to drop by, given how far he had to travel. Most of his district lies closer to Canada than Canarsie. Unfortunately, he came bearing not season's greetings but a threat. He and his fellow Republicans, he said, intend to eliminate rent regulations once and for all, a proposal of some importance to the city's many horseless and pool-less residents. 
 Whether rent control has become outdated is certainly a fair topic of debate. But when did the city become so bereft of ideas that it needed help from Rensselaer County? More to the point, some New Yorkers wonder how it is that their fate on almost every significant matter of governance lies with faraway lawmakers, many of whom treat the five boroughs as though they were Sodom and Gomorrah without the charm.
(Funny thing about those who sneer at the city as a crime-ridden horror. Many upstate politicians practically trip over one another in their scramble for state contracts to build prisons, which would largely house inmates from New York City. "Our crime is their economic development," said Mitchell Moss, director of New York University's Urban Research Center.)
A few people here who are fed up with Albany's running their lives are ready to go to the ramparts carrying a banner that has not been raised in a while: statehood for New York City. We have nothing to lose, they say, but our pains. As things now stand, "we have the worst of all possible worlds," lamented Esther Fuchs, a political scientist at Barnard College. "We have the largest fiscal burden and the least control over policy."
WITH the Legislature reconvening today, it may be useful to recall how much upstaters dominate our affairs. When the city and its police union have a labor dispute, Albany intervenes. When the city tries to make all its employees live within its boundaries, the Legislature exempts uniformed workers and teachers. When the city wants to borrow reasonable sums to keep its bridges from falling down, it learns it may be stymied by an obscure provision of the State Constitution. When the city seeks to change how its schools are run, state lawmakers fancying themselves as modern Montessoris pretend that they know how to run a classroom.
How many New York City residents can name their own Assemblyman, let alone a North Country politician who probably thinks that "knish" is pronounced "nish"? That's how distant, socially and psychically, the upstate powers are from New York Harbor.
Who needs it?
The idea of New York City becoming "the 51st state" was popularized by Norman Mailer and Jimmy Breslin in the 1969 mayoral campaign. But counting on the Legislature to approve secession -- or on Congress to give the five boroughs two United States Senators to call their own -- is not realistic, Mr. Breslin says. He now leans more toward declaring New York an "international city" instead.
Over the years, the 51st-state proposal has enjoyed support from people spanning the political spectrum. For many, a central issue is whether the city, often derided by upstaters as a moocher, in fact keeps the state afloat, sending appreciably more in taxes to Albany than it gets back.
NO question it does, says Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. While not advocating statehood, the Mayor has cited a study by the Center for Governmental Research showing that the city runs a "balance of payments deficit" of $2.1 billion a year. More than once, he has said that the city would be in the black if only it could shake free of expensive state (not to mention Federal) mandates.
Apparently using a different set of calculations, the Citizens Budget Commission, a private organization, concludes that going independent would actually be a fiscal loser for the city. That's also the sense of former Mayor Edward I. Koch, who prefers not statehood but legislation to expand "home rule" in the city.
O.K., the call for a 51st state may well be a weak one. But why not be prepared, just in case? The original New Amsterdam is a worthy name. The Norway maple, a hardy survivor on city streets, would make a fine state tree. For a state motto, we could try: "Yo! Check it out!"
As for the state bird, how about the pigeon? That, many would say, is what Albany takes us for anyway.

HEADLINE: Municipal Bond Dealers Face Scrutiny

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL

 BODY:
In recent years, Wall Street's municipal bond operations have been rocked by one scandal after another: evidence of political payoffs; fallout from the bankruptcy of Orange County, Calif.; the conviction of one of the industry's leading advisers for concealing his role in steering business to one firm in return for a fee.
But in terms of money, these pale by comparison with allegations contained in a legal filing to be made today that if proved could end up requiring Wall Street firms that market municipal securities to pay back as much as $1 billion in illicit profits earned at the expense of the Treasury and municipal borrowers. 
 These new accusations, backed by extensive research into the pricing practices of securities firms, contend that Wall Street has frequently charged artificially high and potentially illegal prices for securities that were sold to local governments in complex bond deals. The extra markups in special municipal escrow accounts, according to experts in municipal finance, accounted for half or more of the firms' profits in the municipal bond market in the early 1990's.
The Public Securities Association, in an October letter to the Internal Revenue Service that reflected the views of many leaders of the securities industry, defended Wall Street's pricing practices for selling securities to these municipal escrow accounts. The price markups, it said, were not improper or illegal because they correctly reflected risks that firms took on when they pledged to provide securities to such accounts.
Under the longstanding practice, known in the industry as "yield burning," issuers buy a mixture of ordinary Treasury securities and special zero-interest or very-low-interest Treasury paper issued specifically for escrow accounts. But the securities firms were said to have frequently sold Treasuries to the accounts at artificially high prices, creating profit that would otherwise have gone to the Treasury.
The allegations are contained in detailed comments prepared for the Internal Revenue Service by the Los Angeles County Metropolitan Transportation Authority, one of the nation's leading public borrowers. The I.R.S. has been seeking to recover the lost tax revenue from municipal borrowers, the only group over which it has jurisdiction in the matter.
But the transportation authority, arguing that the real beneficiaries of the practice were the securities firms that arranged the deals rather than the municipalities themselves, is appealing to the Government to turn its attention to Wall Street instead. It is invoking the Justice Department's powers under the False Claims Act and the enforcement powers of the Securities and Exchange Commission to "recover damages directly from the wrongdoers."
"The False Claims Act provides the Department of Justice with an appropriate and powerful enforcement tool with which to pursue investment providers who have routinely overcharged municipal escrows and thus cheated the government out of as much as $1.15 billion in interest payments," the transportation authority will contend.
In the last couple of years, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department have shown increased interest in this aspect of the municipal bond market, prompted in part by accusations first raised last year by Michael R. Lissack, a former municipal bond executive at Smith Barney.
In a typical case, municipalities hold money in these special escrow accounts that they have raised from issuing securities but have not yet put to work on municipal projects. As interest rates declined in recent years, the funds in the escrow accounts soared as municipalities refunded existing securities to take advantage of lower borrowing costs. To prevent municipalities from simply borrowing at low tax-exempt rates and then earning a profit by lending the money in the open market, they were required to keep any excess funds in the special escrow accounts.
The county transportation authority's filing with the Internal Revenue Service was prepared by its lawyers, Phillips & Cohen of Washington, which hired the Michel/Shaked Group, a Boston economics consultancy, to examine Wall Street pricing practices. Steven P. Feinstein, an economist at Babson College, conducted the group's research, examining more than 100 cases to try to determine whether prices charged for the escrow accounts were fair.
It found, according to the submission to the Internal Revenue, that on average, escrows that were not submitted for competitive bids "were burdened with unjustified markups of about $4 for each $1,000 of a bond's par value."
Using that $4 markup, the researchers concluded that if 80 percent of advance refunding issues were affected, the combined liability would total nearly $1 billion, before taking account of interest owed to the Government.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Plunge As Factory Output Climbs

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Treasury prices dropped sharply yesterday after a stronger-than-expected manufacturing report, weak dollar and supply concerns discouraged many buyers.
The 30-year bond slid 22/32 in thin trading conditions to a price of 9813/32 to yield 6.62 percent, up from 6.57 percent on Friday. 
 Growth in industrial production during November worried investors, for if the economy is strengthening, they fear it could lead to quickening inflation and climbing interest rates in the future.
Yesterday the Government reported a nine-tenths of 1 percent rise in industrial production, or output at the nation's factories, mines and utilities. The increase was nearly double the consensus forecast of five-tenths of 1 percent, as auto production fully recovered from its sharp drop in October. But some economists contend that the output data overstated the strength, because of a weather-related 2.5 percent rise in utility output that added about two-tenths of a percentage point to the overall industrial production gain.
Other factors weighing on the market included oil prices, which jumped $1.30 a barrel, to $25.73 a barrel, on expectations of a cold front for much of the nation this week, and the wavering dollar, which depressed dollar-denominated investments like Government securities.
Not surprisingly, investors were cautious ahead of today's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, which consists of the 7 Fed board members and 5 of the 12 regional bank presidents. The meeting is the last of the year, and very few market participants expect the Federal Reserve to change monetary policy.
Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc., said neither he nor any of the other chief economists employed by the 37 major United States government securities dealers expected the Fed to change the current 5.25 percent Federal funds rate at the meeting. Sixty-two percent, or 23 of the 37, still expect some Fed tightening next year, but Mr. Harris does not.
"As it becomes more apparent that the Fed will not be tightening next year, we continue to believe that there should be a decline in the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond yield into a mostly 6 percent to 6.5 percent trading range, or around a 6.3 percent calendar average for 1997," he said.
One reason the Fed will not need to tighten, Mr. Harris said, "is that banks already have been doing some tightening of consumer credit conditions, which is already moderating growth in consumer borrowing and spending."
Prices were also pressured by year-end portfolio adjustments by managers who are starting to close their books. The prospect of added supply this week gave investors the excuse they needed to move to the sidelines. The Treasury is preparing to sell $30.75 billion in two- and five-year notes tomorrow and Thursday; in when-issued trading ahead of these auctions, dealers were offering the two-year note at a price to yield 5.77 percent and the five-year note at a price to yield 6.09 percent.
At yesterday's regular weekly sale of new three- and six-month bills, rates were mixed, with the average rate for a three-month bill down seven basis points (a basis point is one-hundredth of 1 percent), to 4.76 percent, with the rate for the six-month bill up two basis points, to 4.99 percent. Analysts conceded that the auction results were a bit sloppier than anticipated.

HEADLINE: Industrial Output Surges; Rise is Biggest in 9 Months

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
America's industrial production surged in November, showing the largest gain in nine months as strikes against the General Motors Corporation ended and causing a positive ripple effect through the economy, the Federal Reserve reported today.
Production at factories, mines and utilities increased by a larger-than-expected nine-tenths of a percent last month after falling by a revised two-tenths of a percent in October. Analysts had expected a rise of five-tenths of a percent in November. 
 Industries other than autos reported strength as well. Unusually cold weather led to a rise in utility output. Excluding motor vehicles and parts, production rose six-tenths of a percent in November, and many businesses continued to see orders stack up. "We in the steel industry can't complain," said F. Kenneth Iverson, chairman of the Nucor Corporation, in Charlotte, N. C. Demand for steel is especially strong in the tube, pipe and construction industries, Mr. Iverson said in an interview.
The Fed report suggests that economic growth could exceed 2 percent in the final quarter of the year, said Raymond Worseck, the chief economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons Inc., a St. Louis investment firm. Many economists had expected growth to slow to less than that rate.
Before the revision, industrial output for October was reported to have fallen by five-tenths of a percent, depressed by local walkouts at G. M. plants in the United States and a wider strike in Canada. That crippled the manufacturer's supply chain and idled many North American assembly lines.
Though the Fed said that the end of the G. M. strikes accounted for about half the November gain, "no matter which way you look at the puzzle, it has strength," said William Sullivan, an economist at Dean Witter Reynolds in New York. "You strip away the G. M. strike and you still have solid gains in manufacturing."
In the report on production, the Fed said the plant-use rate, which measures the amount of industrial capacity in use, increased to 83.3 percent in November from a revised 82.9 percent during October. Previously, the October plant-use rate was reported as 82.7 percent.
Before today's report, analysts expected a November plant-use rate of 83 percent, a survey by Bloomberg Business News showed.
"Inventories have been brought in line with sales," said Lynn Reaser, chief economist at the Barnett Banks in Jacksonville, Fla.
The report also showed that manufacturing capacity was growing at a 4.4 percent annual rate. That is a 27-year high, according to Cheryl Katz, senior economist at Merrill Lynch in New York.

HEADLINE: Bristol to Buy 61 More Holiday Inns

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
The Bristol Hotel Company said yesterday that it would acquire 61 Holiday Inns from Bass P.L.C. of Britain for $659 million, in stock, cash and debt. The transaction, expected to close next spring, will make Bristol, which is based in Dallas, the world's biggest Holiday Inn franchisee, with 84 properties, and one of the biggest owner-operators of full-service hotels.
Bass, which operates or franchises more than 2,200 hotels that are part of the Holiday Inn system, will receive 9.37 million shares of Bristol stock, $91 million in cash and $300 million in loan repayments. Those Bristol shares will give Bass a 36.1 percent stake in the company, the same stake currently held by the Hampstead Group, Bristol's largest shareholder. Bass will also have two members on Bristol's nine-member board. 
 Bristol said it had commitments for $505 million in financing for the acquisition from a group of banks, led by the Bankers Trust Company.
Bristol stock rose $1.50 yesterday to close at $30.125.
The purchase will bring Bristol's portfolio to 100 hotels from its current 39. That includes 48 of the approximately 300 Holiday Inn hotels that have 250 rooms or more.
"The hotel industry has basically abandoned the full-service hotel," J. Peter Kline, Bristol's chief executive, said in a telephone interview. "They've either gone upscale or become economy properties, leaving the mid-market customer without much of a choice."
Having earmarked $150 million for renovation, or about $11,000 a room, Bristol expects to compete heavily in the corporate meetings market.
Formerly the Harvey Hotel Company, Bristol started in 1981 by building a hotel in Dallas. Its first 10 hotels were all in Texas; then two years ago it bought United Inns, which is based in Memphis and has Holiday Inn franchises in Georgia and Mississippi, as well as Texas. Most of Bristol's current properties are in Sun Belt states from California to Florida.
Bristol said the properties being acquired from Bass have an occupancy rate 7.3 percentage points above the industry average and a room rate $3.11 higher.
"It's a great acquisition," said Michael J. Rietbrock, a hotel analyst with Smith Barney. "The economics of the deal are favorable, and it also establishes Bristol as a major player in an industry that is expected to undergo a lot of consolidation over the next couple of years." He added that the sale would increase 1997 earnings.
Mr. Kline said that since Bristol was no longer a regional company but still had the same senior management it started with, he was confident it would "be around a long time." The deal, which was reported yesterday in The Wall Street Journal, should create "a pipeline for us," he said, enabling Bristol to attract new offers and be more aggressive in acquisitions.
