HEADLINE: THE AEROSPACE MERGER: THE WASHINGTON POWER;
A Giant in Jets and Foreign Policy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
Long before it announced plans to acquire the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, the Boeing Company was already one of the most influential corporate voices in American foreign policy. It is the country's largest exporter, occasionally a back-channel conduit to China's leaders and the impetus for the tension between Europe and the United States over the huge subsidies and political favors that have bolstered the fortunes of Airbus Industrie, the European consortium that is Boeing's archrival.
Now Boeing is on the brink of becoming an even bigger player on the global stage -- an American national champion whose business interests around the world will influence a broad range of policies. Officials in Washington today, even while saying they welcomed the merger, acknowledged that the deal would only intensify the difficulties for American foreign policy that Boeing's operations often raise. 
 First among the problems is whether the United States should accede to ever-increasing demands from China for advanced technology. Coming from the fastest-growing market for new aircraft, those demands are forcing Washington to choose between losing a deal and aiding Beijing's efforts to build both commercial aircraft and, in the view of some, long-range bombers.
"The question we will now have to ask is whether what's good for Boeing is good for America's interests around the world," a senior State Department official said today, amending the famous remark about General Motors that was made during another era in American economic history. "And usually, there's no easy answer."
In statistical terms alone, Boeing's influence would not seem to be greatly affected by its huge acquisition: McDonnell Douglas's sales of commercial aircraft have flagged in recent years, and by the time the company decided a merger was the only way out it commanded just 5 percent of commercial aircraft sales around the world.
But because Boeing now stands alone, it will be viewed by governments worldwide -- which ultimately make most of the choices about what aircraft to buy -- as a commercial extension of the Government.
"When Boeing comes to Washington to describe what it needs abroad, it will now be on much more powerful ground," said Jeffrey Garten, who departed a year ago as Under Secretary of Commerce responsible for pressing American industrial interests abroad to become dean of the School of Management at Yale. "It will now be supporting jobs in every state -- from California to Missouri. And so you have to think that its desires for the direction of American foreign policy will become more influential than ever."
Already, Boeing has a corporate foreign policy that ranks among the most subtle and sophisticated. But even as it continues to speak softly, it will carry a bigger stick.
From Capitol Hill to the State Department, Boeing has long been a voice urging quiet conciliation with China, which a few years ago purchased one of every seven airplanes Boeing built. (The figure has dropped in recent years, first because of a strike at Boeing, then because airlines elsewhere started expanding even as China -- sending a clear message about its unhappiness with Washington -- directed some large orders to Airbus.)
Earlier this year, in a unusual gesture, Boeing held a meeting of its board in Beijing. It has lobbied the Administration and Congress to end the annual review of China's trading rights, pressing for "permanent most-favored nation" status. The change would enable all sides to avoid the annual debate over whether the Administration's commercial engagement with China is actually improving that nation's performance on human rights.
When America angers China, Philip M. Condit, Boeing chief executive, said earlier this year, "We are the designated hostage."
Today, between visits to the Pentagon, NASA and other Washington agencies to explain the effects of absorbing McDonnell Douglas, Mr. Condit disagreed with those who say that the company's influence in Washington will be significantly magnified once it is the nation's sole maker of commercial aircraft.
"I hope they are right but I suspect that they are not," he said during a brief conversation this afternoon. "We try to make our arguments on a rational basis, and we've been the No. 1 manufacturer for a long time. I don't think that this significantly changes the landscape."
American officials say that in some foreign policy debates here, Boeing has argued against its own short-term business interests. Risking the wrath of China's leaders, for instance, a senior Boeing executive warned the Chinese earlier this year that it would be unwise for them to conduct a large nuclear weapons test. The Chinese detonated the weapon a few days later.
'It is always a careful balancing act," Lawrence W. Clarkson, the company's senior vice president for planning and international development -- and the closest thing it has to a corporate Secretary of State -- said earlier this year.
The most difficult foreign policy test is likely to center on demands from other countries to share in technology. As the price of entry into their emerging markets, savvy countries around the world insist upon commitments from Airbus or Boeing or other manufacturers to move assembly jobs and technology to their countries, often setting up bidding wars in which an offer to manufacture, say, a tail section is played off against another to train workers in assembling fuselages.
Airbus, eager to expand its market share around the world, has long been considered a particularly ripe target for such tactics, and so has McDonnell Douglas as it sought to bolster its dwindling commercial aircraft business.
Boeing has been the most resistant to such demands, but pressure keeps mounting. "The Chinese make linkages to other issues that they would decry if we made the same," Charlene Barshefsky, the acting United States trade representative, said.
Whatever the outcome, Boeing's emergence as America's sole aircraft maker will undoubtedly heighten the tensions with Europe.
For years the United States has complained that Airbus, with support from its European sponsors, has been willing to sell at below its costs to insure its survival. The Europeans have responded that the United States subsidizes its industry, too, by having the Pentagon pick up the cost of research and development of technologies that soon find their way into commercial planes.
"I wouldn't be surprised if we redoubled our efforts to make sure Airbus prospers," one senior European official visiting Washington said a few hours after the Boeing-McDonnell deal was announced. "Now the American industry looks more like our own."

HEADLINE: NEEDY WHO LOSE PARENTAL RIGHTS GAIN IN TOP COURT

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 16

 BODY:
The Supreme Court ruled today that the parent-child relationship is so fundamental that a state cannot prevent poor people from appealing the termination of their parental rights simply because they lack the money to pay court costs.
Although confined to the narrow category of cases involving what the Court called the "awesome authority of the state" to cut off parental rights, the 6-to-3 decision was nonetheless an important statement of the Supreme Court's view of due process and equal protection, the two constitutional guarantees on which Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg based her majority opinion. 
 With dissenting votes by Justices Clarence Thomas and Antonin Scalia and Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, the decision was also a telling indicator of where the Justices are arrayed along the fault lines of current constitutional analysis.
The decision overturned a ruling last year by the Supreme Court of Mississippi, which barred a mother who could not afford more than $2,000 for a trial transcript from appealing a family court decision that freed her two young children for adoption by her former husband's new wife. Mississippi provides a right to appeal in such cases, but requires advance payment of all court costs, including preparation of a transcript of lower court proceedings.
Mississippi was in a minority of states to make such appeals dependent on the ability to pay. Twenty states, including Connecticut and New York, waive costs for indigent appellants in civil cases generally, and 10 others, including New Jersey, make special allowances for cases involving termination of parental rights.
In her opinion today, Justice Ginsburg noted that the Constitution does not require the Government to compensate for most of the disabilities of poverty. But "we place decrees forever terminating parental rights in the category of cases in which the State may not bolt the door to equal justice," she said.
That is a category that, until today, had been confined largely to criminal cases.
There is no general constitutional right to appellate review, in either civil or criminal cases. But in a 1956 case, Griffin v. Illinois, the Court held that if a state does provide an appeal in criminal cases, it cannot condition the right on the ability to pay required fees. In 1971, the Court extended that principle to appeals from convictions for minor offenses that carried only fines rather than prison sentences.
In that same year, in Boddie v. Connecticut, the Court applied the principle of equal justice in a civil case, ruling that the state could not make the right to obtain a divorce conditional on the ability to pay $60 in court costs. But in a separate line of cases, also in the 1970's, the Court refused to apply the principle to cases involving bankruptcy and welfare, reasoning that these did not involve the same fundamental rights as cases involving marriage and the family.
In surveying this complex history, Justice Ginsburg said today that the loss of a parent's relationship with her children was of such "magnitude and permanence" as to make it "barely distinguishable from criminal condemnation," and was therefore covered by the Court's precedents that removed financial barriers to criminal appeals.
Referring to Melissa L. Brooks, the mother in the case, Justice Ginsburg continued: "She is endeavoring to defend against the State's destruction of her family bonds, and to resist the brand associated with a parental unfitness adjudication. Like a defendant resisting criminal conviction, she seeks to be spared from the state's devastatingly adverse action."
In a dissenting opinion, Justice Thomas said not only that the Court should not have relied on the precedents involving criminal appeals but also that the main precedent, Griffin v. Illinois, had been incorrectly decided and should be overruled. Justice Scalia joined the entirety of the dissenting opinion; Chief Justice Rehnquist did not join the section that called for overruling the 1956 precedent.
The three dissenting Justices said the principle established in Justice Ginsburg's opinion was broader than the majority was willing to acknowledge.
"The inevitable consequence," Justice Thomas said, "will be greater demands on the states to provide free assistance to would-be appellants in all manner of civil cases involving interests that cannot, based on the test established by the majority, be distinguished from the admittedly important interest at issue here."
In her opinion, Justice Ginsburg drew a distinction between termination of parental rights and loss of custody in a divorce situation, which she said "does not sever the parent-child bond."
Currently pending before the Court is an appeal in a custody case from the Supreme Court of Illinois, which did not permit a mother who could not pay more than $5,000 for the trial transcript to appeal a decision transferring custody of her 7-year-old child to her former husband. The Justices have not yet said whether they will hear that case, Pope v. Pope, No. 96-447; presumably, if all agree that the ruling today does not extend to custody cases, they will simply deny review without comment.
The most interesting passages in Justice Thomas's dissenting opinion today addressed how the Court, and the Constitution, should deal with the consequences of poverty. The Equal Protection Clause "is not a panacea for perceived social or economic inequity," Justice Thomas said in a section of his opinion that the two other dissenters joined. The Constitution prevents only purposeful discrimination, he added, while "any adverse impact that the transcript requirement has on any person seeking to appeal arises not out of the state's action, but out of factors entirely unrelated to it."
Justice Thomas said the Court had adopted, in Griffin v. Illinois and similar cases, "an equalizing notion of the Equal Protection Clause that would, I think, have startled the 14th Amendment's Framers."
Neither the decision today, M.L.B. v. S.L.J., No. 95-853, nor the lower court opinions provided many details about the dispute between former spouses that led to the termination of Ms. Brooks's rights to her two children. The father, Sammy Lee James, had sought the termination order so that his new wife could adopt the children, of whom he had custody under the divorce agreement. He claimed in court that his former wife had not visited the children, while she maintained that she had been prevented from visiting.
Justice Ginsburg's opinion was joined by Justices John Paul Stevens, Sandra Day O'Connor, David H. Souter and Stephen G. Breyer. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote a separate concurring opinion, in which he said he would have based the decision exclusively on the notion of due process, without reference to equal protection.
There were also these other developments at the Court today:
 
Bible Club
Without comment, the Court turned down a Long Island public school district's appeal from a ruling that gave a student-run religious club the right to limit leadership positions in the club to "professed Christians."
The Roslyn Union Free School District had objected to students' proposal for the Walking on Water Club, on the ground that the district had a non-discrimination policy applicable to all activities. The students sued, and won a ruling last May from the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, which held that the leadership requirement was an inherent part of the club members' right to religious speech.
The students' lawsuit was based on a 1984 Federal law, the Equal Access Act, which provides that a school district that permits student groups to meet may not deny access to a group on the basis of the religious or political content of the speech at its meetings. The case was Roslyn School District v. Hsu, No. 96-583.
 
Indian Rights
Also without comment, the Court refused to hear an appeal by an Indian tribe in western New York, the Tonawanda Band of Seneca Indians, from a ruling of the Second Circuit allowing a group of dissident tribal members to file a Federal lawsuit challenging their banishment from the reservation. The case, which now goes to trial in Federal District Court in Buffalo, was Tonawanda Band v. Poodry, No. 96-609.

HEADLINE: Netanyahu at Bay: Bloom Is Off His Promise

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Dec. 16

 BODY:
This week marks six months since Benjamin Netanyahu took office as Prime Minister of Israel, and the country is already a different place, though perhaps not in the ways he promised.
Progress toward peace with the Palestinians has come to a halt -- and not through any ideological resistance on the part of Mr. Netanyahu, but on the contrary because Yasir Arafat has no faith in the Israeli leader's intentions. The Americans, after a big push in October, have decided to sit back awhile. At the same time, Palestinian leaders and Israeli security officials are issuing stern warnings that pressure in the Palestinian territories is at the boiling point. 
 Hard-won relations with moderate Arab states range from frozen to tense. On Sunday, Mohammed Bassiouni, the veteran Ambassador from Egypt, the first Arab country to make peace with Israel, said in an interview that he could well be called home. "It is impossible to know where the deterioration will stop," he said.
Criticism of the Prime Minister has become so shrill and constant that it is rare to hear a good word about him outside his narrow circle of embattled aides.
This week, for example, opened with another crisis in full bloom, this one over the Government's decision to restore economic incentives for Jewish settlements in the West Bank. In a pattern that has become glumly familiar, tensions rose a notch, Palestinians and Arab neighbors warned of possible violence, Washington and Europe chastised Mr. Netanyahu, Israeli editorials lambasted him and security officials called crisis meetings.
From their tightly guarded offices in Jerusalem, Mr. Netanyahu and his advisers fought back with a combination of tough talk and soothing rationalizations. "We are under an attack aimed at us all," the Prime Minister thundered in one interview, evoking an image of Israel once again standing up to a hostile world and charging that Palestinian leaders were planning a wave of violence.
In other interviews and statements he explained that restoring the incentives for settlers was intended to equalize their benefits with those of other Israelis living in hardship areas and had nothing to do with the issue of peace with the Palestinians.
After Mr. Arafat, the Palestinian leader, spoke on the telephone with Mr. Netanyahu late on Sunday, tensions seemed to subside, but the reproaches continued.
Criticism of the Prime Minister has flowed from all sides. The United States is now distancing itself from Mr. Netanyahu in public, while in private some officials are speaking of his actions with dismay.
President Clinton, for example, said that today Israel is at a juncture that is "full of tension, and full of frustration," and urged Israel not to raise the settlement issue.
The constant hints a month ago that agreement on an Israeli pullout from Hebron was imminent have been replaced by grim warnings. Mr. Arafat, the Palestinian leader, spokeof a "time bomb," while Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader and architect of the peace agreements, charged that the Government was "unwittingly bringing Israel to the gates of war."
In the daily Yediot Ahronot, the popular columnist Nahum Barnea wrote, "Six months after its establishment, the Netanyahu Government has been shorn of all policy." In an editorial on the same theme, the daily Haaretz declared that six months was little time for the Government to show achievements in the fields of security, economy or society, "but long enough to cause severe damage in those areas."
Within the Government, Mr. Netanyahu managed to fall afoul of the powerful and respected intelligence and military establishments as each side leaked recriminations over who was to blame for the big crises of the fall -- the rioting set off by Israel's opening of a new tourist exit to an archeological tunnel near Muslim holy shrines in Jerusalem's Old City in September and the current flap over settler incentives.
Reports surfaced over the weekend that Ami Ayalon, the head of the internal security agency, Shin Bet, sternly warned Mr. Netanyahu during a meeting on Thursday against any decision to boost the settlements. The leaks reportedly led to angry exchanges at a meeting today between Mr. Netanyahu and the Defense and Security Committee of the Parliament.
Compounding Mr. Netanyahu's plight was the fact that the actions that provoked such criticism from one side gained him little praise from the other. Settlers, already suspicious of the Prime Minister over his readiness to withdraw from Hebron, denounced the decision giving them economic benefits as an insufficiently "Zionist" response to the shooting last week of a settler and her son and demanded approval to construct new settlements.
Even the conservative Jerusalem Post, once a staunch supporter of Mr. Netanyahu, now finds fault with him over the settlement issue for giving the Palestinian Authority "the ammunition it needs" to rally the world against Israel.
Crises have plagued Mr. Netanyahu's administration from the beginning.
He came to office as the youngest Prime Minister in Israeli history, a man who had risen on the strength of his youth, a studied mastery of television and a ruthless determination.
But they were skills, his critics say, that did not spell leadership. Once he took office, his plan to create an American-style executive branch crumpled under the realities of a fragmented coalition reluctant to relinquish a scrap of power. His dream of creating an Israeli Camelot with his wife and little sons fizzled in the heat of savage press reports and rumors. His promises to set the Israeli economy on a new, market-driven path have come up against vested interests, political expediency and an economy on the verge of recession.
The initial comparisons of the handsome young leader with John F. Kennedy waned, to be replaced by a detailed comparison to Richard M. Nixon, sketched by Hemi Shalev, a respected columnist at Maariv. Like Mr. Nixon, Mr. Shalev wrote, Mr. Netanyahu is a political outsider with a grudge against the establishment -- in the Israeli's case a Likud establishment that spurned his father; a perception of the press as invariably hostile; a conviction that he can set things right with the appropriate explanation, and a view of a world filled with enemies.
Like Mr. Nixon, Mr. Netanyahu brought in as his closest advisers a team of campaign workers whose main qualification apparently was their loyalty to him. The aides -- Dore Gold, an academic from the United States, on foreign affairs; David Bar-Illan, a right-wing former newspaper editor and pianist on communications; Danny Naveh, a young lawyer, as Cabinet Secretary, and Avigdor Lieberman, a tough immigrant from Moldova, on domestic politics -- have been roundly criticized for their lack of experience in government, which has been evident in many of Mr. Netanyahu's troubles.
In Israeli politics, however, it is dealing with the Arabs that a leader is judged by. And here, the right-wing ideologue who insisted that he knew how to strike a hard bargain with the Arabs quickly found himself stiffed and outmaneuvered by them. Syria responded to his tough talk by moving crack troops to the base of the Golan and reviving a war scare in Israel. Egypt mobilized pan-Arab support against him, and even King Hussein of Jordan, his strongest supporter in the region, castigated him.
"If King Hussein is speaking as he is about Netanyahu, we have apparently reached the hour of genuine crisis," Mr. Arafat declared in an interview with Yediot Ahronot published on Sunday. "Don't they understand where they are dragging the region?"
Mr. Netanyahu's defense to such charges comes in a characteristic but confusing blend of classic revisionist ideology -- in which he stands as the defender of an Israel on which the world is ready to pounce at the slightest provocation -- and the tough, snappy television style that initially gained him political attention as a young United Nations delegate.
The Arabs, he says, have to get used to the fact that a Labor Government whose motto was "give and give" has been replaced by one that says "give and take." In his view, the violence after the tunnel opening, the current tensions, and the delay in reaching agreement on Hebron, are all a deliberate ploy by Mr. Arafat to trigger international attacks on Israel.
At the same time, Mr. Netanyahu insists at every turn that he is committed to the Oslo peace agreements with the Palestinians and will achieve a "peace with security;" that he will make peace with Syria, and that he will forge qualitatively new relations with the Arabs.
Like Mr. Nixon with China, he is convinced that only he can make that peace.

HEADLINE: Bookstore Bounces Back With Mount Kisco's Help

BYLINE: By TRIP GABRIEL

DATELINE: MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Dec. 16

 BODY:
The folks at the Mount Kisco Book Company knew their store was well liked in the community, but it was not until something really bad happened that they got a glimpse of just how deeply the affection ran.
On Nov. 25, a blazing fire gutted the store, putting more than 20 full-time employees out of work and extinguishing a healthy business the very first week of the holiday selling season. It looked like it would be the second lousy December in a row for the staff, most of whom had worked for another book and music store, Fox & Sutherland, that had gone out of business last year after 43 years down the street on South Moger Avenue. 
 On Dec. 7, just 11 days after the fire, the store reopened. Ever since, it has been filled with customers offering congratulations, hugging employees, saying they saved their holiday shopping for the store's rebirth.
"This morning, I got three hugs," Helen Cranley, the manager of the gift department, said on Saturday.
After the fire, Irwin Hersch, the principal owner, began receiving sympathy notes, like the one from a longtime customer who wrote: "The store wasn't about CD's and gift items and books. It was about people and beauty and soul."
When the Chamber of Commerce announced a fund for out-of-work employees of the bookstore and several smaller shops that burned, local residents sent in $3,000, mostly in small sums.
"Hundreds of people expressed their regrets and said they were really upset by what happened," said Mr. Hersch, who is also an owner of Coliseum Books in Manhattan.
When he announced he would try to reopen before Christmas, the village jumped to his aid. Don Ford, a local furniture dealer, arranged for a crew -- his sons, basically -- to install 5,000 square feet of carpet in three days in a temporary space Mr. Hersch leased a few blocks away. A retired painter spent a day wielding a brush. A camera store employee pitched in after closing.
"We could have had 1,200 people here if we wanted," said Mr. Hersch, who with grizzled features and suspenders holding up his khakis looks more like a plumbing contractor than a bookseller.
"It's an amazing story," he said. "I'm from New York. My stores have always been in New York. I could never imagine this thing happening there."
The store's demise seemed to tap into the public's general affection for bookstores, for independent merchants in the age of megastores and for tough-luck Mount Kisco itself, a working-class village surrounded by more affluent communities that has struggled to nurture a fledgling retail revival.
The fire, which investigators have traced to a compressor in a Baskin-Robbins ice cream store, did almost $500,000 in damage to the bookstore, which was insured, Mr. Hersch said. It destroyed not only books -- about 40 percent of the inventory -- but also CD's, fountain pens and children's toys.
The American Booksellers Association, in an appeal faxed and E-mailed to stores two days after the fire, asked for donations of unused shelves. Stores from Massachusetts to Michigan responded. Publishers' sales representatives donated 15 boxes of books.
Chip Edmonston, the book department manager, said, "Everyone who walks in is saying, 'This is almost magical that this has been pulled off.' "
Michael Stone, a customer who had picked out a Mel Torme CD box set, said: "Their inventory is thin. I understand. But I believe in the survival of independent retailers. There should be something else in our chain-dominated society, and I like to see these folks rebuild and survive."
This is the second brush with unemployment for many involved: seventeen employees of the store had worked at the former Fox & Sutherland, which closed last December. Its longtime owner had shut the business when he decided to retire, and in the face of chain-store competition. During the liquidation sale, many longtime customers had been unable to face coming in to pick over the bones.
"It was an awful winter," said Mr. Edmonston, a 20-year Fox & Sutherland employee, who was out of work along with his wife, Lyn, a bookkeeper at the old store.
When Mr. Hersch opened in June, he hired all the former Fox & Sutherland employees who sought work and recreated that store's eclectic mix of departments. The new store had mahogany shelves and a children's reading nook with an eggplant carpet with yellow stars. It quickly became a retail anchor.
Then the fire struck.
That evening, when Mr. Hersch returned to his condominium in Chappaqua, he was greeted by his next-door neighbor, a casual acquaintance.
"He rang my doorbell, and there he was standing with tears rolling down his face," Mr. Hersch said. "I started crying, too. The two of us were standing there crying and I don't think we ever exchanged a word."
On Saturday, customers shopped for James Thurber anthologies and Pearl Jam CD's, for Mount Blanc pens and Crane stationary.
"I know it sounds silly, but we have a love affair with this store," said Walter Joyce, who was with his wife, Lisa, and their toddler, Caroline. "We loved Fox & Sutherland. We loved the Mount Kisco Book Company. We loved what the store did for Mount Kisco."
For many, the way the village rallied has brought a needed sense of pride to the community, which is surrounded by the estate country of Chappaqua, Bedford and Armonk, whose affluent residents sometimes look down on it.
"This town gets a lot of knocks," Mr. Joyce, a village resident, said. "It was nice to see the town come together. There was a real sense of unity."
This Saturday, the store plans to hold its first author reading, by Frank McCourt, of his book "Angela's Ashes."

HEADLINE: Employee Ownership

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The Dec. 1 front-page article "Wealthy, Helped by Wall St., Find New Ways to Escape Tax on Profits" requires a response concerning the use of a Section 1042 transaction by a retiring business owner.
When I drafted Section 1042 of the tax code in 1984, I did it as a means for working men and women to realize the American dream of ownership. Section 1042 is meant to encourage business owners to sell the equity they built in their company to their employees, instead of an outside buyer, by offering a deferral of capital gains taxes. 
Without Section 1042, employees' fates would be uncertain when the owners of their companies retire. New owners could downsize the workforce or lay off long-term workers. There would also be a significant drop in employee ownership.
In times like these, we must continue to bridge the gaps that exist at our companies and in our economy through employee ownership. Section 1042 helps fortify that bridge.
 
RUSSELL B. LONG
Washington, Dec. 12, 1996
 
The writer is a retired United States Senator from Louisiana.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Generals, Battlefields And What Raleigh Said

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:

THE READER'S COMPANION TO MILITARY HISTORY
Edited by Robert Cowley and Geoffrey Parker
Illustrated. 573 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $45.
 In Volume 1 of his biography of Winston Churchill, William Manchester tells how Churchill and the French Prime Minister, Georges Clemenceau, toured a battlefield of World War I. A shell landed nearby; Clemenceau stopped a riderless horse that was streaming with blood. As the two turned reluctantly to leave the scene, Clemenceau observed in an undertone, "Quel moment delicieux!" What a delightful moment!
 That is one anecdote that Robert Cowley and Geoffrey Parker do not tell in their otherwise encyclopedic work, "The Reader's Companion to Military History." Countless other equally pregnant episodes in the history of war are told, however, episodes tending to justify Sir Walter Raleigh's observation, cited in the introduction, that "the ordinary theme and argument of all history is war." 
 Robert E. Lee once said, "It is well war is so terrible -- we would grow too fond of it," and while the editors and dozens of contributors to this book never say as much, one senses sympathy with that and Clemenceau's sensibility. Operating on the assumption that war is the truly universal pursuit, the editors have assembled a reference work whose purpose is to chronicle it factually and unemotionally across the centuries and continents.
Mr. Cowley and Mr. Parker inform readers early on that they followed two principles in choosing their entries. First, they have "privileged" Western matters, on the grounds that the Western way of war has become the global norm. Second, they put more stress on 20th-century events than on others. Still, their book, which begins with a short entry on Abd el-Krim (a Berber commander of the 1920's) and ends with a somewhat longer one on the Zulu wars, is marvelously inclusive, informative and, in its way, entertaining.
It does not offer deep explanations of anything -- the entry on World War II is a crisp five pages, for example. But it has copious cross-referencing, and its sheer coverage is enormous, including everything from the Persian Wars to Hannibal, the An Lu-shan rebellion in eighth-century China and the techniques of nighttime fighting (in an entry called "Darkness").
Explaining their approach, Mr. Cowley, the editor of MHQ: The Quarterly Journal of Military History, and Mr. Parker, a teacher of history at Ohio State University, allow that the old "drums and bugles approach" to warfare is outdated. By this they seem to mean that matters like technology, economics and intelligence have to be given their due along with biographies of generals and descriptions of battlefield maneuvers.
There are entries on such issues as homosexuals in the military, psychological warfare, friendly fire, espionage, "ethnic cleansing," courage, desertion and peace (including Ambrose Bierce's definition: "the interval of cheating between two wars"). But the evidence of the hundreds of selections in "The Reader's Companion to Military History" is that the editors and contributors are traditionalist military historians whose primary interest is in battles, commanders, weaponry and tactics: that is, on actions and outcomes more than on the costs, the horrors, the terror of war, the absurdity, the tragedy, the stupendous waste.
The volume is organized alphabetically, with the author of each entry listed and, in many cases, suggestions for further reading indicated. Helpful maps are placed on pages where major battles are described. One doesn't so much read the book systematically as browse in it, or get pulled along a trail of cross-references. One might start with the entry, say, on theorists of land warfare, which would lead naturally to the entry on Sun Tzu, the famed Chinese strategist of deception and deceit. From there, for purposes of comparison, one might turn to the 19th-century Prussian Carl von Clausewitz and his blunt definition of war: "an act of violence to compel our enemy to do our will."
However one reads this book, its most signal characteristic is its breadth and consistency. Entries on the Battle of Megiddo in the 15th century B.C., and on the Muslim warrior and sultan Saladin two and a half millenniums later, are written with the same authority as those on the Persian Gulf war or the battle of Stalingrad or the British campaign in the Falklands. Entries often begin with a crisp statement of historical significance, like this one on the Battle of Hastings, written by W. Scott Jessee: "The most famous battle on English soil, Hastings changed the destiny of England, and its sheer drama still astounds." Or there is this succinct statement provided by Edward N. Luttwak on the gulf war: "Seldom have so many gathered for a war eventually fought by so few."
The scholarly sure-footedness of the volume is somewhat marred by the editors' inclusion of various lists of 10 -- the best and worst commanders in history, the most overlooked and underestimated commanders, even the 10 best war movies. The effort has a parlor game feeling to it, and some of it is certainly debatable: William Westmoreland's inclusion on the list of 10 worst commanders, for example.
Then again, one can always read each of the relevant entries. The one on General Westmoreland, commander of American forces in Vietnam for four years, is written by David Kaiser of the Naval War College. It provides a straightforward summary of the strategy that General Westmoreland adopted as well as its shortcomings, but its final statement, "Historians may eventually conclude that no American strategy was likely to succeed," seems to take some of the onus for the defeat away from the general. In any case, the volume leaves no doubt that any number of the undisputed geniuses of the battlefield -- including some on the editors' Top 10 hit parade -- lost the wars in which they were engaged, Hannibal and Napoleon among them.
The subject is endless, which is one of the many pleasures of this useful book. On the same page are succinct descriptions of the Battle of Chancellorsville, "Robert E. Lee's greatest defensive victory," and Chandragupta Maurya, the fourth-century-B.C. leader who was the first to unite northern India under one rule. It would be hard to imagine another single volume in which those two entries could be found so close together.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Improves With Stocks; 2 European Banks Trim Rates

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended steady to mostly higher yesterday, deriving strength from a mild stock rebound and two interest-rate cuts in Europe.
The dollar's gains partly erased losses from Monday, when a late selloff in stocks helped drag the currency lower. But dealers said the dollar remained vulnerable to nervousness on Wall Street. "Without a doubt, dollar traders in particular are very focused on what's going on with the stock market and broader asset markets," said Bob Near, a vice president at the Bank of New York. "There's a lot of skittishness." 
 But the gains late yesterday bolstered the dollar.
"The dollar perked up in the afternoon when the stock market gave it the push," said Elliott Dix, assistant vice president for foreign exchange at Signet Bank in Richmond, adding that "the anticipation of a correction in the stock market is keeping the dollar a little bit in check."
In late trading in New York, the dollar rose yesterday to 1.5496 German marks from 1.5455 marks on Monday. The dollar was quoted at 113.88 Japanese yen, down marginally from 113.90 yen. The British pound rose to $1.6706 from $1.6669.
The dollar was also helped after the central banks of France and Sweden made small cuts in short-term interest rates, underscoring European economic weakness. The cuts came on a day that the Federal Reserve left interest rates in the United States unchanged.
And traders said it was still possible that Germany could nudge its short-term rates lower in coming months, even though the central bank there said in its monthly report that the level of rates and the mark's value were appropriate,
The yen weakened in Asian trading after Kabun Muto, director general of Japan's Management and Coordination Agency, said a lower yen was needed to deter manufacturers from moving production abroad to reduce costs. His comments helped lift the dollar past 114 yen before sellers pushed it back down, concluding that Mr. Muto was speaking only for himself.
Other late dollar rates in New York yesterday, compared with late Monday's, included 1.3253 Swiss francs, up from 1.3204; 5.2275 French francs, up from 5.2135, and 1,523.50 Italian lire, down from 1,524.00.

HEADLINE: Turning Colombia's Drug Plots Over to Peasant Plowshares

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 17

 BODY:
To get to her office, the director of the Colombian Government agency for land reform must wade through a living illustration of Government failure: peasants and their children making their homes on mattresses in the hall outside her office.
About 250 people chased off their plots of land at the behest of a nearby landowner are camping at Government agencies, seeking protection, after several of their number were killed and others threatened. 
 But Alba Ortilla Duenas, the Minister of Agrarian Reform, is hoping that a law passed by Congress last week authorizing the seizure of drug dealers' assets will ease the plight of landless peasants.
Either directly or through third parties, drug dealers are estimated to own about 9.9 million acres. Expecting that some share of that will be tied up in lengthy legal wrangles, Ms. Ortilla estimated that 3.7 million acres could be used to settle 120,000 families, which would give a three-year jump on a national timetable for land redistribution. The appropriation has the backing of the powerful Farmers Society of Colombia.
"Everybody wants it," said Ms. Ortilla. "People agree with whatever measures the Government takes to strike at the origin of this stigma."
Authorities estimate the combined assets of Colombia's 10 biggest drug dealers at $76 billion, which would rank them among the dozen largest companies in the world.
In the last two decades, drug dealers or their fronts have acquired land in 42 percent of all municipalities in Colombia, through generous offers that few farmers have had the courage to turn down.
Gabriel Martinez, an economist who is secretary general of the Farmers Society, said drug dealers had driven up the prices for land and for local labor. They have extended their political influence and turned the country's most fertile land into unproductive estates.
"They're not investing in agriculture," said Mr. Martinez. "They just need to launder their money."
The asset seizure law offers Colombia a tool to take back its economy. It allows the seizure of assets gained through drug dealing, kidnapping or extortion.
The law's passage on Dec. 12 essentially resurrected a bill that had been gutted earlier in the week, when the Congress voted 59-57 against seizing ill-gotten assets acquired before the 1991 Constitution was enacted.
Business leaders feared that a lenient asset-seizure law would have sealed Washington's decision to designate Colombia for a third time as a country that is not a serious partner in the fight against drug trafficking. That decision could lead to economic sanctions costing $300 million.
The business leaders mounted a lobbying effort to revisit the issue. President Ernesto Samper met with members of Parliament. The American Ambassador, Myles Frechette, warned that the United States would not take seriously any law that did not strike at assets gained before 1991. The new law, passed 103-4, covers assets acquired over the last 20 years.
In a statement after the Thursday night vote, Mr. Samper said the new law "defines a clear watershed in the history of the fight against drug trafficking and organized crime."
Others were less sure. They warned that if it was so difficult to garner the Congressional votes for a serious bill despite the damage drug wealth provokes in the country, it will undoubtedly be even harder to obtain judicial and political cooperation in actually seizing the ill-gained assets.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A high-technology initial public offering is a novelty in Japan.

BYLINE: By Andrew Pollack 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
AS initial public stock offerings go, a sale by ATL Systems Inc. would not at first appear to be one that would make investors drool. ATL, a five-year-old Japanese software company, recorded a loss of about $230,000 on sales of only $120,000 in its last fiscal year.
But shares of ATL, which makes software that runs on networks of Sun Microsystems and Apple computers and is used to manage business data, were snapped up yesterday as if the 10-employee company were the next Microsoft. Shares closed at 424,000 yen, or about $3,723, up 51 percent from the offering price of 280,000 yen. 
 That ATL is going public at all in Japan is remarkable. It is the first company to use a new over-the-counter market intended to allow technology companies that are still in the money-losing development stage to raise capital by selling shares to the public.
The so-called second over-the-counter market is aimed at remedying a big problem in Japan: the lack of high-technology entrepreneurs, who often take the lead in creating new products and industries.
In the United States, such entrepreneurs are often financed by venture capitalists, which realize a return on their investment when the start-up company goes public.
In Japan, it has been difficult for young companies to go public because they have had to meet certain profit and asset requirements. That difficulty, in turn, has stymied the development of venture capital in Japan. Indeed, Eric Forday, an analyst with SBC Warburg Japan Ltd., said that the companies that have gone public in the last year are 31 years old on average, hardly young growth companies.
In contrast, the Nasdaq market in the United States lists more than 5,000 companies, among them Amgen, Apple, Cisco Systems, Intel, Microsoft and many others that went from zero to billions of dollars in sales in a matter of years.
Japan, on the other hand, has virtually no recent technology start-up companies with similar records, and the Japanese over-the-counter market lists only about 760 companies, mainly in service businesses. New issues in the last few weeks, for instance, have included an installer of air-conditioning equipment, a steel products wholesaler and a men's clothing chain.
The restrictions on initial public offerings were imposed by the Ministry of Finance, which feared that a flood of new issues would further depress a stock market that has been weak since the economic bubble of the 1980's collapsed. Through part of 1992, the ministry effectively blocked all initial offerings, then set limits on how many could occur each week.
But the Ministry of International Trade and Industry, which wants to foster entrepreneurship, pressed for changes. The weekly limits on new offerings were scrapped in April 1995 and the second over-the-counter market, which has no requirements for company profitability, was established in July that year, though it has taken more than a year for any company to use it. While not strictly limited to high-technology companies, companies on the new market must devote an amount exceeding 3 percent of their sales to research and development.
No one expects the market to be an overnight success. Only one other company is scheduled to go public on the market -- A & CMOS Inc., a Tokyo designer of integrated circuits, which will be listed next week. Kaname Seki, vice chairman of the Japan Securities Dealers Association, said he expected about 10 companies to be listed by next autumn.
Despite yesterday's enthusiastic reception for ATL, finding investors might be difficult. "Institutional investors don't invest in companies that are losing money," said Noriko Takahashi, who follows over-the-counter companies for UBS Securities in Tokyo.
To try to improve liquidity and attract investors, the second O-T-C market will use the market maker system, similar to that of Nasdaq, in which securities companies actively buy and sell shares rather than merely act as middlemen.
Even if the new market proves popular, no one expects that by itself it will lead to a burst of entrepreneurialism in Japan because there are other obstacles. Venture capital business is not well developed and many people prefer to work for big companies, which offer the most prestige and lifetime job security.
ATL, meanwhile, which raised about $2.7 million by selling 1,100 new shares, must fulfill its promise of becoming profitable this year to avoid souring investors. The company, which is based in Kofu, about 70 miles west of Tokyo, has so far sold just six software packages at about $85,000 each.
"We feel the weight of responsibility," Yasuhiro Sasaki, an ATL director, said. "We feel we must turn in profits."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Remember that Datsun 240Z you drove 25 years ago? Nissan hopes you will buy it again.

BYLINE: By Robyn Meredith 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
THERE are used cars, and then there are used cars.
The Nissan Motor Corporation U.S.A. has been buying up 1970 to 1972 models of its Z sports cars and restoring them to their former glory. The cars will be sold at 10 dealerships, starting in February. 
 To stimulate interest in the cars, TBWA Chiat/Day, the ad agency for Nissan, has started hawking them with advertisements in December issues of most automotive magazines.
The cars will be priced at more than $20,000, up from the $3,526 -- not adjusted for inflation, of course -- that a 1970 240Z originally fetched. While that might seem to be a steep price for a car that is about a quarter-century old, with the 1970's being all the rage, Nissan is saying, why not?
"Right now, retro is very hip, so I think it is a very interesting concept," said Rob R. Siltanen, creative director at the Venice, Calif., office of TBWA Chiat/Day, a unit of the Omnicom Group.
The three-page print ads hark back to a seemingly simpler time, promising readers: "No power mirrors. No cup holders. No lumbar supports. (First come, first served.)" The ads, expected to run through 1997, feature a flame yellow Datsun 240Z, circa 1972, in front of a cherry-colored background.
Nissan is spending less than $5 million for the ads because they will run only in "buff books" like Auto Week, Road & Track and Automobile magazine, said W. Thomas Orbe Jr., vice president for marketing at Nissan in Gardena, Calif.
The vintage Z ads are a small piece of the $200 million image campaign that Nissan began in the summer to remind customers of its roots. The Japanese company was known in the United States as Datsun until 1983.
"It fits in perfectly with the campaign," Mr. Siltanen said of the image effort, which carries the theme "Life is a journey. Enjoy the ride."
The yellow 240Z is also featured in a two-minute television commercial, titled "Dream Garage," that first ran during the closing ceremonies of the Summer Olympics in August. A toy version of the latest Z -- the 300Z -- is the centerpiece of the delightful 60-second commercial that shows a macho action toy coming to life as the Van Halen version of the rock tune "You Really Got Me" plays in the background. The spot ends as the tough toy, joined by a Barbie-like doll, drive away together in the sports car.
But Nissan has gone a step further, by selling a physical as well as a celluloid version of its heritage.
"We have a very strong brand in the Z car," Mr. Orbe said. Datsun sold about 71,000 of the automobiles from 1970 to 1972, when they were among the most popular sports cars.
"It would be a shame just to let this vehicle go by the wayside," he added.
So the company has chosen 10 of its top-selling dealerships to sell the restored 1970-72 Z cars as well as used Z's from the 1990 through 1996 model years that have been given checkups and warranty extensions.
Nissan expects to sell a total of one dozen to two dozen vintage sports cars monthly at the 10 dealerships and 100 to 150 of the younger used Z's monthly.
The vintage Z's are restored to mint 1970's condition but not updated. That means they are missing advanced safety devices like air bags. Their emissions systems are vintage, too -- polluting just as much as they would have when originally sold.
But the lack of updating may be part of the appeal. "The response we've gotten has been phenomenal," Mr. Orbe said. "Some dealers already have waiting lists." The special Z dealers are in California, Florida, Georgia, Texas and Virginia.
If Nissan decides to add more "Z-stores," as the dealerships that sell the vintage and classic Z's are being called, Mr. Orbe said, one may be added in the New York area.
Nissan says it has done for cars what some watch makers have done for vintage timepieces: restored classic versions of their products to sell alongside new ones.
"Just like a real fine watch, a Rolex or a Patek Philippe, we'll give the public a chance to buy one of these classics," Mr. Orbe said. "Good things have a way of coming back."

HEADLINE: Goldman, Sachs Profit Up, Boding Well for Wall Street

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Goldman, Sachs, the nation's biggest investment banking partnership, said yesterday that its pretax earnings rose 69 percent in the fiscal fourth quarter, as profit from investment banking, trading and sales led the firm to its second- best year.
The Goldman Sachs Group L.P. reported that earnings before taxes increased to $743 million in the three months that ended in November, from $440 million in the similar period a year earlier. It reported its profit to partners on Monday night and to other employees yesterday. 
 Pretax profit for the full year totaled $2.6 billion, just shy of the $2.7 billion in 1993, Goldman's best year.
The firm's fourth-quarter revenue totaled $1.54 billion; the total for the year was $6.14 billion.
The increase in profit comes as Wall Street is on track for record overall profit this year amid a boom in underwriting and in mergers and acquisitions driven by rising stocks and low interest rates.
"The market environment was singularly favorable to Goldman," said John Keefe, an independent securities analyst. "They had a great share of underwriting and lots of M. and A. activity."
Goldman is privately held and, unlike publicly traded securities firms, does not report its after-tax profit. But the strong earnings bode well for big securities firms like Morgan Stanley, Merrill Lynch and Lehman Brothers Holdings, which report their quarterly profits after the first of the year, analysts suggested.
"I think Goldman's results could be representative of the industry," said Charles Vincent of the PNC Bank Asset Management Group in Philadelphia.
The rise in earnings is also good news for Goldman's 190 partners, who share in the profits. Partners will make about $7 million to $8 million each this year, according to people at the firm, though much of that will be reinvested in the firm until they retire or leave. A Goldman, Sachs spokesman said any discussion of partners' compensation was speculative, and declined to comment further.
Goldman was the leading American underwriter of common stocks, one of Wall Street's most lucrative businesses, so far in the fourth quarter and the full year, according to the Securities Data Company of Newark.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bonds Falter On Strong Housing Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Government securities dropped yesterday following a housing report that was stronger than expected, but the bonds partly erased some early losses and managed to end above the day's lows.
The Commerce Department reported that new housing starts in November rose 9.2 percent, to an annual rate of 1.514 million units -- a far larger gain than the gain of one-tenth of 1 percent economists had expected, and a stark reminder to market participants that the economy could still rebound strongly and increase inflationary pressures. 
 The housing data led to a selloff of securities that at one point pushed the yield on the 30-year bond up to 6.68 percent, the highest it has been since Nov. 1.
Then, after a partial recovery, the 30-year bond finished the session down 15/32 , to a price of 98; its yield, which moves in the opposite direction of its price, rose to 6.65 percent, from 6.62 percent on Monday.
The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee concluded its final meeting for the year yesterday without taking action on short-term interest rates. But with the majority of market participants correctly expecting the Fed to keep monetary policy on hold, it had little effect on trading.
Discussing the increased housing starts, Marilyn Schaja, an economist with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said: "It should be realized that the rise in starts in November merely indicates a stagnant housing sector going forward. The data should not be interpreted as suggesting a great deal of momentum going forward."
She said that housing starts so far during the fourth quarter, even with last month's advance of 9.2 percent, are still 2.7 percent below the average rate of starts seen in the third quarter.
Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said, "Just as the sharp drop in October seemed to be an overstatement of weakness, the surge in housing starts in November is likely an overstatement of strength, and averaging the levels for two months may well be a good approximation of the trend.
"However, housing does appear to be slowing, but at a very gradual rate," he said, "as the fourth-quarter averages for both starts and permits appear to be only slightly lower than the third, which were only moderately below the second."
Concerning the Fed, Mr. Fine predicted that it would "continue to adhere to an unchanged policy stance in an economic environment that is neither overheating nor slowing substantially, and producing little in the way of inflationary pressures."
The Fed's policy-making committee is next scheduled to meet for two days, starting Feb. 4.
The Fed has not adjusted short-term interest rates since Jan. 31, when it lowered the Federal funds rate -- which banks charge one another for overnight loans -- and the discount rate -- which the Fed charges banks -- both by a quarter of a percentage point.
The bond market took satisfaction from the weekly LJR Redbook chain-store sales index covering the first two weeks of December. That report showed sales increased six-tenths of 1 percent, below the rise of eight-tenths of 1 percent or even a full percent the market had expected. Earlier in the day, the weekly Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi/Schroder Wertheim index of chain-store sales showed a gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent for the week ended Dec 14. According to that report, sales were near or at expectations for most retailers.
Elsewhere, dealers and traders prepared for today's $18.25 billion two-year note auction by the Treasury, which will also be selling $12.5 billion of five-year notes tomorrow.
In when-issued trading, the two-year maturity was being offered at a price to yield 5.84 percent and the five-year at a price to yield 6.18 percent.

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Yankees Lost More From Pitching Staff Than They Gained

BYLINE: By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
Pat Gillick, the Baltimore Orioles' general manager, was on the telephone asking about the status of the Yankees' negotiations with David Wells. Told the numbers they were discussing, he said, "I like my contract better than the one they're talking about."
A few hours later, the Yankees and Wells's agent, Greg Clifton, reached agreement on a three-year contract for a guaranteed $13.5 million. 
 If Wells, in each season of the contract, pitches as frequently as he did last season for Gillick's team, that package will inflate to $14.65 million, only $950,000 less than twice the $7.8 million the Orioles gave Jimmy Key for two years.
That's why Gillick liked his contract more. That's why, in retrospect, the Yankees may wish they had given Key the contract Gillick gave him.
Now that they finally have pieced together their pitching puzzle, the Yankees can step back and scrutinize the overall effect of their moves. They have swapped Key and the unbeatable bullpen tandem of John Wetteland and Mariano Rivera for David Wells and the untested bullpen alignment of Rivera and a committee that includes Mike Stanton, the staff's other new pitcher.
The Yankees did not sign Key, who wanted to stay, because they did not want to give him a second year. They did not sign Wetteland, who wanted to stay, because they did not want to spend the kind of money he wanted on each of two pitchers and they preferred giving it to a starter.
They tried to give Roger Clemens $8 million or more a year, but he opted for Canadian money, so they turned around and guaranteed Wells $4.5 million a year.
It's George Steinbrenner's money to spend, but he seemed to lose his sense of direction in his obsession to snare Clemens. He lost sight of his real goal.
The Yankees, in December 1996, are not looking ahead to 1999 and figuring out how to win the pennant that season.
In this era of hit-and-miss baseball, teams cannot live for the distant future unless they are starting from scratch, like the Pittsburgh Pirates have decided to do.
Teams of the caliber of the Yankees and the Orioles can think of the future with their younger players, like Andy Pettitte and Derek Jeter, and make sure they keep their best prospects. But with division championships and pennants so elusive in the era of free agency, their priority first and foremost is to win now. In December 1996, that means 1997.
By signing Wells, the Yankees have not improved their 1996 pitching staff for 1997; they have not added a good veteran starter to their rotation.
By signing Wells, they have simply swapped left-handed starters with the Orioles. Just like the Yankees with Key, the Orioles did not run to re-sign Wells because they did not want to pay his price.
"We have never been in it," Gillick said. "We were out of it when it went past two years.
"Last summer, they told us they'd take $9 million for three years," Gillick added, referring to Wells and his agent. "We said no then. In this day and age, you've got to be flexible. You have to limit your exposure. Three, four-year contracts get you in trouble."
If the Yankees had kept their focus on 1997, they might have found more sense in giving Key a second year than in giving Wells three years.
But after refusing to pay Key's price, the Yankees paid for Wells, and he will cost them far more than the $7 million or $7.5 million Key would have accepted to stay in New York.
He also has cost them Wetteland. If they had given Key the second year at a lower annual salary than they gave Wells for three years, the Yanks wouldn't have faced the conflict of starter versus No. 1 reliever.
When Rivera and Wetteland pitched last season, they took care of one-third of the game, Rivera overwhelming hitters for two innings and Wetteland scaring the Yankees for one inning but getting the final out nevertheless. Rivera preceded Wetteland in 25 of Wetteland's 43 regular-season saves.
Gillick recalled a similar situation he had when he was the Toronto general manager, when the Blue Jays had Duane Ward and Tom Henke.
"Ward pitched to the team's toughest hitters in the seventh and eighth," Gillick said.
"Ward took the spirit out of those guys. When Henke came in, he didn't have as difficult a job. I think that's what happened with Rivera. He breaks the spirit of a team."
Mike Stanton, Jeff Nelson and Graeme Lloyd have never been known for smashing spirits. Yet they will replace Rivera as the setup man to the closer, who will be Rivera. The Yankees sacrificed the unique weapon they had because Rivera comes cheaper than Wetteland. But Key would have been cheaper than Wells.
Evidently, in the face of the double-barreled economic weapon of luxury tax and revenue sharing, Steinbrenner no longer is prepared to win at any cost. That is understandable. But if the Yankees' pitching decisions cost them a chance to repeat, that outcome will be less easily comprehended.

HEADLINE: For Retailers, Weather Is Wild Card in Holiday Sales

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
As the final week of the holiday selling season begins, retailers are finding their sales stuck between mediocre and decent, meaning that these last few days could be crucial to their success.
While many merchants told Wall Street early in the season that they planned to have sales increases of 4 to 9 percent this season, many are reporting weekly sales in the lower end of that range. November, except for the Thanksgiving weekend, was weak. 
 And, because that weekend was later than usual, there were five fewer shopping days this year than in 1995. To top it off, the weather may also be turning against retailers. After a relatively mild start to December, much of the central United States has been hit with harsh weather. Beginning on Monday, cold weather pushed south from Canada, with snow falling in the upper Midwest and as far south as Texas. Forecasters said yesterday that much of the nation east of the Rockies was due for more icy weather and that there would be more snow in parts of the Midwest. Rain has fallen in the Northeast for weeks, and more of it could be on the way.
Last year, bad weather, particularly in the Northeast, contributed to one of the poorest Christmas selling seasons in a decade. "You do not want sleet and ice," said Mark J. Schoifet, the spokesman for the International Council of Shopping Centers. "Because that keeps people out of their cars, and that can be just deadly."
Neither rain nor sleet kept shoppers from their destinations last weekend. Mr. Schoifet's organization reported that for the holiday season so far, sales per square foot in 60 malls nationwide were up 21.5 percent from last year. But he warned that that number was significantly inflated because the period it covered, the first two weeks after Thanksgiving, was much closer to Christmas than the comparable two weeks last year.
"The selling season will end up with about 4 or 5 percent increases over all," Mr. Schoifet said.
Those numbers are fairly consistent with other sales data released this week. Telecheck Services, for example, a Houston-based check acceptance company, reported that the first 17 days of the shopping season resulted in a 5 percent sales gain over 1995. LJR Redbook Research reported that in the week ending on Dec. 14 sales were up 5.7 percent from a year earlier. Melissa Bane, the senior analyst at the Yankee Group, a technology consulting firm, said that holiday sales over the Internet were running at four times the yearly average, compared with three times the average last year.
"Because of the shortened season this year," said William Ford, Telecheck's senior economic adviser, "we are not seeing the typical mid-season lull in holiday spending."
There seems little doubt that apparel will be the big winner this year. The strongest areas appear to be designer sportswear and casual clothing brands like Tommy Hilfiger and Polo by Ralph Lauren. "Fashion designers get a lot of press, but they are not that meaningful out there," said Jay Meltzer, managing director of LJR Redbook Research. "Active wear and casual wear continues to take market share from tailored clothing."
But even apparel stores' numbers are a bit suspect, because many specialty stores are now chock full of candles, bath oils and other personal care products. "The numbers are not as clean as you might think," said John Konarski, vice president of the I.C.S.C. "A lot of stores like Banana Republic are giving more and more square footage to home furnishing and cosmetics and that has to skew the sales numbers."
Analysts said that retailers were putting more goods on sale than they said they would at the beginning of the season, though retailers insisted that what was on sale was part of "planned promotions." That means that the stores went into the season planning to put a few goods on sale to attract traffic, but that price slashing on the scale of last year's is not being done this season.
Still, some retailers said they believed that shoppers were delaying purchases in part in the belief that prices would be cut as Christmas approaches.
"I think consumers are still waiting for Christmas Eve. They like to stick it out and see who blinks," said Coleman Nee, a spokesman for Bradlees, which is operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy-law protection and depending on a good season to restore its creditors' faith.
Low inventory levels may help stores keep from cutting prices too much, but shoppers apparently will still keep sniffing for bargains. "November showed people that consumers are ready and willing to spend money but not at full price," said Melvyn Plotzker, first president of Bank Leumi Trust Company of New York, which has many retail clients.
The Limited stores have had deep promotions since Thanksgiving, as have other mall stores like American Eagle Outfitters and Casual Corner. At Saks Holdings' Saks Fifth Avenue, executives have been boasting about strong cashmere sales for weeks. But there is still plenty of it around on Fifth Avenue, and at slashed prices.
Last year, about 30 retail bankruptcies resulted in rampant promoting and subsequent store closings. Fewer stores and fewer sales in stores that are dying have certainly helped the malls this year. "A few people are in trouble, but nowhere near last year," said James Rice, director of credit at Barnard Sands, the credit consultants. "Last year there were literally thousands of stores being liquidated, so this year it will be easier to keep gross margins."
But there are still too many stores to meet demand, he added. "I think people are getting lulled into a false sense of security because it has been a good year," Mr. Rice said. "But the overstored problem is not solved yet."
But the biggest problem for retailers, in this shortened season, could be unexpectedly bad weather. To try to gauge shopping patterns, one analyst said he was spending less time in mall parking lots and more in front of the television.
"I watch the Weather Channel at least three times a day now," said Walter Loeb, who runs his own retail consulting firm in New York.

HEADLINE: Japan Trade Surplus Rises Unexpectedly

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Japan's merchandise trade surplus rose unexpectedly last month, the Government reported today. It was the first monthly increase in two years.
The Finance Ministry said that the November trade surplus edged up two-tenths of 1 percent, to 675.19 billion yen, or $5.92 billion, as a weaker yen bolstered Japanese exports, especially of cars. 
 The surplus with the United States, often a source of trade friction, surged 31.2 percent in November to 378.39 billion yen, or $3.31 billion, from last year, reflecting the increase in automotive exports.
Last month, Japan's surplus with the United States widened, compared with last year's levels, for the first time in 20 months.
Private economists had forecast a hefty drop of around 28 percent in the overall surplus, continuing the long-standing decline.
"It's quite a surprise," Richard Jerram, an analyst with ING Baring Securities, Tokyo, said. "Certainly, if anything, it shows the trade surplus is going to be turning around earlier than we expected."
A fall in the value of the yen from last year's record highs has steadily put the brakes on the drop in Japan's trade surplus, but economists had not been expecting to see an increase so soon.
A Finance Ministry official said the major reason for the rise in the trade surplus with the United States was a 45.7 percent surge in car exports to the United States. A drop in imports of aircraft also contributing to the increase in the overall surplus. But the official said the general downward trend in the trade surplus would continue.

HEADLINE: The Fed Holds Rates Steady; Housing Gains

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve voted today to leave interest rates unchanged, concluding that inflation remained dormant despite sporadic surges in economic activity.
The Fed's decision had been widely anticipated among economists and in the financial markets. The Fed has not raised or lowered rates since January, and analysts said monetary policy was likely to remain unchanged well into 1997 because the economy had shown few signs of deviating from its course of moderate growth with low inflation, even though unemployment is low and other economic indicators occasionally send warning signals. 
 Indeed, just before the central bank's Federal Open Market Committee began meeting to consider interest rate policy today, the Commerce Department reported that construction of housing jumped sharply higher last month, suggesting that the economic growth could be picking up again in the fourth quarter after cooling down substantially over the summer.
Driven in part by a decline in mortgage rates, housing starts rose 9.2 percent in November, the biggest monthly jump since July 1995, the department said. The increase, which put housing starts at an annual rate of 1.514 million units, wiped out nearly all of a decline in new housing activity recorded in September and October.
Starts were 20.8 percent higher in the Midwest and 12 percent higher in the South, but flat in the West and down 2.2 percent in the Northeast.
The housing report unsettled the bond market, which saw the pickup in construction as possibly presaging inflation. With bond prices falling, the yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.65 percent from 6.62 percent in late trading.
Despite the weakness in the bond market, stocks had a more positive day. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 39.98 points, to 6,308.33.
While economists had discerned nothing in the economic fundamentals to justify a rate increase by the Fed, investors had been keeping a close watch on today's policy meeting anyway because of comments about stock prices made earlier this month by Alan Greenspan, the central bank's chairman.
Mr. Greenspan had questioned whether the steep rise in the stock market was a result of "irrational exuberance." Some analysts had seen the comments by Mr. Greenspan as a warning that he might raise rates, if not immediately then in the long run, to deflate stock prices.
The Fed, as usual, gave no explanation of its decision today. A synopsis of its deliberations will be released after its next monetary policy meeting, which will be held Feb. 4 and 5.
The Fed's last move was to cut rates by a quarter of a percentage point in January, leaving the Federal funds target rate for overnight bank lending at 5.25 percent and the discount rate for short-term Fed loans to banks at 5 percent.
Since then the economy has alternately slowed and accelerated, albeit within a relatively narrow range, leaving both Fed officials and the markets off balance and making the search for clues to incipient inflation that much more difficult.
Although some economists believe the economy will slow enough next year that the Fed will feel compelled to reduce rates again to stimulate more growth, the predominant opinion among Fed watchers is that the next move in interest rates, whenever it comes, will be up.
"While we expect inflation to remain low, the risk of rising inflation far outweighs the risk of deflation," Bruce Steinberg, an economist with Merrill Lynch & Company, said.
The statistics on housing starts were the latest to indicate that the economy was again picking up momentum. On Monday, the Fed said that industrial output in November increased nine-tenths of 1 percent, its sharpest rise in nine months, and that the capacity utilization rate edged up four-tenths of 1 percent, to 83.3 percent. Economists consider an 85 percent capacity utilization rate the point at which factories have trouble keeping up with orders, causing bottlenecks that can set off an upward inflationary spiral.
But analysts said the housing numbers were so strong that they probably represented a brief rebound in construction from a temporary downturn in the previous two months. Another indicator of housing construction, the number of building permits issued, rose a more moderate 3.9 percent in November.
"We don't expect a rise in starts activity at that level again next month," said Paul Taylor, an economist at America's Community Bankers, the trade group for savings and loan institutions.
