HEADLINE: Balancing Quantity, Quality and Inflation;
How Should the Price Index Change When Consumers Pay More but Get More?

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
As heart bypass operations are perfected, more people have them, extending their lives. But the operations raise health care costs. Is this inflation, as the Government's statisticians contend? Or is it simply fair value for the promise of longer, healthier lives, as a blue-ribbon panel of economists argues?
Or consider what happens when people shift from going out to the movies to bringing videos home. Watching "Independence Day" at the neighborhood theater costs, say, $7 a ticket while the video rental is $3.50, no matter how many people crowd around the television. Both prices have held steady for a while. Is that zero inflation, as the Government says? Or should the Consumer Price Index register a price decline for movies as people shift to a different movie experience that is less costly but comparable in quality, as the economists contend? 
 In the suddenly expanding debate over the accuracy of the C.P.I. -- which is used to set everything from Social Security pensions and union wage increases to individual tax brackets -- questions like these are crucial. Indeed, behind the controversy, which was set off when the Congressionally appointed panel of economists recently released its report, lie two fundamentally different ways of looking at the economy.
The blue-ribbon panel, led by Michael A. Boskin, President George Bush's chief economic adviser, concluded that the C.P.I. exaggerates the rate of inflation by slightly more than one percentage point a year. Defenders of the current way of measuring price changes -- a group that includes representatives of the elderly, labor unions and a number of economists as well -- contend that any error is much smaller.
If little were at stake, most people would be happy to leave it to the experts to argue over a few tenths of a percentage point one way or another. But much is at stake -- each tenth adds or subtracts billions of dollars in Government payments now pegged to the C.P.I. -- and so a struggle has developed for control of the Consumer Price Index.
Today, health care and movies are among the thousands of items purchased by Americans that are cranked into the calculation of America's standard inflation gauge. The C.P.I. essentially measures changes in the prices of a relatively static market basket of goods and services.
But if the measure of inflation is redefined to put more emphasis on what it takes to maintain a given standard of living, then subjective value judgments must play a much bigger role. Higher costs for open-heart surgery, instead of registering as inflation, might instead be counted as a qualitative improvement in the chances of living a better life.
Video rental and theater tickets are listed separately in the C.P.I. But with VCR's in so many homes now, a video today might be judged a reasonably satisfying alternative to a night at the movies. Shouldn't that be reflected somehow as a lower cost to purchase the same living standard?
So the debate intensifies, and as it does, very different views emerge on measuring human well-being.
"I don't think we know how to construct a cost-of-living index that would deal with all of the issues about quality of life to everyone's satisfaction," said Katherine Abraham, Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The bureau, an independent agency within the Labor Department, is the keeper of the Consumer Price Index, calculating each month the price changes for a market basket of 71,000 items. But now the bureau is under pressure from the commission of five economists, appointed by the Senate Finance Committee, to recast the index so that the C.P.I. does more to quantify the values that people attach to what they buy.
"Such values are not chiseled in stone," said Zvi Griliches, a Harvard economist and a commission member. "They are squishy numbers, but they are better than a firm but wrong zero."
Adopting the commission's outlook would change the economic picture drawn by the Consumer Price Index, making American living standards look more solid. The C.P.I. is currently rising at an annual rate of 3.2 percent, but if the panel's estimates are accurate, the annual rate is really closer to 2.1 percent.
The report is already serving as a catalyst for action. With commission members setting the pace, discussions are under way among economists across the country in an attempt to develop a consensus behind reducing the growth rate of the C.P.I. by late next year. Rather than count on the Bureau of Labor Statistics to adjust its numbers, there is a move afoot, pushed by the Clinton Administration, for Congress to act.
"The bureau is a very important expert in this process," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said, "but there are a lot of other experts as well. Congress, in acting, would have to reflect a broad-based agreement among these experts about changes in the C.P.I. that would cause it to better reflect inflation."
If such a consensus emerges, the Administration might back a bill that would leave the C.P.I. unchanged, but -- for purposes of determining Federal benefits and tax brackets -- would subtract four- or five-tenths of a percentage point from each published index figure. The billions of dollars saved would reduce the budget deficit, a goal of both major political parties.
But complicated value judgments must be incorporated into the Consumer Price Index to slice off that initial fraction. Mr. Boskin, now a Stanford professor, argues that the bureau could reach the goal "in the time frame of a year," by "expanding, improving and accelerating" studies it already has under way.
Ms. Abraham is not so sanguine. Although she accepts many of the commission's proposals in principle, she insists on moving cautiously. "There are a lot of issues associated with the measurement of the cost of living that I don't think we will solve in my lifetime," said Ms. Abraham, who is 42.
Her bureau is constantly studying changes, she says, that might make the C.P.I. more of a measure of the cost of maintaining one's standard of living. Changes adopted in the last two years have already reduced the level of the C.P.I. by 0.22 percentage point, she notes. And the bureau is considering others that the Boskin commission would applaud.
The huge market basket of goods on which the C.P.I. is based is to be updated more frequently to reflect shifts in the purchases that Americans actually make. And new products are to be added more quickly. The cell phone is one. It is still not calculated in the national index, although its falling price might dampen the inflation rate. "That was a mistake, not introducing cell phones sooner," Ms. Abraham said.
Still, in other ways, she and her lieutenants are digging in their heels. Shifting the C.P.I. to a standard-of-living index is not the goal, they say, accuracy is, and that rules out what some officials describe as "hip pocket guesswork" in trying to quantify how people value the goods and services they buy.
How, for example, do they feel about renting videos instead of going to the movies? Mr. Griliches, the Harvard economist, acknowledges that the two experiences are not interchangeable for everyone, but they are for enough people to drive down the price of maintaining this particular pleasure.
"I would not argue that the cost fell from the $7 ticket price to the $3.50 movie rental," Mr. Griliches said, "but it wasn't zero either. We are trying to make an estimate and this is where it goes ad hoc. I would try to base it on how many people shifted from one to the other. Or I would do a crude approximation and say half the difference in price is a real decline in the cost of experiences that are similar in quality."
But Patrick Jackman, chief of the division at the bureau that calculates each month's C.P.I., is not swayed. "You can get off cheaper by viewing the movie at home," he said, "but you may not get the same pleasure of an evening out away from the kids in a movie house, which can be a communal experience."
The commission and the bureau differ, too, over Zantac, the heartburn medicine. It is rapidly replacing Tagamet, which many doctors consider less effective. The bureau attributes the higher cost, about 60 cents a pill, to higher quality, not inflation. But the commission would go further, counting it as a price decline on the ground that the quality improvement exceeds the price increase.
Similarly, the bureau undervalues quality improvements in autos, says Robert Gordon, a Northwestern University economist who was also on the Boskin commission. Too many of the price increases in autos have been attributed to inflation, he says, rather than taking into account that cars are more durable and require less maintenance.
The classic example in this debate is meat versus chicken. Meat prices rise, so people shift to less expensive but nutritionally equal chicken. The C.P.I. registers an increase in inflation, because of the higher meat prices. But the panel calls this a decline in inflation: less cost to maintain the same standard of living. "The Consumer Price Index pretends that people are not free to shift to chicken when that is cheaper, or sweatshirts when sport shirts are too expensive," Mr. Gordon said.
But in judging these shifts, isn't the Boskin commission being too optimistic, often failing to recognize deteriorations in the quality of American life, too? That is the view of Dean Baker, an economist at the Economic Policy Institute. "If people perceive they are making a switch in response to a rising price," he said, "they can perceive a loss in the quality of their lives that may not be fully picked up by the Boskin commission's recommended price index."
That complicates the puzzle, and the commission recognizes this. To quantify the most difficult value judgments -- representing roughly six-tenths of a percentage point of the 1.1 points that the commission would shave off the C.P.I. -- the panel would establish a separate, parallel index. The second index would deal with such things as crime-fighting, where value judgments require measurements over a period of time.
"If I install a better alarm system," Mr. Griliches said, "that is an improvement in the quality of my life, and therefore a decline in inflation. But if the burglars learn how to trick this alarm system, that is a rise in price, because the quality advantage will be eroded. So one of the issues is that this whole notion of quality, of standard of living, is not a constant."
Such complexities give Ms. Abraham pause. But the panel contends that properly handled, they can be incorporated relatively soon, by means of the second index.
This parallel index would be adjusted, up or down, in hindsight over a one- or two-year period, to deepen understanding of living standards and the economy. The regular C.P.I., tracking each month's changes, cannot be adjusted; too many payments are tied to it.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 3; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1133 words

HEADLINE: AS TORCH PASSES, U.N. CHIEF SCOLDS U.S. FOR ARREARS

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 17

 BODY:
 Minutes before the General Assembly appointed his successor, Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali used a reflective farewell speech today to scold the United States for failing in its obligations to the United Nations.
In an oblique but unmistakable swipe at the country that vetoed his reappointment, faulting him for failing to reform the United Nations bureaucracy, Mr. Boutros-Ghali said the United Nations lacked the resources to do its job. 
 "It is not the result of mismanagement," he said. "It is the refusal to fulfill a treaty obligation." He was referring to the array of debts to the United Nations, with the largest unpaid balance being that of the United States.
The General Assembly hailed the outgoing leader with a standing ovation, then formally appointed Kofi Annan of the West African country of Ghana as his successor.
Mr. Annan, who will become the seventh Secretary General on Jan. 1, is the first person from sub-Saharan Africa to hold the job and the first career United Nations official to rise through the ranks to the highest office.
In a characteristic speech after his swearing-in, Mr. Annan, 58, dwelt on human themes, referring to economic development issues as affecting "real people with basic needs: food, clothing, shelter and medical care." [Excerpts from speeches, page A8.]
In contrast to the intellectual, analytical remarks of Mr. Boutros-Ghali, Mr. Annan said:
"I intend to stress not only our legal obligations, not only our fiscal limitations, not only our political and diplomatic considerations, but above all, the moral dimension of our work in this organization. In that spirit, let us embark on a time of healing: a healing of fractures and frictions between member states and this organization, which cannot function without their political and material support; and a healing of wounded morale and ideals within the Secretariat, whose dedicated staff deserve our thanks and encouragement."
"Alone I can do nothing," he concluded, after a brief address in English and some French, imploring a badly buffeted United Nations staff and quarreling member nations to get on the same team.
On Thursday, Mr. Annan plans to go home to Ghana for a brief celebratory visit. His 88-year-old mother, Victoria, lives in Accra, the Ghanaian capital. His late father, Henry, a businessman from a prominent family, served as regional Governor of Ashanti Province.
Mr. Annan, who began his education in Africa, has two American degrees, a bachelor's in economics from Macalester College in St. Paul, Minn., and a master's in management from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
Daniel Abibi, the Congo's representative, spoke for all of the African countries in welcoming Mr. Annan.
"It is night in Africa," he said, "but from Algiers to Cape Town, from Praia to Mombasa, numerous are the Africans of all generations who follow with passion the unfolding of this event at the United Nations in New York. Since Friday, the great news has traversed our deserts, our savannas, our forests. This is a great day for the sons of Africa."
Mr. Boutros-Ghali, 74, an Egyptian diplomat and scholar, recalled in his speech how he had come to office in 1992 amid ambitious plans for a United Nations freed for the first time from the political shackles of the cold war, and how setbacks soon occurred and disillusion set in.
He chided member countries for their failure to deal with the massacres in Rwanda because they had become gun-shy after a bad experience in Somalia and for their refusal to make hard choices and allocate adequate resources for effective action in Bosnia.
In conversations, Mr. Boutros-Ghali shows deep bitterness and frustration at having gone to the Security Council time and time again to ask for a tougher response to fighting in Bosnia, only to be outmaneuvered by minimalist resolutions dictated by Washington, Paris and London, whose Governments and news organizations then blamed him for a failure to keep the peace and save lives.
For example, he requested more than 35,000 troops to protect the Security Council's safe havens in Srebrenica and other cities. He got fewer than 8,000. "The concept of peacekeeping was turned on its head, and worsened by the serious gap between mandates and resources," he said in his speech today.
Clearly addressing the United States, he turned to the organization's financial crisis, saying: "We know what causes it and what is needed to end it. It is not the result of mismanagement. It is the refusal to fulfill a treaty obligation. Now that a new Secretary General is being appointed, all arrears should be paid at once, as has been promised so often in the past few months."
The Clinton Administration, in deciding to veto a second term for Mr. Boutros-Ghali, has said that only with a new leader will there be any hope of getting Congress to pay an overdue debt of about $1.3 billion, more than half of the total bill that the United Nations is owned in regular budget payments and peacekeeping assessments.
Mr. Boutros-Ghali also had pointed words about reform, saying it would occur within the United Nations system only when member governments were able to agree on what they wanted. Finally, he warned of pressures on the Secretary General by powerful nations, not naming the United States, but describing the situation in a way that left no doubt which country he had in mind.
"If one word above all is to characterize the role of the Secretary General, it is independence," he said. "The holder of this office must never be seen as acting out of fear or in an attempt to curry favor with one state or group of states. Should that happen, all prospects for the United Nations would be lost."
Before the day was over, Mr. Annan had announced a transition team to take over from Mr. Boutros-Ghali's cabinet. Most of the faces are familiar, drawn from Mr. Annan's close-knit colleagues in the peacekeeping department, where he served as Under Secretary General.
The team will be headed by Iqbal Riza, a Pakistani who is now the United Nations representative in Bosnia. Gillian Martin Sorensen, who was Mr. Boutros-Ghali's public affairs consultant during the 50th anniversary year, and Fred Eckhard, a spokesman for peacekeeping operations, will handle public relations.
On Monday, Sylvana Foa, whom Mr. Boutros-Ghali appointed spokesman for the United Nations last year, said she would leave at the end of this month.
Javier Perez de Cuellar of Peru was present at today's Assembly sesssion, seated next to Mr. Boutros-Ghali's wife, Leia. Kurt Waldheim of Austria, the other living former Secretary General, has been barred from the United States because of documents linking him to war crimes during his service in the German Army during World War II.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Up 39.98 Points As I.B.M. Rises
Stocks rose as the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged. I.B.M. climbed sharply, recouping some of its losses from a selloff in computer-related shares that began last week and giving impetus to the Dow industrials, which finished up 39.98 points, at 6,308.33.
Though the broader market did not do as well as the blue chips -- declining issues led advancers on the New York Stock Exchange -- the Nasdaq composite managed to rise 5.34 points, closing at 1,266.32. [Page D8.]
 
The Frontier Corporation, stung by the loss of a big wholesale customer, warned analysts that its long-distance telephone revenue would be well below analysts' expectations. Its shares tumbled 21 percent in heavy trading. [D5.]
 
The prices of Treasury securities fell following a November housing report that was stronger than expected. The 30-year bond yield rose to 6.65 percent from 6.62 percent. [D18.]
 
Conrail Shareholder Vote Ordered
A judge ordered Conrail to let shareholders vote on a crucial aspect of its $8.5 billion deal to merge with CSX. A group of investors questioned the merger's fairness. [D2.]
 
Deadline Near in Prudential Case
The last opportunity for policyholders of Prudential Insurance to battle the company on their own over whether they were cheated by agents is this week. A lawyer said that by last week, about 9,000 policyholders had declared that they were opting out of a class-action settlement, not nearly enough for the company to withdraw from the settlement. [D4.]
 
LVMH Proceeding With DFS Deal
LVMH Moet-Hennessy Louis Vuitton, one of the world's leading purveyors of high-priced perfume, liquor and other luxury goods, won the go-ahead for its $2.47 billion deal for a controlling interest in the DFS Group, a chain of duty-free shops that sells its wares. [D2.]
 
American Home Products in Deal
American Home Products said that it was exercising an option to buy 40 percent of Genetics Institute that it does not already own for about $1 billion. Last week an F.D.A. panel recommended approval of Genetics' blood clotting treatment for hemophilia B. [D4.]
 
Goldman, Sachs Profits Surge
Goldman, Sachs said that its pretax earnings rose 69 percent in the fiscal fourth quarter, to $743 million. Thanks to a boom in underwritings and mergers, Wall Street is on track for record profits this year. [D2.]
 
With the lean times apparently over for now, employees on Wall Street are not just busy making deals. They are partying, too. The champagne is flowing at rates not seen since the 80's, and the current wave of consumption is no less lavish. But it is intricately choreographed to seem less conspicuous. [B1.]
 
F.T.C. Clears Ciba-Sandoz Merger
The F.T.C. removed the last hurdle to the merger of Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz, after winning an agreement intended to insure competition in the development of gene therapy treatments. The companies also agreed to sell two businesses. [D7.]
 
2d Flu Shot Urged for Some
Because 5.8 million of the 75 million doses of flu vaccine produced this season were not full strength, Federal health officials advised doctors to consider giving another shot to some people. The vaccine with some weakened doses was Fluogen, made by Warner Lambert's Parke-Davis division. [A18.]

Going Public in a New Tokyo Market
ATL Systems, a five-year-old Japanese software company that lost $230,000 on sales of $120,000 last year, went public in Tokyo, where its shares closed up 51 percent. It is the first company to use a new over-the-counter market for developing technology companies that want to go public. Market Place. [D8.]
 
The 240Z, New for '97
Nissan has been buying up 240Z sports cars from the early 1970's, intending to sell them after they have been restored. Though the cars will lack amenities like air bags and cup holders, one thing about them will be updated for the 90's -- the price. Advertising. [D6.]

HEADLINE: Clinton Made Political Appointments to Panel

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
President Clinton expanded an advisory panel on trade with Pacific nations earlier this year so that it could include several political appointees, including an Arkansas businessman who several months later orchestrated more than $639,000 in questionable donations to the President's legal defense fund.
The name of the businessman, Charles Yah Lin Trie, was a last-minute addition to the list of commission members assembled by the White House last November. Four months later, Mr. Trie, who runs a small trading company called Daihatsu International, delivered the first batch of checks and money orders at the office of the Washington lawyer who directs the legal trust fund. Lawyers for the fund said the money raised by Mr. Trie has been returned because of questions about its origin. 
 When the White House office of personnel issued its final list of the committee's members and distributed it inside the Administration on Nov. 27, 1995, Mr. Trie's name appeared with the boldface notation: "Supported by White House. Democrat-Ar." Several people familiar with the compilation of the list, which took place over months, said Mr. Trie's name appeared for the first time just a few weeks before the final list was settled upon.
"This just showed up from the White House," one official involved in the process said today. "We had no idea who this guy was."
Soon after Mr. Trie's name was included on the internal list, several officials noticed that the White House had exceeded the limit of 15 members who could be appointed to the Commission on United States-Pacific Trade and Investment Policy. So on Jan. 31, President Clinton signed Executive Order 12987, a one-paragraph declaration that increased the size of the commission to "up to 20" members.
Mr. Trie has not been a very active member of the commission, which is preparing to issue its final report.
Another committee member, Ron Sims, now the county executive of King County, Wash., which includes Seattle, recalled today that he had seen Mr. Trie "once or twice" since the committee began actively meeting at mid-year.
Mr. Trie did not say much at those meetings, other members said, and his attendance has fallen off sharply in recent months.
The commission was created by Senator Jeff Bingaman, a New Mexico Democrat with a long interest in the United States' challenges in trading with Asia. Mr. Bingaman included language authorizing the commission in the bills that approved the worldwide trade accord that created the World Trade Organization.
But it took most of last year for the White House to organize the commission, and the appointment of the chairman, Kenneth Brody, a former head of the Export-Import Bank of the United States, was not announced until April 1996. The panel is charged with reporting to Mr. Clinton on steps the United States could take to "achieve a significant opening of Japan, China and other Asian and Pacific markets to U.S. business."
"I can't shed any light on the essential question of how the members were appointed," Mr. Bingaman said today from Santa Fe, N.M. "We made recommendations about who the members should be. I was happy that some we recommended were chosen. But I did not know some of the members, including Mr. Trie."
The commission is a curious mixture of academics, business executives and former officials with considerable knowledge of Asia and its markets, and some who appear to have only a cursory familiarity with those issues. Several officials involved in the group's creation expressed frustration over the last few months that the White House had included several political appointees in place of academics and others.
But commission members say dissatisfaction with an early draft of the final report has now been largely resolved.
The internal White House list, for example, includes the appointment of Jason Berman, the chairman of the Recording Industry Association and an active Democrat, with the notation "replaced Chalmers Johnson." Professor Johnson is the author of one of the leading studies of Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry, but has also been highly critical of the Administration's trade policy.
Other commission members include Morton Bahr, the president of the Communication Workers of America, and Jack Tai, the former manager of J. P. Morgan Asia. The vice chairman is Clyde Prestowitz of the Economic Strategy Institute, who served in the Commerce Department in the Reagan Administration.
Some officials suggested today that Mr. Trie might have hoped that his title as a member of a Presidential advisory commission could aid his status in Asia, where he has been trying to close several business deals.

HEADLINE: An Underdog Victor Savors the Limelight

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 17

 BODY:
Wherever she goes now, from a shopping mall in California to an orientation for Congressional freshmen at Harvard, Representative-elect Loretta Sanchez encounters strangers who suddenly declare, "Thank you!" as if she had stamped out a social disorder.
What she actually did was score the most unexpected upset in the recent Congressional elections. As an absolute political unknown, she defeated Representative Robert K. Dornan, the aggressive California Republican known for his attacks on President Clinton, homosexuals and lesbians, and assorted other targets of his bare-knuckle commentary. 
 "Absolutely everywhere -- at the airport, in D.C. when I'm meeting legislators, back home at the mall -- they keep coming up, saying things like, 'Just thank you for what you did,' " Ms. Sanchez said.
The 36-year-old financial management consultant smiled as she tried to adjust to her sudden place in Washington political lore as Nemesis of the Mouth of the House: the silencer of the lawmaker who called the President "a sleazeball who can't keep his pants on," of the merciless orator who once outed a gay colleague on the House floor by berating him as having "a revolving door on his closet."
"Beating Bob Dornan has caught the attention of the people," Ms. Sanchez said with obvious satisfaction, having survived her own barrage of Dornan denunciation as a champion of homosexuals, a carpetbagger in her hometown and a "Catholic for abortion and sodomy rights."
She is a daughter of Mexican immigrants, a fiscally conservative Democrat who switched parties four years ago when, she said, she sensed anti-immigrant, anti-woman strategems emerging among Republicans. Even so, her door-to-door campaign against Mr. Dornan emphasized jobs and education more than his signature issues of opposition to abortion and homosexual rights.
Not that Mr. Dornan concedes he has been beaten.
The nine-term Congressman who garrulously ran for two offices this year, the Presidency and Congress, continues to deny Ms. Sanchez's 1,002-vote victory margin. With a recount strategy and a new round of fund-raising advertisements, he is accusing the opposition of having used illegal aliens to pack ballot boxes in the heavily Hispanic district. His cry of fraud includes assertions that pro-Sandinista communist interlopers organized motivation "troops" to prod Sanchez voters forth in low-turnout areas.
"Despite what the liberal media is telling you, Dornan has not lost yet," Mr. Dornan, an accomplished broadcaster who fills in for Rush Limbaugh, declared in one recent advertisement seeking a fresh infusion of contributions.
Thus Ms. Sanchez, while eager to get established here as the new, less confrontational voice of her constituents, has had to start raising more money to defend her victory even before she can savor it fully.
"He can raise as much as he wants, with no limits, no disclosure," she said, a newcomer sounding startled by the fund-raising laws of politics. "I have to hire lawyers and monitors to watch him."
Perhaps the crucial fact according to all the territorial laws of politics is that the Republican leadership is not keeping an office vacant for Mr. Dornan pending his challenge. In his lingering appetite for combat, Mr. Dornan is asserting in an advertisement that Ms. Sanchez's husband, Stephen S. Brixey 3d, "was arrested for destroying dozens of Bob Dornan's campaign posters."
Actually, the Congresswoman-elect said, her husband, a securities trader, was subjected to an unusual "citizen's arrest" by one of Mr. Dornan's grown sons who, she said, had been following him as he put up pro-Sanchez posters.
The contest's forced postscript only makes victory sweeter for the Sanchez campaign. Party professionals are reappraising the Hispanic businesswoman who came from nowhere to wrest the nomination from her own party machine by defeating two better-known, better-financed candidates in a primary in the blue-collar, suburban 46th Congressional District of Southern California.
"We recognized Dornan was vulnerable as an ineffective Congressman and not just as a crazy yahoo spewing right-wing extremism," said John Shallman, the 32-year-old director of the Sanchez campaign.
"The only thing better than beating Bob Dornan once is beating him a second time," Mr. Shallman added, contending that the recount campaign was mainly Mr. Dornan's effort to "maintain a public platform."
Ms. Sanchez is intent on rapidly reducing the Dornan legend to a memory, not extending his reputation for conflict.
"I went out every day door to door to beat this guy, discussing issues that unite people, not divide them," she said, citing district concerns about employment, education and crime as well as Mr. Dornan's votes against gun controls and a raise in the minimum wage. "I found people worrying about putting food on the table and whether their children are learning in school and will have a better future. Abortion, gay rights -- that really doesn't impact them on a day-to-day basis."
She ran as a hometown professional, one of seven children put through college by immigrant parents.
"I am a Head Start child," she emphasized, delighted now to have been appointed to the House committee on economic and educational opportunities.
As a candidate, she used her insurgent's status to stress her lack of "big money" support, although Mr. Dornan's attacks on homosexuals eventually sparked a fund-raising event sponsored by two lovers of incumbent Congressmen he had attacked. This led to a "gay caballeros" photo being brandished by anti-Sanchez supporters, with no evident effect among voters.
"What's relevant is that being virulently anti-gay didn't stop Dornan from losing," said Representative Barney Frank, a homosexual Massachusetts Democrat often attacked by Mr. Dornan and glad to bid good riddance to him from the Capitol.
In victory, Ms. Sanchez now finds she is a "sort of curiosity for the nation," particularly in doing what so many white male candidates had not been able to.
"But the news stories tend to say I won because I'm Latina or because Bob Dornan was extreme -- not because I was strategic or smart," she said, sensing that the upset will only cause fresh impetus to prove herself.
"I'm respected in my industry; I put together business deals for a living," emphasized the freshman, who sought public office only one other time, for a seat on the Anaheim City Council in 1994, and lost.
In that campaign, she ran under her married name, Loretta Sanchez Brixey, but not this time in the district that is one-third Hispanic.
"Dornan called me an Hispanic pretender," she said. "But this time people realized it was me, Loretta Sanchez, who lived there 30 years."
Ms. Sanchez is vowing to commute cross-country to her district every weekend.
"I ran to better my hometown," she said. "I didn't run to be the woman who beat Bob Dornan. I ran for love, not hate."

HEADLINE: Society, Not Science, Owns the Worry Gene

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "What, Me Not Worry?" (Op-Ed, Dec. 13), Adam Phillips calls genetics a "Supreme Fiction" and compares it to Marxist economics and Freudian psychology. Mr. Phillips concludes, after noting that a recent scientific report suggested that genetic makeup might affect one's tendency to worry: "If we can lop off the worry gene, what else might go with it? People without worries are people without self-doubt. And we know what people are capable of in states of ultimate conviction."
Mr. Phillips is confusing the pursuit of science with its application. The goal of science is to seek knowledge. It is the role of society to determine how that knowledge is applied. The "worry gene" is used by Mr. Phillips as a straw man to argue against scientific discovery. 
 We know of no scientist advocating genetic manipulation to insure a worry-free population. In fact, scientists themselves worry considerably, sometimes to great effect. Furthermore, Mr. Phillips's concept of a "worry gene" is highly misleading: even if genes can affect worry, such a finding would not imply that worry is determined simply by genes.
The answer to Mr. Phillips' worry is simple: It is the job of scientists to help us understand our world, and ourselves; it is the job of all of us to insure appropriate application of this knowledge.
 
H. ROBERT HORVITZ
Bethesda, Md., Dec. 16, 1996
 
The writer is former president of the Genetics Society of America and a professor of biology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

HEADLINE: Bacall Still Walks and, Especially, Talks

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 18

 BODY:
She's 72, still glamorous and feisty, and looking for work.
"Suddenly I've finished three pictures, can you imagine?" said Lauren Bacall with a soft laugh. "But now I'm unemployed. I mean, I've had a lot of dry years. So these pictures will, I hope, bring attention to the fact that I am around, breathing, walking and talking at the same time." 
 She shrugged. "Whoever said it would be easy?"
Ms. Bacall lives in Manhattan but was visiting Los Angeles to promote her movies. One of them is "A Mirror Has Two Faces," in which she plays the vain and haughty mother of Barbra Streisand, who also directed. "I didn't always agree with her, but she's a good director, she helped me, and that's what a director is supposed to do," said Ms. Bacall.
She is in "My Fellow Americans," a comedy about two ex-Presidents, played by Jack Lemmon and James Garner, which opens tomorrow. "Frankly, I don't have much of a part in that, but I play Jack's wife, which is the reason I wanted to do it," she said. Then there is a French film, "Le Jour et Le Nuit," scheduled for release early in 1997.
"I'm a mystery woman in that one," she said, rolling her eyes.
Seated in a room at the Bel Air Hotel, less than a mile from the house in which she lived for years with Humphrey Bogart, Ms. Bacall talked about her career and life with the kind of candor that one somehow expects of an actress whose earliest role, in "To Have and Have Not" in 1944, stamped her image of sultriness and tough sophistication.
"I've managed O.K.," said Ms. Bacall, sipping a cup of tea. "I have no beefs. I've been lucky."
She has always been blunt. "I was brought up that way, except when I didn't tell Howard Hawks I was Jewish, because he was anti-Semitic and scared the hell out of me," said Ms. Bacall, referring to the director who discovered her. "He made me so nervous so I didn't say anything. I was cowardly, I must say. I was not proud of myself."
Ms. Bacall said she did not see herself as especially confident ("I've been scared all my life") or beautiful. "People think I'm a woman in control, or that I'm this glamorous creature that can only be cast in parts that are glamorous or grand or chic or whatever," she said. "It's not where my head is at all. I've never been crazy about my looks. I mean, I look the way I look, and there's not a hell of a lot I can do about that."
Ms. Bacall does not view her film career as especially successful, either. At 19 she was on the cover of Harper's Bazaar. At 20 she starred with Bogart in "To Have and Have Not." Shortly after that, they were married.
"I've had a lousy career in many ways," she said. "Very sparse, very up and down, in and out. I've had a lot of years when nobody offered me anything. But because I have a tremendous will, I've been able to continue."
In "To Have and Have Not" her smoky voice and beauty made her a star. "It was out of all proportion to any reality," she said. "I was this brilliant, wonderful, funny, sexy genius. Can you imagine? And then Jack Warner, who was not a creative genius, made me do this second movie called 'Confidential Agent,' in which I was cast as an English girl. Directed by Herman Shumlin, who was no help. It was the worst movie, a nightmare, and I was terrible in it. And as quickly as I had been placed on a pedestal, I fell off. My career was all but over. It took me years to kind of claw my way back again."
Had she not married Bogart, Ms. Bacall said, her career would probably have flourished. Not that she regretted the marriage. "I would not have had a better life, but a better career," she said.
"Howard Hawks was like a Svengali, he was molding me the way he wanted. I was his creation, and I would have had a great career had he been in control of it. But the minute Bogey was around, Hawks knew he couldn't control me, so he sold my contract to Warner Brothers. And that was the end. Hawks wanted to control me, and I think he may have had other things in mind, too. He thought I was a cute little thing." She laughed.
Bogart died of cancer in 1957, and she moved to New York the following year. "I had no life here," she said of Los Angeles. "To be a woman alone in this town is not a happy situation. It was an unnurturing atmosphere out here. My career was not thriving. I was just dismissed. I had my mother and relatives in New York, and I needed them."
Ms. Bacall won two Tony awards for her Broadway musical performances in "Applause" and "Woman of the Year." She also starred on Broadway in "Cactus Flower" and "Goodbye Charlie," and has appeared in London and Australia in "Sweet Bird of Youth." She has written two books, "Lauren Bacall by Myself" (Ballantine) a 1979 autobiography that won a National Book Award, and "Now" (Alfred A. Knopf, 1994), a memoir of her later life. Recently, she has earned money lecturing to women's groups and appearing in television commercials for Carnival Cruise Lines.
After moving to New York, Ms. Bacall married and divorced the actor Jason Robards Jr. She has three children: Steven Bogart, a television producer; Leslie Bogart, a yoga teacher, and Sam Robards, an actor.
Ms. Bacall said she hoped that her current spate of film roles would lead to more parts. But she seemed to have few illusions about acting or jobs or just about anything else.
"If they don't know me by now, or don't want to use me, I mean, forget it," she said with a shrug. "You just learn to cope with whatever you have to cope with. I spent my childhood in New York, riding on subways and buses. And you know what you learn if you're a New Yorker? The world doesn't owe you a damn thing."

GRAPHIC: Photo: After some lean years, Lauren Bacall recently made three films. She's ready for more. (Nathaniel Welch for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Politicized trade law: helping companies avoid market forces.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
IF free market economists wrote their own fair trade law from scratch, the little known Antidumping Act of 1916 would not be a bad model. The law, which is still on the books, provides antitrust protection against predatory pricing by foreigners, sanctioning importers who sell at low prices in America with the intent of putting American competitors out of business.
But free market types are hardly applauding a lawsuit brought by Geneva Steel of Utah contending that two importers of steel from Russia, China and Ukraine are violating the 1916 law. The still-murky tale, as first told in The Rushford Report, a newsletter on international trade published in Washington, makes all too clear that in the highly politicized world of trade, the game is to use the law to circumvent market forces -- not reinforce them. "The 1916 act could prove to be a great way to beat competitors into submission," cautions Ron Cass, a former member of the United States International Trade Commission who is now dean of Boston University's School of Law. 
 When Ford and General Motors duel for sales, virtually anything goes. But the Tariff Act of 1930 (updated numerous times since) sets a different standard for, say, Toyota or Volkswagen. Foreigners are not permitted to sell below cost in the American market, an act defined as "dumping." And with the Commerce Department acting as judge and jury in antidumping cases, domestic producers can count on a friend in high places. The department has used creative accounting to assess huge penalties against everything from Colombian roses to Chinese honey to bomb-grade Russian uranium.
By contrast, the 1916 act is a model of equal justice. Federal courts, not the flag wavers at the Commerce Department, administer it. And to win a case, notes Patrick McCrory, a trade lawyer in Washington, a plaintiff "must prove an intention of seriously injuring or destroying a U.S. industry" -- a standard so tough that it has never been met.
In 1983, the last time anyone tried, Zenith's case against Matsushita and other Japanese television makers was tossed out by the Supreme Court. The Court, in effect, demanded that Zenith offer a plausible explanation how the Japanese would be able to recoup their losses from low-ball pricing, once they drove Zenith into bankruptcy. Since plenty of other producers were likely to enter the television market if prices went up, the Court decided that predation was a nonstarter.
Geneva Steel, a 1987 spinoff from USX that has been losing money despite heavy investments in modernization, is following the tried-and-true antidumping route. The company is asking the Commerce Department to penalize steel from the offending exporters with tariffs ranging from 33 to 274 percent of the selling price. But it has piqued the curiosity of trade and antitrust specialists by also invoking the 1916 act against the two companies -- Ranger Steel Supply and Thyssen Steel -- that actually imported the metal.
Geneva's prospects of winning are apparently small. "It's absurd to imagine they can prove predatory intent," when dozens of producers, domestic and foreign, are ready to fill the market niche left by Geneva, argues Alfred E. Kahn, a former adviser to President Jimmy Carter on economic regulation. Lawrence White, an economist at New York University's Stern School of Business, is even less diplomatic: "It's Loony Tunes," he concludes.
What, then, is going on here? One plausible motive is intimidation. If the case gets as far as a jury in Geneva's home state of Utah, anything is possible -- including a verdict that costs the defendants $100 million or more. Indeed, while Ranger's lawyer, Butch Armsteadt of O'Melvany & Meyers, insists Ranger has no intention of yielding, he concedes that his client is "betting the company" in contesting rather than settling the case.
Nicholas Tolerico, executive vice president at Thyssen (a German company with much deeper pockets than Ranger), has a different theory. He speculates that Geneva is hoping the courts will lower the standard of proof of intent, making it unnecessary for plaintiffs to show how importers could eventually recoup their losses from predatory pricing. Should Geneva fail in court, he expects the company to ask Congress to make the 1916 act more user-friendly. After all, the argument goes, if the law does not shield American producers from foreign competition, it must not be working.
The real story here is how the antidumping laws have evolved from an extension of antitrust to a politicized weapon of special interests. The change is easy to understand: no longer protected by heavy tariffs or America's unchallenged technological dominance, domestic producers have looked for subtler barriers to imports. But the fact that consumers' interests in low prices have so little weight in the political equation is not easily forgivable.

HEADLINE: Boys Choir Is Scrambling, Again

BYLINE: By IRA ROSENBLUM 

 BODY:
It has sung before presidents and diplomats, at the United Nations, the Statue of Liberty and the 1992 World's Fair in Spain. Despite its high profile, however, the 28-year-old Boys Choir of Harlem has frequently had to scramble for money, and now, according to its director, faces a financial crisis that threatens to drastically diminish its voice.
Walter J. Turnbull, the choir's founder and director, said that if the organization did not raise half a million dollars to cover a shortfall in its budget, many of the tutoring and counseling programs offered at its school, the Choir Academy of Harlem, would be jeopardized. 
 "People don't realize that we are about much more than singing," Mr. Turnbull said in an interview at the school on East 127th Street last week. "What we're really doing is trying to save lives."
Most people think of the Boys Choir of Harlem as the 40 who make up the performing choir, he said, the one that is appearing Saturday at 3 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall with members of the New York Philharmonic. In fact, the performing group, which gives some 120 concerts a year around the world, is one of seven training and concert choirs which are part of the daily curriculum for the 563 pupils -- boys and girls -- who study at the academy. Seventy-five percent of them come from single-parent households headed by women, many with incomes below poverty level. Some have parents with drug or alcohol problems. Mr. Turnbull said the tutoring and counseling services helped keep the students in class and off the streets.
The choir will continue to perform, he said. But without adequate counseling programs, its quality will be compromised, he added, since it will be harder to keep students interested in staying in school.
Though this is not the first time the choir has had financial problems, Mr. Turnbull said, the outlook had never seemed so grim. He cited cutbacks in state financing, cancellation of a French tour and a general ebb in corporate and foundation donations. Adding to the predicament, he said, "we have no endowment of note, no long-term security."
"When it comes to raising money, every year it's like starting from scratch," he said.
Less than half the choir's annual budget of $3.2 million is covered by receipts from its concerts and album sales. The rest comes from donations. In addition to counseling programs, which cost about $600,000 a year, the school spends about $1 million on music teachers, instruments and the music library, and $800,000 on tutors, computers, curriculum development and other academic services. The remainder of the budget is for administrative, fund-raising and other expenses. The pupils pay no tuition.
Horace H. Turnbull, who is in charge of operations and programs and is Walter Turnbull's brother, said that the choir just received a challenge grant of $250,000 from the Christian A. Johnson Endeavor Foundation; the foundation will match every dollar received. But the deadline for raising the money is Dec. 31. To date, he said, the choir has verbal commitments of about $100,000. "But until the checks come, there are no guarantees," he added.
Past corporate donors have included Citicorp, Time Warner, Xerox, I.B.M. and A.T.&T. The Texaco Foundation, a supporter since 1991, has promised the choir $80,000. When asked if he had any second thoughts about accepting money from Texaco after the recent charges of racial discrimination brought against some of the company's top executives, Mr. Turnbull emphatically answered "no."
"Texaco has been a friend of ours for years," said Mr. Turnbull, whose choir is mostly made up of black children. "Why should I look at everyone in Texaco as bad because you have an individual or individuals with an opinion that I find appalling? I can't paint everyone with the same broad brush. If I were to do that, it would teach the kids that nobody is worth anything."
The program on Saturday reflects the choir's versatility, with some Schubert, some Duke Ellington, some gospel. "We encompass all the music that is important to African-Americans," Walter Turnbull said, noting that the choir regularly commissions works from black composers.
A performing tenor himself, the 52-year-old Mr. Turnbull established the Boys Choir of Harlem in 1968 when he was a doctoral student at the Manhattan School of Music. Back then it was a small group of 20 based at the Ephesus Seventh Day Adventist Church in central Harlem. He said he never dreamed it would gain such renown. In addition to live performances throughout the United States, Europe and Asia, the choir has recorded the soundtracks for the movies "Glory" and "Malcolm X," had its own show on Broadway in 1993 and was the subject of an Emmy-award-winning documentary, "From Harlem to Haarlem: The Story of a Choirboy." It even has its own imprint, 127th Street Records, the result of a venture with the Unencumbered Entertainment Group.
But the choir's renown has its down side, Mr. Turnbull said. "People see 40 kids onstage who are poised, sounding good, looking good. So they think that everything is O.K., that we must have plenty of money."
Since 1993, through a special arrangement with the Board of Education, the Choir Academy of Harlem has been housed in a three-story school building at Madison Avenue and 127th Street surrounded by boarded-up tenements. Its 563 students range in age from 8 to 18. About 1,500 New York City children audition each year, hoping to be among the 100 who are accepted into the school, which encompasses grades 4 through 12. Members of the first graduating class received their diplomas last spring.
But the building is ill-equipped as a music school, Horace Turnbull said. The auditorium needs renovation. Better rehearsal spaces are needed for the seven choirs. There is no music-listening room. The list goes on. "We are so busy living day to day that we barely have time to work on the long-range plans," he said. Those include a dormitory, so that the school can accept children from other cities, and the establishment of a technology-learning center, with up-to-date computer equipment.
Dana Rogers, 15, and a choir member for four years, said that were it not for the academy, he might be out on the streets "doing things I have no business doing." He said the choir "teaches us how to be disciplined and well-trained, and that's what we're going to need in the real world if we want to survive."
Most members do more than just survive. Over the years, 98 percent have graduated from high school, Walter Turnbull said, an impressive statistic considering that more than half the neighborhood's teen-agers are high school dropouts. Many choir members have gone on to college, becoming doctors, lawyers and other professionals. Some have continued in music, as singers or teachers.
Whatever profession they ultimately choose, Mr. Turnbull said he hoped his students learned to be "solid citizens of the community." If they maintain a passion for music, so much the better.
For one alumnus, that has been the case. "Music is a great challenge; life is a challenge," said 29-year-old Gilbert Robinson, who now works on the school's counseling staff. "That's what we try to instill in the kids. If you can learn to do music, you can learn to do life."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Members of the Boys Choir of Harlem rehearsing at their school building on East 127th Street near Madison Avenue. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rises Against Mark, But Falls vs. Yen and Pound

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose against the mark yesterday after German money supply data suggested to traders that the Bundesbank would have room to lower interest rates. But the dollar fell against the yen and pound.
An unexpectedly large monthly rise in Japan's politically sensitive trade surplus pushed the dollar lower against the yen. In Britain, strong economic news increased speculation that interest rates there would soon rise, which helped start a broad rally in the pound. 
Traders said volume was light, exaggerating currency movements.
In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 1.5518 marks from 1.5496 marks on Tuesday. The dollar fell to 113.69 yen from 113.88 yen. The pound rose to $1.6748 from $1.6706.
Some traders focused on the news that Germany's broadest measure of the money supply, known as M-3, fell to an 8 percent growth rate in November from 8.4 percent in October, a sign of diminished inflationary pressure in the German economy.
The data suggested the Bundesbank's central committee, which meets Thursday for the last time in 1996, might nudge short-term interest rates lower to stimulate economic growth. Lower rates hurt the mark.
"This gave room for people to speculate they would lower rates," said Roger Chapin, foreign-exchange director at Bank One in Columbus, Ohio. "It certainly gives the Bundesbank the ability to lower rates."
Others said they doubted the Bundesbank would lower rates, partly because the central bank said on Tuesday in a monthly report that rates and the mark's value were at appropriate levels. But they did not rule it out.
"It does increase the probability of a rate cut, even though it's probably not going to happen," said Robert Nelson, managing director of foreign exchange at Westdeutsche Landes Bank in New York. Nonetheless, he said, "you can't predict what the Bundesbank will do."
The dollar also indirectly derived strength against the mark from the German currency's weakness against the pound, which strengthened after the British Government said retail sales surged in November and unemployment dropped by the largest monthly amount in 25 years.

HEADLINE: U.N. Says Iraq May Be Hiding More Missiles Than Suspected

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 18

 BODY:
The leader of a United Nations team in charge of destroying Iraqi weapons told the Security Council today that he believes Baghdad may be hiding more operational missiles than monitors had suspected.
Until recently, inspectors had concluded that there might be as many as 16 Iraqi missiles unaccounted for. That number is now thought to be as high as 18 to 25 missiles. 
 "If they are operational, that's a missile force," a diplomat said in response to a report to the council by Rolf Ekeus, chairman of the special commission charged with disarming Iraq. He raised questions about whether President Saddam Hussein, who apparently continues to conceal biological, chemical and possibly nuclear components, may pose renewed threats to his neighbors.
The Iraqis appear to have removed key parts from missiles they said they had destroyed and buried as early as 1991, when the Persian Gulf war ended, Mr. Ekeus said.
Inspectors excavating sites where Iraq says missiles were buried after being crushed, have found two new, disturbing pieces of evidence, diplomats said. One is that turbo pumps had been removed from some missiles before they were destroyed.
Last year, Mr. Ekeus found that Iraq, which is still under an international embargo, had been trying to import gyroscopes. Turbo pumps and gyroscopes are two key missile pieces Iraq does not manufacture.
A shipment of Russian-made gyroscopes, apparently bought on the black market, was intercepted by Jordan. Based on a tip, Mr. Ekeus then called in divers who found other gyroscopes at the bottom of the Tigris canal in Baghdad, where they had been jettisoned.
The other major find was that not all of the missiles crushed and buried were from armories. Some seemed to have been training missiles placed there to dupe arms monitors.
Mr. Ekeus asked Iraq to allow him to remove some excavated weapons and send them abroad for examination. His request was rejected, with the vague promise that the issue could be reopened next year.
Mr. Ekeus has written to Tariq Aziz, Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister and leading negotiator with the United Nations, to tell him that the latest disclosures indicate that Iraq is in violation of its 1991 cease-fire agreement, which set up the weapons destruction and inspection system.
Security Council members, led by the United States and Britain, have been eager to impress on President Hussein that economic sanctions will not be lifted until Iraq has eliminated all its weapons of mass destruction and met other conditions.
Although Iraq has resumed limited oil sales under United Nations control, Security Council members emphasize that the plan to allow $2 billion of oil sales over six months is not the beginning of lifting sanctions.

HEADLINE: Calm Seas Roil Currency Markets;
Trading Ebbs as Technology Advances, Costing Jobs

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
In the rough-and-tumble world of foreign exchange trading, where $1.2 trillion changes hands every day, Matthew S. Lifson fought his way through a string of small banks all the way to the big show -- a job at the Chase Manhattan Bank and the presidency of Forex USA, the industry association.
Mr. Lifson was no star, but he was solid, trading secondary currencies and dealing with smaller American banks. Then, on Aug. 20, his boss asked the Brooklyn College graduate to cancel a trip to Ohio. The next day, Mr. Lifson and three colleagues were laid off. That put him in the awkward role of being host for a Pan American foreign exchange conference in Washington in October and listening to predictions that by 2000, half of the traders in the business would be gone. 
 "It's a shame, but it is a factor of the market," Mr. Lifson said stoically.
The 43-year-old Mr. Lifson, and many traders like him are caught up not in the turmoil that used to be associated with the foreign exchange market, but in an eerie calm that has descended on it, at least for now.
Gone are the roller-coaster rides the dollar took for two decades on its way to record highs in 1985 and back down to record lows since. Gone too is the speculative fever that enabled the financier George Soros to make $1 billion in a single day in 1992 by betting against the British pound.
This lack of volatility -- driven by the narrowing of inflation rates around the globe, the end of the cold war and fast- approaching European monetary union -- is eating into banks' foreign exchange profits, spurring layoffs and forcing institutions to rethink their roles in the market.
As if that were not enough for traders to deal with, new technology has taken over a lot of the work they once did. Banks have embarked on margers and cost-cutting drives that further reduce their ranks. The convergence of these forces, so soon after the alluring profits of the early 1990's attracted new players to the market, "has shaken up the industry," said Guy Whittaker, global head of foreign exchange at Citibank, the world's No. 1 currency trader.
"The foreign exchange markets had some extremely profitable years in 1992 and 1993," Mr. Whittaker recalled, "and as a result of that new people came in thinking that was part of a brand-new, long-term sustainable position."
But it was not, particularly for business in New York, which lacks the London market's advantage of overlapping with trading in Tokyo and New York. The Big Apple's 16 percent share of the worldwide foreign exchange business has not grown since 1989, while London controls nearly one-third of the trading and its portion is rising, according to the latest survey by the Bank for International Settlements.
As a result, said James H. Hohorst, head of global trading at American Express Bank, "people are re-evaluating what they have dedicated to foreign exchange"
While nobody compiles figures on the industry's overall profits, Mr. Whittaker estimates they have declined in recent years, adding that Citibank's profits "are a little less this year." Although not a direct proxy for profits, foreign exchange revenue is down this year at many banks, including a drop of 27 percent at Citibank, a unit of Citicorp, and a slide of 18 percent at Chase Manhattan.
"The trend is in the numbers and the numbers are bad -- a downward trend in revenue," said Peter M. Mesrobian, head of global foreign exchange at First Chicago NBD Corporation, who laid off 25 traders in London and Chicago in October -- nearly 25 percent of the total.
To be sure, what is bad news for the banks is good news for the multinational corporations, trading companies, financial institutions and other customers that have to spend less on the currency trading and hedging that come with any kind of business abroad.
But the retrenchment has set off a race among the top banks in the business to corral an even greater share of the action. It has also forced a struggle for survival by second- and third-tier players. Bankers are reluctant to throw in the towel, because even with lower profits, the foreign exchange business remains an important component of any bank with global aspirations.
"I've got to reinvent my business," said Jamie K. Thorsen, the global head of foreign exchange at the Bank of Montreal. She reduced her staff by 7 percent this year in a reorganization of the bank's trading operations in Toronto and Chicago. "New technology has allowed us to shrink, and to have critical mass at the same time," she said.
No longer is it enough, she said, for a foreign exchange desk to try to make money on the ups and downs in the currency markets. Traders will have to continually upgrade their skills and be able to handle products that are important to a customer's business, like options and other derivatives. "The skill needed to be a foreign exchange trader is being elevated," Ms Thorsen said. "The people who were successful 10 years ago may not be successful now."
Strategy is also changing at the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company in New York. It now contracts out the trading it used to do with its own capital, enabling the company -- a unit of the First Empire State Corporation -- to cut its dealer ranks to three from seven.
The signs of the consolidation are everywhere.
Britain's HSBC Midland, one of the top foreign exchange operations, suddenly retreated this fall from its effort to build a major trading operation in New York. The man brought in to do the building, David S. Ogg, was let go less than a year and a half after his arrival from Lehman Brothers and more than 50 traders and support staff went with him.
"You've got to know what your business is because the day of trying to do everything is gone," said Anthony F. Rademeyer, treasurer Americas for HSBC Midland. That means using new technology to consolidate most of the bank's trading in London and leaving New York's emphasis on dealing with customers.
The Nationsbank Corporation, the fast-expanding American bank, has abandoned its effort to be a force in foreign exchange, laying off traders in London and Singapore.
CS Holding's Credit Suisse, which had made major hires to beef up its trading operations, is now merging them with those of CS First Boston, resulting in about 15 layoffs. Lehman Brothers has gotten out of most of its daily spot-trading business. Citibank has significantly reduced the number of its trading rooms and traders. And Chase Manhattan is scaling back its foreign-exchange operations in the wake of its mega-merger with Chemical Bank.
While precise statistics are not available, people in the industry estimate that the total number of traders has declined by 7 percent to 10 percent this year. And for the employed, salaries are coming down. Several managers said that they could now hire a talented trader for 30 percent less than several years ago.
Like sailors, traders do not like windless seas, and many of them yearn for the good old days of tempests and tidal waves. "Volatility has a very high correlation with profits," said Kenneth P. Gettinger, managing director for foreign exchange at Union Bank of Switzerland in New York.
Citibank notes this problem in describing the fall in its trading revenue in this year's third quarter, compared with 1995, "when volatile foreign exchange markets provided substantial revenue opportunities."
Market volatility could recede even further as the 15 nations of the European Union move toward the creation of a common currency by 1999. Chase Manhattan said its decline in foreign-exchange revenue in the first nine months of this year was caused in part "by the decrease in the level of cross-currency trading activity in the European markets in anticipation of the integration of the European Monetary System."
And prospects for the profession are, if anything, likely to get bleaker, because computers have become adept at doing things people used to do.
An entire class of traders known as voice brokers, for example, risks getting wiped out by an electronic substitute. Currency trading rooms are dotted with speakers that pipe in an unending stream of bid and offer quotes barked out by specialists distributing prices anonymously for their customers.
But two electronic brokering systems, one devised by a consortium of major foreign exchange banks called the EBS Partnership, and the other by Reuters Holdings P.L.C. of Britain, have invaded their turf, snapping up 29 percent of all spot voice-brokering business in three years, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York's 1995 foreign exchange market survey.
And to the surprise of the industry, the impact has gone beyond the voice brokering business. Banks that used to trade directly with each other have begun using the machines to make deals, enabling them to reduce their staffs further.
In the case of Mr. Lifson, the Chase Manhattan trader laid off in August, his regional desk began to lose business because the smaller banks it dealt with could use the electronic brokering systems instead of calling the bigger banks for prices. "I could see the business slowing down," Mr. Lifson said.
New technology has also had the perverse effect of cutting into banks' trading profits because the wider circulation of price quotes tends to reduce the gap between bid and offer prices.
In the scramble to adapt and survive, foreign exchange managers say they are focusing more on their customers. "How do I distinguish myself from the machine?" asked one foreign exchange executive at Chase Manhattan. "We have to focus on value-added services. We have to become better at things like research and the trading of exotic currencies" like the Polish zloty, Slovenian tolar and Indonesian rupiah.
Not everybody is cutting back. Goldman, Sachs & Company and Union Bank of Switzerland, among others, are taking advantage of the layoffs at competing banks and securities firms to hire seasoned traders. Mr. Gettinger at U.B.S. thinks that currency markets will come alive again and offer lots of new opportunities, including those in emerging markets. And Richard E. Witten, a managing director for foreign exchange at Goldman, said that the recent contraction was "just part of the boom-bust cycle of the Street."
"What is new is that the banking community is no longer willing to live through these periods with their high overhead," Mr. Witten said.
Even Mr. Lifson is optimistic. He has landed on his feet at the National Australia Bank in New York. "I can see the market continuing to consolidate," he said. "But if these new markets arise, there will be need for traders."

HEADLINE: Nafta's Impact on Employment Is Slight, Study Says

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 18

 BODY:
Despite arguments from supporters of the North American Free Trade Agreement that the pact would bring big employment gains to the United States and warnings from opponents that it would cost hundreds of thousands of jobs, the accord's net impact so far has been slight, according to an academic study to be released on Thursday.
The study by researchers at the University of California at Los Angeles is one of the most comprehensive looks at the trade accord's effect on employment to date. It concluded that "the impact on trade-related employment during the first three years after Nafta is estimated to be, at the very least, a near zero net impact, and more likely, a moderately positive number." 
 Using a new model of how exports and imports influence jobs in various product categories and regions, the study estimated that the net job gain to the United States since the agreement took effect at the beginning of 1994 has been just 2,990 jobs.
The net figure, however, masked a much greater level of both job losses and gains among different companies. Increased imports to the United States killed an estimated 28,168 jobs the last three years, the study said, while increased exports supported creation of 31,158 jobs.
Organized labor, among other interest groups, continues to argue that the agreement is spurring a migration of jobs to Mexico, where wages are far lower than in the United States. And the U.C.L.A. study did not directly address the politically sensitive question of whether better-paying jobs were being lost to Mexico, leaving lower-wage jobs behind, as critics of the pact, like Ross Perot, had predicted.
But Raul Hinojosa Ojeda, the research director at U.C.L.A.'s North American Integration Development Center and the study's co-author, said that unpublished data clearly established that jobs that support exports from the United States to Mexico paid better than those that were shifted to Mexico.
And the long-term trend, he said, is that the United States will gain more jobs than it loses from the agreement.
If nothing else, the study is likely to stimulate new debate about the economic impact of free-trade agreements in general and the North American Free Trade Agreement in particular. The debate is certain to arise as a political issue again next year, when the Clinton Administration must report to Congress on the trade pact's effect on jobs.
Although the study took account of trade with Canada, its focus was on the economic relationship between the United States and Mexico, and its ultimate conclusion was that the main influence on trade-related employment was not the trade agreement, but Mexico's overall economic health.
"The lowering of tariffs through Nafta has not had a significant impact on the rate of growth of imports or exports between Mexico and the United States, or on the composition of trade between sectors recently liberalized by Nafta and those sectors still awaiting liberalization," the study said.
Instead, the study said, "the real issue with respect to U.S. employment levels concerns the development of policies that can achieve sustainable growth in Mexico."
The near-collapse of the Mexican economy in 1995 had a far greater effect on trade-related jobs in the United States than the trade agreement itself, the study found. A sharp drop in demand from Mexico for American goods last year led to a net loss of 20,000 jobs among American exporters to Mexico in 1995. With the Mexican economy now rebounding, the study projected that the number of jobs attributable to exports to Mexico will grow again this year by 15,000.
The study said that job losses could accelerate again as tariffs are reduced in coming years in more labor-intensive categories like agriculture and apparel that have yet to feel the full effects of the trade accord. Moreover, its conclusions do not take account of job losses in the United States because of plant relocations to Mexico -- more than 33,000 in the last three years by the Labor Department's count -- because the phenomenon was under way well before the agreement took effect and has continued at roughly the same pace.
The study said further research on the trade agreement's economic impact was needed and that its job loss and gain estimates were intended to be approximations rather than definitive counts.
Jeffrey J. Schott, an economist at the Institute for International Economics, said the study was a valuable improvement on the "back of the envelope calculations that were the norm during the Nafta debate."
Mr. Schott and Gary C. Hufbauer of the institute had done a study in 1993 projecting that the North American Free Trade Agreement would create 170,000 jobs in the United States over five years. Mr. Schott said their primary conclusion had been that 170,000 jobs were insignificant in the huge American economy, but that the number had been seized on by proponents of the agreement as evidence of its benefits.
But Mark Anderson, an economist at the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which had warned that the accord would cost the United States hundreds of thousands of jobs, said the last three years have confirmed the agreement's negative impact on American workers.
"Clearly the benefits, not so much of the agreement itself but of the economic relationship that the agreement solidified, went to corporate elites in the United States and Mexico," Mr. Anderson said. "From our perspective the job situation has been negative in the U.S. in terms of jobs lost or not created."

PUB-DATE: December 19, 1996

SECTION: Section D; Page 20; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 567 words

HEADLINE: Yield Climbs To 6.70% for 30-Year Bond

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities came under pressure in thin volume yesterday, after traders were disappointed that the response to the Government's auction of new two-year notes was only average.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 17/32 , to 9715/32 , to yield 6.70 percent, up from 6.65 percent on Tuesday. It was the highest yield since Oct. 30, when it was also 6.70 percent. 
 With no economic news scheduled, the market focused on new supply. Some buyers at yesterday's $18.25 billion two-year-note auction appeared to be foreign investors, traders said. But with little economic news to justify buying the issue, buyers' reluctance was apparent.
Yesterday, the two-year note was awarded at a high yield of 5.874 percent, up from 5.662 percent last month and the highest since Oct. 22, when the yield was 5.930 percent.
Treasury securities were up in morning trading ahead of the note auction, with buying spurred by expectations of good demand, both in the United States and abroad. But as the auction deadline for bids drew near, traders began to worry.
Dealers fear being stuck with a large inventory of securities, which makes them vulnerable to losses if the market continues to drop while the securities are in their possession. They would like the market to be weaker going into the auction, so as yields rise the securities become more attractive to investors.
Part of the market's problem over the last weeks has been supply. With the heavy supply of corporate debt, some investors have been hedging Treasury securities for corporates, and with fewer foreign investors, the situation has taken a toll on the Treasury market.
Another concern is that after the supply is finally absorbed, market participants will probably take a long look at the holiday shopping season. If it is strong, the worry is that the Fed may begin to think about increasing rates. The market has already priced in an expected "on hold" Fed policy, so any rate rise would cause prices to decline.
Jack Ablin, director of fixed-income and senior fund manager at the Private Bank of the Bank of Boston, called the note auction lackluster. "There was not much enthusiasm, as the market dropped about three-quarters of point on the results," he said, adding, "People are now are pretty much focused on 1997 as they close their books on 1996."
Mr. Ablin expects to see more volatility on low volume in the next week or two. He said the $12.5 billion of five-year notes scheduled to be auctioned today would be a harder sell because of the lack of demand.
In when-issued trading, the five-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.22 percent, up about 7 basis points since dealers started offering the securities to customers last Wednesday.
The remaining economic data this week are a trade report, the Philadelphia Fed index, weekly claims for unemployment insurance and the final third-quarter gross domestic product; none is likely to bring buyers back into the market.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new two-year notes:
